chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER I. IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG AND PASSEPARTOUT ACCEPT EACH OTHER, THE ONE AS MASTER, THE OTHER AS MAN

events.title: Introduction to the Enigmatic Phileas Fogg
detailed_summary: Introduces Phileas Fogg, residing at 7 Saville Row in 1872, a house with historical significance.
He is noted as a prominent member of the Reform Club, yet maintains a low profile, fostering an air of mystery.
Little is known about him beyond his polished demeanor; comparisons are drawn to a tranquil, bearded, potentially ageless Byron.
His English nationality is certain, but his connection to London is questioned due to his absence from the city's financial, legal, and commercial centers.
He owns no ships docking in London, holds no public office, and has no known ties to legal inns or courts.
He is not involved in manufacturing, trade, or farming.
His name is unfamiliar in scientific or learned circles, and he doesn't participate in the activities of London's various societies, from arts associations to entomological groups.
His sole confirmed affiliation is his membership at the Reform Club.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Phileas Fogg lived, in 1872, at No. 7, Saville Row, Burlington Gardens, the house in which Sheridan died in 1814.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Phileas Fogg was a member of the Reform, and that was all.

events.text_segment:
Mr. Phileas Fogg lived, in 1872, at No. 7, Saville Row, Burlington Gardens, the house in which Sheridan died in 1814. He was one of the most noticeable members of the Reform Club, though he seemed always to avoid attracting attention; an enigmatical personage, about whom little was known, except that he was a polished man of the world. People said that he resembled Byron—at least that his head was Byronic; but he was a bearded, tranquil Byron, who might live on a thousand years without growing old.
Certainly an Englishman, it was more doubtful whether Phileas Fogg was a Londoner. He was never seen on ’Change, nor at the Bank, nor in the counting-rooms of the “City”; no ships ever came into London docks of which he was the owner; he had no public employment; he had never been entered at any of the Inns of Court, either at the Temple, or Lincoln’s Inn, or Gray’s Inn; nor had his voice ever resounded in the Court of Chancery, or in the Exchequer, or the Queen’s Bench, or the Ecclesiastical Courts. He certainly was not a manufacturer; nor was he a merchant or a gentleman farmer. His name was strange to the scientific and learned societies, and he never was known to take part in the sage deliberations of the Royal Institution or the London Institution, the Artisan’s Association, or the Institution of Arts and Sciences. He belonged, in fact, to none of the numerous societies which swarm in the English capital, from the Harmonic to that of the Entomologists, founded mainly for the purpose of abolishing pernicious insects.
Phileas Fogg was a member of the Reform, and that was all.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Mr. Phileas Fogg lived, in 1872, at No. 7, Saville Row, Burlington Gardens, the house in which Sheridan died in 1814. He was one of the most noticeable members of the Reform Club, although he seemed always to avoid attracting attention; an enigma, concerning whom little was known, except that he was a polished man of the world. People said that he resembled Byron—at least that his head was Byronic; but he was a bearded, tranquil Byron, who might live a thousand years without growing old. Certainly an Englishman, it was more doubtful if Phileas Fogg was a Londoner. He was never seen on the London Exchange, nor in the Banques of England, nor in any of the great counting-houses. He neither built ships, nor sold produce, and the directors of the great British railways never saw his name posted in connection with any of their undertakings. He was not a manufacturer, nor was he a merchant or a gentleman farmer. His name was unknown to the scientific or learned societies, and he never was known to patronise the Opera or the other theatres, even when they were giving the best performances. In short, no one knew what this Phileas Fogg did, except that he was an exceedingly particular gentleman; and that he was a member of the Reform Club, and indifferently rich. The best of Barings would not have had a credit open for him; for he deposited his money with them in a running account. In fact, Mr. Phileas Fogg was not known to have any bank at all. He paid his notes at sight, and his checks were always good. He was not a member of any of the societies of London, but he belonged to the Reform Club, which was quite sufficient.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Mr. Phileas Fogg lived, in 1872, at No. 7, Saville Row, Burlington Gardens, the house in which Sheridan died in 1814. He was a gentleman of the most exact and methodical habits, one who performed his daily routine with a clockwork precision that astonished all who observed him. Though possessed of considerable wealth, the source of which was a mystery even to his most intimate associates (of which he had none), he lived a life devoid of ostentation or excess. He breakfasted at exactly 8:23 AM, dressed, and then walked to the Reform Club, where he spent the remainder of his day engaged in reading newspapers and playing whist, returning home at midnight. No one knew where Phileas Fogg had come from, or how he had made his fortune. He was a member of the Reform Club, certainly, and that was proof enough for many of his respectability, but beyond that, he was a cipher. He was a solitary man, who seemed to have no family, no friends, and no connections beyond the four walls of the club and his quiet house in Saville Row. He was not known to travel, indeed, he was a man who seemed utterly rooted to London, his life a perfect circle within its confines. He required nothing from the outside world except the punctual delivery of his newspapers and the correct serving of his meals. His life was a model of regularity, a testament to his unwavering adherence to routine, a stark contrast to the unpredictable adventure that awaited him. His existence was so perfectly ordered, so entirely predictable, that the very idea of him embarking on a spontaneous journey was almost ludicrous to contemplate. Yet, this was the man who would soon stake his entire fortune on circling the globe in eighty days.

events.title: Fogg's Wealth, Habits, and Mysterious Knowledge
detailed_summary: Fogg gained entry to the Reform Club through a recommendation from the Barings, with whom he possessed an open line of credit, indicating financial stability.
His checks are always honored promptly, drawing from a consistently well-funded account.
His wealth is undeniable, yet its origins remain a mystery even to those who know him best, a topic Fogg himself avoids.
He is characterized as neither extravagant nor stingy, quietly providing funds for worthy causes, sometimes anonymously.
He is described as exceptionally uncommunicative, his silence adding to his mysterious persona.
His daily routines are observable but unchanging, perplexing those curious about him.
Speculation exists about his past travels due to his extensive knowledge of the world, often displayed by accurately correcting geographical conjectures with seemingly prophetic insight.
Despite this apparent worldliness, it is confirmed by acquaintances that he has not left London for many years.
His only known leisure activities are reading newspapers and playing whist.
He frequently wins at whist, a silent game suiting his nature, but allocates his winnings to charity, playing purely for the intellectual challenge rather than monetary gain.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The way in which he got admission to this exclusive club was simple enough.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The game was in his eyes a contest, a struggle with a difficulty, yet a motionless, unwearying struggle, congenial to his tastes.

events.text_segment:
The way in which he got admission to this exclusive club was simple enough.
He was recommended by the Barings, with whom he had an open credit. His cheques were regularly paid at sight from his account current, which was always flush.
Was Phileas Fogg rich? Undoubtedly. But those who knew him best could not imagine how he had made his fortune, and Mr. Fogg was the last person to whom to apply for the information. He was not lavish, nor, on the contrary, avaricious; for, whenever he knew that money was needed for a noble, useful, or benevolent purpose, he supplied it quietly and sometimes anonymously. He was, in short, the least communicative of men. He talked very little, and seemed all the more mysterious for his taciturn manner. His daily habits were quite open to observation; but whatever he did was so exactly the same thing that he had always done before, that the wits of the curious were fairly puzzled.
Had he travelled? It was likely, for no one seemed to know the world more familiarly; there was no spot so secluded that he did not appear to have an intimate acquaintance with it. He often corrected, with a few clear words, the thousand conjectures advanced by members of the club as to lost and unheard-of travellers, pointing out the true probabilities, and seeming as if gifted with a sort of second sight, so often did events justify his predictions. He must have travelled everywhere, at least in the spirit.
It was at least certain that Phileas Fogg had not absented himself from London for many years. Those who were honoured by a better acquaintance with him than the rest, declared that nobody could pretend to have ever seen him anywhere else. His sole pastimes were reading the papers and playing whist. He often won at this game, which, as a silent one, harmonised with his nature; but his winnings never went into his purse, being reserved as a fund for his charities. Mr. Fogg played, not to win, but for the sake of playing. The game was in his eyes a contest, a struggle with a difficulty, yet a motionless, unwearying struggle, congenial to his tastes.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The way in which he got admission to this exclusive club was simple enough. He was commended by the Barings, with whom he had an open credit. Hence his high financial standing was unquestionable. And as he was Phileas Fogg, Esq., of that ilk, who paid his bills when due, even if he lived in a coal-mine, his cheques were always honoured. Not that Phileas Fogg was rich—he was merely well off. His fortune, though a mystery to his best friends, was not large; and none knew how he had made it. He was neither extravagant nor parsimonious; for, whenever he knew that money was needed for a noble or useful purpose, he supplied it generously, sometimes anonymously. He was, in short, the least communicative of men, who talked the least, and who seemed to be least in need of talking. What with his punctuality, his silence, and his regularity, he had become an enigma, a puzzle to his acquaintance, who, perhaps, thought he had travelled. It is true that no one had been known to have seen him outside of London for many years, and that those who knew him best declared that he had not left the city. His only pastimes were reading the papers and playing whist. This silent game suited his reserve and nature. He often won at it, but the money he gained was invariably devoted to charity. Mr. Fogg played not for money, but for the game; and he seemed to look upon it as a contest, a struggle against a difficulty, yet without the grand movement and without the noise.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The way in which he got admission to this exclusive club was simple enough. Phileas Fogg was not a man who sought recognition or made efforts to impress; indeed, his life was a testament to rigid regularity and absolute privacy. He appeared, one might say, out of nowhere, and settled into the club's routine with the precision of a finely tuned automaton. There were no references sought, no lengthy discussions of his background or merits. He simply began to frequent the establishment. His punctuality was legendary; he arrived and departed at precisely the same hours each day. He occupied the same armchair, read the same newspapers in the same order, took his meals at the same table, and played whist with the same partners at the same time. He spoke little, disturbed no one, and paid his dues promptly. This unwavering adherence to habit, this perfect predictability, was so absolute that it became, paradoxically, his most striking characteristic. The members, accustomed to the formal rituals of introduction and sponsorship, found themselves confronted with a man who seemed to exist outside such conventions. His very regularity became his credentials. No one knew him, yet everyone saw him. He was, in effect, vetted not by references or reputation, but by his own clockwork existence. He was perceived as a man of means, though his source of wealth was as mysterious as everything else about him. He lived simply, without ostentation, yet his pockets never seemed empty. His attire was impeccable, his manner reserved but never discourteous. He did not mingle in the usual social sense; his interactions were limited almost exclusively to his whist partners, and even then, the conversation rarely strayed beyond the game itself. Over time, his silent, systematic presence became an integral part of the club's atmosphere. He was simply Phileas Fogg, the man who was always there, always on time, always doing exactly what he had done the day before. His acceptance was not voted upon; it was simply a fact that seemed to have established itself through sheer force of habit. His admission was less a process of being let in and more a process of having been there all along, unnoticed yet undeniably present, until his presence became so regular it could no longer be questioned or ignored. He slid into membership through the sheer frictionless perfection of his routine, a silent, precise inclusion that required no words, no sponsors, no fuss. He was simply there, one day, and remained there, day after day, year after year, a permanent, unmoving fixture in the transient world of London society and the Reform Club's hallowed halls.

events.title: Fogg's Regimented Solitude and Exacting Standards
detailed_summary: Fogg's complete lack of known family, relatives, or even close friends is highlighted as unusual, emphasizing his solitary life.
He lives alone in his Saville Row house, inaccessible to outsiders, with only one servant.
His meals (breakfast and dinner) are taken at the Reform Club at mathematically precise times, always in the same room and at the same table, without company or guests.
He returns home precisely at midnight, retiring immediately, never utilizing the club's residential facilities.
His day is rigidly structured: ten hours at home for sleeping and grooming, followed by methodical walks within the Reform Club's hall or gallery when he chooses to stroll.

His club meals are described as luxurious, featuring the best provisions, served by formal waiters using special porcelain, fine linen, and unique club decanters, with ice imported expensively from American lakes.
The narrative suggests that such extreme eccentricity might contain some inherent value.
His Saville Row house is noted as exceedingly comfortable, though not opulent.
Fogg's demanding habits require near-superhuman precision from his servant.
It's revealed that on this specific day, October 2nd, he fired his servant, James Forster, for bringing shaving water at 84°F instead of the required 86°F.
Consequently, Fogg is waiting for Forster's replacement, expected between 11:00 and 11:30 AM.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: On this very 2nd of October he had dismissed James Forster, because that luckless youth had brought him shaving-water at eighty-four degrees Fahrenheit instead of eighty-six; and he was awaiting his successor, who was due at the house between eleven and half-past.

events.text_segment:
Phileas Fogg was not known to have either wife or children, which may happen to the most honest people; either relatives or near friends, which is certainly more unusual. He lived alone in his house in Saville Row, whither none penetrated. A single domestic sufficed to serve him. He breakfasted and dined at the club, at hours mathematically fixed, in the same room, at the same table, never taking his meals with other members, much less bringing a guest with him; and went home at exactly midnight, only to retire at once to bed. He never used the cosy chambers which the Reform provides for its favoured members. He passed ten hours out of the twenty-four in Saville Row, either in sleeping or making his toilet. When he chose to take a walk it was with a regular step in the entrance hall with its mosaic flooring, or in the circular gallery with its dome supported by twenty red porphyry Ionic columns, and illumined by blue painted windows. When he breakfasted or dined all the resources of the club—its kitchens and pantries, its buttery and dairy—aided to crowd his table with their most succulent stores; he was served by the gravest waiters, in dress coats, and shoes with swan-skin soles, who proffered the viands in special porcelain, and on the finest linen; club decanters, of a lost mould, contained his sherry, his port, and his cinnamon-spiced claret; while his beverages were refreshingly cooled with ice, brought at great cost from the American lakes.
If to live in this style is to be eccentric, it must be confessed that there is something good in eccentricity.
The mansion in Saville Row, though not sumptuous, was exceedingly comfortable. The habits of its occupant were such as to demand but little from the sole domestic, but Phileas Fogg required him to be almost superhumanly prompt and regular. On this very 2nd of October he had dismissed James Forster, because that luckless youth had brought him shaving-water at eighty-four degrees Fahrenheit instead of eighty-six; and he was awaiting his successor, who was due at the house between eleven and half-past.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Phileas Fogg was not known to have either wife or children, which may happen to the most honest people; either relatives or near friends, which is certainly more unusual. He lived alone in his house in Saville Row, to which no one had the right to penetrate. He had no friends, or at least it was not known that he had any. As for this gentleman, the members of the Reform Club, of which he was one, could only say that he was a most exact gentleman, that he ate well and dressed well, and that he did not talk. From midday to midnight, he was always in the club, in the reading-room, or the smoking-room, or in the billiards-room, or the dining-saloon, as if he had no other place of residence. At midnight, he would return home to his house in Saville Row, and retire immediately, without ever sleeping at the club. He passed ten hours out of the twenty-four in his home, either in sleeping or in making his toilet. When he walked, it was methodically from the great hall to the dining-saloon, and from the dining-saloon to the great hall; and he never lingered at the club during the hours that he did not spend there. The domestics of the club were accustomed to serving him, but they knew nothing of his life. His meals were exquisitely prepared, and served on a special porcelain, on the finest linen, with unique club decanters. The ice, imported from American lakes, was brought at great expense, and was used for his drinks. He had the reputation of being very peculiar and of great originality. His dwelling in Saville Row was comfortable without being ostentatious. The reader might not have been able to discover what value was contained in such an eccentricity, but the regularity of his habits, which was so exact that it might have been taken for a mania, might contain some concealed value. The servant whom he had dismissed, James Forster, had been discharged the previous day, October 2nd, because he had brought him shaving-water at eighty-four degrees Fahrenheit instead of eighty-six. Phileas Fogg was waiting for his new servant, who was due between eleven and half-past.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Phileas Fogg was not known to have either wife or children, which may happen to the most honest people; either relatives or near friends, which is certainly more unusual. Phileas Fogg lived alone in his house on Saville Row, and no one called upon him—unless it was to do business. He permitted no one to cross his threshold, and was served by a single domestic whom he had chosen at his will, and who came to him at eleven o’clock in the morning and went out at the stroke of midnight, preparing his master’s toilet and clothes, ministering at breakfast and dinner, looking after the six things necessary to the comfortable gentleman: neatness, regularity, and punctuality, and absolute freedom from disturbance.  Phileas Fogg was a member of the Reform Club, and no other. If anyone was surprised at this, they did not show it. He did not belong to any society, nor did he frequent any public places. He played whist, and that was all. Four of his friends, who were as absorbed in whist as himself, lunched with him every day at the Reform, in a private room, from one to a quarter to two; then they played, and returned to their homes at ten minutes past two. They did not talk of business, nor of politics, nor of any other worldly affairs. They talked of nothing but cards, and always of the chances of the game, of the fine points and strategies.  It is unnecessary to state that Mr. Fogg was not a man of sentiment. He was a man of action, and a man of precision. He never went to the theatre, nor to concerts, nor to lectures. He did not read, except the paper. He did not travel, for it bothered him. He did not care for anything but the game of whist, which was, it is true, a silent occupation, but which suited him perfectly.

events.title: Passepartout is Hired
detailed_summary: A knock signals an arrival; James Forster, the recently dismissed servant, enters and announces the presence of the new applicant.
A thirty-year-old man enters and introduces himself as Jean Passepartout.
Fogg verifies his French nationality and name.

Passepartout elaborates on his surname, explaining it stems from his tendency to move between various professions: street singer, circus acrobat and rope-dancer, gymnastics teacher, and sergeant fireman in Paris.
He recounts leaving France five years earlier to seek the quiet stability of domestic service in England.
Having heard of Mr. Fogg's reputation for extreme regularity and orderliness, Passepartout expresses his desire to serve him, hoping for a peaceful life that will make him forget his restless past.
Fogg finds the name suitable and acknowledges receiving positive recommendations.
He asks Passepartout the current time.
Passepartout checks his large silver watch and replies it's 11:22.
Fogg immediately corrects him, stating his watch is four minutes slow.
Acknowledging the error is sufficient, Fogg formally employs Passepartout, declaring his service begins at precisely 11:29 AM on Wednesday, October 2nd.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A rap at this moment sounded on the door of the cosy apartment where Phileas Fogg was seated, and James Forster, the dismissed servant, appeared.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Now from this moment, twenty-nine minutes after eleven, a.m., this Wednesday, 2nd October, you are in my service.”

events.text_segment:
A rap at this moment sounded on the door of the cosy apartment where Phileas Fogg was seated, and James Forster, the dismissed servant, appeared.
“The new servant,” said he.
A young man of thirty advanced and bowed.
“You are a Frenchman, I believe,” asked Phileas Fogg, “and your name is John?”
“Jean, if monsieur pleases,” replied the newcomer, “Jean Passepartout, a surname which has clung to me because I have a natural aptness for going out of one business into another. I believe I’m honest, monsieur, but, to be outspoken, I’ve had several trades. I’ve been an itinerant singer, a circus-rider, when I used to vault like Leotard, and dance on a rope like Blondin. Then I got to be a professor of gymnastics, so as to make better use of my talents; and then I was a sergeant fireman at Paris, and assisted at many a big fire. But I quitted France five years ago, and, wishing to taste the sweets of domestic life, took service as a valet here in England. Finding myself out of place, and hearing that Monsieur Phileas Fogg was the most exact and settled gentleman in the United Kingdom, I have come to monsieur in the hope of living with him a tranquil life, and forgetting even the name of Passepartout.”
“Passepartout suits me,” responded Mr. Fogg. “You are well recommended to me; I hear a good report of you. You know my conditions?”
“Yes, monsieur.”
“Good! What time is it?”
“Twenty-two minutes after eleven,” returned Passepartout, drawing an enormous silver watch from the depths of his pocket.
“You are too slow,” said Mr. Fogg.
“Pardon me, monsieur, it is impossible—”
“You are four minutes too slow. No matter; it’s enough to mention the error. Now from this moment, twenty-nine minutes after eleven, a.m., this Wednesday, 2nd October, you are in my service.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
A rap at this moment sounded on the door of the cosy apartment where Phileas Fogg was seated, and James Forster, the dismissed servant, appeared.

“The new servant,” said Forster.

A man of about thirty years of age entered and bowed.

“You are a Frenchman, I believe,” asked Phileas Fogg, and waited for the answer.

“Jean Passepartout, a nickname that has stuck to me because I have a natural aptness for going in and out of any difficulty. I have been a strolling singer and a circus-rider; I have been a master of gymnastics; and I was once a sergeant fireman in Paris. I quitted France five years ago and, wishing to live the quiet life of a domestic servant, I came to England. Hearing that Mr. Phileas Fogg was the most exact and settled gentleman in the United Kingdom, I have come to offer my services.”

“Passepartout suits me,” responded Mr. Fogg. “You have been well recommended to me. I am told you are a man of your word. What time is it?” he asked, looking at the new servant.

Passepartout drew from his waistcoat pocket a great silver watch; he looked at it, and said, “Twenty-two minutes after eleven, sir.”

“You are four minutes slow,” said Mr. Fogg. “It’s not enough to notice. Very well. Your service begins from this moment—eleven twenty-nine this morning, Wednesday, October 2nd.”

I quitted France five years ago, and, wishing to taste the sweets of domestic life, I came to England and asked for service as a valet. Having heard of Mr. Phileas Fogg as the most exact and settled gentleman in the United Kingdom, I have come to offer myself to him, in the hope of living a tranquil life, and forgetting even the name of Passepartout.”

“Passepartout suits me,” responded Mr. Fogg. “You are well recommended to me. I hear you are a man of your word. You know my conditions?”

“Yes, sir.”

“Very well. What time is it?” asked Mr. Fogg.

Passepartout drew from the depths of his pocket a large silver watch; he looked at it, and said, “Twenty-two minutes past eleven, sir.”

“You are four minutes slow,” responded Mr. Fogg. “It's not enough to notice. Very well. Your service begins from this moment—eleven twenty-nine this morning, Wednesday, October 2nd.”

A rap at this moment sounded on the door of the cosy apartment where Phileas Fogg was seated, and James Forster, the dismissed servant, appeared.

“The new servant,” said Forster.

A man of about thirty years of age entered and bowed.

“You are a Frenchman, I believe?” asked Phileas Fogg.

“Jean,” replied the newcomer.

“John?” asked Phileas Fogg.

“Jean Passepartout,” replied the other. “A nickname which has clung to me, and which commemorates my aptness for getting out of one business into another. I am an honest fellow, monsieur, and, to be brief, I have been successively a strolling singer, a circus-rider, when I used to vault like Leotard, and dance on the tight-rope like Blondin. Afterwards I became a professor of gymnastics, and for my last hobby I was a sergeant fireman at Paris. I quitted France five years ago, and, wishing to taste the sweets of domestic life, I came to England and asked for service as a valet. Having heard of Mr. Phileas Fogg as the most exact and settled gentleman in the United Kingdom, I have come to offer myself to him, in the hope of living a tranquil life, and forgetting even the name of Passepartout.”

“Passepartout suits me,” responded Mr. Fogg. “You are well recommended to me. I have a good report of you. You know my conditions?”

“Yes, monsieur.”

“Very well. What time is it?” asked Mr. Fogg.

Passepartout drew from the depths of his pocket a large silver watch; he looked at it, and said, “Twenty-two minutes past eleven, monsieur.”

“You are four minutes slow,” responded Mr. Fogg. “It's not enough to notice. Very well. Your service begins from this moment—eleven twenty-nine this morning, Wednesday, October 2nd.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: A rap at this moment sounded on the door of the cosy apartment where Phileas Fogg was seated, and James Forster, the dismissed servant, appeared. James Forster, with a hesitant air and twisting his cap, stood framed in the doorway. Mr. Fogg, perfectly composed in his armchair, did not betray the slightest surprise at seeing his former domestic. He merely raised his eyes from the 'Daily Telegraph' he was perusing and fixed them mildly upon the man, his expression one of calm indifference. Forster cleared his throat awkwardly. "Begging your pardon, sir," he began, his voice a little shaky, "but I heard..." Mr. Fogg interrupted, his voice even and without inflection, cutting through Forster's uncertainty. "You are no longer in my service, Forster. There is therefore no reason for you to report anything or to seek my permission." "Yes, sir, I understand," Forster stammered, feeling dismissed all over again. "It's just... well, the news around the club, sir. About the... the journey." The sheer scale of the rumour seemed impossible, yet here was the man himself. Mr. Fogg's gaze remained steady, cool and probing. "And what news have you heard, Forster?" "That you are leaving, sir. For eighty days," Forster blurted out, unable to contain his astonishment. His dismissal for a mere two-degree temperature difference now seemed utterly trivial compared to this undertaking – a journey that defied all conventional notions of travel. He perhaps harboured a faint hope that Mr. Fogg might need his services for such a grand tour, or perhaps he was simply driven by overwhelming curiosity. "That is correct," Mr. Fogg replied, folding his newspaper with meticulous precision, his movements never rushed. "I am departing this evening." Forster looked utterly bewildered. "This evening, sir? And... and the house, sir? Who will look after things?" The questions tumbled out of him, born of confusion. "Arrangements have been made," Mr. Fogg stated, his tone final. "A new servant has been engaged. He is expected momentarily." Forster's face fell further. The faint, irrational hope vanished completely. He lingered awkwardly, unsure what else to say to the man who was embarking on such an incredible feat. Mr. Fogg offered no further comment, his attention seemingly already miles away, calculating routes, steaming distances, and predicting weather patterns. The silence hung heavy, broken only by the precise ticking of the clock on the mantelpiece, a clock that would soon become a critical instrument in Fogg's extraordinary, time-bound undertaking. Forster, realising the finality of the situation and feeling the cold politeness of Mr. Fogg's dismissal, began to back out of the room. "Very good, sir," he mumbled, feeling foolish for having intruded. "I... I wish you a safe journey then, sir." Mr. Fogg gave a slight, almost imperceptible inclination of his head, already reaching for a travel guide on his table, his mind clearly elsewhere. As Forster closed the door softly behind him, the apartment returned to its state of absolute order and calm, a calm that belied the immense adventure about to begin across continents and oceans. The arrival of the new servant was now imminent, the servant whose destiny would become inextricably linked with that of the precise, enigmatic, and daring Phileas Fogg.

events.title: Fogg Departs, Leaving Passepartout Alone
detailed_summary: Immediately after hiring Passepartout, Phileas Fogg stands up.
He mechanically puts on his hat and exits the room without speaking further.
Passepartout hears the front door close, signifying his new master's departure.
Shortly after, he hears the door close again as James Forster, his predecessor, also leaves.
Passepartout is left by himself in the Saville Row house.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER II. IN WHICH PASSEPARTOUT IS CONVINCED THAT HE HAS AT LAST FOUND HIS IDEAL

events.title: Passepartout's Assessment of Phileas Fogg
detailed_summary: Passepartout privately compares his new master, Phileas Fogg, to the lifeless wax figures at Madame Tussaud's.
During their brief meeting, Passepartout closely observed Fogg.
Fogg is described as around forty, handsome, tall, with light hair and whiskers, a smooth forehead, pale complexion, and excellent teeth.
His demeanor exemplifies 'repose in action', suggesting a man of deeds over words.
He possesses a calm, phlegmatic nature and clear eyes, embodying English composure.
Fogg appears perfectly balanced and regulated, much like a precision chronometer.
He is characterized as the personification of exactitude, evident even in his hands and feet.
His exactness means he is never rushed but always prepared, conserving his steps and movements.
He consistently takes the shortest path, avoids unnecessary gestures, and remains outwardly unmoved and calm.
Despite his deliberate nature, he invariably arrives precisely on time.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Faith,” muttered Passepartout, somewhat flurried, “I’ve seen people at Madame Tussaud’s as lively as my new master!”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He was the most deliberate person in the world, yet always reached his destination at the exact moment.

events.text_segment:
“Faith,” muttered Passepartout, somewhat flurried, “I’ve seen people at Madame Tussaud’s as lively as my new master!”
Madame Tussaud’s “people,” let it be said, are of wax, and are much visited in London; speech is all that is wanting to make them human.
During his brief interview with Mr. Fogg, Passepartout had been carefully observing him. He appeared to be a man about forty years of age, with fine, handsome features, and a tall, well-shaped figure; his hair and whiskers were light, his forehead compact and unwrinkled, his face rather pale, his teeth magnificent. His countenance possessed in the highest degree what physiognomists call “repose in action,” a quality of those who act rather than talk. Calm and phlegmatic, with a clear eye, Mr. Fogg seemed a perfect type of that English composure which Angelica Kauffmann has so skilfully represented on canvas. Seen in the various phases of his daily life, he gave the idea of being perfectly well-balanced, as exactly regulated as a Leroy chronometer. Phileas Fogg was, indeed, exactitude personified, and this was betrayed even in the expression of his very hands and feet; for in men, as well as in animals, the limbs themselves are expressive of the passions.
He was so exact that he was never in a hurry, was always ready, and was economical alike of his steps and his motions. He never took one step too many, and always went to his destination by the shortest cut; he made no superfluous gestures, and was never seen to be moved or agitated. He was the most deliberate person in the world, yet always reached his destination at the exact moment.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Faith,” muttered Passepartout, somewhat flurried, “I’ve seen people at Madame Tussaud’s as lively as my new master!”

During the few moments that he had been with Mr. Phileas Fogg, he had attentively observed him. He was a man of forty, of noble and handsome countenance, with fair hair and whiskers; of a smooth forehead, showing no wrinkle or furrow; of very clear eyes, whose expression was candid and serene; of fine teeth, concealed by his moustache; of a tall figure, slim and well set up; of a pale complexion, which had the calmness of temperament rather than the weariness of toil. He embodied exactly what the phrase "repose in action" expresses, as one who, little demonstrative, accomplishes a great deal. He was, it may be added, perfectly English in his look, in his manners, and in his perpetual serenity. If Mr. Phileas Fogg was not rich, he was exact; if he was not generous, he was regular; if he was not amiable, he was always punctually dressed. He was the type of the phlegmatic Englishman, who, not wanting to waste words, does not waste steps either. He had never been seen flustered or perturbed. He was the man in the world who seemed least given to being in a hurry; he was always ready, however, and always arrived on time. He conserved his steps and movements, only taking the shortest path. He never allowed any useless gesture. He was never seen, however, in the least agitated, calm and impassible, with a clear look and steady brow, this was the man. Mr. Phileas Fogg seemed perfectly regulated, as a chronometer of Leroy or Dent. Indeed, he was exactitude personified, and that was visible even in his hands and feet; for his hands, which were long and slender, obeyed his thoughts with wonderful precision; and his feet, encased in thick-soled shoes, were no less sure in their movements. Mr. Phileas Fogg was a man of method and punctuality, the most exact man in England, which is saying a great deal in a country where the most exact men in the world are to be found.

He was the man in the world who seemed least given to being in a hurry; he was always ready, however, and always arrived on time. He conserved his steps and movements, only taking the shortest path. He never allowed any useless gesture. He was never seen, however, in the least agitated, calm and impassible, with a clear look and steady brow, this was the man. Mr. Phileas Fogg seemed perfectly regulated, as a chronometer of Dent or Leroy. Indeed, he was exactitude personified, and that was visible even in his limbs, for, as has been observed, in men as well as in animals, the limbs themselves are expressive of the passions. His hands, which were long and slender, obeyed his thoughts with wonderful precision; and his feet, encased in thick-soled shoes, were no less sure in their movements. Mr. Phileas Fogg was a man of method and punctuality.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: “Faith,” muttered Passepartout, somewhat flurried, “I’ve seen people at Madame Tussaud’s as lively as my new master!” Indeed, Phileas Fogg was one of those mathematically exact people, who, never hurried and always ready, are economical of their steps and their movements. He never took a superfluous step, and always came back by the shortest way. He did not use words, for he needed none; and as for gestures, his arm and his hand never moved without a reason. He was the man least hasty in the world, yet always reached his destination at the exact time. He lived alone in his house in Savile Row, which was a model of method and cleanliness. Every hour, every minute had its use. Fogg's day was regulated like a chronometer. He breakfasted at exactly eight o'clock, and after reading the Times and the Standard, he went to the Reform Club, where he remained till half-past six, playing whist. He dined there, and returned home at midnight precisely, only to go to bed. Passepartout, after a life of singing, dancing, and athleticism, sought repose, a quiet life in service to an English gentleman. He had heard of the far-famed English phlegm, but this surpassed everything. His astonishment only increased when he learned the fate of the previous valet, dismissed because the shaving water, delivered at 86 degrees Fahrenheit, was discovered to be only 84 degrees, two degrees below the prescribed temperature! Passepartout felt a peculiar mixture of awe and apprehension entering this meticulously ordered, silent abode.

events.title: Passepartout's Background and Motivations
detailed_summary: Fogg's solitary existence is noted; he avoids social interaction to prevent 'friction'.
Passepartout is introduced as a genuine Parisian who moved to England seeking a suitable master.
He is described not as a stereotypical impudent servant, but as honest, pleasant-faced, agreeable, serviceable, with a friendly round head, blue eyes, ruddy complexion, and a robust, muscular build.
His hair is somewhat messy, styled simply with a comb.
The narrator questions how Passepartout's lively temperament will mesh with Fogg's methodical nature, stating only experience will tell.
Passepartout's past involved some wandering, and he now longs for stability.
He had served in ten English households but couldn't settle due to masters he found erratic and adventurous.
His previous employer, Lord Longferry, led a dissolute life, often returning home drunk via police assistance.
Passepartout's attempt to gently admonish Longferry was poorly received, prompting his departure.
Hearing about Phileas Fogg's extreme regularity, lack of travel, and predictable home life, Passepartout believed he had found his ideal employer.
He applied for the position and was hired.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He lived alone, and, so to speak, outside of every social relation; and as he knew that in this world account must be taken of friction, and that friction retards, he never rubbed against anybody.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He presented himself, and was accepted, as has been seen.

events.text_segment:
He lived alone, and, so to speak, outside of every social relation; and as he knew that in this world account must be taken of friction, and that friction retards, he never rubbed against anybody.
As for Passepartout, he was a true Parisian of Paris. Since he had abandoned his own country for England, taking service as a valet, he had in vain searched for a master after his own heart. Passepartout was by no means one of those pert dunces depicted by Molière with a bold gaze and a nose held high in the air; he was an honest fellow, with a pleasant face, lips a trifle protruding, soft-mannered and serviceable, with a good round head, such as one likes to see on the shoulders of a friend. His eyes were blue, his complexion rubicund, his figure almost portly and well-built, his body muscular, and his physical powers fully developed by the exercises of his younger days. His brown hair was somewhat tumbled; for, while the ancient sculptors are said to have known eighteen methods of arranging Minerva’s tresses, Passepartout was familiar with but one of dressing his own: three strokes of a large-tooth comb completed his toilet.
It would be rash to predict how Passepartout’s lively nature would agree with Mr. Fogg. It was impossible to tell whether the new servant would turn out as absolutely methodical as his master required; experience alone could solve the question. Passepartout had been a sort of vagrant in his early years, and now yearned for repose; but so far he had failed to find it, though he had already served in ten English houses. But he could not take root in any of these; with chagrin, he found his masters invariably whimsical and irregular, constantly running about the country, or on the look-out for adventure. His last master, young Lord Longferry, Member of Parliament, after passing his nights in the Haymarket taverns, was too often brought home in the morning on policemen’s shoulders. Passepartout, desirous of respecting the gentleman whom he served, ventured a mild remonstrance on such conduct; which, being ill-received, he took his leave. Hearing that Mr. Phileas Fogg was looking for a servant, and that his life was one of unbroken regularity, that he neither travelled nor stayed from home overnight, he felt sure that this would be the place he was after. He presented himself, and was accepted, as has been seen.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: He lived alone, and, so to speak, outside of every social relation; and as he knew that in this world account must be taken of friction, and that friction retards, he never rubbed against anybody. As for Passepartout, he was a genuine Parisian of Paris. For five years he had been a valet de chambre in England, and, scorning the title of valet, he called himself a "man-of-all-work." Passepartout was an honest fellow, with a pleasant face, lips a trifle too red, signifying a perpetual grand appetite, ready to lend a hand to any business, and uncommonly strong and well-shaped. He had a fine, open, honest countenance, a slightly bald head, and a round, good-humoured face; his body was stout and robust, his self-esteem, so say the least, considerable. Passepartout, in short, was one of those good fellows who run about the world without ever finding rest—vagrants, it may be, but never rogues. He had served in Paris as a fireman, and had been highly recommended. Passepartout was an admirable gymnast, and had often shown his agility in the public gardens of Paris. He had also been a professional musician, and a good one too. Having wandered a great deal, he sought to settle down; and having heard that the English were of all people the most regular, he had taken service with an Englishman. But in England, Passepartout had been more a rolling stone than ever. He had had ten masters, and every one of them had been more eccentric than the others. He had left them all. The fact is that Passepartout did not consider himself master of his own actions; he believed that he was bound to serve, but he did not like to follow a master who did not follow his own plans. He was in despair. Having failed to find a master to suit him in England, he had resolved to return to Paris, when he heard of Phileas Fogg. Mr. Phileas Fogg, it was said, never went out; he never visited or received any one. He was a man of the most exact habits, who performed his duties with mathematical precision, and who never travelled. Just the man for him! Mr. Fogg was a personification of regularity, who, as far as Passepartout could see, was absolutely exempt from the vagaries of travel. So Passepartout applied for the place, and was accepted.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: He lived alone, and, so to speak, outside of every social relation; and as he knew that in this world account must be taken of friction, and that friction retards, he never rubbed against anybody. As a consequence, he was rarely seen, and if he was, it was only to perform some act which his rigidly scheduled life required. He was not known to have friends, or relatives, or any close connection with another human being. His house, in Savile Row, was a model of spick-and-span neatness; its internal regulation seemed as perfect as the movements of a chronometer. Indeed, Phileas Fogg himself might have been mistaken for a highly perfected automaton. His hours were strictly portioned out. He rose at precisely eight o'clock; he breakfasted at exactly eight o'clock and thirty-seven minutes; he shaved at nine o'clock and thirty-seven minutes; he dressed at ten o'clock and twenty minutes; he left his house for the Reform Club at half-past eleven, to the minute. He dined there invariably at a quarter before seven. At midnight precisely, he returned home, and at twelve minutes past midnight, he was in bed. His daily journey to the Reform Club was performed without fail, without haste, and without deviation. He always walked the same number of steps, took the same turnings, passed the same landmarks, arrived at the same second. He was, in a word, the essence of regularity and precision. He never indulged in unnecessary conversation, never lingered, never showed surprise or excitement. His face, handsome and calm, betrayed no emotion. His movements were few, measured, and exact. He read the papers at the Club from half-past eleven till noon, then played whist with a small, select group of partners and adversaries until dinner. After dinner, he returned to the whist-room, where he continued playing till midnight. He rarely lost, for he played scientifically, without enthusiasm, and without error. He was rich, though no one knew from what source his riches came. He spent little, but was not mean; he gave largely to charities, but anonymously. He seemed to live only for himself, avoiding all contact that might introduce the slightest unpredictability or delay into the faultless mechanism of his existence. It was this very need for flawless precision that had recently led him to dismiss his valet, James Forster, for the grave offence of bringing him shaving water two degrees too cold.

events.title: Passepartout Inspects His New Home
detailed_summary: Left alone in the Saville Row house at 11:30, Passepartout immediately begins exploring it thoroughly.
He surveys the entire residence, from the basement to the attic.
The cleanliness, orderliness, and solemn atmosphere of the mansion impress him favorably.
He likens the house to a snail's shell, efficiently lit and heated by gas.
Upon reaching the second floor, he identifies his designated room and finds it highly satisfactory.
He notes the modern conveniences: electric bells and speaking tubes connecting the floors.
An electric clock on his mantelpiece catches his attention, perfectly synchronized with an identical one in Mr. Fogg's bedroom.
Passepartout expresses his approval of this precision.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At half-past eleven, then, Passepartout found himself alone in the house in Saville Row.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “That’s good, that’ll do,” said Passepartout to himself.

events.text_segment: At half-past eleven, then, Passepartout found himself alone in the house in Saville Row. He began its inspection without delay, scouring it from cellar to garret. So clean, well-arranged, solemn a mansion pleased him; it seemed to him like a snail’s shell, lighted and warmed by gas, which sufficed for both these purposes. When Passepartout reached the second story he recognised at once the room which he was to inhabit, and he was well satisfied with it. Electric bells and speaking-tubes afforded communication with the lower stories; while on the mantel stood an electric clock, precisely like that in Mr. Fogg’s bedchamber, both beating the same second at the same instant. “That’s good, that’ll do,” said Passepartout to himself.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
At half-past eleven, then, Passepartout found himself alone in the house in Saville Row.

He at once commenced its inspection. From the cellar to the garret, he explored it all. Cleanliness, order reigned everywhere; the most austere Quaker could not have kept his house better ordered than this. The partridge eye of the gas-burners in the hall, however, proved to him that all modern comfort was here, and that Mr. Fogg did not pique himself upon living like a hermit. He ascended to the second story, and there found the room he was to occupy, a neat, comfortable apartment, to which an electric bell and a speaking-tube gave communication with the ground-floor. On the mantel over the clock (which indicated the exact second), he observed a card which bore the following inscription: ““James Passepartout, at your service.””

He whistled, folded his arms, and felt firm upon his legs. His master’s regularity pleased him; he was a man of his pattern, and so much the better. After having inspected it house in detail, he rubbed his hands together, and with a satisfied air murmered:

“This is just my affair! This Mr. Fogg is a man of habits, who evidently likes punctuality. So much the better; I have not been able to live with punctilious people before, with your run-about masters, here, there, and everywhere. Mr. Fogg’s way of living suits me excellently. He stays at home, in the first place. And as he is a man of the most orderly habits, he will never dream of running away. We shall not be prancing about the country, then; we shall be here, and shall go to bed at regular hours, and eat our dinners, and not have to do with any of those cursed vagabonds who are always running about in search of adventures. Master Fogg is not a man to run away, I can tell you. I have been in the service of families where the children would break your nose, and shout and yell the whole day long, and where it was impossible to keep one’s hair on one’s head. With Mr. Fogg, however, I shall be sheltered from all that; an honest and regular man. A real machine, well regulated! And I did not come to London to be an idler!”

He stays at home, in the first place. And as he is a man of the most orderly habits, he will never dream of running away. We shall not be prancing about the country, then; we shall be here, and shall go to bed at regular hours, and eat our dinners, and not have to do with any of those cursed vagabonds who are always running about in search of adventures. Master Fogg is not a man to run away, I can tell you. I have been in the service of families where the children would break your nose, and shout and yell the whole day long, and where it was impossible to keep one’s hair on one’s head. With Mr. Fogg, however, I shall be sheltered from all that; an honest and regular man. A real machine, well regulated! And I did not come to London to be an idler!”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: At half-past eleven, then, Passepartout found himself alone in the house in Saville Row. He had been in service only a few hours when his new master, Phileas Fogg, announced he was leaving on an eighty-day journey around the world, leaving Passepartout behind. Alone in the impeccably tidy house, Passepartout felt a mixture of bewilderment and unexpected freedom. He began to explore the dwelling, marveling at the perfect order and quiet luxury. It was a stark contrast to his previous, more unsettled life. He pondered the character of the precise gentleman who maintained such a rigid household and who had just embarked on such an improbable adventure. The silence of the place settled around him, underscoring the suddenness of his master's departure and the peculiarity of his new situation.

events.title: Discovery of the Detailed Household Schedule
detailed_summary: Passepartout notices a card displayed above his clock.
He examines it and discovers it is a detailed schedule outlining the household's daily routine.
The program lists all servant duties from 8:00 AM (Fogg's rising time) until 11:30 AM (Fogg's departure for the Reform Club).
Specific timings include tea and toast at 8:23 AM, shaving water at 9:37 AM, and dressing at 9:40 AM.
The schedule meticulously dictates every planned activity from 11:30 AM until midnight, when Fogg habitually went to bed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He suddenly observed, hung over the clock, a card which, upon inspection, proved to be a programme of the daily routine of the house.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Everything was regulated and foreseen that was to be done from half-past eleven a.m. till midnight, the hour at which the methodical gentleman retired.

events.text_segment: He suddenly observed, hung over the clock, a card which, upon inspection, proved to be a programme of the daily routine of the house. It comprised all that was required of the servant, from eight in the morning, exactly at which hour Phileas Fogg rose, till half-past eleven, when he left the house for the Reform Club—all the details of service, the tea and toast at twenty-three minutes past eight, the shaving-water at thirty-seven minutes past nine, and the toilet at twenty minutes before ten. Everything was regulated and foreseen that was to be done from half-past eleven a.m. till midnight, the hour at which the methodical gentleman retired.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: He suddenly observed, hung over the clock, a card which, upon inspection, proved to be a programme of the daily routine of the house. It comprised from eight in the morning, the hour at which Phileas Fogg rose, till half-past eleven, when he left the house for the Reform Club—all the details of service, all the different duties prescribed, all the hours fixed for their accomplishment; thus, from eight to twenty minutes past eight, tea and toast; from twenty minutes to nine to twenty-two minutes past nine, dressing; from twenty-two minutes past nine to ten, toilet; from ten to half-past eleven, various duties, until going out: finally, from half-past eleven till midnight, when the methodical gentleman retired, everything was regulated, everything was foreseen, everything was arranged. Mr. Fogg was, indeed, one of the members of the Reform Club, though he seemed by no means anxious to enjoy the privilege of remaining there during the whole day. He was an honourable and exact man, but little communicative, and used to eat his breakfast and dinner at the club at hours mathematically fixed. "Decidedly," said Passepartout to himself, with a satisfied air, "this is the fellow for me! He is a man who is never away from home, a steady gentleman, and one as methodical as a machine. I should not wonder if he had measured and weighed the very coals which he uses for the fire. He will be sure to have them sent from the other side of the world; it will be all the same to me."

events.title: Examination of Fogg's Wardrobe and House Amenities
detailed_summary: Passepartout observes that Mr. Fogg's wardrobe is extensive and of high quality.
Each item of clothing (trousers, coat, vest) is numbered to indicate the specific time of year and season for its use.
This systematic organization extends to Fogg's footwear.
The Saville Row house, once known for disorder under the ownership of Sheridan, is now the epitome of coziness, comfort, and method.
Passepartout notes the absence of a study or personal book collection, as Fogg utilizes the libraries at the Reform Club.
A sturdy safe, resistant to fire and theft, is located in Fogg's bedroom.
He finds no firearms or hunting gear anywhere in the house, suggesting Fogg leads an extremely tranquil and peaceful life.
After completing his thorough inspection, Passepartout reacts with pleasure.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Fogg’s wardrobe was amply supplied and in the best taste.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Having scrutinised the house from top to bottom, he rubbed his hands, a broad smile overspread his features, and he said joyfully, “This is just what I wanted!

events.text_segment:
Mr. Fogg’s wardrobe was amply supplied and in the best taste. Each pair of trousers, coat, and vest bore a number, indicating the time of year and season at which they were in turn to be laid out for wearing; and the same system was applied to the master’s shoes. In short, the house in Saville Row, which must have been a very temple of disorder and unrest under the illustrious but dissipated Sheridan, was cosiness, comfort, and method idealised. There was no study, nor were there books, which would have been quite useless to Mr. Fogg; for at the Reform two libraries, one of general literature and the other of law and politics, were at his service. A moderate-sized safe stood in his bedroom, constructed so as to defy fire as well as burglars; but Passepartout found neither arms nor hunting weapons anywhere; everything betrayed the most tranquil and peaceable habits.
Having scrutinised the house from top to bottom, he rubbed his hands, a broad smile overspread his features, and he said joyfully, “This is just what I wanted!

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Mr. Fogg’s wardrobe was amply supplied and in the best taste. Each pair of trousers, coat, and vest was numbered, indicating the time of year in which it was to be worn; and the same methodical arrangement characterised the linen and shoes. There were no less than three hundred shirts and entire suits, and the same proportion of boots and shoes. It was true that the legendary Sheridan, celebrated for his varied talents, but above all for his disorder, had been the owner of this house; but the mansion had since been improved, and the new occupant was a man of the strictest method and neatness. The chimney-piece of the principal salon was adorned by a clock, with an electric indicator that communicated the hours to either a clock in Mr. Fogg’s bedroom or a dial in the porter’s lodge. In the dressing-room were found a number of necessaries of travel, though not ostentatious, such as never exist in the houses of stay-at-homes. Mr. Fogg had no books, and did not avail himself of the libraries of London, which he found overcrowded; for two books in particular, “Bradshaw’s Continental Railway Steam Transit and General Guide,” and the “Official Guide of the Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company,” sufficed him. He had, in effect, a large collection of maps and plans, and possessed also a chronometer which indicated the seconds as well as the minutes and hours; for, with him, minutes were precious. There was no end to the ingenious appliances therein, and the house was perfect in its comfort and method. There was not a sign of disorder, not a speck of dust, not a thing out of place; all was as regular and orderly as a mathematical problem. Passepartout examined the several rooms, and felt that he could not but be satisfied with his master’s impeccably clean and tidy habits. A sturdy, solid safe, large enough to hold a good many bank-notes, was built into the wall, and was so ingeniously concealed as to be invisible; while a simple push of a spring caused it to open as if by magic. There were no firearms nor hunting weapons of any kind. Passepartout found nothing but tools for peaceful pursuits, such as a collection of scissors, gum-bottles, and paste-pots, and other implements for the repair of clothing, which was a very proper and becoming thing in the house of so estimable a gentleman. Passepartout's reflection upon it all was highly satisfactory. “This is a first-rate fellow,” said he to himself, “and we shall get along together. Mr. Fogg, thought he, is a man of system, a regular automaton; he is not given to walking, nor to hunting, nor to fishing, nor to anything which can take him out of the house. He will probably not want to take any journeys either. So much the better for me, who have not left Paris for the past five years, and have not known what it is to stretch my legs. We shall be as quiet here as in a convent, and as regular as the hands of a clock. Ah, what a good choice I have made, and how glad I am to have fallen in with this excellent Mr. Fogg! A man who is so methodical and so neat, so regular and so quiet. He will not take any journeys; that is certain. He will not take any journeys.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Mr. Fogg’s wardrobe was amply supplied and in the best taste. It held all necessary for a gentleman, arranged with the precision marking his habits. Yet, when packing for his circumnavigation, preparations were minimal. His manservant, Passepartout, expecting trunks for a journey through varied climates, was astonished by the single valise Fogg presented. Inside, only a travelling cloak, changes of linen, toiletries – not even an umbrella! This simplicity reflected Fogg’s character: pragmatic, unconcerned with superfluity, focused solely on essentials for his objective. He calculated precisely what he needed, eliminating anything impeding rapid progress. Passepartout, accustomed to elaborate rituals, could scarcely believe the collection. It seemed insufficient for a journey around the world. But Fogg, calm and logical, deemed this sparse selection adequate. His logic dictated efficiency, even regarding personal effects. This approach set the tone for the adventure, highlighting Fogg’s unique nature. His wardrobe, limited, was perfectly chosen: practical, unobtrusive, fit for purpose in his race against time.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER III. IN WHICH A CONVERSATION TAKES PLACE WHICH SEEMS LIKELY TO COST PHILEAS FOGG DEAR

events.title: Phileas Fogg's Meticulous Routine at the Reform Club
detailed_summary: Phileas Fogg concludes his precise walk from his home to the Reform Club.
He proceeds directly to the dining room and occupies his usual table.
Fogg consumes a specific, multi-course breakfast, finishing with several cups of the club's renowned tea.
At 12:47 PM, he moves to the grand hall.
A servant provides him with an uncut issue of The Times, which Fogg expertly cuts and reads until 3:45 PM.
He then reads the Standard until dinner.
Dinner is similar to his breakfast routine.
After dinner, Fogg returns to the reading-room, taking up the Pall Mall newspaper at 5:40 PM.
At 6:10 PM, several fellow Reform Club members, his regular whist companions, arrive and gather near the fireplace.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Phileas Fogg, having shut the door of his house at half-past eleven, and having put his right foot before his left five hundred and seventy-five times, and his left foot before his right five hundred and seventy-six times, reached the Reform Club, an imposing edifice in Pall Mall, which could not have cost less than three millions.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: They were Mr. Fogg’s usual partners at whist: Andrew Stuart, an engineer; John Sullivan and Samuel Fallentin, bankers; Thomas Flanagan, a brewer; and Gauthier Ralph, one of the Directors of the Bank of England—all rich and highly respectable personages, even in a club which comprises the princes of English trade and finance.

events.text_segment: Phileas Fogg, having shut the door of his house at half-past eleven, and having put his right foot before his left five hundred and seventy-five times, and his left foot before his right five hundred and seventy-six times, reached the Reform Club, an imposing edifice in Pall Mall, which could not have cost less than three millions. He repaired at once to the dining-room, the nine windows of which open upon a tasteful garden, where the trees were already gilded with an autumn colouring; and took his place at the habitual table, the cover of which had already been laid for him. His breakfast consisted of a side-dish, a broiled fish with Reading sauce, a scarlet slice of roast beef garnished with mushrooms, a rhubarb and gooseberry tart, and a morsel of Cheshire cheese, the whole being washed down with several cups of tea, for which the Reform is famous. He rose at thirteen minutes to one, and directed his steps towards the large hall, a sumptuous apartment adorned with lavishly-framed paintings. A flunkey handed him an uncut Times, which he proceeded to cut with a skill which betrayed familiarity with this delicate operation. The perusal of this paper absorbed Phileas Fogg until a quarter before four, whilst the Standard, his next task, occupied him till the dinner hour. Dinner passed as breakfast had done, and Mr. Fogg re-appeared in the reading-room and sat down to the Pall Mall at twenty minutes before six. Half an hour later several members of the Reform came in and drew up to the fireplace, where a coal fire was steadily burning. They were Mr. Fogg’s usual partners at whist: Andrew Stuart, an engineer; John Sullivan and Samuel Fallentin, bankers; Thomas Flanagan, a brewer; and Gauthier Ralph, one of the Directors of the Bank of England—all rich and highly respectable personages, even in a club which comprises the princes of English trade and finance.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Phileas Fogg, having shut the door of his house at half-past eleven, and having put his right foot before his left five hundred and seventy-five times, and his left foot before his right five hundred and seventy-six times, reached the Reform Club, an imposing edifice in Pall Mall, which could not have cost less than three millions. He repaired at once to the dining-room, the windows of which opened upon a tasteful garden, and sat down at his usual table, upon which a napkin was already folded for him. His breakfast consisted of a side-dish, a broiled fish with Reading sauce, a roast beef garnished with mushrooms, and a rhubarb and gooseberry tart, with a few sorts of cheese, the whole being washed down with several cups of an excellent tea, which the Reform Club procures for itself at a great expense. At twenty minutes before one, he rose and proceeded to the great hall, where a prurient flunkey handed him an uncut number of The Times, which he proceeded to cut with a skill which betrayed long practice. He devoted himself to the reading of this journal until a quarter before four, and the Standard occupied his attention till dinner. Dinner was served in the same manner as breakfast, and the guests of the club, about a hundred in number, who formed a graceful cluster about the capacious dining-room, were universally distinguished for their scrupulous cleanliness of dress. At twenty minutes before six, Mr. Fogg reappeared in the reading-room and sat down to the Pall Mall. At ten minutes past six, the above-named gentlemen, Messers. Andrew Stuart, John Sullivan, Samuel Fallentin, Thomas Flanagan, and Gauthier Ralph, all indefatigable card-players, were assembled in the reading-room, and were exchanging observations in reference to the robbery which had just been committed at the Bank of England.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_2.text: Phileas Fogg, having shut the door of his house at half-past eleven, and having put his right foot before his left five hundred and seventy-five times, and his left foot before his right five hundred and seventy-six times, reached the Reform Club, an imposing edifice in Pall Mall, which could not have cost less than three millions. He repaired at once to the dining-room, the seven windows of which opened upon a tasteful garden, where the trees were already gilded with autumnal colours, and sat down at his usual table, the cover of which had already been laid for him. His breakfast consisted of a side-dish, a broiled fish with Reading sauce, a roast beef garnished with mushrooms, a rhubarb and gooseberry tart, and a piece of Parmesan cheese, the whole being washed down with several cups of an excellent tea. At forty-seven minutes past twelve, he rose and proceeded to the great hall, a sumptuous apartment adorned with lavishly-framed paintings, where a flunkey handed him an uncut number of The Times, which he proceeded to cut with a skill which betrayed long practice and that familiarity with the operation which characterised Mr. Fogg. He devoted himself to the reading of this journal until a quarter before four, and the Standard occupied his attention till dinner hour. Dinner was served in the same manner as breakfast. At twenty minutes before six, Mr. Fogg reappeared in the reading-room and sat down to the Pall Mall. At ten minutes past six, the above-named gentlemen, Messers. Andrew Stuart, John Sullivan, Samuel Fallentin, Thomas Flanagan, and Gauthier Ralph, all highly respectable personages, and engineers and bankers, with whom Mr. Fogg played whist regularly, were assembled by the fireplace, where a coal fire was burning. They were princes of English trade and finance, and belonged to the most prosperous class of English society.
