LLM_completions.prefix-probing: In the semi-obscurity they saw the victim, quite senseless, stretched out beside her husband’s body. It was a woman, young and beautiful, dressed in rich silks, her features pale and still. Fogg, ever the pragmatist, knelt and quickly checked for a pulse, finding a faint but steady beat. Passepartout, his heart pounding with a mixture of horror and pity, gripped his master's arm, a silent question in his eyes. The air hung heavy, thick with the scent of sandalwood and the dread anticipation of the impending ritual. Time was their enemy. The Brahmins who were to carry out the horrific sacrifice had momentarily withdrawn, likely for final prayers or preparations, but they could return at any instant. Their absence offered a fleeting window of opportunity, but also immense danger should they be discovered interrupting a sacred rite. Without a word wasted, Fogg directed Passepartout and the hesitant guides. "Lift her," he commanded quietly. The guides, visibly terrified of the consequences of interfering with the suttee, initially shrank back, but Fogg's firm, authoritative presence and the promise of a substantial reward spurred them into action, albeit with nervous glances towards the grove's edge. Carefully, reverently almost, they lifted the unconscious woman. She felt incredibly light in their arms. Carrying her swiftly, though cautiously, they moved away from the ghastly pyre and the silent, lifeless form lying beside it. The jungle foliage offered concealment, but every snapped twig or rustle of leaves seemed magnified in the tense silence. They knew the danger was profound; discovery would mean not only failure to save her but facing the fanatical rage of the priests and potentially the law. They put distance between themselves and the site of doom, making their way towards the edge of the clearing where their elephant waited patiently, a dark, silent shape. They reached the great beast, which knelt docilely. They gently placed the woman, Aouda, onto its back, wrapping her securely in a blanket one of the guides produced. With their precious cargo safe, they mounted the elephant, the guides scrambling on behind them. The mahout, understanding the urgency without needing words, urged the animal forward. It turned and silently melted back into the dense shadows of the Indian jungle, just as the faintest blush of dawn began to streak the eastern sky, a stark reminder of how narrowly they had escaped. The rescue was complete, but they were now fugitives, carrying a rescued woman, deeper into unfamiliar territory, the threat of pursuit looming large behind them.

events.title: Escape Under Fire
detailed_summary: Shortly after the rescue, the four companions vanish into the surrounding woods.
The elephant rapidly carries them away from the scene.
The sounds of shouting and pursuit, along with a bullet whizzing past Fogg's hat, confirm their deception has been uncovered.
The actual corpse of the rajah becomes visible on the pyre.
The priests, overcoming their fear, realize an abduction has occurred.
They lead soldiers into the forest in pursuit, firing a volley of shots at the escaping party.
However, the fugitives on the elephant quickly gain distance, soon moving beyond the effective range of the bullets and arrows.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A moment after all four of the party had disappeared in the woods, and the elephant was bearing them away at a rapid pace.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: They hastened into the forest, followed by the soldiers, who fired a volley after the fugitives; but the latter rapidly increased the distance between them, and ere long found themselves beyond the reach of the bullets and arrows.

events.text_segment:
A moment after all four of the party had disappeared in the woods, and the elephant was bearing them away at a rapid pace. But the cries and noise, and a ball which whizzed through Phileas Fogg’s hat, apprised them that the trick had been discovered.
The old rajah’s body, indeed, now appeared upon the burning pyre; and the priests, recovered from their terror, perceived that an abduction had taken place. They hastened into the forest, followed by the soldiers, who fired a volley after the fugitives; but the latter rapidly increased the distance between them, and ere long found themselves beyond the reach of the bullets and arrows.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: A moment after all four of the party had disappeared in the woods, and the elephant was bearing them away at a rapid pace. It was then about half-past four. The ground, having become more practicable, the elephant marched very rapidly, and, an hour after leaving the temple of Pillaji, a few stray cries indicated that the priests had become aware of their loss, and that the pursuit had been organized. The shouts were at first distant, but gradually approached, and a great number of cries soon resounded in the forest. The firing of muskets was heard, and balls whizzed past the travellers. But the fugitives hurried on, and gained on the pursuers the distance which separates the sportsman from the game. The elephant, quickly getting out of the reach of the balls, soon reached a clearing, by which Sir Francis Cromarty recognised the route which they had proposed following.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XIV. IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG DESCENDS THE WHOLE LENGTH OF THE BEAUTIFUL VALLEY OF THE GANGES WITHOUT EVER THINKING OF SEEING IT

events.title: Post-Rescue Celebration and Reflection
detailed_summary: The successful rescue mission concludes, bringing relief.
Passepartout expresses great amusement over his role in the exploit.
Sir Francis congratulates Passepartout warmly.
Phileas Fogg offers rare praise, saying "Well done!"
Passepartout deflects the praise, crediting Fogg and calling his own contribution a mere "queer" idea.
He humorously reflects on his brief impersonation as the husband of a venerable rajah.
Aouda remains unconscious from the ordeal, resting in a howdah.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The rash exploit had been accomplished; and for an hour Passepartout laughed gaily at his success.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: As for the young Indian woman, she had been unconscious throughout of what was passing, and now, wrapped up in a travelling-blanket, was reposing in one of the howdahs.

events.text_segment: The rash exploit had been accomplished; and for an hour Passepartout laughed gaily at his success. Sir Francis pressed the worthy fellow’s hand, and his master said, “Well done!” which, from him, was high commendation; to which Passepartout replied that all the credit of the affair belonged to Mr. Fogg. As for him, he had only been struck with a “queer” idea; and he laughed to think that for a few moments he, Passepartout, the ex-gymnast, ex-sergeant fireman, had been the spouse of a charming woman, a venerable, embalmed rajah! As for the young Indian woman, she had been unconscious throughout of what was passing, and now, wrapped up in a travelling-blanket, was reposing in one of the howdahs.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The rash exploit had been accomplished; and for an hour Passepartout laughed gaily at his success. Sir Francis shook his hand, and declared him to be a brave fellow, and that he had saved Aouda. Mr. Fogg simply said, "Well done," which, coming from him, was high praise. Passepartout replied that all the honour belonged to his master; that the idea of the rescue was Mr. Fogg's, and that he was only the agent. He added that it was a "queer" idea for him, a servant, to be the husband of a venerable rajah, and for a few moments he was the venerated rajah himself. As for Aouda, she remained, during the journey, in a sort of trance, and was not yet fully conscious of her position.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The rash exploit had been accomplished; and for an hour Passepartout laughed gaily at his success. His narrow escape from the opium den and quick boarding of the Carnatic filled him with relief. He had outsmarted the Detective Fix! Mr. Fogg would be pleased on hearing his exploit. He was on the proper ship for Yokohama, on schedule for the journey. But as the steamer moved further from Hong Kong, a horrifying question pierced his mood: He was here, but where were Mr. Fogg and Mrs. Aouda? The truth crashed down like waves. He was alone on the Carnatic, separated from his master and the tour.

events.title: Journey Continuation and Concerns for Aouda
detailed_summary: Guided skillfully by the Parsee, the elephant travels swiftly through the dark forest and across a plain.
They halt after about an hour's travel past the pagoda.
Aouda remains deeply unconscious; the guide administers brandy and water without effect.
Sir Francis, recognizing the symptoms of hemp intoxication, reassures the others about her current state.
However, he expresses grave concern for Aouda's future safety if she stays in India.
He warns Fogg that fanatics would find her anywhere in the country, even under English police protection.
Sir Francis concludes that leaving India permanently is her only path to safety.
Phileas Fogg states he will consider the situation.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The elephant, thanks to the skilful guidance of the Parsee, was advancing rapidly through the still darksome forest, and, an hour after leaving the pagoda, had crossed a vast plain.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Phileas Fogg replied that he would reflect upon the matter.

events.text_segment:
The elephant, thanks to the skilful guidance of the Parsee, was advancing rapidly through the still darksome forest, and, an hour after leaving the pagoda, had crossed a vast plain. They made a halt at seven o’clock, the young woman being still in a state of complete prostration. The guide made her drink a little brandy and water, but the drowsiness which stupefied her could not yet be shaken off. Sir Francis, who was familiar with the effects of the intoxication produced by the fumes of hemp, reassured his companions on her account. But he was more disturbed at the prospect of her future fate. He told Phileas Fogg that, should Aouda remain in India, she would inevitably fall again into the hands of her executioners. These fanatics were scattered throughout the county, and would, despite the English police, recover their victim at Madras, Bombay, or Calcutta. She would only be safe by quitting India for ever.
Phileas Fogg replied that he would reflect upon the matter.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The elephant, thanks to the skilful guidance of the Parsee, was advancing rapidly through the still darksome forest, and, an hour after leaving the pagoda, had crossed a vast plain. He had proceeded several miles farther, when the guide stopped, and fixed his attention upon a faint glimmering which appeared a few feet above the surface of the ground. It was a fire, and on the borders of the forest, the branches of which concealed it, were some huts which the travellers easily recognised as belonging to the profession of Indian elephant drivers. There they could no doubt procure a guide who could take them across the country to Allahabad, and luckily the fire was burning when they arrived, so that it was not yet night. The Parsee gently woke one of the drivers, who led the way into one of the huts. There was no lamp burning, but a dim light came from a fire which was smouldering amongst some ashes, and by this light the travellers could see that the hut was built of branches and leaves, and was occupied by half a dozen elephant drivers, snoring in every variety of attitude and tone. The driver whom the Parsee had aroused, after rubbing his eyes and yawning, readily accepted the offer of Phileas Fogg to guide him to Allahabad, and asked a hundred pounds in advance, which was immediately paid him. The Indian then placed in the corner of the hut a quantity of leaves, and invited the travellers to lie down upon them. This they did, and in a few moments they were all asleep. The next morning, at six o'clock, they started off again, accompanied by the new guide, and in two hours they arrived at the village of Allahabad, which is situated at the confluence of the Ganges and the Jumna, and is a large and important city, with a population of about seventy thousand inhabitants. There they found a railway station, and, after having breakfasted, they took their places in a first-class carriage for Bombay. As they were getting into the train, Phileas Fogg turned to Sir Francis Cromarty, and said: 'Sir Francis, I am very much obliged to you for the service you have rendered me.' 'It is nothing, Mr. Fogg,' replied Sir Francis. 'I hope you will have a pleasant journey.' 'Thank you,' said Phileas Fogg, and the train started. They arrived at Bombay without any accident, and Phileas Fogg lost no time in going to the office of the Steam Navigation Company, where he found that the steamer Mongolia, bound for Hong Kong, was to start that very day at eleven o'clock. He therefore had just time to go to the Consulate to get his passport viséed, and then to go on board the steamer, which was already alongside the quay. When he arrived on board, he found that the departure had been postponed till noon, so he had an hour to spare. He employed it in writing to the Reform Club, informing them that he had arrived at Bombay, and that he intended to leave that very day for Hong Kong. He then went on deck and looked about him. The Mongolia was a fine steamer, of eighteen hundred tons, and had a powerful engine. There were a great many passengers on board, amongst whom were several officers of the English army, and a number of civilians, some of whom were going to Hong Kong, and others to Japan. Phileas Fogg then went to his cabin, and, after having ordered his breakfast, he lay down on his berth, and was soon asleep. He did not wake up till the next morning, when he found that the steamer was already at sea. He got up and dressed, and went on deck. It was a beautiful day, and the sea was calm. The Mongolia was making good speed, and the coast of India was rapidly disappearing in the distance. Phileas Fogg then went to the dining-room, and had his breakfast. After breakfast, he went back on deck, and sat down in a comfortable chair. He took out his pocket-book, and consulted his itinerary. He found that he was due at Hong Kong on the 26th of October, and that he had plenty of time to spare. He therefore resolved to pass the time in reading and playing whist. He had brought with him a large stock of books, and also a pack of cards. He began by reading a book, and then he played several games of whist with some of the other passengers. He found that they were all very agreeable people, and that they were very good players. In the evening, he went to bed early, and slept soundly. The next morning, he got up at the usual hour, and went on deck. It was still a beautiful day, and the sea was still calm. The Mongolia was continuing to make good speed, and the coast of India had entirely disappeared. Phileas Fogg then went to the dining-room, and had his breakfast. After breakfast, he went back on deck, and sat down in his comfortable chair. He took out his pocket-book, and consulted his itinerary. He found that he was still due at Hong Kong on the 26th of October, and that he still had plenty of time to spare. He therefore continued to pass the time in reading and playing whist. In the evening, he went to bed early, and slept soundly. This went on for several days. The weather continued to be fine, and the sea continued to be calm. The Mongolia continued to make good speed, and Phileas Fogg continued to pass the time in reading and playing whist. On the 25th of October, they sighted the coast of China. The next morning, they arrived at Hong Kong. Phileas Fogg went on shore, and went to the office of the Steam Navigation Company, where he found that the steamer Carnatic, bound for Yokohama, was to start that very day at five o'clock in the afternoon. He therefore had just time to go to the Consulate to get his passport viséed, and then to go on board the steamer, which was already alongside the quay. The ground was now covered in a low, sparse vegetation, quite different from the dense jungle they had just left. Far ahead, misty shapes began to appear on the horizon, gradually resolving into the formidable peaks of the Vindhya mountains. The air grew cooler as they ascended the gentle slope leading towards the foothills. Fix was growing increasingly uneasy, the presence of the elephant and the speed of their journey unsettling him. Passepartout, however, seemed to revel in the adventure, occasionally whistling a cheerful tune despite the early hour. Fogg remained impassive, seated comfortably in the howdah, consulting his map and stopwatch with his usual precision. The landscape became more rugged, dotted with large rocks and occasional clusters of stunted trees. The Parsee navigated with confidence, occasionally shouting instructions to the magnificent beast. The elephant’s pace remained steady and strong.

events.title: Arrival at Allahabad and Passepartout's Shopping Errand
detailed_summary: The group reaches the Allahabad railway station around ten o'clock.
The railway line continues from here, promising arrival in Calcutta within 24 hours.
This timing allows Fogg to catch the planned steamer to Hong Kong.
Aouda is settled in a waiting room.
Fogg tasks Passepartout with buying necessary clothing and toiletries for Aouda, giving him unlimited funds.
Passepartout ventures into Allahabad, noting its significance as the 'City of God' at the confluence of the Ganges and Jumna rivers.
He observes the city's landmarks, including its fort-turned-prison, and finds its commerce disappointing compared to London.
He eventually locates an elderly Jewish merchant selling second-hand goods.
Passepartout purchases a Scottish dress, a large mantle, and an otter-skin pelisse for seventy-five pounds.
He returns to the station, pleased with his purchases.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The station at Allahabad was reached about ten o’clock, and, the interrupted line of railway being resumed, would enable them to reach Calcutta in less than twenty-four hours.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He then returned triumphantly to the station.

events.text_segment:
The station at Allahabad was reached about ten o’clock, and, the interrupted line of railway being resumed, would enable them to reach Calcutta in less than twenty-four hours. Phileas Fogg would thus be able to arrive in time to take the steamer which left Calcutta the next day, October 25th, at noon, for Hong Kong.
The young woman was placed in one of the waiting-rooms of the station, whilst Passepartout was charged with purchasing for her various articles of toilet, a dress, shawl, and some furs; for which his master gave him unlimited credit. Passepartout started off forthwith, and found himself in the streets of Allahabad, that is, the City of God, one of the most venerated in India, being built at the junction of the two sacred rivers, Ganges and Jumna, the waters of which attract pilgrims from every part of the peninsula. The Ganges, according to the legends of the Ramayana, rises in heaven, whence, owing to Brahma’s agency, it descends to the earth.
Passepartout made it a point, as he made his purchases, to take a good look at the city. It was formerly defended by a noble fort, which has since become a state prison; its commerce has dwindled away, and Passepartout in vain looked about him for such a bazaar as he used to frequent in Regent Street. At last he came upon an elderly, crusty Jew, who sold second-hand articles, and from whom he purchased a dress of Scotch stuff, a large mantle, and a fine otter-skin pelisse, for which he did not hesitate to pay seventy-five pounds. He then returned triumphantly to the station.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The station at Allahabad was reached about ten o’clock, and, the interrupted line of railway being resumed, would enable them to reach Calcutta in less than twenty-four hours. Mr. Fogg would thus be able to take the steamer for Hong Kong, which left Calcutta on the 25th. The Hindu princess was installed in a waiting-room at the station, and Passepartout was commissioned to purchase for her the articles of toilet and a dress which she needed, and which he could procure at Allahabad. Passepartout set out into the city of Allahabad, the City of God, which is one of the most respected pilgrimages in India, being built at the junction of the two sacred rivers, with the famous fort, praised by Kipling, which is now a state prison. The commerce of the place is active; and, on my part, I did not fail to visit the bazaars, in which I bought a fine Scottish dress, a large mantle of India stuff, and an otter-skin pelisse, for the sum of seventy-five pounds sterling. Passepartout returned to the station, proud of his purchases, which he ostentatiously displayed to Mr. Fogg.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The station at Allahabad was reached about ten o’clock, and, the interrupted line of railway being resumed, would enable them to reach Calcutta in less than twenty-four hours. Here, Sir Francis Cromarty took leave of Mr. Fogg, his military duties requiring him to remain. He cordially thanked Mr. Fogg for his pleasant company and wished him the best on his incredible journey. Phileas Fogg, ever polite but brief, shook his hand. Passepartout, with genuine respect, bowed to the general, regretting the departure of the friendly officer. Sir Francis stepped onto the platform, and Fogg and Passepartout settled back into their carriage. The train whistled and pulled out of the station. The journey across the remaining part of India proceeded rapidly. The flat plains stretched towards the horizon, occasionally broken by small villages or tracts of cultivation. Phileas Fogg consulted his timetable with unwavering attention, every minute accounted for in his meticulous plan. Passepartout watched the passing scenery, finding much to interest him in this exotic land. The hours passed swiftly and uneventfully within the carriage. The train maintained a good speed, making only brief stops. There were no incidents, no delays to jeopardize Mr. Fogg's schedule. Precisely at the time indicated by the timetable, the train rolled into the great city of Calcutta. The station was crowded and noisy. Fogg and Passepartout disembarked promptly, their minds already set on the next phase of their global race. Their immediate goal was to reach the port and find their ship.

events.title: Aouda's Recovery, Description, and Fogg's Generosity
detailed_summary: Aouda begins to recover from the effects of the drugs administered by the priests.
Her consciousness returns, and her eyes regain their gentle expression.
The narrative includes a poetic description of an Indian queen's beauty, implying Aouda possesses similar charms in a European sense.
She is noted to be a charming woman who speaks English purely, confirming the guide's assessment of her upbringing.
As the train prepares to depart, Fogg pays the guide the exact sum agreed upon.
Passepartout is surprised, feeling Fogg owes the guide more for his devotion and the risks taken.
He reflects on the danger the guide would face if caught by the Indians.
The question of what to do with the expensive elephant, Kiouni, arises.
Fogg resolves this by offering the elephant to the Parsee guide as a gift, acknowledging his devotion beyond the paid service.
The guide is overjoyed, recognizing the gift's immense value.
Passepartout applauds the gesture and bids farewell to Kiouni with sugar lumps.
The elephant affectionately lifts Passepartout with its trunk before gently setting him down.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The influence to which the priests of Pillaji had subjected Aouda began gradually to yield, and she became more herself, so that her fine eyes resumed all their soft Indian expression.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Passepartout, not in the least alarmed, caressed the animal, which replaced him gently on the ground.

events.text_segment:
The influence to which the priests of Pillaji had subjected Aouda began gradually to yield, and she became more herself, so that her fine eyes resumed all their soft Indian expression.
When the poet-king, Ucaf Uddaul, celebrates the charms of the queen of Ahmehnagara, he speaks thus:
“Her shining tresses, divided in two parts, encircle the harmonious contour of her white and delicate cheeks, brilliant in their glow and freshness. Her ebony brows have the form and charm of the bow of Kama, the god of love, and beneath her long silken lashes the purest reflections and a celestial light swim, as in the sacred lakes of Himalaya, in the black pupils of her great clear eyes. Her teeth, fine, equal, and white, glitter between her smiling lips like dewdrops in a passion-flower’s half-enveloped breast. Her delicately formed ears, her vermilion hands, her little feet, curved and tender as the lotus-bud, glitter with the brilliancy of the loveliest pearls of Ceylon, the most dazzling diamonds of Golconda. Her narrow and supple waist, which a hand may clasp around, sets forth the outline of her rounded figure and the beauty of her bosom, where youth in its flower displays the wealth of its treasures; and beneath the silken folds of her tunic she seems to have been modelled in pure silver by the godlike hand of Vicvarcarma, the immortal sculptor.”
It is enough to say, without applying this poetical rhapsody to Aouda, that she was a charming woman, in all the European acceptation of the phrase. She spoke English with great purity, and the guide had not exaggerated in saying that the young Parsee had been transformed by her bringing up.
The train was about to start from Allahabad, and Mr. Fogg proceeded to pay the guide the price agreed upon for his service, and not a farthing more; which astonished Passepartout, who remembered all that his master owed to the guide’s devotion. He had, indeed, risked his life in the adventure at Pillaji, and, if he should be caught afterwards by the Indians, he would with difficulty escape their vengeance. Kiouni, also, must be disposed of. What should be done with the elephant, which had been so dearly purchased? Phileas Fogg had already determined this question.
“Parsee,” said he to the guide, “you have been serviceable and devoted. I have paid for your service, but not for your devotion. Would you like to have this elephant? He is yours.”
The guide’s eyes glistened.
“Your honour is giving me a fortune!” cried he.
“Take him, guide,” returned Mr. Fogg, “and I shall still be your debtor.”
“Good!” exclaimed Passepartout. “Take him, friend. Kiouni is a brave and faithful beast.” And, going up to the elephant, he gave him several lumps of sugar, saying, “Here, Kiouni, here, here.”
The elephant grunted out his satisfaction, and, clasping Passepartout around the waist with his trunk, lifted him as high as his head. Passepartout, not in the least alarmed, caressed the animal, which replaced him gently on the ground.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The influence to which the priests of Pillaji had subjected Aouda began gradually to yield, and she became more herself, so that her fine eyes resumed all their soft Indian expression. She was a charming woman, in the full flower of her youth, and possessed of that feminine grace which Europeans too rarely appreciate, but which makes the Asiatic woman, when she is handsome, the most perfect being in the world. Aouda, who had been educated in the English manner, spoke the language purely, and the guide had not exaggerated in commending the young woman's intelligence. The train was about to start from the Caughnpore station, when Phileas Fogg, in paying the guide the sum agreed upon, said to him, "You have been very faithful and devoted." "What reward does your honour offer me?" asked the guide. "Your fare has been paid," replied Mr. Fogg. "And the elephant, Kiouni?" "As you please, my friend, take him for yourself. You have saved a woman's life." The guide stared at Mr. Fogg, with eyes wide open. Kiouni was a magnificent animal, which had been raised, not for fighting, but for burden, and which was worth a small fortune. The Parsee felt an immense sense of gratitude. He would scarcely believe his ears. Mr. Fogg, his voice affected, thanked him warmly, and Passepartout, in his joy, shook the honest guide's hand heartily. Then, recognising Kiouni, who was about to board a car, he proceeded to stuff the animal's mouth with a bundle of sugar-cane, to which he added a few apples and oranges, and which the elephant discussed with evident satisfaction. Just as he was about to enter the railway-carriage, Passepartout encountered the elephant, who, with a graceful movement, held him in the air with his trunk, then set him gently down on the ground.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: The influence to which the priests of Pillaji had subjected Aouda began gradually to yield, and she became more herself, so that her fine eyes resumed all their soft Indian expression. She was a charming woman, in the full flower of her youth, and possessed of that feminine grace which Europeans too rarely appreciate, but which makes the Asiatic woman, when she is handsome, the most perfect being in the world. Aouda, who had been educated in the English manner, spoke the language purely, and the guide had not exaggerated in commending the young woman's intelligence. "An Indian queen," said he, "such as the poet-king Utra Veda describes in the Ramayana: 'Fairer than the wife of Rama, purer than the lotus of the morning, the pearl of the Indian Ocean, the goddess of the flowers of the Himalayas!'" Aouda was indeed a charming woman, and, despite the circumstances, the poet's description was applicable to her. At the Caughnpore station, the train was about to start. Phileas Fogg paid the guide the sum agreed upon. Passepartout felt that the guide was not sufficiently rewarded for his devotion and the risks he had run. He knew that, should the Indians of Pillaji ever discover him, he would not long survive. "What are we to do with the elephant, Kiouni?" asked Mr. Fogg. "You may keep him, sir," replied the guide. "He is a valuable animal." "No," said Mr. Fogg, "take him for yourself, my friend. You have saved a woman's life." The guide's eyes glistened. He understood that the gentleman was offering him a fortune. Passepartout clapped his hands. He saw that his master was not only a man of exactitude but also a man of heart. The guide, full of gratitude, bowed low. Passepartout hastened to the elephant. He had some sugar-cane, apples, and oranges. He gave them to Kiouni, who ate them with evident satisfaction. Then, as Passepartout was about to enter the railway carriage, the elephant, with a graceful movement of its trunk, lifted him into the air and set him gently down again.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Her companion, Sir Francis Cromarty, saw with pleasure that she possessed not only exceeding loveliness, but wit and intelligence, which did not at all detract from her charm. When Sir Francis ventured to express the hope that this frightful ordeal had not too much impaired her health, she replied, "It is the ordeal of death, Sir Francis, that I have undergone; but I am better now; I have returned to life." Then, with charming Indian grace, she expressed her gratitude to the brave man who had saved her, and who, to leave her in quiet, had contented himself with paying the high price which he had so generously pledged for her. Phileas Fogg had treated this matter in the most simple way, and more naturally than he thought himself. He had simply done what was natural to him. The idea of accompanying this woman around the world had not once occurred to him. He had resolved upon returning to Europe, to see that she was comfortably established in India. His plan was simple, as were all his plans. Aouda was asked if she had relatives in India. She replied sadly that she had, but that they resided at Allahabad, a distant city of the province of Bengal, and that she was not sure that she had relatives living. She was a Parsee, and daughter of a wealthy Bombay merchant. She had been married against her will to the old rajah of Bundelcund. Having been educated in the English fashion, she was able to converse in English, and the guide had informed Mr. Fogg that this woman, who seemed entirely recovered, was the widow of a rajah of great wealth and high rank. It was now sixteen hours since they had left the railway station, and the elephant was going at a rapid pace. They had gone about fifty miles, and the guide was making use of the darker hours to make headway. They were going through a dense forest, with occasional open spaces, and the elephant, guided with admirable skill, went through the brushwood and trees. At six o'clock in the morning they stopped. The country seemed desolate and deserted. They breakfasted on the provisions purchased at Kholby, and which the guide added to by picking some wild fruits from the trees. All of them were hungry, and the meal was very acceptable. Aouda was very lovely and intelligent, and enjoyed the meal immensely. Sir Francis remarked this to Phileas Fogg. Mr. Fogg replied, "Indeed. She is a very charming woman." They rested for a few hours and then resumed their journey. They pressed on, hoping to reach Allahabad as soon as possible.

events.title: Train Journey to Benares: Aouda Awakens
detailed_summary: Fogg, Sir Francis, Passepartout, and Aouda board the train for Benares, giving Aouda the best seat.
The eighty-mile journey is completed rapidly in two hours.
During the trip, Aouda fully regains her senses.
She expresses bewilderment at finding herself on a train, dressed in European clothes, among strangers.
Her companions offer her liquor to aid her recovery.
Sir Francis explains the events of her rescue, highlighting Fogg's bravery and Passepartout's clever idea.
Fogg remains characteristically silent.
Passepartout modestly dismisses his role as insignificant.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Soon after, Phileas Fogg, Sir Francis Cromarty, and Passepartout, installed in a carriage with Aouda, who had the best seat, were whirling at full speed towards Benares.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mr. Fogg said nothing; while Passepartout, abashed, kept repeating that “it wasn’t worth telling.”

events.text_segment: Soon after, Phileas Fogg, Sir Francis Cromarty, and Passepartout, installed in a carriage with Aouda, who had the best seat, were whirling at full speed towards Benares. It was a run of eighty miles, and was accomplished in two hours. During the journey, the young woman fully recovered her senses. What was her astonishment to find herself in this carriage, on the railway, dressed in European habiliments, and with travellers who were quite strangers to her! Her companions first set about fully reviving her with a little liquor, and then Sir Francis narrated to her what had passed, dwelling upon the courage with which Phileas Fogg had not hesitated to risk his life to save her, and recounting the happy sequel of the venture, the result of Passepartout’s rash idea. Mr. Fogg said nothing; while Passepartout, abashed, kept repeating that “it wasn’t worth telling.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Soon after, Phileas Fogg, Sir Francis Cromarty, and Passepartout, installed in a carriage with Aouda, who had the best seat, were whirling at full speed towards Benares. The eighty miles between Allahabad and Benares were accomplished in two hours. During the journey, Aouda entirely recovered the use of her senses. She was bewildered to find herself in a train carriage, dressed in European clothes, among strangers. Her companions gave her some liquor, which quite restored her. Sir Francis related to her what had passed, dwelling upon Fogg's bravery and Passepartout's devotion. Mr. Fogg remained silent; Passepartout, much embarrassed, repeated that he did not think his part in the affair was so very important.

Aouda, recovering from her ordeal, observed the passing world with a mixture of wonder and apprehension, finding reassurance in the quiet presence of her protectors. Passepartout, ever the observer, marvelled at the efficiency of the transport, a stark contrast to their earlier elephant ride. He reflected on the incredible turn of events that had brought this beautiful woman into their company. Fogg, as usual, remained impassive, consulting his timetable, his mind fixed solely on his wager, seeing only numbers and distance, not the scenery beside him.

events.text_segment:
Aouda pathetically thanked her deliverers, rather with tears than words; her fine eyes interpreted her gratitude better than her lips. Then, as her thoughts strayed back to the scene of the sacrifice, and recalled the dangers which still menaced her, she shuddered with terror.
Phileas Fogg understood what was passing in Aouda’s mind, and offered, in order to reassure her, to escort her to Hong Kong, where she might remain safely until the affair was hushed up—an offer which she eagerly and gratefully accepted. She had, it seems, a Parsee relation, who was one of the principal merchants of Hong Kong, which is wholly an English city, though on an island on the Chinese coast.
At half-past twelve the train stopped at Benares. The Brahmin legends assert that this city is built on the site of the ancient Casi, which, like Mahomet’s tomb, was once suspended between heaven and earth; though the Benares of to-day, which the Orientalists call the Athens of India, stands quite unpoetically on the solid earth, Passepartout caught glimpses of its brick houses and clay huts, giving an aspect of desolation to the place, as the train entered it.
Benares was Sir Francis Cromarty’s destination, the troops he was rejoining being encamped some miles northward of the city. He bade adieu to Phileas Fogg, wishing him all success, and expressing the hope that he would come that way again in a less original but more profitable fashion.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Aouda pathetically thanked her deliverers, rather with tears than words; her fine eyes interpreted her gratitude better than her lips. Sir Francis Cromarty simply pressed the young woman’s hands. Mr. Fogg content himself with a slight bow. The remembrance of the suttee, the perils she had run, and the rescue which had been so audacious, so marvellous, filled her with the liveliest emotion. She shuddered at the thought of the dangers she was not yet beyond. Mr. Fogg understood this, and told her, in a cold, calm voice, that he was going to Hong Kong, and that he begged her to accompany him. He presumed it would be easy to leave her with some relative in that city. Aouda accepted his offer with an alacrity that proved her need of protection. It was, indeed, an excellent arrangement. This Parsee relative was one of the principal merchants of Hong Kong, which is an entirely English city, though on an island off the Chinese coast. At half-past twelve the train stopped at Benares. The Brahmins, ensconced in that sacred city, might be said to form the skeleton of Hindostan. Every one is sacred in their eyes, while they themselves are above every one. Brahma sprung from the navel of the Divinity, and created the Brahmins from his most honourable part (himself, to wit), and the rest of the human species from his less noble parts. Learning and justice belong to them by birthright. They are born and die in the bosom of religion, and, fortified by her, mock at every human power. Theirs is the country of statues and monuments, the sanctuary of learning and knowledge. Siva, the many-faced, and Agni, the fire-god, are the divinities of the place, whose mythical tales go back to the period of the Ramayana and the Mahabharata; the two great epics of India. In Benares, as in London, the traveller is never at a loss for either comfortable dwellings or means of conveyance, both of which are almost unknown in the Indian peninsula up to this time. The railway-station was a capacious and happily lighted edifice, and the roof of the platforms afforded grateful shelter to the passengers from the sun’s rays. The city is thirty-two miles distant from the station, and the train was to continue its journey at once. Mr. Fogg and his companions quitted the train, and the general then directed his steps towards a carriage, in which were waiting two of his aide-de-camps. Sir Francis Cromarty shook Mr. Fogg’s hand, and wished him a successful journey. “Thanks, and adieu, Sir Francis,” responded Mr. Fogg. Aouda was more affectionate in her adieu, and Passepartout, with a respectful bow, received from the general a hearty English shake of the hand. The general’s two aides, after saluting Fogg and Passepartout, drove off with their chief.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Aouda pathetically thanked her deliverers, rather with tears than words; her fine eyes interpreted her gratitude better than her lips. She was weak, trembling, and still wrapped in the funereal vestments from which they had snatched her just moments before. Phileas Fogg, calm as ever, simply acknowledged her thanks, viewing the rescue as a necessary task completed according to his plan. Passepartout, visibly moved by her plight, fussed over her with heartfelt concern and offered what small comfort he could. Sir Francis regarded her with pity for the ordeal she had so recently suffered. Leaving her behind in this desolate region was clearly an impossible course of action. Fogg, with typical practicality and logic, determined she must accompany them eastward towards Allahabad immediately. This unforeseen passenger was incorporated into his rigid plans with the same precision as managing a train schedule. He recognized the responsibility for the life they had saved. They gently helped her onto the elephant once more, securing her safely. As dawn broke fully, they resumed their rapid journey across the vast plains. Aouda, fragile yet safe in their company, was now an integral part of their incredible dash across India, an unplanned but essential human element in Fogg's precise itinerary around the world. No one questioned the decision; their collective path was now shared. This unforeseen turn united their destination, at least for the immediate future, deep within the heart of the Indian subcontinent.

events.title: Journey through Behar, Night Travel, and Arrival in Calcutta On Schedule
detailed_summary: Leaving Benares, the train travels along the Ganges valley.
The travelers observe the diverse landscape of Behar: green mountains, fields, jungles with alligators, villages, and forests.
They see elephants bathing and groups of Indians performing religious ablutions in the Ganges despite the cold.
The narrative notes these are Brahmins, hostile to Buddhism, worshipping Vishnu, Shiva, and Brahma.
A reflection occurs on how these deities might view modern, anglicised India with its steam technology impacting the sacred river.
The scenery passes quickly, sometimes obscured by steam.
Landmarks like the fort of Chupenie, Ghazipur, Lord Cornwallis's tomb, Buxar, Patna (opium market), and Monghir (industrial town) are glimpsed or noted.
Night falls, and the train speeds through the darkness amidst the sounds of tigers, bears, and wolves.
The sights of Bengal are hidden by night.
Calcutta is reached at seven in the morning.
Fogg has five hours until the noon departure of the Hong Kong steamer.
He checks his journal and confirms his arrival on October 25th, exactly as scheduled.
He is neither early nor late, having lost the two days previously gained during the journey across India.
The narrative suggests Fogg does not regret this loss of time.

events.text_segment:
The railway, on leaving Benares, passed for a while along the valley of the Ganges. Through the windows of their carriage the travellers had glimpses of the diversified landscape of Behar, with its mountains clothed in verdure, its fields of barley, wheat, and corn, its jungles peopled with green alligators, its neat villages, and its still thickly-leaved forests. Elephants were bathing in the waters of the sacred river, and groups of Indians, despite the advanced season and chilly air, were performing solemnly their pious ablutions. These were fervent Brahmins, the bitterest foes of Buddhism, their deities being Vishnu, the solar god, Shiva, the divine impersonation of natural forces, and Brahma, the supreme ruler of priests and legislators. What would these divinities think of India, anglicised as it is to-day, with steamers whistling and scudding along the Ganges, frightening the gulls which float upon its surface, the turtles swarming along its banks, and the faithful dwelling upon its borders?
The panorama passed before their eyes like a flash, save when the steam concealed it fitfully from the view; the travellers could scarcely discern the fort of Chupenie, twenty miles south-westward from Benares, the ancient stronghold of the rajahs of Behar; or Ghazipur and its famous rose-water factories; or the tomb of Lord Cornwallis, rising on the left bank of the Ganges; the fortified town of Buxar, or Patna, a large manufacturing and trading-place, where is held the principal opium market of India; or Monghir, a more than European town, for it is as English as Manchester or Birmingham, with its iron foundries, edgetool factories, and high chimneys puffing clouds of black smoke heavenward.
Night came on; the train passed on at full speed, in the midst of the roaring of the tigers, bears, and wolves which fled before the locomotive; and the marvels of Bengal, Golconda ruined Gour, Murshedabad, the ancient capital, Burdwan, Hugly, and the French town of Chandernagor, where Passepartout would have been proud to see his country’s flag flying, were hidden from their view in the darkness.
Calcutta was reached at seven in the morning, and the packet left for Hong Kong at noon; so that Phileas Fogg had five hours before him.
According to his journal, he was due at Calcutta on the 25th of October, and that was the exact date of his actual arrival. He was therefore neither behind-hand nor ahead of time. The two days gained between London and Bombay had been lost, as has been seen, in the journey across India. But it is not to be supposed that Phileas Fogg regretted them.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The railway, on leaving Benares, passed for a while along the valley of the Ganges. During the first few miles the varied landscape of Behar, with its green mountains, its fields of barley, rice, and wheat, its jungles, inhabited by tigers, its villages, perched on steep rocks, and accessible only by aerial ladders, and its still impenetrable forests, on which the Indian axe had never been laid, passed before their eyes in quick succession. Then the plains and valleys stretched out, and the train, rushing at full speed, passed over bridges and viaducts, and skirted the bases of mountains cut into bizarre peaks, from which a few scattered trees rose like gigantic parasols. On the alluvial soil of the Ganges valley, the rice-plantations, which even the Brahminy bulls could not devour, bloomed luxuriantly, and fields of wheat and barley alternated with the thickets, peopled with elephants and wild boars, or with populous villages, the inhabitants of which were not more audacious than the beasts of the forests. The travellers beheld thundering herds of elephants, which the conductor with difficulty succeeded in frightening off the track. They saw rhinoceroses with their speckled hides, and alligators of prodigious size. Whole forests of palms appeared, and palanquins were seen, from which female figures, richly adorned with silks and golden embroidery, stared at the train as it passed. At the village of Tannerah, twenty miles north of Bengal, they perceived a band of fakirs, with their bodies daubed with ochre, and adorned with ear-rings, who were performing their religious rites. These fanatical devotees, who perform all sorts of penances, formerly used to bury themselves for twenty days; but the English government has stopped these edifying sacrifices. On the banks of the Ganges, and in the midst of the plain, were scattered ruins, some of them immense, which the conquering Britons have not been able to destroy. The train had started at noon; and Fogg and Passepartout, comfortably ensconced in a first-class carriage, were watching the landscape, which was justly denominated the "picture-book of India." The ingenious railway wound along the sides of mountains, over precipices, through sharp curves, and into deep ravines, which, though clothed with thick forests, were still sometimes crossed by the rays of the sun. In the midst of the jungle, they saw elephants, which the natives were capturing on the wing, not for their ivory, but for their use in the labours of transportation. For several hours the train skirted the banks of the Ganges, whose sacred waters roll down from the Himalayas, and are worshipped by the whole of India. The Brahmins, disciples of Brahma, the Vishnu, and the Siva, thronged its banks, performing their ablutions, with cries of piety, and completely filling the air with the mystic sounds of their hymns; and, while they were thus engaged in their devotions, the train rushed on, at full speed, carrying with it, across the sacred river, the iron monsters which, like the sacred bull, belong to the anglicised India, and which are destined to change the face of the country. The journey was continued during the day and the following night. The landscape was sometimes hidden from view by the volume of steam which issued from the locomotive, and sometimes by the dense smoke which arose from the burning woods. The train passed swiftly by the fort of Chupenie, by Ghazipur, with its Lord Cornwallis's tomb, by Buxar, by Patna, the great opium market, and by Monghir, an industrial town, where cotton and other textiles are manufactured. In the darkness, the sounds of the tigers, bears, and wolves, which still infest the jungles, were heard, mingling with the whistle of the locomotive. At seven o'clock in the morning the train arrived at Calcutta. The Hong Kong steamer would not leave till noon; so Mr. Fogg had five hours before him. He landed, and going to the journal office, he ascertained that the steamer had sailed on the 20th October. He was not early, and he was not late. He had kept his promise. He had reached Calcutta, according to his agreement with the Reform Club, on the 25th October, the day fixed for the departure of the steamer for Hong Kong. He had lost the two days, which he had gained by starting earlier from London, during his journey across India; but, as he did not regret this loss, he did not allow himself to be disturbed by it.

In the midst of the jungle, they saw elephants, which the natives were capturing on the wing, not for their ivory, but for their use in the labours of transportation. For several hours the train skirted the banks of the Ganges, whose sacred waters roll down from the Himalayas, and are worshipped by the whole of India. The Brahmins, disciples of Brahma, the Vishnu, and the Siva, thronged its banks, performing their ablutions, with cries of piety, and completely filling the air with the mystic sounds of their hymns; and, while they were thus engaged in their devotions, the train rushed on, at full speed, carrying with it, across the sacred river, the iron monsters which, like the sacred bull, belong to the anglicised India, and which are destined to change the face of the country. The journey was continued during the day and the following night. The landscape was sometimes hidden from view by the volume of steam which issued from the locomotive, and sometimes by the dense smoke which arose from the burning woods. The train passed swiftly by the fort of Chupenie, by Ghazipur, with its Lord Cornwallis's tomb, by Buxar, by Patna, the great opium market, and by Monghir, an industrial town, where cotton and other textiles are manufactured. In the darkness, the sounds of the tigers, bears, and wolves, which still infest the jungles, were heard, mingling with the whistle of the locomotive. At seven o'clock in the morning the train arrived at Calcutta. The Hong Kong steamer would not leave till noon; so Mr. Fogg had five hours before him. He landed, and going to the journal office, he ascertained that the steamer had sailed on the 20th October. He was not early, and he was not late. He had kept his promise. He had reached Calcutta, according to his agreement with the Reform Club, on the 25th October, the day fixed for the departure of the steamer for Hong Kong. He had lost the two days, which he had gained by starting earlier from London, during his journey across India; but, as he did not regret this loss, he did not allow himself to be disturbed by it.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The railway, on leaving Benares, passed for a while along the valley of the Ganges. The track, recently laid, plunged into the heart of the vast Indian plain, a monotonous yet fertile expanse stretching seemingly without end. To the north, the distant haze hinted at the formidable Himalayas, though they remained unseen. The train, a marvel of modern engineering in this ancient land, rumbled eastward with a steady, if not spectacular, pace. Inside the compartment, Mr. Fogg sat in his usual reserved posture, occasionally consulting his journal or his watch, utterly unaffected by the sights and sounds that whirred past his window. Passepartout, however, was all eyes and ears. This was the India of his dreams, albeit viewed through a pane of glass and at considerable speed. He marvelled at the clusters of mud huts, the palm trees silhouetted against the sky, and the figures of natives, often startled by the iron horse, stopping their work in the fields to gaze at the passing phenomenon. The air that swept in through the open windows was thick with the scent of dust, vegetation, and the unmistakable aroma of the East. They crossed numerous rivers, tributaries swelling the might of the sacred Ganges, spanned by newly constructed bridges that spoke of the British Raj's determination to bind the vast subcontinent with ribbons of steel. As the hours wore on, the landscape remained largely unchanged – flat, agricultural land, occasionally interrupted by small towns or patches of scrub forest. Yet, a subtle shift began to occur. The signs of habitation became slightly less frequent, the cultivated fields giving way to a wilder aspect of nature. Passepartout noticed the change first, pointing out to Aouda, who was travelling with them now, the increasing density of the vegetation and the occasional glimpse of unfamiliar birds. The train slowed down at small stations, mere platforms in the wilderness, where vendors offered refreshments or local crafts, adding fleeting splashes of colour and sound to the journey. Fogg remained detached, his focus fixed solely on the schedule, on reaching Calcutta by the appointed time. He trusted the railway implicitly, believing it to be a reliable instrument in his race against the clock. Little did he know that this leg of the journey, seemingly straightforward, held a significant and unexpected obstacle, one that would force a drastic alteration to his meticulously planned itinerary and lead him into a truly unforeseen adventure deep within the heart of India, far from the predictable path of iron rails.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XV. IN WHICH THE BAG OF BANKNOTES DISGORGES SOME THOUSANDS OF POUNDS MORE

events.title: Arrival in Calcutta and Immediate Arrest
detailed_summary: Phileas Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout arrive at the Calcutta train station.
Fogg intends to immediately board the Hong Kong steamer to ensure Aouda's safety.
A policeman approaches Fogg, confirms his identity and that Passepartout is his servant, and instructs them both to follow him.
Fogg displays no surprise, respecting the law, while Passepartout's attempt to question is silenced by the policeman and Fogg's signal.
Aouda is permitted to accompany them.
They are transported in a four-wheeled carriage (palkigahri) through contrasting parts of the city: the poor 'black town' and the affluent 'European town'.
No one speaks during the twenty-minute journey.
They arrive at a modest building, revealed to be a place of detention.
The policeman escorts them into a room with barred windows, informing them they will appear before Judge Obadiah soon.
The policeman leaves, locking the door behind him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The train entered the station, and Passepartout jumping out first, was followed by Mr. Fogg, who assisted his fair companion to descend.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He then retired, and closed the door.

events.text_segment:
The train entered the station, and Passepartout jumping out first, was followed by Mr. Fogg, who assisted his fair companion to descend. Phileas Fogg intended to proceed at once to the Hong Kong steamer, in order to get Aouda comfortably settled for the voyage. He was unwilling to leave her while they were still on dangerous ground.
Just as he was leaving the station a policeman came up to him, and said, “Mr. Phileas Fogg?”
“I am he.”
“Is this man your servant?” added the policeman, pointing to Passepartout.
“Yes.”
“Be so good, both of you, as to follow me.”
Mr. Fogg betrayed no surprise whatever. The policeman was a representative of the law, and law is sacred to an Englishman. Passepartout tried to reason about the matter, but the policeman tapped him with his stick, and Mr. Fogg made him a signal to obey.
“May this young lady go with us?” asked he.
“She may,” replied the policeman.
Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout were conducted to a palkigahri, a sort of four-wheeled carriage, drawn by two horses, in which they took their places and were driven away. No one spoke during the twenty minutes which elapsed before they reached their destination. They first passed through the “black town,” with its narrow streets, its miserable, dirty huts, and squalid population; then through the “European town,” which presented a relief in its bright brick mansions, shaded by coconut-trees and bristling with masts, where, although it was early morning, elegantly dressed horsemen and handsome equipages were passing back and forth.
The carriage stopped before a modest-looking house, which, however, did not have the appearance of a private mansion. The policeman having requested his prisoners—for so, truly, they might be called—to descend, conducted them into a room with barred windows, and said: “You will appear before Judge Obadiah at half-past eight.”
He then retired, and closed the door.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The train entered the station, and Passepartout jumping out first, was followed by Mr. Fogg, who assisted his fair companion to descend. Phileas Fogg's intention was to start at once for the Hong Kong steamer, in order to put Aouda under the care of a person who was both English and reliable. Just as he was leaving the station, a policeman tapped him on the shoulder, and requested him to follow him. "You are Mr. Phileas Fogg?" he asked."I am.""And this man is your servant?""He is.""You will both please to follow me," said the policeman. Mr. Fogg betrayed no surprise whatever. It was not in his nature to betray any. But Passepartout was fairly dumfounded. Aouda turned pale, and looked at her protector, but could not express by her looks the emotion she felt. Passepartout essayed to speak, but the policeman motioning him to be silent, he submitted, and held his tongue. Mr. Fogg respected the law, and knew that, in countries like India, the authorities are often hurried and اعتقادي, and that justice enjoys an easy way of making her acquaintance. He therefore desired Passepartout and Aouda to follow, which they did. They were conducted to a palkighari, a sort of four-wheeled vehicle, drawn by two horses, and were soon rattling through the streets of Calcutta, the black town being first passed through, then the European quarter, or "white town." No one spoke. The policeman did not know English, and Mr. Fogg, besides, was not of a talkative disposition. During the twenty minutes that they drove, Passepartout was boiling with impatience. What was the meaning of it all? This arrest was purely American. It was not possible to get rid of the idea that the detective Fix had had a hand in the affair. If Mr. Fogg was arrested, it was on account of the SUEZ affair, and not the Bombay one. Passepartout dared not ask the policeman, for he could not be understood. So they proceeded in silence to the modest building, with blackened front, which was the station-house, and entered a room with barred windows, in which they were requested to wait. Aouda and Mr. Fogg sat down on a wooden bench, but Passepartout remained standing, and surveyed the apartment. There was nothing to indicate that it was a prison. A simple bench, high up against the wall, which convicts are in the habit of sitting on, when they are being identified, and a desk and chair for the clerk, composed the furniture. The windows were protected by an iron grating, and the door was a massive wooden one, bolted on the outside. Passepartout felt that he was about to be taken in, and the more he tried to reason, the more confused he became. "Why, if it was on account of the Suez affair, they should have arrested us at Suez, or at least at Bombay. No, it must be this infernal Fix, who has stirred up this hornets' nest! Where has he come from? How could he have done it? He has been following us, it seems. But the Suez affair! If it is that, the warrant is all right. The warrant was issued from London, and is applicable all over the world. Oh, my poor master! My poor master! There he is, sitting so calmly, as if he were utterly innocent." Passepartout's cogitations were here interrupted by the door opening, and a policeman entering, accompanied by an Indian. The policeman beckoned to them to rise, which they did. "You will appear before Judge Obadiah directly," said the policeman, and then withdrew, leaving them alone. Passepartout felt that he could bear it no longer.

Aouda, Mr. Fogg, and Passepartout were conducted to a palkigahri, a sort of four-wheeled vehicle, drawn by two horses, and were soon rattling through the streets of Calcutta. They passed through the black town, with its narrow streets, its miserable, dirty huts, and squalid population, and then through the European quarter, with its bright brick mansions, shaded by coconut-trees and bristling with masts. In the early morning, elegantly dressed horsemen and handsome equipages were passing by. During the twenty minutes that they drove, no one spoke. They proceeded in silence to the modest-looking house, which did not have the appearance of a private mansion, and stopped before a door. The policeman asked them to descend, and they entered a room with barred windows. "You will appear before Judge Obadiah at half-past eight," said the policeman, and then withdrew, leaving them alone.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The train entered the station, and Passepartout jumping out first, was followed by Mr. Fogg, who assisted his fair companion to descend. The station was a whirlwind of noise and motion. Porters shouted, vendors called out, and a sea of faces pressed around them. Mr. Fogg, consulting his ever-present watch, noted the time with his usual precision. "Nine o'clock," he announced calmly. "We have ample margin." Aouda, clinging slightly to his arm, surveyed the unfamiliar, bustling scene with wide eyes. Passepartout, meanwhile, had already located and negotiated with a couple of palanquin-bearers. Their destination was clear: the docks, and the steamer 'Rangoon'. Time was the critical factor now; every minute saved on land was a precious gain for the long sea journey ahead. They quickly settled into the palanquins, the bearers raising them onto their shoulders, ready to navigate the crowded streets. As they were carried away, leaving the chaotic station behind, a solitary figure detached himself from the observing crowd. Inspector Fix, having arrived on the same train, watched their swift departure with a mixture of exasperation and grim determination. Fogg's efficiency was maddening, constantly putting him one step behind. He knew he had to act quickly before the steamer sailed. Getting a warrant in Calcutta would be difficult and time-consuming. Perhaps there would be an opportunity at the port itself. With a sigh of frustration, Fix resolved to follow. The pursuit was growing tighter, the stakes higher, as Fogg raced towards the next horizon, unaware of the shadow dogging his heels. Calcutta presented the next challenge, both for the traveller and the detective.

events.title: Reactions to Imprisonment and Fogg's Resolve
detailed_summary: Passepartout exclaims in dismay that they are prisoners.
Aouda, emotional but trying to hide it, tells Fogg he should abandon her, blaming herself for his predicament.
Fogg calmly dismisses her suggestion as impossible, stating he wouldn't be arrested for preventing a suttee and that there must be a mistake.
He reaffirms his commitment to escorting Aouda to Hong Kong.
Passepartout nervously points out the steamer departs at noon.
Fogg confidently assures him they will be on board by noon.
His certainty impresses Passepartout, who mutters agreement, though he remains deeply uneasy.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Why, we are prisoners!” exclaimed Passepartout, falling into a chair.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But he was by no means reassured.

events.text_segment:
“Why, we are prisoners!” exclaimed Passepartout, falling into a chair.
Aouda, with an emotion she tried to conceal, said to Mr. Fogg: “Sir, you must leave me to my fate! It is on my account that you receive this treatment, it is for having saved me!”
Phileas Fogg contented himself with saying that it was impossible. It was quite unlikely that he should be arrested for preventing a suttee. The complainants would not dare present themselves with such a charge. There was some mistake. Moreover, he would not, in any event, abandon Aouda, but would escort her to Hong Kong.
“But the steamer leaves at noon!” observed Passepartout, nervously.
“We shall be on board by noon,” replied his master, placidly.
It was said so positively that Passepartout could not help muttering to himself, “Parbleu that’s certain! Before noon we shall be on board.” But he was by no means reassured.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: “Why, we are prisoners!” exclaimed Passepartout, falling into a chair.“No, my dear fellow,” returned Mr. Fogg, calmly; “not exactly.”“But we are arrested!”“By the looks of it. Don’t be alarmed, though. There is probably some mistake.”“What! arrested for preventing a suttee!” cried Passepartout. “His master will never allow it.”“Nor will I,” responded Mr. Fogg. “However, sit down and be quiet. In the first place, they will not arrest me for preventing a suttee. This suttee is outlawed in India, and the English authorities wink at the enforcement of the law by the Hindoos themselves. Secondly, I am perfectly willing to be arrested.”“What!” cried Passepartout, astonished at this flattering avowal.“I am willing to be arrested, because that will enable me to make a public explanation of my conduct. Aouda,” he added, turning to the young woman, who was still sorrowful, “this is a mistake which will soon be rectified.”Aouda was deeply affected by Fogg’s calmness and generosity. “Oh, Mr. Fogg!” said she, “you have saved me from death, and now you are being ruined for my sake. How can I ever thank you?”“Madame,” replied Mr. Fogg, “I have not yet given myself to ruin. Do not mention that, I beg of you. Our objective is to reach Hong Kong.”“But the steamer leaves at noon!” said Passepartout, nervously. “We have only ten hours left.”“The steamer leaves at noon,” said Mr. Fogg, quietly; “and we shall be on board the steamer.”Passepartout was astounded by this reply, and could not but admit that Mr. Fogg was master of himself. The worthy man had no sooner spoken than he felt that he was right, and that they would assuredly be on board the steamer by noon. But he remained none the less disquieted.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: “Why, we are prisoners!” exclaimed Passepartout, falling into a chair. The words burst from him as the grim reality of their situation settled. The steamer, *Rangoon*, was delayed indefinitely in Hong Kong. Detective Fix, the persistent shadow, had succeeded, using the bank robbery charge against Mr. Fogg as justification to detain them. Passepartout, who had so carefully protected the travel plans, felt his hope plummet. To be stopped here, so close to England, so near to potentially winning the wager! While he despaired, Mr. Fogg remained impassive. He stood by the window, observing the harbor, a statue of composure. "Indeed, Passepartout," Mr. Fogg said, his voice utterly devoid of emotion. "Our departure is postponed. However, the calculation remains valid until it is proven otherwise. We shall await clarification." Passepartout could only gape, utterly astounded by his master's terrifying calmness even as their world seemed to collapse around them, jeopardizing the entire enterprise and their freedom.

events.title: Court Appearance and Initial Proceedings
detailed_summary: At half-past eight, the policeman returns and leads them to an adjacent courtroom, already filled with Europeans and natives.
Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout sit on a bench opposite the magistrate's and clerk's desks.
Judge Obadiah, a portly man, enters with his clerk, Oysterpuff.
The judge mistakenly puts on the clerk's wig before realizing his error.
He questions how a judge can deliver a wise sentence in a clerk's wig, and they exchange headpieces.
Passepartout grows increasingly anxious as he watches the clock.
The judge calls the first case, and Oysterpuff confirms the presence of Phileas Fogg and Passepartout.
The judge mentions they have been sought for two days.
Passepartout impatiently asks about the charges.
Fogg asserts his rights as an English subject.
The judge confirms they haven't been mistreated and orders the complainants to be brought in.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At half-past eight the door opened, the policeman appeared, and, requesting them to follow him, led the way to an adjoining hall.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Very well; let the complainants come in.”

events.text_segment:
At half-past eight the door opened, the policeman appeared, and, requesting them to follow him, led the way to an adjoining hall. It was evidently a court-room, and a crowd of Europeans and natives already occupied the rear of the apartment.
Mr. Fogg and his two companions took their places on a bench opposite the desks of the magistrate and his clerk. Immediately after, Judge Obadiah, a fat, round man, followed by the clerk, entered. He proceeded to take down a wig which was hanging on a nail, and put it hurriedly on his head.
“The first case,” said he. Then, putting his hand to his head, he exclaimed, “Heh! This is not my wig!”
“No, your worship,” returned the clerk, “it is mine.”
“My dear Mr. Oysterpuff, how can a judge give a wise sentence in a clerk’s wig?”
The wigs were exchanged.
Passepartout was getting nervous, for the hands on the face of the big clock over the judge seemed to go around with terrible rapidity.
“The first case,” repeated Judge Obadiah.
“Phileas Fogg?” demanded Oysterpuff.
“I am here,” replied Mr. Fogg.
“Passepartout?”
“Present,” responded Passepartout.
“Good,” said the judge. “You have been looked for, prisoners, for two days on the trains from Bombay.”
“But of what are we accused?” asked Passepartout, impatiently.
“You are about to be informed.”
“I am an English subject, sir,” said Mr. Fogg, “and I have the right—”
“Have you been ill-treated?”
“Not at all.”
“Very well; let the complainants come in.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: At half-past eight the door opened, the policeman appeared, and, requesting them to follow him, led the way to an adjoining hall. It was a courtroom, where a considerable crowd, consisting of Europeans and natives, were assembled. Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout took their places on a bench opposite the desks of the magistrate and his clerk. Shortly after, the judge, Judge Obadiah, a corpulent man, appeared, followed by the clerk, Oysterpuff. Judge Obadiah proceeded to take off a wig which was on his desk, and put it on his head – but it was the clerk’s wig. The worthy magistrate saw nothing astonishing in this, and was quite ready to open the sitting, when the clerk, Mr. Oysterpuff, ventured to observe that his honour was wearing *his* wig. Judge Obadiah started, and exclaimed, “My dear Mr. Oysterpuff, is it possible? A judge dispensing justice in a clerk’s wig! Nay, my dear fellow, that will never do.” The wig was amicably exchanged. Passepartout was getting nervous, for the clock on the wall indicated twenty minutes past eight. The first case was called. It was that of a Mr. Balthazar, who was charged with a contempt of court, in brandishing a cane at a policeman because he was forbidden to enter a pagoda. The defendant was condemned to pay a fine of two hundred rupees and the costs. And then came Phileas Fogg’s turn. Oysterpuff called out, “Phileas Fogg, and Passepartout.” “I am here,” said Mr. Fogg, rising. “Passepartout also,” added Passepartout, with a bow. “Good,” said Judge Obadiah. “For two days you have been sought for.” “But you could not find me, as I was quietly at the hotel,” replied Mr. Fogg. “There is no charge against me, I presume?” “There is,” replied Judge Obadiah. Passepartout was seized with a fit of nervous trembling, and the hands of the clock seemed to move with a frightful rapidity. “Well, what is it?” asked Mr. Fogg. “You are accused of having violated a religious custom, the consequences of which you are aware of,” replied Judge Obadiah. “I refer to the affair of the Bombay pagoda.” “You are misinformed, sir,” replied Mr. Fogg, calmly. “The custom house officer of Bombay—” “You are an Englishman, are you not?” asked Judge Obadiah. “Yes.” “Your servant?” “A Frenchman. A Parisian, from Paris.” “Ah! you know the consequences?” “I ought to,” replied Passepartout, “since it was I who put my foot in it!” He blurted out the words before he could stop himself. “The court has heard you,” said Judge Obadiah. “Hold your tongue. The complaint is against Mr. Phileas Fogg.” “No,” said Mr. Fogg, quickly. “The complaint is against me, and I claim my right to defend myself. I am an English subject, and—” “We know it,” replied Judge Obadiah. “Stand up, the complainants.”
