A serious dog, my friend,” answered Fix. “
Stop a bit and listen. ”
He lowered his voice and said, “
Don't you see that you have to do with a detective?”
Passepartout stared at him, winked his eye, and said, smiling: “
Mr. Fix, you are making fun of me.”
“
Of you! Not at all. Listen to me. ”
“
Ah, I see! You want to pump me.”
“
Exactly. ”
“
I may say, my friend, that you have fallen upon a dry pump. It would have been as well to have saved yourself the trouble. ”
“
Come, come, Fix was getting impatient. “
Let us not beat about the bush. Do you understand me? ”
“
I am perfectly sure I do. ”
“
And you know what I mean?”
“
Perfectly. ”
“
Then don't make a face as if you didn't. ”
“
But we are countrymen,” said Passepartout; “we must understand each other. ”
“
As you say, let us be frank with each other,” replied Fix. “
Do you know who Mr. Fogg is?”
“
I do, perfectly. ”
“
And do you know what his occupation is?”
“
That of a gentleman who amuses himself by going around the world. ”
This time Fix did not frown. He preserved his imperturbable expression, and resumed: “
Do you think Mr. Fogg is doing this merely to please himself?”
“
I am sure of it.”
“
Buddy, you are mistaken. ”
“
Why so? Is he not a gentleman of leisure? ”
“
No. ”
“
A traveller, then?”
“
No. ”
“
Mr. Fix, I'm sure I don't know what you mean! ”
“
He's a criminal, my boy. ”
Passepartout was seized with an irresistible desire to shout with all his might. A criminal! A gentleman just like his master—so noble, so open-hearted, so generous, who was carrying out his whim of travelling around the world, was a criminal! It was a good joke. And he replied to Fix, with a most serious air, and in his countryman's argot: “
You don't mean it!”
“
A criminal,” repeated Fix. “
The police have issued a warrant for his arrest, and I have him in charge. ”
“
The police!” exclaimed Passepartout; “a warrant! You have him in charge! What an idea! Mr. Fogg a brigand, who is carrying me around the world!”
“
A brigand who has stolen fifty-five thousand pounds from the Bank of England. ”
“
Impossible!” cried Passepartout, rising to his feet. “
Our wager!”
“
I know it,” replied Fix; “the wager of twenty thousand pounds. But he doesn't care for that. ”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: They ordered two bottles of port, to which the Frenchman did ample justice, whilst Fix observed him with close attention. Passepartout, recovering from his sea-sickness and perhaps emboldened by the drink, became quite talkative. He recounted tales of his various former employments, from itinerant singer to circus rider, all with a cheerful disregard for sequence or coherence. Phileas Fogg listened with his usual impassive demeanour. Fix, meanwhile, paid less heed to the anecdotes than to the narrator himself. He scrutinised Passepartout's face, his gestures, the very enthusiasm with which he described his past life. Was this the face of a hardened criminal's accomplice? The detective had seen many rogues, but none possessed such a frank, almost innocent air. Yet, this very openness could be a masterful disguise. Could Fogg, the meticulously precise gentleman, have chosen such a seemingly guileless companion to deflect suspicion? Fix pondered this paradox. He was convinced of Fogg's guilt; the sudden departure, the immense sum risked, the very precision of his itinerary screamed of a fugitive. But Passepartout? He seemed genuinely delighted by the journey, captivated by the novelty of each place, astonished by the speed. This did not fit the profile of a confederate aware of the stakes. Perhaps, Fix mused, Passepartout was merely a dupe, an unwitting pawn in Fogg's audacious plan. The thought was unsettling. He needed to be certain, to find the irrefutable link. The port was finished, the conversation winding down, but Fix's observation had yielded no concrete proof, only deepening his perplexity regarding the valet's true role in the affair that had shaken the Bank of England. He decided to keep a closer watch on the Frenchman than ever before.

events.title: The True Revelation: Fix's Identity and Fogg's Accusation
detailed_summary: Fix corrects Passepartout, stating the sum is actually fifty-five thousand pounds.
Passepartout is stunned, first interpreting this as an incredibly high wager by Fogg, which makes him feel even more urgency to leave.
Fix pushes Passepartout back into his chair, clarifying the £55,000 is the amount stolen, and offers Passepartout £500 of his potential £2,000 reward for helping detain Fogg.
Passepartout is horrified, accusing Fix (still perceived as a Reform Club agent) of resorting to dishonorable tactics and obstacles against his master.
He calls it shameful trickery, comparing it to robbing Fogg directly.
Fix ambiguously confirms that taking the money is their intention.
Passepartout, becoming more agitated under the influence of alcohol, decries it as a conspiracy by supposed gentlemen.
Fix appears puzzled by Passepartout's reaction.
Passepartout staunchly defends Fogg's honor, insisting he is competing fairly.
Fix directly asks Passepartout who he believes him to be.
Passepartout repeats his conviction that Fix is an agent hired by Reform Club members to disrupt the journey, admitting he'd figured this out earlier but kept it from Fogg.
Fix ascertains that Fogg is unaware of Fix's pursuit.
The detective realizes Passepartout's mistaken belief is genuine, complicating his plan but also confirming Passepartout isn't Fogg's accomplice.
Fix reasons that since Passepartout is innocent, he might be convinced to cooperate.
Feeling pressured for time, Fix decides to reveal his true identity.
He explicitly states he is not working for the Reform Club.
Passepartout reacts with playful disbelief.
Fix declares he is a police detective from London.
Passepartout is skeptical.
Fix produces his official commission as proof, rendering Passepartout speechless with astonishment.
Fix explains that Fogg's wager is a facade to cover his escape, deceiving both Passepartout and the Reform Club.
He reveals the Bank of England robbery of £55,000 occurred on September 28th.
Fix presents the official description of the robber, asserting it is an exact match for Phileas Fogg.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Twenty thousand pounds.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Here is his description; it answers exactly to that of Mr. Phileas Fogg.”

events.text_segment:
“Twenty thousand pounds.”
“Fifty-five thousand!” answered Fix, pressing his companion’s hand.
“What!” cried the Frenchman. “Has Monsieur Fogg dared—fifty-five thousand pounds! Well, there’s all the more reason for not losing an instant,” he continued, getting up hastily.
Fix pushed Passepartout back in his chair, and resumed: “Fifty-five thousand pounds; and if I succeed, I get two thousand pounds. If you’ll help me, I’ll let you have five hundred of them.”
“Help you?” cried Passepartout, whose eyes were standing wide open.
“Yes; help me keep Mr. Fogg here for two or three days.”
“Why, what are you saying? Those gentlemen are not satisfied with following my master and suspecting his honour, but they must try to put obstacles in his way! I blush for them!”
“What do you mean?”
“I mean that it is a piece of shameful trickery. They might as well waylay Mr. Fogg and put his money in their pockets!”
“That’s just what we count on doing.”
“It’s a conspiracy, then,” cried Passepartout, who became more and more excited as the liquor mounted in his head, for he drank without perceiving it. “A real conspiracy! And gentlemen, too. Bah!”
Fix began to be puzzled.
“Members of the Reform Club!” continued Passepartout. “You must know, Monsieur Fix, that my master is an honest man, and that, when he makes a wager, he tries to win it fairly!”
“But who do you think I am?” asked Fix, looking at him intently.
“Parbleu! An agent of the members of the Reform Club, sent out here to interrupt my master’s journey. But, though I found you out some time ago, I’ve taken good care to say nothing about it to Mr. Fogg.”
“He knows nothing, then?”
“Nothing,” replied Passepartout, again emptying his glass.
The detective passed his hand across his forehead, hesitating before he spoke again. What should he do? Passepartout’s mistake seemed sincere, but it made his design more difficult. It was evident that the servant was not the master’s accomplice, as Fix had been inclined to suspect.
“Well,” said the detective to himself, “as he is not an accomplice, he will help me.”
He had no time to lose: Fogg must be detained at Hong Kong, so he resolved to make a clean breast of it.
“Listen to me,” said Fix abruptly. “I am not, as you think, an agent of the members of the Reform Club—”
“Bah!” retorted Passepartout, with an air of raillery.
“I am a police detective, sent out here by the London office.”
“You, a detective?”
“I will prove it. Here is my commission.”
Passepartout was speechless with astonishment when Fix displayed this document, the genuineness of which could not be doubted.
“Mr. Fogg’s wager,” resumed Fix, “is only a pretext, of which you and the gentlemen of the Reform are dupes. He had a motive for securing your innocent complicity.”
“But why?”
“Listen. On the 28th of last September a robbery of fifty-five thousand pounds was committed at the Bank of England by a person whose description was fortunately secured. Here is his description; it answers exactly to that of Mr. Phileas Fogg.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“Twenty thousand pounds.”
“Fifty-five thousand pounds, if you please,” replied Fix.
“What!” cried Passepartout; “has Mr. Fogg won fifty-five thousand pounds?”
“No,” returned Fix, “it is not the money he has won, but the money he has stolen.”
“From whom?”
“From the Bank of England.”
“What! my master, who is the most honourable of men, a robber!”
“Your master is the robber, and I am Fix, a detective of the London police,” replied the agent, producing a card on which he had pencilled his name and quality. “You have come to my assistance, and I will keep my word; I will give you five hundred pounds.”
“But I don’t understand,” replied Passepartout, quite dumbfounded, and falling into a chair.
“I will make it clear to you,” said Fix, who retained his coolness. “Listen to me. On the 28th of September last a robbery of fifty-five thousand pounds was committed at the Bank of England by a person with a polished bearing, a gentleman well known in the fashionable clubs. The description of this person was sent to all the police stations of the United Kingdom, and to those of the principal cities of the two worlds. You can see that description here; it is as exact as a photograph.—”
Fix exhibited a notice which had been taken from the records of the detective police. Passepartout, trembling, took the paper, and read it. It was as follows:

“Height, five feet ten inches; hair, brown; eyes, grey; large reward offered;” and the description descended to the most minute details of dress and personal appearance.
Passepartout passed his hand over his eyes. The description was certainly that of Mr. Fogg. And beside this, he recalled the fact that Mr. Fogg had left home on this very 28th of September, and that he had taken the tour of the world under a false pretext, after having committed this grand robbery. The twenty thousand pounds were but a blind—a wager, not so very considerable, which Mr. Fogg affected to be making, but which was only a cover for his real design—to elude the detectives. He was right in not bringing Passepartout with him when he started, for the honest fellow would have surely insisted on returning the money.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: “Twenty thousand pounds.” Phileas Fogg articulated the sum with the same measured precision he applied to everything else in his meticulously ordered life, from the temperature of his shaving water to the duration of his morning walk. The declaration, delivered without a hint of emotion or hesitation, hung in the air of the Reform Club, momentarily silencing the low hum of conversation and the rustle of newspapers. It was the stake, the formidable wager he calmly proposed in response to the increasingly agitated discussion among his fellow members: Stuart, Fallentin, Sullivan, Ralph the banker, and the Reverend Mr. Wilson. The topic had been the audacious recent robbery of the Bank of England and the subsequent impossibility of catching the perpetrator. Given the modern means of travel, Stuart had argued, the thief could be anywhere, lost in the immense anonymity of a world that, despite railways and steamships, remained too vast to police effectively. "The world has grown smaller?" Stuart had scoffed, leaning back in his armchair. "It has grown larger, since a man can now go round it in ten days, and be hidden in any part of it!" It was this exaggeration, this dismissal of the very routes that Phileas Fogg had quietly studied, that had prompted him to speak. "It is possible, on the contrary," Fogg had stated, his voice even and devoid of argument, "to go round it in eighty days." This seemingly simple assertion had ignited a firestorm of disbelief. Eighty days! It was madness. The others enumerated the potential pitfalls: unforeseen accidents, delays, bad weather, missed connections, the inherent unreliability of schedules. Ralph, the banker, spoke of the financial folly of such a reckless endeavour. But Phileas Fogg was not a man swayed by popular opinion or the anticipation of difficulty. He dealt in facts, in the undeniable reality of published timetables and established routes. He knew the journey was possible. Stuart, provoked by Fogg’s unwavering certainty, challenged him directly. "I should like to see you do it!" Fogg’s reply was immediate. "It depends on you. Shall we make the tour together?" Stuart, perhaps regretting his impulsiveness but bound by the club’s etiquette, responded, "On a wager? Yes. I will bet four thousand pounds on it." And then, Phileas Fogg, fixing his clear gaze upon his friends, had calmly raised the ante to a level that took their breath away. “Twenty thousand pounds.” The sheer magnitude of the sum, combined with Fogg’s absolute composure, struck the other members with a mixture of awe and alarm. Twenty thousand pounds! Half of Fogg’s entire fortune, risked on what seemed to them an impossible whim. But to Fogg, it was not a whim; it was a certainty, a calculation based on empirical data. The bet was accepted, the terms agreed upon and minuted: Phileas Fogg would leave London that very evening and must return to the Reform Club by 8:45 p.m. on Saturday, December 21st, 1872. He rose, adjusted his hat, and announced, "I am going home." His calm departure left the others in a state of stunned disbelief, having just set in motion a journey that the entire world would soon be watching.

events.title: Passepartout's Loyalty Tested and Fix's Desperate Measure
detailed_summary: Passepartout forcefully rejects the accusation, slamming the table and affirming his master's honor.
Fix casts doubt on Passepartout's knowledge of Fogg, highlighting his recent employment, Fogg's sudden departure without luggage but with substantial cash, and the seemingly irrational trip.
Passepartout weakly insists Fogg is honest.
Fix threatens Passepartout with arrest as an accomplice.
Deeply distressed, Passepartout holds his head, torn between his loyalty to the generous Fogg and the detective's accusations and evidence; he resists believing his master is a thief.
He eventually asks Fix what he wants him to do.
Fix reiterates his need for help detaining Fogg in Hong Kong until the arrest warrant arrives.
He offers Passepartout a share of the £2,000 reward from the Bank of England.
Passepartout vehemently refuses, attempting to stand but collapsing back, overwhelmed.

He declares that even if Fogg were guilty (which he denies), his loyalty, born from witnessing Fogg's kindness, is absolute; he wouldn't betray him for any amount of money, invoking his humble upbringing.
Fix confirms the refusal.
Fix suggests they drop the subject and continue drinking.
Passepartout agrees and drinks more, becoming increasingly intoxicated.
Fix, determined to prevent Passepartout from warning Fogg, decides to incapacitate him.
He places an opium pipe into Passepartout's hand.
Passepartout accepts it, lights it, and smokes.
The narcotic takes effect, his head becomes heavy, and he slumps onto the table, unconscious.
Fix expresses grim satisfaction, stating Fogg will now miss the warning about the 'Carnatic's' early departure and will likely have to proceed without his servant.
Fix settles the bill and departs the opium den.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “What nonsense!” cried Passepartout, striking the table with his fist.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And, after paying his bill, Fix left the tavern.

events.text_segment:
“What nonsense!” cried Passepartout, striking the table with his fist. “My master is the most honourable of men!”
“How can you tell? You know scarcely anything about him. You went into his service the day he came away; and he came away on a foolish pretext, without trunks, and carrying a large amount in banknotes. And yet you are bold enough to assert that he is an honest man!”
“Yes, yes,” repeated the poor fellow, mechanically.
“Would you like to be arrested as his accomplice?”
Passepartout, overcome by what he had heard, held his head between his hands, and did not dare to look at the detective. Phileas Fogg, the saviour of Aouda, that brave and generous man, a robber! And yet how many presumptions there were against him! Passepartout essayed to reject the suspicions which forced themselves upon his mind; he did not wish to believe that his master was guilty.
“Well, what do you want of me?” said he, at last, with an effort.
“See here,” replied Fix; “I have tracked Mr. Fogg to this place, but as yet I have failed to receive the warrant of arrest for which I sent to London. You must help me to keep him here in Hong Kong—”
“I! But I—”
“I will share with you the two thousand pounds reward offered by the Bank of England.”
“Never!” replied Passepartout, who tried to rise, but fell back, exhausted in mind and body.
“Mr. Fix,” he stammered, “even should what you say be true—if my master is really the robber you are seeking for—which I deny—I have been, am, in his service; I have seen his generosity and goodness; and I will never betray him—not for all the gold in the world. I come from a village where they don’t eat that kind of bread!”
“You refuse?”
“I refuse.”
“Consider that I’ve said nothing,” said Fix; “and let us drink.”
“Yes; let us drink!”
Passepartout felt himself yielding more and more to the effects of the liquor. Fix, seeing that he must, at all hazards, be separated from his master, wished to entirely overcome him. Some pipes full of opium lay upon the table. Fix slipped one into Passepartout’s hand. He took it, put it between his lips, lit it, drew several puffs, and his head, becoming heavy under the influence of the narcotic, fell upon the table.
“At last!” said Fix, seeing Passepartout unconscious. “Mr. Fogg will not be informed of the ‘Carnatic’s’ departure; and, if he is, he will have to go without this cursed Frenchman!”
And, after paying his bill, Fix left the tavern.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: “What nonsense!” cried Passepartout, striking the table with his fist. “My master a robber, who so generously rewarded me, and who is the most upright man on earth! That's a good one, that is!” “Very well,” said Fix. “Let us not speak of it. It is a subject that must be disagreeable to you.” “Yes, it is,” returned Passepartout, “but it must be still more disagreeable to Mr. Fogg.” “There are people who like such jokes,” resumed Fix. “But, let us change the subject. Did you not say yesterday that Passepartout was not your real name?” “Yes, it is only a nickname.” “Well, Passepartout,” continued Fix, “you do not, perhaps, know what a lucky chance has brought us together.” “I am sure I don't,” replied Passepartout. “Listen. Do you suspect your master of nothing?” “Nothing whatever.” “Absolutely nothing?” “Absolutely nothing. I defy anyone to make me suspect the most honourable and fixed of men.” “Do you know,” asked Fix, “that, relatively speaking, Mr. Fogg has left London very recently?” “Yes, I know it,” replied Passepartout; “but he started on his tour the same day that I entered his service.” “Ah! you entered his service that day?” “Yes.” “And he took you with him?” “Yes.” “Come, come!” said Fix, “let us reason a little. An honest man does not throw himself out of doors in that way. He does not travel around the world without luggage, and with a pocket-book full of bank-notes. ” “Excuse me,” said Passepartout; “he had a trunks with him, a portmanteau which was just full; and as for bank-notes, he carried a goodly bundle of them.” “Which he had withdrawn from the bank?” “Yes, at the Bank of England.” “A bundle of notes so large as that was not usually carried by a gentleman unless he is a robber,” said Fix, drily. “If you mean to arrest my master,” said Passepartout, “I will answer for it that he is an honest man, and you have come to the wrong place.” “You are mistaken,” said Fix, “I don't arrest gentlemen. I am here in my private capacity, and I am speaking to you as man to man. But take care what you say, for if you do not hold your tongue, you will be arrested yourself.” Passepartout felt a cold tremor run over him. He saw that Fix was a determined man. He bit his lips and said nothing. “You see, Passepartout,” continued Fix, “I am trying to get you to assist me.” “Assist you in what?” “In arresting this Fogg.” “Arrest my master! Never!” “But consider, my good fellow, that if he is a robber, you are his accomplice.” “Accomplice!” cried Passepartout, in a rage. “I, his accomplice! Never! I will suffer myself to be hanged, but I will not betray my master!” “You are a brave fellow,” said Fix, “but I am sure you will regret not having accepted my offer. I offer you a share of the £2,000 reward which the Bank of England has offered for his apprehension.” “A reward!” cried Passepartout. “Do you think that I would take money for betraying my master? Not if I were to be hanged twenty times over! Even if I were to be hanged once, I would not betray him.” “Come, come!” said Fix, “let us drop the subject, and have a drink.” “Very well,” said Passepartout, and they returned to their drinking. Fix watched Passepartout. The brave fellow was getting drunk; but his drunkenness was of a cheerful, good-natured sort. He was still firm on the question of his master. “Come, come!” said Fix, “you are too warm, my good fellow. Let us drink and be merry.” Passepartout was in a mood to do anything he was asked. He drank again and again, and, in an hour or two, he was as drunk as a lord. Fix saw that his time had come. He filled a pipe with opium, and put it into Passepartout's hand. Passepartout took it, lit it, and began to smoke. He did not know what it was, but he liked the taste of it. He smoked and smoked, and, by degrees, his head became heavy, and his eyes closed. He fell back on the table, and was soon fast asleep. Fix looked at him for a moment, and then, with a grim smile, he said: “He will not warn his master now. He will not be able to leave with him on the Carnatic. Mr. Fogg will have to go without him. So much the better! He will be left behind, and I shall have him safely in Hong Kong.” He paid the bill and left the opium den.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: “What nonsense!” cried Passepartout, striking the table with his fist. "Around the world in eighty days! And for what purpose? This cannot be serious!" His eyes, wide with astonishment, darted from the newspaper lying open before Mr. Fogg to his master's impassive face. Passepartout, the freshly-hired valet, who had sought a quiet life with a methodical gentleman, felt his hopes of domestic tranquility shatter like glass. He had only been in service for a few hours, having accepted the position earlier that very day, delighted by Mr. Fogg's reputation for impeccable routine and predictable habits. Now, this! A sudden, impulsive, utterly improbable journey spanning the globe! Mr. Phileas Fogg, however, remained perfectly calm, his gaze fixed on the calendar, calculating probabilities with the cold precision of a machine. He had just won a wager with his fellow members of the Reform Club, a wager of twenty thousand pounds that he could accomplish this seemingly impossible feat. To Passepartout, the idea was madness. Eighty days! It seemed an absurdly short time to traverse continents and oceans, facing untold dangers and unforeseen delays. "It is quite serious, Passepartout," Mr. Fogg replied, his voice devoid of emotion. "We are leaving for Dover at precisely 8:45 this evening." "But... but the trunks!" stammered the valet, "the luggage! We have none prepared!" "We shall carry only carpet-bags," Fogg stated. "Two suits apiece. I have provided for all necessities. We are traveling lightly." Passepartout stood frozen, his mind reeling. Two suits! For a trip around the world? His previous masters had required an entire train of luggage for a simple trip to the continent. This Mr. Fogg was unlike anyone he had ever encountered. Was he mad? Or was this simply the eccentric whim of a wealthy Englishman with too much time and money on his hands? The prospect of circumnavigating the globe filled him with a mixture of dread and reluctant excitement. He had envisioned a peaceful existence in London, serving a man of quiet, unchanging habits. Instead, he found himself embarking on the adventure of a lifetime, propelled into the unknown by a wager and the peculiar determination of Phileas Fogg. He looked around the elegant room at the Reform Club, the scene of this extraordinary declaration. The other gentlemen, initially incredulous, were now observing Mr. Fogg with a mixture of awe and apprehension. They had taken his wager, confident in the impossibility of his claim. Now, facing his absolute resolve, they seemed to sense that this quiet, unassuming man might actually attempt the unthinkable. "Eight o'clock, monsieur?" Passepartout managed to ask, still trying to process the magnitude of the news. "No, Passepartout, 8:45," Fogg corrected precisely. "Be ready." Ready? Passepartout felt anything but ready. His head was spinning. He had dreamed of a stable, predictable life. Now, within hours of entering Mr. Fogg's service, he was being whisked away on a whirlwind journey across the planet. He could barely comprehend it. A quiet English gentleman wagering his fortune and embarking on a breakneck race against time around the globe? It was indeed nonsense, but it was also undeniably happening. He looked at Mr. Fogg again, searching for any sign of jest or hesitation. There was none. Just calm, unwavering resolve. Passepartout sighed, running a hand through his hair. His quiet life had just taken a decidedly loud and unexpected turn. He had no choice but to follow.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XX. IN WHICH FIX COMES FACE TO FACE WITH PHILEAS FOGG

events.title: Fogg Assists Aouda While Passepartout is Missing
detailed_summary: Unaware of Passepartout's situation, Mr. Fogg assists Aouda with shopping for their journey.
He justifies the purchases to a grateful Aouda as being essential to his travel plan.
After shopping, they return to their hotel and dine.
Aouda retires for the night after thanking Fogg.
Mr. Fogg spends the evening reading newspapers, seemingly unperturbed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: While these events were passing at the opium-house, Mr. Fogg, unconscious of the danger he was in of losing the steamer, was quietly escorting Aouda about the streets of the English quarter, making the necessary purchases for the long voyage before them.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mr. Fogg absorbed himself throughout the evening in the perusal of the Times and Illustrated London News.

events.text_segment:
While these events were passing at the opium-house, Mr. Fogg, unconscious of the danger he was in of losing the steamer, was quietly escorting Aouda about the streets of the English quarter, making the necessary purchases for the long voyage before them. It was all very well for an Englishman like Mr. Fogg to make the tour of the world with a carpet-bag; a lady could not be expected to travel comfortably under such conditions. He acquitted his task with characteristic serenity, and invariably replied to the remonstrances of his fair companion, who was confused by his patience and generosity:
“It is in the interest of my journey—a part of my programme.”
The purchases made, they returned to the hotel, where they dined at a sumptuously served table-d’hôte; after which Aouda, shaking hands with her protector after the English fashion, retired to her room for rest. Mr. Fogg absorbed himself throughout the evening in the perusal of the Times and Illustrated London News.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: While these events were passing at the opium-house, Mr. Fogg, unconscious of the danger he was in of losing the steamer, was quietly escorting Aouda about the streets of the English quarter, making the necessary purchases for the long voyage before them. He made his purchases with that never-failing equanimity which accompanied him everywhere. He replied with his usual imperturbability to the remarks of his companion, who was charming, and evinced the liveliest gratitude for his kindness. When he proposed to her that she should provide herself with dresses and articles of comfort, she found it quite natural that this gentleman should, of his own accord, think of everything. He simply told her that it was requisite, if they were to travel as they did, that she should be provided for. This was an explanation which she admitted to be thoroughly unanswerable. The shopping over, Mr. Fogg and Aouda returned to the hotel, and dined at their leisure. Aouda, though feverish, and feeling the effects of the fatigues she had gone through, ate with appetite, and her charming face regained something of its natural colour. At the request of Mr. Fogg, she readily consented to pass the night on board the steamer, and pass the next day, the 22nd of October, at Hong Kong. She was still a little confused, it is true, but her mind was beginning to be clearer, and she was even able to appreciate the kindness of her protector. When the time came to retire, she took leave of Mr. Fogg, and went to her room, whither the ayah had followed her. Mr. Fogg returned to the reading-room, and set himself to the perusal of the papers. If Fix had been able to perceive his countenance, he would have said that he had never beheld so perfect a type of unconcern and coolness. There was the same impassive expression on his face, the same slightly rigid air, the same abstinence from any superfluous movement, which characterised him always. He was there, in short, perfectly himself, without evincing the slightest disturbance at the prospect of losing the Rangoon, and of being obliged to use another eight days of the tour.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: While these events were passing at the opium-house, Mr. Fogg, unconscious of the danger he was in of losing the steamer, was quietly escorting Aouda about the streets of the English quarter, making the necessary purchases for the long voyage before them. He methodically selected items from tailors and outfitters, choosing practical and durable clothing suitable for varied climates. Aouda, still somewhat disoriented by the sudden change in her life, followed his lead, observing his unwavering composure. Fogg seemed completely detached from the frenetic energy of the port city, where preparations for the steamer's departure were reaching a fever pitch. He consulted his watch with habitual precision, noting the time, but without any apparent anxiety regarding their schedule. His sole focus remained on ensuring Aouda was adequately equipped for the journey, acquiring trunks, wraps, and all the essential accoutrements required for a lady embarking on a journey around the globe. He moved with the same measured pace and unhurried efficiency he applied to every undertaking, utterly oblivious to the fact that the moments were slipping away, and that Passepartout, upon whom their timely arrival depended, was not with them.

events.title: Discovery of the Missed Steamer and Passepartout's Absence
detailed_summary: Mr. Fogg notes Passepartout's absence at bedtime but remains untroubled, knowing the steamer departs the next morning.
When Passepartout fails to appear the following morning, Fogg proceeds without visible annoyance.
He summons Aouda and arranges for a palanquin to take them to the harbour.
They arrive at the quay half an hour before the scheduled departure time (9:30 AM).
Fogg learns the "Carnatic" had actually departed the previous evening.
Facing the loss of both his transport and his servant, Fogg displays remarkable composure, calling it merely an accident to Aouda.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Had he been capable of being astonished at anything, it would have been not to see his servant return at bedtime.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He had expected to find not only the steamer, but his domestic, and was forced to give up both; but no sign of disappointment appeared on his face, and he merely remarked to Aouda, “It is an accident, madam; nothing more.”

events.text_segment:
Had he been capable of being astonished at anything, it would have been not to see his servant return at bedtime. But, knowing that the steamer was not to leave for Yokohama until the next morning, he did not disturb himself about the matter. When Passepartout did not appear the next morning to answer his master’s bell, Mr. Fogg, not betraying the least vexation, contented himself with taking his carpet-bag, calling Aouda, and sending for a palanquin.
It was then eight o’clock; at half-past nine, it being then high tide, the “Carnatic” would leave the harbour. Mr. Fogg and Aouda got into the palanquin, their luggage being brought after on a wheelbarrow, and half an hour later stepped upon the quay whence they were to embark. Mr. Fogg then learned that the “Carnatic” had sailed the evening before. He had expected to find not only the steamer, but his domestic, and was forced to give up both; but no sign of disappointment appeared on his face, and he merely remarked to Aouda, “It is an accident, madam; nothing more.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Had he been capable of being astonished at anything, it would have been not to see his servant return at bedtime. But, knowing that the steamer was to depart the next morning and that Passepartout could not but be on board, he did not let Passepartout’s absence give him the slightest uneasiness. When Passepartout did not make his appearance, however, on the following morning, Mr. Fogg, though not in the least disturbed, felt it necessary to acquire information. He summoned Aouda, who was ready, and desired her to await him on the steamer, while he repaired to the police-station. It was there ascertained that Passepartout had been carried to prison, and, on inquiry, Mr. Fogg learned that it was for having disturbed the public peace by getting drunk in a pagoda. Mr. Fogg paid the fine and bail demanded, and the Frenchman, enabled to get away, at once rejoined his master. Before the steamer Carnatic, which was to leave at nine o’clock, the party found Mr. Fogg quite tranquil, not showing the least trace of annoyance at the misadventure which had befallen his servant. He had, indeed, only added this incident to the list of those which he was constantly expecting to meet on his route. When he requested Passepartout to tell him what had occurred, the latter recounted his adventure from beginning to end, not omitting the least detail. Mr. Fogg listened attentively, and replied only by the observation that it was a matter of regret that Passepartout should have been arrested, for it would not have happened if he had kept to the letter of his instructions. By this, neither master nor servant was offended. The steamer was ready to leave, and the adventurers were all on board, when, half an hour before the time fixed for sailing, Mr. Fogg, observing that the Carnatic was getting up steam, and having a sudden inspiration, rang for the engineer. “Are you ready?” asked he. “Yes, sir,” was the reply. “But you are getting up steam before the proper time.” “We are ordered to get under way at nine o’clock.” “But you are getting up steam before the proper time,” repeated Mr. Fogg. “Sir, we are ordered to get under way at nine o’clock,” insisted the engineer, looking very much surprised at the question. Mr. Fogg said no more, but went to the bridge. A moment after, he returned to the deck, and ordered the gangway to be lowered. The order was executed at once, and he and Aouda, followed by Passepartout, disembarked. Passepartout thought it was some caprice of his master, and inwardly chafed, for he knew that the steamer was to leave at nine o’clock. He was all the more surprised when, on reaching the quay, Mr. Fogg went up to the captain of the port, and asked him, in a quiet voice: "Are you quite sure that the Carnatic will not leave before nine o’clock?” “Not a minute before,” was the reply. “And where is she going?” “To Hong Kong, sir.” “To Hong Kong direct?” “Yes, sir.” “Very well. I thank you, sir.” Mr. Fogg bowed and returned to the quay, where Passepartout and Aouda were awaiting him. “What is it?” asked Passepartout, quite bewildered. “What do we do now?” “We wait,” replied Mr. Fogg, gravely. Passepartout was about to question his master further, but Mr. Fogg, seeing his stupefaction, replied quickly, and in a tone which admitted no further remark: “There has been a misunderstanding, my dear Aouda; the Carnatic sailed yesterday evening. We must find another steamer.” Aouda looked at Mr. Fogg with an air of profound pity. She could not understand his calmness. He was simply calling it merely an accident to Aouda.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Had he been capable of being astonished at anything, it would have been not to see his servant return at bedtime. But Phileas Fogg was not capable of being astonished. Punctuality was his religion, and Passepartout’s absence was simply an anomaly, an interruption in the meticulously planned itinerary. He did not speculate, did not worry, did not fret. A delay, however inconvenient, was merely a fact to be dealt with. He calmly consulted his pocket calendar and the departure times of the steamers. The Rangoon, bound for Hong Kong, was set to sail the next morning at noon. Passepartout had not returned. Very well. This necessitated a slight adjustment. Mr. Fogg, with the same imperturbable demeanor, began the preparations for the departure himself. He packed the remaining bags with his usual methodical precision. He checked the travel documents and funds. His mind was not on his missing valet, but on the necessary arrangements to ensure the journey continued precisely as planned. The unexpected event, while unforeseen, did not alter his resolve or disturb his composure. He would depart on the Rangoon as scheduled, with or without his servant. The wager, and the precise execution of his itinerary, remained his sole focus. He completed his preparations, wound his watch, and retired at the usual hour, his thoughts strictly on the next leg of the circumglobal voyage.

events.title: Fix Informs Fogg of the Early Departure and Delay
detailed_summary: Detective Fix, who had been watching, approaches Mr. Fogg.
Fix identifies himself as a fellow passenger from the "Rangoon".
He feigns surprise when asking about Fogg's servant, Passepartout.
Aouda expresses worry about Passepartout's disappearance since the previous day and asks if he might have boarded the "Carnatic".
Fix confirms Fogg and Aouda intended to take the "Carnatic".
He informs them the ship left twelve hours early due to completed repairs, necessitating a week's wait for the next steamer.
Fix internally celebrates this delay, hoping it provides time for the arrest warrant to arrive.
His hope is dashed when Fogg calmly suggests seeking alternative vessels in the harbour.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At this moment a man who had been observing him attentively approached.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But there are other vessels besides the ‘Carnatic,’ it seems to me, in the harbour of Hong Kong.”

events.text_segment:
At this moment a man who had been observing him attentively approached. It was Fix, who, bowing, addressed Mr. Fogg: “Were you not, like me, sir, a passenger by the ‘Rangoon,’ which arrived yesterday?”
“I was, sir,” replied Mr. Fogg coldly. “But I have not the honour—”
“Pardon me; I thought I should find your servant here.”
“Do you know where he is, sir?” asked Aouda anxiously.
“What!” responded Fix, feigning surprise. “Is he not with you?”
“No,” said Aouda. “He has not made his appearance since yesterday. Could he have gone on board the ‘Carnatic’ without us?”
“Without you, madam?” answered the detective. “Excuse me, did you intend to sail in the ‘Carnatic’?”
“Yes, sir.”
“So did I, madam, and I am excessively disappointed. The ‘Carnatic’, its repairs being completed, left Hong Kong twelve hours before the stated time, without any notice being given; and we must now wait a week for another steamer.”
As he said “a week” Fix felt his heart leap for joy. Fogg detained at Hong Kong for a week! There would be time for the warrant to arrive, and fortune at last favoured the representative of the law. His horror may be imagined when he heard Mr. Fogg say, in his placid voice, “But there are other vessels besides the ‘Carnatic,’ it seems to me, in the harbour of Hong Kong.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: At this moment a man who had been observing him attentively approached. It was the detective, Fix, who, seeing Mr. Fogg at last without the troublesome Passepartout, thought it a good opportunity to accost him. He advanced and, politely bowing, said, "Is it not Mr. Fogg whom I have the honour of addressing?" "It is, sir," replied Mr. Fogg, stiffly. "I think I recognise you as one of the passengers from Bombay?" "Just so, sir; Fix is my name, a detective of the English police. I have been sent to find you, Mr. Fogg; but I will not conceal from you that I had great difficulty in discovering you." "Sir," replied Mr. Fogg, "you have not been looking for me." "On the contrary, I have been looking for you all the time," responded Fix. "But what is the meaning of all this? Are you arrested?" "Sir," said Mr. Fogg, "you are mistaken. I am Mr. Fogg, and you are certainly—" "Mr. Phileas Fogg of London," interrupted Fix. "Precisely, sir. And you have been travelling with a servant named Passepartout?" "Yes, sir." "And you expected to sail for Yokohama in the steamer Carnatic?" "Yes, sir." "Which sailed this morning at eight o'clock?" "No, sir, at noon," replied Mr. Fogg. "But how do you know all this?" "Oh, sir, I am an agent of the Peninsular Company, and I am acquainted with the movements of their vessels. And since you intended to sail by the Carnatic, I thought I would inquire whether you had any commands for Europe." "None, sir," replied Mr. Fogg. "I am not going to Europe." "Ah! I beg your pardon," said Fix. "You are going to America, then?" "No, sir," returned Mr. Fogg. "I am going round the world." Fix, whose hand was on Mr. Fogg's arm, started as if he had been suddenly electrified. "Round the world?" cried he. "In eighty days," returned Mr. Fogg, coolly. "But, sir, what has become of Passepartout?" "I don't know," replied Mr. Fogg. "Ah! Indeed!" exclaimed Fix, with an air of surprise. "You don't know where he is? Has he deserted you?" "He did not arrive at the hotel yesterday evening with us, and he has not been seen since," said Aouda, her voice trembling. "Do you think, Mr. Fogg," she added, "that he may have gone on board the Carnatic without our knowing it?" "That is possible, madame," replied Fix. "But, after all, it is of no consequence, as the Carnatic is now on its way to Yokohama." "No, sir," said Mr. Fogg. "The Carnatic was to leave this morning at noon, and she has not sailed yet. I am just going to the harbour to inquire." "Indeed!" cried Fix, pretending to be astonished. "You have not heard that the Carnatic's repairs were completed yesterday, and that she sailed this morning, twelve hours before the appointed time?" "Since yesterday?" exclaimed Mr. Fogg, a slight sign of surprise escaping him. "Yes, sir; and you can ascertain the fact by going to the Company's office. The steamer has been gone these twelve hours. There will not be another vessel for Yokohama until the 25th of October." (It was then the 14th.) "The 25th of October!" repeated Mr. Fogg, without betraying the least emotion. "That is a delay of ten days!" "Yes, sir; ten days, at least," added Fix, who felt a thrill of pleasure. "Passepartout will be very sorry when he hears this, I am sure," said Aouda. "He was so anxious to reach Yokohama by the Carnatic." "This cursed bad luck!" muttered Fix to himself. "Ten days lost! The warrant will be here! Well, it's not Calcutta, to be sure, and he hasn't skipped the jurisdiction, but he is in a fair way to do so. And Passepartout is not with him! All the better!" "But what shall we do?" asked Aouda, anxiously. "We will look for another vessel," replied Mr. Fogg, quietly.

"Oh, sir, I am an agent of the Peninsular Company, and I am acquainted with the movements of their vessels. And since you intended to sail by the Carnatic, I thought I would inquire whether you had any commands for Europe." "None, sir," replied Mr. Fogg. "I am not going to Europe." "Ah! I beg your pardon," said Fix. "You are going to America, then?" "No, sir," returned Mr. Fogg. "I am going round the world." Fix, whose hand was on Mr. Fogg's arm, started as if he had been suddenly electrified. "Round the world?" cried he. "In eighty days," returned Mr. Fogg, coolly. "But, sir, what has become of Passepartout?" "I don't know," replied Mr. Fogg. "Ah! Indeed!" exclaimed Fix, with an air of surprise. "You don't know where he is? Has he deserted you?" "He did not arrive at the hotel yesterday evening with us, and he has not been seen since," said Aouda, her voice trembling. "Do you think, Mr. Fogg," she added, "that he may have gone on board the Carnatic without our knowing it?" "That is possible, madame," replied Fix. "But, after all, it is of no consequence, as the Carnatic is now on its way to Yokohama." "No, sir," said Mr. Fogg. "The Carnatic was to leave this morning at noon, and she has not sailed yet. I am just going to the harbour to inquire." "Indeed!" cried Fix, pretending to be astonished. "You have not heard that the Carnatic's repairs were completed yesterday, and that she sailed this morning, twelve hours before the appointed time?" "Since yesterday?" exclaimed Mr. Fogg, a slight sign of surprise escaping him. "Yes, sir; and you can ascertain the fact by going to the Company's office. The steamer has been gone these twelve hours. There will not be another vessel for Yokohama until the 25th of October." (It was then the 14th.) "The 25th of October!" repeated Mr. Fogg, without betraying the least emotion. "That is a delay of ten days!" "Yes, sir; ten days, at least," added Fix, who felt a thrill of pleasure. "Passepartout will be very sorry when he hears this, I am sure," said Aouda. "He was so anxious to reach Yokohama by the Carnatic." "This cursed bad luck!" muttered Fix to himself. "Ten days lost! The warrant will be here! Well, it's not Calcutta, to be sure, and he hasn't skipped the jurisdiction, but he is in a fair way to do so. And Passepartout is not with him! All the better!" "But what shall we do?" asked Aouda, anxiously. "We will look for another vessel," replied Mr. Fogg, quietly.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: At this moment a man who had been observing him attentively approached. He was a stout gentleman, neatly dressed, with a florid face and a somewhat impatient air. He was Mr. Thomas Flanagan, one of Fogg’s usual companions at the Reform Club, a man of considerable fortune and equally considerable opinions. He paused beside the table where Mr. Fogg had been reading, newspaper still in hand, and without preamble, said, 'Well, Fogg, what do you think of this affair?' His voice was robust, cutting through the quiet murmur of the room. Mr. Fogg, who had already begun to gather his belongings with his customary precision, paused and looked up. Before he could reply, the door to the great saloon opened once more, admitting Mr. Samuel Fallentin and Mr. John Sullivan, followed closely by Mr. Andrew Stuart. These three, also prominent members and acquaintances of both Fogg and Flanagan, made their way towards the group, their attention also drawn by some pressing news of the day. Flanagan, however, pressed on with his question, assuming Fogg knew his meaning. 'The affair of the robbery?' Mr. Fogg inquired, ever precise, referring to the widely discussed recent theft at the Bank of England. Flanagan gave a short laugh. 'The robbery? No, no! Though that is indeed serious. I mean this other matter! This article in the 'Daily Telegraph'! About the journey around the world!' He gestured towards the newspaper Mr. Fogg held. Mr. Stuart, now standing close by, interjected with a skeptical frown. 'Ah, yes, that absurdity! Around the world in eighty days! Utterly impossible, I say!' The air grew tense as all eyes turned to Phileas Fogg, waiting for his inevitable, coolly delivered opinion on the matter. The stage was set.

events.title: Fogg's Determined Search for Alternative Transport
detailed_summary: Fogg escorts Aouda towards the docks to find another ship immediately.
A bewildered Fix follows, feeling compelled to stay close to Fogg.
Despite Fogg's previous good fortune, finding a suitable vessel proves difficult.
For three hours, Fogg searches the docks, considering chartering a vessel if needed.
He only finds ships currently loading or unloading, unable to depart promptly.
This temporary setback gives Fix a renewed sense of hope that Fogg will be delayed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: And, offering his arm to Aouda, he directed his steps toward the docks in search of some craft about to start.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Fix began to hope again.

events.text_segment: And, offering his arm to Aouda, he directed his steps toward the docks in search of some craft about to start. Fix, stupefied, followed; it seemed as if he were attached to Mr. Fogg by an invisible thread. Chance, however, appeared really to have abandoned the man it had hitherto served so well. For three hours Phileas Fogg wandered about the docks, with the determination, if necessary, to charter a vessel to carry him to Yokohama; but he could only find vessels which were loading or unloading, and which could not therefore set sail. Fix began to hope again.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
And, offering his arm to Aouda, he directed his steps toward the docks in search of some craft about to start.

Fix, who beheld the departure of the steamer *Carnatic* had a feeling of utter disappointment. The chase was on again, and the ship he had relied on to keep Fogg under surveillance was gone! He resolved to follow Fogg wherever he went, and only waited for the opportunity to telegraph to Mr. Elder, at Calcutta.

If Fix had been able to have a moment's reflection, he would have seen that, upon the supposition that Fogg was the robber, he must have left the steamer at Hong Kong, as he had now to make his way to America, and that, consequently, the warrant would be awaiting him at the American ports, and not at Calcutta. But, besides the perplexity which was the outgrowth of his agitated feelings, he had not time to think the matter over and come to a clear understanding of the situation. He followed Fogg, therefore, to the docks, and saw him with Aouda, whom he had hitherto thought to be an accomplice, search the harbour for a vessel about to leave.

Fogg was singularly fortunate in this respect, as in everything else; for the *Carnatic*, though she did not leave for Calcutta, was about to start full steam for Yokohama. Without doubt, if Fogg had not left the steamer, he would have been carried to Japan, and delay would have been occasioned, which would have rendered the journey a failure.

Mr. Fogg and Aouda went from one vessel to another, finding in each case that they were either just arriving or preparing to depart, and had no berths for passengers.

Fogg was not discouraged, however, and was determined to find a vessel, if he had to charter one himself.

He spent three hours in this search, and saw only ships which were either loading or unloading, and were therefore not ready for departure. The state of things gave Fix a little hope. Fogg had already lost three hours, and, if he could not find a vessel ready to depart, he would be obliged to pass twenty-four hours at least at Hong Kong.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: And, offering his arm to Aouda, he directed his steps toward the docks in search of some craft about to start. He knew the precious minutes were vanishing. He interrogated sailors and dockworkers with his usual curtness. "A vessel for London, sailing instantly!" he demanded. Time was running out. His calm exterior belied the immense pressure he felt. Among the moored ships, he located a small, swift steam-tender. Its captain, astonished but tempted by a substantial payment, agreed to cast off immediately. There was no negotiation beyond the price asked. Moments later, they were aboard, the shore receding as the little boat powered away.

events.title: Negotiating Passage on the Pilot Boat 'Tankadere'
detailed_summary: Undeterred, Fogg continues his search and is approached by a sailor offering a pilot boat, No. 43.
The sailor, John Bunsby, confirms the boat is ready and fast.
Fogg asks if Bunsby will take him to Yokohama to catch the San Francisco steamer by the 14th.
Bunsby is incredulous, stating the voyage is too long and risky at that time of year.
Fogg offers £100 per day plus a £200 bonus for timely arrival.
Bunsby hesitates, torn between the large payment and the danger.
Fix waits anxiously during the negotiation.
Fogg reassures Aouda, who affirms her lack of fear when with him.
Bunsby declines the Yokohama trip but suggests an alternative: sailing to Shanghai, only 800 miles away.
He explains the San Francisco steamer actually starts in Shanghai, stopping at Nagasaki and Yokohama later.
The Shanghai steamer departs on the 11th at 7 PM, leaving four days for the journey.
Bunsby believes they can reach Shanghai in time with favorable conditions.
Fogg agrees to the Shanghai trip and confirms Bunsby is the master of the boat, the "Tankadere".
Fogg pays £200 upfront and offers a place on the boat to Fix.
Fix accepts Fogg's offer.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: But Mr. Fogg, far from being discouraged, was continuing his search, resolved not to stop if he had to resort to Macao, when he was accosted by a sailor on one of the wharves.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Thanks, sir; I was about to ask the favour.”

events.text_segment:
But Mr. Fogg, far from being discouraged, was continuing his search, resolved not to stop if he had to resort to Macao, when he was accosted by a sailor on one of the wharves.
“Is your honour looking for a boat?”
“Have you a boat ready to sail?”
“Yes, your honour; a pilot-boat—No. 43—the best in the harbour.”
“Does she go fast?”
“Between eight and nine knots the hour. Will you look at her?”
“Yes.”
“Your honour will be satisfied with her. Is it for a sea excursion?”
“No; for a voyage.”
“A voyage?”
“Yes, will you agree to take me to Yokohama?”
The sailor leaned on the railing, opened his eyes wide, and said, “Is your honour joking?”
“No. I have missed the ‘Carnatic,’ and I must get to Yokohama by the 14th at the latest, to take the boat for San Francisco.”
“I am sorry,” said the sailor; “but it is impossible.”
“I offer you a hundred pounds per day, and an additional reward of two hundred pounds if I reach Yokohama in time.”
“Are you in earnest?”
“Very much so.”
The pilot walked away a little distance, and gazed out to sea, evidently struggling between the anxiety to gain a large sum and the fear of venturing so far. Fix was in mortal suspense.
Mr. Fogg turned to Aouda and asked her, “You would not be afraid, would you, madam?”
“Not with you, Mr. Fogg,” was her answer.
The pilot now returned, shuffling his hat in his hands.
“Well, pilot?” said Mr. Fogg.
“Well, your honour,” replied he, “I could not risk myself, my men, or my little boat of scarcely twenty tons on so long a voyage at this time of year. Besides, we could not reach Yokohama in time, for it is sixteen hundred and sixty miles from Hong Kong.”
“Only sixteen hundred,” said Mr. Fogg.
“It’s the same thing.”
Fix breathed more freely.
“But,” added the pilot, “it might be arranged another way.”
Fix ceased to breathe at all.
“How?” asked Mr. Fogg.
“By going to Nagasaki, at the extreme south of Japan, or even to Shanghai, which is only eight hundred miles from here. In going to Shanghai we should not be forced to sail wide of the Chinese coast, which would be a great advantage, as the currents run northward, and would aid us.”
“Pilot,” said Mr. Fogg, “I must take the American steamer at Yokohama, and not at Shanghai or Nagasaki.”
“Why not?” returned the pilot. “The San Francisco steamer does not start from Yokohama. It puts in at Yokohama and Nagasaki, but it starts from Shanghai.”
“You are sure of that?”
“Perfectly.”
“And when does the boat leave Shanghai?”
“On the 11th, at seven in the evening. We have, therefore, four days before us, that is ninety-six hours; and in that time, if we had good luck and a south-west wind, and the sea was calm, we could make those eight hundred miles to Shanghai.”
“And you could go—”
“In an hour; as soon as provisions could be got aboard and the sails put up.”
“It is a bargain. Are you the master of the boat?”
“Yes; John Bunsby, master of the ‘Tankadere.’”
“Would you like some earnest-money?”
“If it would not put your honour out—”
“Here are two hundred pounds on account sir,” added Phileas Fogg, turning to Fix, “if you would like to take advantage—”
“Thanks, sir; I was about to ask the favour.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: But Mr. Fogg, far from being discouraged, was continuing his search, resolved not to stop if he had to resort to Macao, when he was accosted by a sailor on one of the wharves. He was a native, who asked if the gentleman was not looking for a boat. "Yes," replied Mr. Fogg, "a boat to take me to Yokohama." "To Yokohama?" exclaimed the native. "You are not serious?" "Yes. I am ready to pay a good price." "For a journey at this season of the year it would be very dangerous," said the sailor; "and it is sixteen hundred miles from Hong Kong." "Sixteen hundred miles! very well. Have you a boat that will suit me?" "Yes; a pilot-boat, No. 43, the Tankadere." "Is she fast?" "Yes, pretty fast. And she will carry you to Yokohama, if you risk it." "Do you risk it?" asked Mr. Fogg. "I have a wife and children, sir; and this is the time of year when the gales are the severest on the coasts of Japan. The regular steamers do not run then." "Is there not a steamer from Hong Kong for Yokohama or Shanghai to-morrow or the day after?" "No, sir; the last steamer sailed yesterday; and she will not return for a month." "Is the Shanghai steamer a fast one?" "Yes; but she does not go farther than Shanghai, and stops there. Her destination is San Francisco, and she crosses the Pacific from Shanghai." "Ah!" said Mr. Fogg, who seemed to be reflecting. Fix, who was near at hand, could not but feel a cold shudder run over him at the thought of the enormous sum Mr. Fogg was going to squander if he should carry out his design of going to Yokohama. "Perhaps you know," said Mr. Fogg, resuming his conversation with the sailor, "that the San Francisco steamer does not start from Shanghai on the 14th?" "Ah! you know that?" said the sailor. "No, I am mistaken; I thought she sailed from Yokohama. It is not true, then, that she sails from Shanghai?" "Yes," replied the native, "she sails from Shanghai; but it is on the 11th, at seven in the evening." "The 11th, at seven in the evening! We have till then," cried Mr. Fogg, calmly; "four days and a half. We can reach Shanghai in four days and a half." "Provided you have fair wind and smooth sea," added the sailor. "Provided I have fair wind and smooth sea. When can we start?" "In an hour," replied the native, "as soon as the tide serves." "Your name?" asked Mr. Fogg. "John Bunsby, master of the Tankadere." "Is there any one in your boat with you?" "No one. I am sole owner." "What price do you ask for taking me to Shanghai?" "Two hundred pounds." "Two hundred pounds!" cried Fix, in amazement. "It is true that it is more than a thousand miles to Shanghai," said the sailor, coolly. "A thousand miles! Yes, about that. And you would take me there in four days and a half?" "Yes, sir, if I have a good passage." "Agreed. Here are two hundred pounds." Mr. Fogg, having taken the sum from the valise, paid it to Bunsby, who examined it and put it in his pocket. "You are a very worthy man," said Bunsby, examining the notes. "Very worthy," repeated Mr. Fogg. "And I may depend upon you?" "Yes, sir. I will take you to Shanghai, wind and tide permitting." "Very well. A word more. I have a friend here who wants to go with me." "There is room for two in the Tankadere," replied Bunsby. "Good," said Mr. Fogg. And turning to Aouda and Fix, he added, "You will come with me?" "I?" said Fix, in a tone of surprise. "Yes; unless you would rather remain in Hong Kong." Fix would not remain in Hong Kong. He saw that Mr. Fogg was determined to reach Shanghai. He had lost all trace of the detective who was watching him. He had no longer any doubt that Mr. Fogg was going to Shanghai to take the San Francisco steamer, and that he could not arrest him there. He was thus resolved to accompany Mr. Fogg to Shanghai, and to make a last attempt to arrest him there, either by producing the warrant, or by informing the police of his character as a suspected person. "I will go with you," said Fix. "Very well. The Tankadere is ready, then?" "Not quite. I have to lay in a few provisions and water." "Very well. Here is ten pounds for that purpose." "Thank you, sir," said Bunsby. And with the ten pounds in his hand, he went to the provisioners, and bought what was necessary. Mr. Fogg remained on the wharf with Aouda and Fix. He went into the custom-house, and had his passport viséd for Shanghai. Aouda was a little frightened. "Do not be afraid, madam," said Mr. Fogg; "I am here." Aouda, reassured, thanked him by a look. At the end of an hour, the Tankadere was ready to start. She was a small pilot-boat of about twenty tons, lightly rigged, and built for speed. She had but a single mast, and a large fore-and-aft mainsail, with a jib and a topsail. She carried very little ballast, and was capable of taking a considerable quantity of canvas when the wind was fair. She was a fine, fast boat, as John Bunsby had said. At a quarter past twelve, the tide began to ebb. John Bunsby ordered the ropes to be cast off, and the Tankadere stood out to sea. The wind was fair. The sea was calm. The sun shone brightly. The Tankadere made her way rapidly towards the south-west. She soon left the island of Hong Kong behind her. She passed between the island and the mainland. She followed the coast of China. The wind freshened. The sea became a little rough. The Tankadere pitched a little, but not enough to inconvenience any one. The passengers were on deck. Aouda, who was a little seasick, reclined on a coil of ropes. Mr. Fogg sat near her, and held her hand. Fix stood near the mast, and looked at the waves. He was not seasick, but he was ill at ease. He felt himself cut off from the world, from his duties, from his life as a detective. He saw Mr. Fogg taking him away from the very spot where he should have arrested him. He saw the chances of arresting him diminish with every mile. He saw himself transported to the other side of the world by a man whom he was pursuing. He saw himself the accomplice, as it were, of this man whom he was pursuing. It was a strange situation. It was a terrible situation.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: But Mr. Fogg, far from being discouraged, was continuing his search, resolved not to stop if he had to resort to Macao, when he was accosted by a sailor on one of the wharves. This man, a weather-beaten individual with shrewd eyes, had evidently noticed the Englishman's persistent inquiries for a vessel. Approaching Mr. Fogg, he touched his cap and asked, "Are you looking for a boat, sir? A schooner? Perhaps a pilot-boat?" "I am looking for a vessel to take me to Yokohama," replied Mr. Fogg, with his usual succinctness. "To Yokohama?" the sailor repeated, rubbing his chin. "That's a long way, sir. The regular steamer left yesterday. But," he added, his eyes glinting with a professional shrewdness, "I have a pilot-boat here, the Tankadere. She's not going directly to Yokohama, but she's bound for Shanghai, and she's fast." Mr. Fogg's face, usually so impassive, showed a flicker of interest. Shanghai was on the route to Yokohama. "When does she leave?" he inquired. "In an hour, sir. As soon as we can cast off." "And how long will the voyage to Shanghai take?" "With fair wind, four days, sir. Three hundred and fifty miles." "Can she carry passengers?" "Two, comfortably. Three, if necessary." "What is your price for taking two passengers to Shanghai?" The sailor named a considerable sum, knowing the urgency of the matter. Mr. Fogg listened without blinking. "Does that price include the sustenance for the passengers?" "Yes, sir. Whatever humble provisions we have." Mr. Fogg paused for a moment, calculating. The delay in Hong Kong was already significant. A four-day trip to Shanghai would put him within reach of the steamer bound for Yokohama. It was risky, relying on a small pilot-boat in the China Sea, but it seemed to be the only option now that the Carnatic was gone. "Very well," said Mr. Fogg. "I will take your boat. My companion and I will be ready in an hour. What is your name, Captain?" "John Bunsby, sir," replied the sailor, clearly pleased with the quick decision. "And she's my boat, the Tankadere." "Captain Bunsby, you will be paid upon arrival in Shanghai," Mr. Fogg stated, his tone leaving no room for doubt or negotiation on that point. "Agreed, sir," said Bunsby, smiling, anticipating a good sum. Mr. Fogg then left the wharf and made his way back towards the Hong Kong Club, where he had left Aouda. He found her anxious about Passepartout's disappearance, which remained a complete mystery to them both. Mr. Fogg, however, did not allow this grave concern to deviate him from his objective. "Aouda," he said calmly, "we must leave Hong Kong immediately. I have found a vessel, a pilot-boat called the Tankadere, bound for Shanghai. We will catch the Japanese steamer from there." Aouda, though saddened by leaving without Passepartout, understood the necessity. She trusted Mr. Fogg implicitly. Within minutes, their small bags were packed, containing only essentials, as their main luggage was presumably still on the Carnatic with the missing valet. They returned to the designated wharf. The Tankadere was a neat, sturdy craft, about forty tons burden, built for speed rather than comfort, with two masts and a gaff rig. Captain Bunsby was bustling about, supervising his small crew of four men, all hardened sailors. Mr. Fogg and Aouda were shown to the cramped cabin below deck, a simple space with bunks and a table. It was a far cry from the luxurious steamers they had travelled on, but Mr. Fogg seemed entirely unconcerned. His focus was solely on the nautical miles and the schedule. Precisely one hour after the agreement was made, the Tankadere cast off from the wharf. The sails were hoisted, catching the afternoon breeze. The little pilot-boat skillfully navigated the crowded harbour, leaving the bustling port of Hong Kong behind. As they cleared the breakwater and entered the open sea, the motion became more pronounced. Aouda watched the coastline recede, her heart heavy with worry for Passepartout, while Mr. Fogg consulted his watch and his notebook, already calculating the estimated time of arrival in Shanghai, his mind fixed on the next connection and the crucial journey around the world.

events.title: Final Preparations and Departure from Hong Kong
detailed_summary: Aouda expresses concern for Passepartout.
Fogg assures her he will do everything possible to find his servant.
While Fix nervously heads to the pilot boat, Fogg and Aouda go to the police station.
Fogg provides Passepartout's description and leaves money for the search.
They repeat the process at the French consulate.
Returning to the hotel briefly to collect their luggage, they proceed back to the wharf.
By three o'clock, the pilot boat "Tankadere" is provisioned and ready with its crew.
The boat is described as a well-maintained, fast, twenty-ton vessel with two masts, skippered by the capable John Bunsby.
Fogg and Aouda board, finding Fix already there.
The cabin accommodations are small but neat.
Fogg apologizes to Fix for the modest offering; Fix feels humbled by Fogg's courtesy despite suspecting him.
At ten past three, the sails and English flag are raised.
Fogg and Aouda scan the quay one last time for Passepartout.
Fix secretly hopes Passepartout does not appear, avoiding a difficult explanation.
Passepartout remains missing, likely still affected by the opium.
John Bunsby gives the order, and the "Tankadere" sets sail for Shanghai.

events.text_segment:
Very well. In half an hour we shall go on board.”
“But poor Passepartout?” urged Aouda, who was much disturbed by the servant’s disappearance.
“I shall do all I can to find him,” replied Phileas Fogg.
While Fix, in a feverish, nervous state, repaired to the pilot-boat, the others directed their course to the police-station at Hong Kong. Phileas Fogg there gave Passepartout’s description, and left a sum of money to be spent in the search for him. The same formalities having been gone through at the French consulate, and the palanquin having stopped at the hotel for the luggage, which had been sent back there, they returned to the wharf.
It was now three o’clock; and pilot-boat No. 43, with its crew on board, and its provisions stored away, was ready for departure.
The “Tankadere” was a neat little craft of twenty tons, as gracefully built as if she were a racing yacht. Her shining copper sheathing, her galvanised iron-work, her deck, white as ivory, betrayed the pride taken by John Bunsby in making her presentable. Her two masts leaned a trifle backward; she carried brigantine, foresail, storm-jib, and standing-jib, and was well rigged for running before the wind; and she seemed capable of brisk speed, which, indeed, she had already proved by gaining several prizes in pilot-boat races. The crew of the “Tankadere” was composed of John Bunsby, the master, and four hardy mariners, who were familiar with the Chinese seas. John Bunsby, himself, a man of forty-five or thereabouts, vigorous, sunburnt, with a sprightly expression of the eye, and energetic and self-reliant countenance, would have inspired confidence in the most timid.
Phileas Fogg and Aouda went on board, where they found Fix already installed. Below deck was a square cabin, of which the walls bulged out in the form of cots, above a circular divan; in the centre was a table provided with a swinging lamp. The accommodation was confined, but neat.
“I am sorry to have nothing better to offer you,” said Mr. Fogg to Fix, who bowed without responding.
The detective had a feeling akin to humiliation in profiting by the kindness of Mr. Fogg.
“It’s certain,” thought he, “though rascal as he is, he is a polite one!”
The sails and the English flag were hoisted at ten minutes past three. Mr. Fogg and Aouda, who were seated on deck, cast a last glance at the quay, in the hope of espying Passepartout. Fix was not without his fears lest chance should direct the steps of the unfortunate servant, whom he had so badly treated, in this direction; in which case an explanation the reverse of satisfactory to the detective must have ensued. But the Frenchman did not appear, and, without doubt, was still lying under the stupefying influence of the opium.
John Bunsby, master, at length gave the order to start, and the “Tankadere,” taking the wind under her brigantine, foresail, and standing-jib, bounded briskly forward over the waves.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Very well. In half an hour we shall go on board.”

Aouda, seeing Mr. Fogg so calm, and that he seemed about to sacrifice his fortune, had taken his hand and pressed it tenderly. Aouda, after having passed a restless night, began to be more composed. Passepartout's absence had given her great concern; and Mr. Fogg had asked her not to despair. While Fix was nervously proceeding towards the pilot-boat, a portmanteau in his hand, Mr. Fogg and Aouda went to the police-station. Phileas Fogg there gave a description of Passepartout, and offered a considerable reward to anyone who should find him and restore him to the party. Having done this, he proceeded to the French consulate, and there made the same offer. Then, returning to the hotel, he took his light luggage, and that of the young woman, and went to the wharf. At three o'clock the "Tankadere" was ready to weigh anchor. John Bunsby, the master, a man of forty-five or thereabouts, with a jolly face, tanned by the sun and sea-breezes, stood on the poop. He had engaged to carry the passengers to Shanghai, some eleven or twelve hundred miles distant, in a vessel of about twenty tons, with a taut rig, and admirably kept. John Bunsby, Skipper, was a trustworthy and active man, who well knew the Indian seas. His wages were eighty pounds a week, besides a percentage on the profits. When Mr. Fogg and Aouda stepped on board the "Tankadere," they found Fix already there. “You here, Mr. Fix?” asked Mr. Fogg, in surprise. “Myself,” replied the detective. “I am going to remain on board?” “Apparently not, since you are going to Shanghai,” returned Fogg. “No doubt; but I shall avail myself of the opportunity to return to Europe with you.” “All right, Mr. Fix,” said Mr. Fogg. It was the most natural thing in the world. Mr. Fogg, however, hardly betrayed the slightest astonishment. Fix felt a thrill pass through him. Fogg's politeness, so perfect and of such good weight, disturbed him. Was it possible that this man, whom he was pursuing, and whom he expected to arrest at Shanghai, was not the real Phileas Fogg? It perplexed him to be forced to regard as an honest man one whom he was strictly charged to follow as a criminal. Still, he could not but consider Fogg's offer to pay his fare to Europe. It was certainly a gain of money, and he would not have to regret his journey across Hong Kong, from which he was about to be so poorly repaid. The luggage was at once taken on board, and the “Tankadere” could have set sail at once, had not Mr. Fogg desired to ascertain if Passepartout could not be found at the docks. But, of course, the search was fruitless. Passepartout was not there; and was, no doubt, sleeping off the opium in some opium den. John Bunsby, meanwhile, had taken up his station and given orders to cast off the moorings. At ten past three the sails were hoisted, and the English flag and pennant flew from the masthead. Mr. Fogg and Aouda, for the last time, mounted the poop to scan the quay, in case Passepartout should be there. Fix was not without his fears, lest the unfortunate fellow should make his appearance; in which case his master's legal arrest would be prevented, and the detective's part be made much more difficult. But the French servant did not show himself, and the "Tankadere," escaping from the creek, bore away under full sail for Shanghai.
