LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Very well. In half an hour we shall go on board.”

Phileas Fogg, having spoken with characteristic calmness, proceeded to settle the financial details with swift efficiency. He paid Captain Speedy the agreed sum, arranged for a carriage, and ensured their luggage was ready.

Passepartout, though still amazed by the rapid turn of events, felt relief. They were moving again. He helped Mademoiselle Aouda prepare, his mind fixed on the imminent conclusion of their incredible journey. Reaching England now seemed tantalizingly close.

Precisely thirty minutes later, they arrived at Pier 13. The *Henrietta* lay alongside – a rough-looking screw steamer, clearly a cargo vessel. Her funnels emitted thick smoke, and sailors hurried about the deck.

Stepping aboard, they were met by Captain Andrew Speedy himself. Short and broad, with a red face and a bushy grey beard, he eyed them with suspicion.

“So you’re the man who thinks he can buy my ship’s course?” he rasped. “You’ve paid well enough, I’ll grant you. But this is a freight steamer, not a passenger packet!”

Mr. Fogg merely gave a slight nod. “I require speed, Captain. And I have provided the means for the necessary coal.”

“Coal? Aye, enough to steam to perdition and back!” Speedy grumbled. “But weather’s weather, and the Atlantic in December is no millpond.”

Despite the captain’s manner and the ship’s appearance, Mr. Fogg remained undisturbed. He directed Passepartout to find their quarters, which proved simple and cramped. Mademoiselle Aouda accepted the lack of comfort with quiet grace, her faith in Mr. Fogg absolute.

Soon, the lines were cast off. The *Henrietta* pulled away from the dock, heading east into the vast, grey Atlantic. The engine's vibration permeated the vessel.

As New York faded, Passepartout watched it go. This was the final, crucial leg. Less than eight days remained to reach London. The *Henrietta* felt small against the rising swell, but his faith in his master endured. He hoped the curmudgeonly captain and this sturdy steamer could somehow deliver them on time. The wind picked up, and the cold spray hit his face. The race continued.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXI. IN WHICH THE MASTER OF THE “TANKADERE” RUNS GREAT RISK OF LOSING A REWARD OF TWO HUNDRED POUNDS

events.title: Perilous Voyage Begins and Fix's Contemplation
detailed_summary: The journey from Hong Kong to Shanghai is presented as extremely dangerous due to the small size of the vessel, the 'Tankadere', and the volatile November weather in the Chinese seas, known for gales and equinoctial storms.
Despite the risks, the pilot, John Bunsby, trusts his boat's seaworthiness, even though proceeding to Yokohama would have been more profitable but far too dangerous.
The 'Tankadere' successfully navigates Hong Kong's channels and sails well in favourable winds upon reaching open water.
Phileas Fogg instructs the pilot to maximize speed, expressing confidence in the pilot's expertise.
Fogg stands steadily on deck observing the sea, unaffected by the motion.
Aouda, seated aft, feels overwhelmed looking at the vast, darkening ocean, perceiving the sails like large wings carrying the frail boat.
As night falls and the moon provides limited light, clouds gather, and the pilot activates the boat's lights for safety in the busy shipping lanes.
Fix remains isolated in the bow, reflecting on his situation. He avoids interaction with Fogg due to Fogg's reserved nature and Fix's discomfort at accepting Fogg's generosity.
Fix speculates that Fogg intends to proceed directly to San Francisco from Yokohama, using the vastness of America to escape justice with the stolen bank money.
He reaffirms his commitment to pursuing Fogg until extradition is secured, feeling it's his duty.
Fix finds solace in Passepartout's absence, realizing the importance of preventing any conversation between the servant (to whom he revealed much) and his master.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: This voyage of eight hundred miles was a perilous venture on a craft of twenty tons, and at that season of the year.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: At all events, there was one thing to be thankful for; Passepartout was not with his master; and it was above all important, after the confidences Fix had imparted to him, that the servant should never have speech with his master.

events.text_segment:
This voyage of eight hundred miles was a perilous venture on a craft of twenty tons, and at that season of the year. The Chinese seas are usually boisterous, subject to terrible gales of wind, and especially during the equinoxes; and it was now early November.
It would clearly have been to the master’s advantage to carry his passengers to Yokohama, since he was paid a certain sum per day; but he would have been rash to attempt such a voyage, and it was imprudent even to attempt to reach Shanghai. But John Bunsby believed in the “Tankadere,” which rode on the waves like a seagull; and perhaps he was not wrong.
Late in the day they passed through the capricious channels of Hong Kong, and the “Tankadere,” impelled by favourable winds, conducted herself admirably.
“I do not need, pilot,” said Phileas Fogg, when they got into the open sea, “to advise you to use all possible speed.”
“Trust me, your honour. We are carrying all the sail the wind will let us. The poles would add nothing, and are only used when we are going into port.”
“It’s your trade, not mine, pilot, and I confide in you.”
Phileas Fogg, with body erect and legs wide apart, standing like a sailor, gazed without staggering at the swelling waters. The young woman, who was seated aft, was profoundly affected as she looked out upon the ocean, darkening now with the twilight, on which she had ventured in so frail a vessel. Above her head rustled the white sails, which seemed like great white wings. The boat, carried forward by the wind, seemed to be flying in the air.
Night came. The moon was entering her first quarter, and her insufficient light would soon die out in the mist on the horizon. Clouds were rising from the east, and already overcast a part of the heavens.
The pilot had hung out his lights, which was very necessary in these seas crowded with vessels bound landward; for collisions are not uncommon occurrences, and, at the speed she was going, the least shock would shatter the gallant little craft.
Fix, seated in the bow, gave himself up to meditation. He kept apart from his fellow-travellers, knowing Mr. Fogg’s taciturn tastes; besides, he did not quite like to talk to the man whose favours he had accepted. He was thinking, too, of the future. It seemed certain that Fogg would not stop at Yokohama, but would at once take the boat for San Francisco; and the vast extent of America would ensure him impunity and safety. Fogg’s plan appeared to him the simplest in the world. Instead of sailing directly from England to the United States, like a common villain, he had traversed three quarters of the globe, so as to gain the American continent more surely; and there, after throwing the police off his track, he would quietly enjoy himself with the fortune stolen from the bank. But, once in the United States, what should he, Fix, do? Should he abandon this man? No, a hundred times no! Until he had secured his extradition, he would not lose sight of him for an hour. It was his duty, and he would fulfil it to the end. At all events, there was one thing to be thankful for; Passepartout was not with his master; and it was above all important, after the confidences Fix had imparted to him, that the servant should never have speech with his master.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: This voyage of eight hundred miles was a perilous venture on a craft of twenty tons, and at that season of the year. The Chinese seas are usually boisterous, subject to terrible gales, and especially so in the equinoctial months. M. Fogg was not afraid, and to the question asked by Mr. Bunsby, if he did not feel uneasy, he simply replied that he was there to be tossed about. Aouda was delighted to find herself on the sea. It seemed to her that she was safe now from the reach of Fix and the influence of the governor of Hong Kong. Mr. Bunsby was in ecstasies with the trip. A reward of two hundred pounds! He already saw himself smoking a pipe on the deck of his boat, which would be thenceforth as famous as the largest steamers. During the first few hours the "Tankadere" got along gallantly. The wind was fair, and the sea was not very rough. M. Fogg and Aouda sat astern, and contemplated the vast expanse of water, with its whitecaps glittering in the moonbeams. Mr. Bunsby, with his pipe in his mouth, stood at the helm, and directed the boat with the skill that belonged to him as a pilot. His men were all well trained, and they knew their work perfectly. Fix was shut up in his cabin, and gave no sign of life. He saw that his only chance of success was to keep himself concealed until he reached Shanghai. He hoped that M. Fogg would land there, and that he should be able to arrest him. But he did not know M. Fogg. The wind increased towards evening, and the sea became rougher. The "Tankadere" was tossed about like a feather, and the spray washed over the deck. Aouda was frightened, and clung to M. Fogg's arm. M. Fogg, however, was perfectly calm. He watched the waves with the same impassivity that he had shown in all the dangers through which he had passed. Mr. Bunsby, too, was quite unconcerned. He was used to such weather, and he knew that his boat was a good one. He did not even take his pipe out of his mouth. The night came on, and the moon disappeared behind the clouds. The darkness was complete, and the wind howled through the rigging. The waves grew higher and higher, and the "Tankadere" plunged into them as if she were going to the bottom. Aouda screamed, and M. Fogg put his arm round her waist to support her. Mr. Bunsby, however, laughed at her fears. "It's nothing," he said. "It's only a bit of a breeze. We shall be all right." He knew that the boat would weather the storm, and he felt confident of reaching Shanghai in safety. Fix, in his cabin, was also in a state of great anxiety. He heard the howling of the wind and the roaring of the waves, and he thought that the boat would be lost. He was sorry that he had not remained in Hong Kong. He would have been safe there, and he would have had another chance of arresting M. Fogg. He had made a mistake, and he knew it. He had been too hasty, and he had missed his opportunity. He now saw that M. Fogg was a man of resources, and that it would not be easy to catch him. He also felt a sort of remorse for the trick he had played upon Passepartout. He knew that the poor fellow had been cruelly deceived, and that he was now in a foreign land, without friends or money. He wished that he could tell him the truth, but he dared not. He was afraid of M. Fogg, and he knew that he would be severely punished if his treachery were discovered. He had nothing to do now but to wait for the end. If the boat went down, he would go down with her. If she reached Shanghai, he would try to carry out his plan. He was resolved to do his duty, whatever might be the consequences.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: This voyage of eight hundred miles was a perilous venture on a craft of twenty tons, and at that season of the year. The Chinese seas are usually boisterous, subject to terrible gales, and especially so in the equinoctial months. Early in November, it was not unusual to encounter violent hurricanes. It was therefore very hazardous to navigate these seas, particularly in so small a craft. John Bunsby, however, was confident in his boat, and, if he had not been, he would not have undertaken the voyage, though a reward of two hundred pounds was in the case. To go to Yokohama would have been more profitable, but it would have been too dangerous. The “Tankadere” got under way about three o’clock in the afternoon, and, having cleared the channels of Hong Kong, she stood out to sea under a press of sail. The wind was fair, and the little craft sailed well. Mr. Fogg was on deck, and, as usual, perfectly calm. He had given the pilot instructions to crowd on sail, and to make the best of his way to Shanghai. “I have confidence in you, sir,” he said to Mr. Bunsby. “I know that you are a good sailor.” Mr. Fogg stood steadily on the deck, observing the sea, and apparently unaffected by the motion of the boat. Aouda was seated aft, and looked with a sort of terror upon the vast expanse of water, which was growing darker and darker as the night came on. The sails seemed to her like great white wings carrying the frail boat over the waves. As night fell, the moon appeared, but her light was soon obscured by clouds. The wind freshened, and the sea became rougher. The pilot, however, held on his course, and the “Tankadere” behaved admirably. As the boat was in the track of the steamers plying between Hong Kong and Shanghai, it was necessary to hang out lights, to avoid collision. Fix was in the bow, quite alone. He avoided Mr. Fogg, not only because he was naturally reserved, but because he felt a sort of shame at accepting the hospitality of the man whom he was pursuing. He reflected upon his situation. He had missed Passepartout, and he had no doubt that the servant had rejoined his master. He thought that Mr. Fogg would land at Shanghai, and that he would then proceed to San Francisco, where he would be safe from arrest. America was a vast country, and he would easily be able to conceal himself there. Fix resolved to follow him to America, and to wait for an opportunity to arrest him. He felt that it was his duty to do so, and that he would be disgraced if he abandoned the pursuit. He was glad that Passepartout was not with him, for he knew that the servant would have told his master all that he had said to him, and that Mr. Fogg would then have been on his guard. He felt that he had been very imprudent in confiding in Passepartout, and he resolved to be more cautious in the future.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- The completion gives inaccurate or invented emotional states and actions for several characters, such as Aouda's delight at being at sea, Bunsby's excitement about a reward, and Fix's regret and fear.
- The sequence of events is altered, with invented scenes of rough weather and character interactions that do not match the original's order or content.
- The completion attributes thoughts and motivations to Fix that are not present in the original, such as his remorse over Passepartout and his fear of Fogg.

To improve, focus on accurately representing the sequence of events, preserving the original character interactions and dialogue, and avoiding the introduction of invented scenes or emotional responses. Ensure that all key descriptive and narrative elements from the original are included and that character perspectives remain faithful to the source material.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
This voyage of eight hundred miles was a perilous venture on a craft of twenty tons, and at that season of the year. The Tankadere, though sturdily built for its size, was but a toy on the immense and often furious waters of the South China Sea. The monsoon was brewing, and though not yet in its full fury, the winds were treacherous and the waves formidable. Each swell lifted the little schooner as if she were a feather, only to drop her into the trough with a sickening plunge. The spray lashed the decks constantly, soaking everything and everyone. The cramped quarters below deck offered little respite from the ceaseless motion. Every timber groaned in protest against the relentless assault of the sea.

Mr. Fogg, however, remained undisturbed. Seated upright on a small bench, clutching his indispensable Bradshaw, he seemed utterly impervious to the tempestuous elements. His eyes, clear and calm behind his spectacles, scanned the horizon or meticulously checked his watch and the chronometer. He spoke little, only occasionally addressing Captain Bunsby with precise inquiries about their speed, bearing, and the estimated time of arrival.

Passepartout, conversely, was in a state of perpetual misery. Seasick and terrified, he clung to whatever he could find, his usually cheerful face pale and drawn. The thought of missing the steamer at Hong Kong gnawed at him, but the immediate terror of being swallowed by the waves overshadowed even that anxiety. He watched the monstrous waves with wide, fearful eyes, convinced that each one would be their last.

Aouda, too, found the journey trying, but she bore it with a quiet fortitude. She sat near Mr. Fogg, her face reflecting some of Passepartout's apprehension, yet she drew strength from the prefect's serene confidence. She marvelled at his composure in the face of such danger, a stark contrast to the usual reactions of men to the fury of the sea.

Captain Bunsby, a grizzled, weather-beaten man with eyes that seemed to have seen every kind of storm, handled his little craft with consummate skill. He stood at the helm, his face set, barking orders to his small crew of four Lascars. He knew the dangers they faced – the shifting currents, the hidden reefs, the unpredictable temper of the sea in November. He relied on instinct and experience as much as on his charts.

The winds shifted capriciously, sometimes filling their sails and pushing them forward at a reasonable pace, at other times dying down or blowing against them, forcing them to tack painstakingly. The nights were long and dark, illuminated only by the meager lamps of the Tankadere and the phosphorescent glow of the waves. Navigation required constant vigilance. Every knot gained felt like a triumph, every lost hour a crushing setback in their desperate race against the clock. The immensity of the ocean surrounding their tiny vessel was a constant reminder of their vulnerability. They were a speck on a vast, indifferent stage, battling forces infinitely greater than themselves. The journey seemed endless, a relentless series of pitching, rolling, and the constant roar of wind and waves.

Despite the hardships, Mr. Fogg never once betrayed a hint of doubt or impatience. He had set a course and a schedule, and he adhered to it with unyielding determination. Hong Kong lay some eight hundred miles away, a beacon of hope and the next critical link in his extraordinary journey. But between them and that vital port lay days of uncertainty, peril, and the unceasing challenge of conquering the tempestuous sea on their fragile, twenty-ton boat.

events.title: Concerns for Passepartout and Night Sailing
detailed_summary: Phileas Fogg contemplates Passepartout's sudden disappearance, considering it possible that his servant mistakenly boarded the 'Carnatic' at the last minute.
Aouda shares this view, expressing sadness over the loss of Passepartout, to whom she feels indebted.
They entertain the hope of finding Passepartout in Yokohama by checking the 'Carnatic's' passenger list.
Around ten o'clock, a strong breeze develops, but the pilot decides against reducing sail after assessing the sky, confident in the 'Tankadere's' stability.
At midnight, Fogg and Aouda retire to the cabin, where Fix is already resting, leaving the pilot and crew on deck overnight.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Phileas Fogg was also thinking of Passepartout, who had so strangely disappeared.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The pilot and crew remained on deck all night.

events.text_segment:
Phileas Fogg was also thinking of Passepartout, who had so strangely disappeared. Looking at the matter from every point of view, it did not seem to him impossible that, by some mistake, the man might have embarked on the “Carnatic” at the last moment; and this was also Aouda’s opinion, who regretted very much the loss of the worthy fellow to whom she owed so much. They might then find him at Yokohama; for, if the “Carnatic” was carrying him thither, it would be easy to ascertain if he had been on board.
A brisk breeze arose about ten o’clock; but, though it might have been prudent to take in a reef, the pilot, after carefully examining the heavens, let the craft remain rigged as before. The “Tankadere” bore sail admirably, as she drew a great deal of water, and everything was prepared for high speed in case of a gale.
Mr. Fogg and Aouda descended into the cabin at midnight, having been already preceded by Fix, who had lain down on one of the cots. The pilot and crew remained on deck all night.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Phileas Fogg was also thinking of Passepartout, who had so strangely disappeared. He asked himself if the worthy fellow, when he found he was really to leave Hong Kong, had not taken it into his head to embark on the Carnatic at the last moment. And, if this were the case, would he not reach Yokohama at the same time as Mr. Fogg himself? This was an even more probable story than the other. Aouda shared this idea, for she was fond of the faithful servant to whom she owed so much. They both hoped to find him at Yokohama; and this was an additional motive for precipitating the journey. Around ten o’clock the wind was blowing briskly from the north-west, and it was thought best to take in a reef or two. But the master, having examined the heavens and sounded the wind, maintained his sails as they were. The Tankadere was an excellent sailer, and could doubtless carry more canvas. At midnight Mr. Fogg and Aouda retired to their cabin, and John Bunsby left the pilot and crew to keep the watch.

- There is an inaccurate implication about the timing and reasoning for adjusting the sails, differing from the original's account of the pilot's decision-making process.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Phileas Fogg was also thinking of Passepartout, who had so strangely disappeared. The unexpected separation in India weighed subtly on the imperturbable gentleman's mind. Passepartout's devotion, despite his anxieties about the itinerary, had become a quiet cornerstone of the journey. While Fogg rarely displayed emotion, the sudden void left by his valet was a disruption to the precise order he demanded. He reviewed the circumstances: the hurried departure from Calcutta, the elephant ride, the incident at the Pillaji temple, the pursuit by Fix disguised as a detective. It was after the temple event, escaping Bombay's jurisdiction, that Passepartout vanished. Fogg, accompanied by Aouda and the resourceful Parsi guide, had pressed on, driven by the relentless clock. Yet, the question lingered: where was the faithful Frenchman? Was he captured? Lost? Had he somehow managed to get ahead of them? The lack of information was an unwelcome variable in Fogg's meticulously calculated enterprise. The wager demanded speed, precision, and no unforeseen delays, but Passepartout's absence was the most significant, and inexplicable, delay of all.

events.title: Good Progress and Fix's Awkward Offer
detailed_summary: By sunrise on November 8th, the boat has covered over a hundred miles, averaging eight to nine miles per hour.
The 'Tankadere' continues at maximum speed under full sail, indicating favourable prospects if the wind persists.
The boat stays close to the coast to benefit from favourable currents, keeping the irregular shoreline within about five miles.
The sea remains relatively calm due to the offshore wind, advantageous for the small vessel.
The wind briefly weakens around noon, prompting the pilot to raise poles, but they are soon lowered as the wind strengthens again.
Fogg and Aouda handle the sea well and eat heartily.
Fix is invited to join their meal but accepts with resentment, disliking being dependent on Fogg.
After eating, Fix privately approaches Fogg, expressing discomfort and offering to pay his share for the passage.
Fogg firmly refuses, stating the cost is part of his overall travel expenses, leaving no room for argument.
Feeling rebuffed and stifled, Fix retreats to the bow and remains silent for the rest of the day.

events.text_segment:
At sunrise the next day, which was 8th November, the boat had made more than one hundred miles. The log indicated a mean speed of between eight and nine miles. The “Tankadere” still carried all sail, and was accomplishing her greatest capacity of speed. If the wind held as it was, the chances would be in her favour. During the day she kept along the coast, where the currents were favourable; the coast, irregular in profile, and visible sometimes across the clearings, was at most five miles distant. The sea was less boisterous, since the wind came off land—a fortunate circumstance for the boat, which would suffer, owing to its small tonnage, by a heavy surge on the sea.
The breeze subsided a little towards noon, and set in from the south-west. The pilot put up his poles, but took them down again within two hours, as the wind freshened up anew.
Mr. Fogg and Aouda, happily unaffected by the roughness of the sea, ate with a good appetite, Fix being invited to share their repast, which he accepted with secret chagrin. To travel at this man’s expense and live upon his provisions was not palatable to him. Still, he was obliged to eat, and so he ate.
When the meal was over, he took Mr. Fogg apart, and said, “sir”—this “sir” scorched his lips, and he had to control himself to avoid collaring this “gentleman”—“sir, you have been very kind to give me a passage on this boat. But, though my means will not admit of my expending them as freely as you, I must ask to pay my share—”
“Let us not speak of that, sir,” replied Mr. Fogg.
“But, if I insist—”
“No, sir,” repeated Mr. Fogg, in a tone which did not admit of a reply. “This enters into my general expenses.”
Fix, as he bowed, had a stifled feeling, and, going forward, where he ensconced himself, did not open his mouth for the rest of the day.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: At sunrise the next day, which was 8th November, the boat had made more than one hundred miles. The Tankadere was a light craft, and with a good breeze she sailed well. All day she kept close to the coast, profiting by the currents, and the wind was favourable. The sea was less rough, too, an advantage for the small vessel. The Tankadere still carried her full amount of canvas, and with the wind abeam, she kept steadily on her course. At noon, the pilot, a keen-eyed old sailor, could not but think that the reward promised by Fogg was as good as earned. The weather continued fair, and the sea was comparatively smooth. At one time, towards noon, the wind seemed slightly to abate, and the pilot proposed taking in the top-gallant sail, but Fogg begged him to keep it on. The wind soon rose again, and the Tankadere was once more ploughing the waves at her full speed. Aouda and Fogg bore the sea well. Fix, on the other hand, was very uncomfortable, though he made the best of it. Towards evening, the wind began to fresh, and the little vessel shipped a good deal of water. But she was a stanch boat, and made her way bravely through the waves. The day passed without accident, and at sunset, the pilot reckoned that they were not more than two hundred miles from Singapore. This was excellent news, and they might hope to reach their destination by the next day at latest. Fogg was quite satisfied with the progress they were making, and Aouda seemed to take pleasure in their journey. Fix was too much occupied with his own reflections to notice anything. He had been trying to persuade Fogg to give him a share of the expenses, but Fogg had positively refused, saying that the whole cost of the journey belonged to his general expenses, and that he could not permit anyone else to share them. This was very irritating to Fix, as it showed that Fogg had no idea of being dependent on him, and that he considered himself quite able to carry out his plan without any help from the police. He felt himself more than ever at the mercy of the man he was pursuing, and this thought was very disagreeable to him. He had no hope of arresting him until they reached Singapore, and there was no saying what might happen in the meantime. simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: At sunrise the next day, which was 8th November, the boat had made more than one hundred miles. The log showed a mean speed of eight or nine miles an hour. The Tankadere was a light craft, and with a good breeze she sailed well. If the wind held, the prospects were favourable. The Tankadere kept close to the coast, which is very irregular, and in some places is bordered by mountains. The irregular profile of the shore was always in sight, and from time to time they could see across clearings to the interior of the island. The sea was comparatively calm, thanks to the offshore wind, which was a great advantage for the small vessel. All day the Tankadere carried her full amount of canvas, and with the wind abeam, she kept steadily on her course. Towards noon, the wind seemed slightly to abate, and the pilot proposed taking in the top-gallant sail, but Fogg begged him to keep it on. The wind soon rose again, and the Tankadere was once more ploughing the waves at her full speed. Aouda and Fogg bore the sea well. They ate heartily, and Fix, who was invited to join their meal, accepted with a very ill grace. He disliked being dependent on Mr. Fogg's hospitality. After eating, Fix felt himself compelled to speak to Mr. Fogg. He could not bear the thought of owing him anything. He approached him, and said, "Mr. Fogg, I feel very uncomfortable. I should like to pay my share of the passage." "That is useless, Mr. Fix," replied Mr. Fogg. "I have included the cost of the passage in my general expenses." "But..." "There is no 'but,' Mr. Fix. The cost is included." Fix felt himself stifled. He could not speak. He went and sat down at the bow, and remained there, silent, for the rest of the day.

He was going to Hong Kong with Mr. Fogg! that was the important thing. It seemed now that he was really performing the tour of the world, and not merely accomplishing a voyage across the Atlantic. He was travelling, then! This Eastern steamer, long and black, with four masts, and her smokestack looming up in the middle, the Great Britain, was the noblest vessel he had ever seen. And the thought that she was carrying him easily and surely across these seas, so justly dreaded by their old master, filled him with satisfaction. By noon the Great Britain had made one hundred and sixty-two miles, and the daily record was posted, as usual, upon a card in the saloon. Mr. Fogg was an old acquaintance of the captain, a very well-bred man, who at the close of each day's work took his observations and entered them in a log-book. He then measured the ship's progress during the preceding twenty-four hours, and posted the result as Passepartout had seen. On this day, November 8th, Fogg accosted him after the operation was over, and asked him politely, and with that air of indifference which was peculiar to him, how many miles the Great-Britain had made. The captain was surprised at the question. Mr. Fogg was not in the habit of asking such questions, nor of seeming in any way interested in the vessel. He knew the precise whereabouts of the ship, however, as well as the captain himself. "One hundred and sixty-two miles," replied the captain; "this being an average of twelve miles an hour." events.title: Rapid Progress Meets Rising Storm
detailed_summary: The 'Tankadere' makes excellent progress, fueling John Bunsby's optimism about reaching Shanghai on time, which Fogg calmly acknowledges.
The crew works diligently, motivated by the promised reward, ensuring every sail is perfectly set and the steering is precise.
By evening, they have traveled 220 miles from Hong Kong, bolstering Fogg's hope of reaching Yokohama without further delays impacting his schedule.
During the night, the boat enters the rough Straits of Fo-Kien, encountering challenging eddies and choppy waves that make standing difficult.
At daybreak, the wind intensifies, and the sky signals an impending gale, confirmed by erratic barometer readings and large swells from the south-east.
The previous sunset had been ominous, occurring amidst a red mist and phosphorescent ocean.
John Bunsby observes the worsening weather with concern and informs Fogg that a squall is approaching.
Fogg calmly inquires about the wind direction.
Bunsby confirms it's a southern wind, warning of an oncoming typhoon.
Fogg pragmatically notes that a southerly typhoon will actually help push them forward.
Bunsby, taken aback by Fogg's perspective, accepts his view, though his own meteorological knowledge indicates a violent winter typhoon is likely.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Meanwhile they were progressing famously, and John Bunsby was in high hope.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: At a less advanced season of the year the typhoon, according to a famous meteorologist, would have passed away like a luminous cascade of electric flame; but in the winter equinox it was to be feared that it would burst upon them with great violence.

events.text_segment:
Meanwhile they were progressing famously, and John Bunsby was in high hope. He several times assured Mr. Fogg that they would reach Shanghai in time; to which that gentleman responded that he counted upon it. The crew set to work in good earnest, inspired by the reward to be gained. There was not a sheet which was not tightened, not a sail which was not vigorously hoisted; not a lurch could be charged to the man at the helm. They worked as desperately as if they were contesting in a Royal yacht regatta.
By evening, the log showed that two hundred and twenty miles had been accomplished from Hong Kong, and Mr. Fogg might hope that he would be able to reach Yokohama without recording any delay in his journal; in which case, the many misadventures which had overtaken him since he left London would not seriously affect his journey.
The “Tankadere” entered the Straits of Fo-Kien, which separate the island of Formosa from the Chinese coast, in the small hours of the night, and crossed the Tropic of Cancer. The sea was very rough in the straits, full of eddies formed by the counter-currents, and the chopping waves broke her course, whilst it became very difficult to stand on deck.
At daybreak the wind began to blow hard again, and the heavens seemed to predict a gale. The barometer announced a speedy change, the mercury rising and falling capriciously; the sea also, in the south-east, raised long surges which indicated a tempest. The sun had set the evening before in a red mist, in the midst of the phosphorescent scintillations of the ocean.
John Bunsby long examined the threatening aspect of the heavens, muttering indistinctly between his teeth. At last he said in a low voice to Mr. Fogg, “Shall I speak out to your honour?”
“Of course.”
“Well, we are going to have a squall.”
“Is the wind north or south?” asked Mr. Fogg quietly.
“South. Look! a typhoon is coming up.”
“Glad it’s a typhoon from the south, for it will carry us forward.”
“Oh, if you take it that way,” said John Bunsby, “I’ve nothing more to say.” John Bunsby’s suspicions were confirmed. At a less advanced season of the year the typhoon, according to a famous meteorologist, would have passed away like a luminous cascade of electric flame; but in the winter equinox it was to be feared that it would burst upon them with great violence.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Meanwhile they were progressing famously, and John Bunsby was in high hope. He calculated that they would reach Shanghai in good season, for the wind was favourable, and the sea not very rough. "To Shanghai in good season," repeated Phileas Fogg, placidly, "is to-day the 11th of November, and we ought to reach it to-morrow. I shall even have twenty-four hours to spare." "Well, sir," said Bunsby, "let's not crow before we're out of the woods. The fact is, we are not yet there." At noon the schooner's position was recorded as two hundred and twenty miles from Hong Kong. An excellent run, and Phileas Fogg had reason to hope that he was not destined to encounter the typhoon. He had faced the monsoon with success, but the typhoon was still to be apprehended. And, in fact, during the night, the boat entered the Straits of Fo-Kien, which separate the island of Formosa from the Chinese coast, and are always greatly disturbed by eddies and currents. The sea was very heavy, and the wind blew a gale, sometimes from the north-west, sometimes from the north-east. The Tankadere rolled fearfully, and the crew had difficulty in working the sails. At daybreak the wind nearly became a hurricane, and there were fearful signs. The barometer had fallen to twenty-nine inches, and indicated the approach of an atmospheric perturbation of great violence. The heavens were in a frightful condition, and it seemed as if the storm were brewing in the depths of the horizon. The previous sunset had been covered with a red mist, and the sea was phosphorescent, and the swell of the ocean very heavy. "Shall we have the typhoon, Captain?" asked Phileas Fogg, quietly, of John Bunsby. "Well, sir," responded Bunsby, "I hope we can get through it. The wind is south-east." "A southern wind, you mean, to carry us forward?" "Yes, sir; but in the case of a typhoon, the wind often shifts suddenly, and with such violence that-" "Let it shift," said Mr. Fogg. "Provided it pushes us along." John Bunsby did not like to admit that Mr. Fogg was right, for in such weather a shifting of the wind was dangerous. However, he saw that his employer was calm and did not appear disturbed by the danger, so he yielded to his fate. The crew worked with a will, despite the risks, and the Tankadere held her own bravely. All hands were on deck, keeping a sharp lookout, and every stitch of canvas was set. It was a hard night, but they passed through it safely. By the next morning, the weather began to improve. The wind moderated, and the sea went down. Phileas Fogg was pleased with the speed of the boat, and still hoped to reach Shanghai on the 12th, as he had planned.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_2.text: Meanwhile they were progressing famously, and John Bunsby was in high hope. He calculated that they would reach Shanghai in good season, for the wind was favourable, and the sea not very rough. "To Shanghai in good season," said Mr. Fogg, placidly. The crew were all in the best possible humour, and worked with a will. The reward promised by Mr. Fogg acted as a powerful stimulant. They tightened the sheets, hoisted the sails, and worked the pumps with a zeal that would have done credit to a yacht's crew in a regatta. By evening, the Tankadere had made two hundred and twenty miles from Hong Kong, and Mr. Fogg had reason to hope that he was not destined to encounter the typhoon. He had faced the monsoon with success, but the typhoon was still to be apprehended. And, in fact, during the night, the boat entered the Straits of Fo-Kien, which separate the island of Formosa from the Chinese coast, and are always greatly disturbed by eddies and currents. The sea was very heavy, and the wind blew a gale, sometimes from the north-west, sometimes from the north-east. The Tankadere rolled fearfully, and the crew had difficulty in working the sails and in standing on deck. At daybreak the wind nearly became a hurricane, and there were fearful signs. The barometer had fallen to twenty-nine inches, and indicated the approach of an atmospheric perturbation of great violence. The heavens were in a frightful condition, and it seemed as if the storm were brewing in the depths of the horizon. The previous sunset had been covered with a red mist, and the sea was phosphorescent, and the swell of the ocean very heavy. "A squall is coming on," said John Bunsby. "It is a typhoon." "Let it come on," said Mr. Fogg. "The wind is south-east." "A southern wind, you mean, to carry us forward?" "Yes, sir; but in the case of a typhoon, the wind often shifts suddenly, and with such violence that—" "Let it shift," said Mr. Fogg. "Provided it pushes us along." John Bunsby did not like to admit that Mr. Fogg was right, for in such weather a shifting of the wind was dangerous. However, he saw that his employer was calm and did not appear disturbed by the danger, so he yielded to his fate. A typhoon in winter is not so much to be dreaded as in summer; but it is still very dangerous, and the opinion of the celebrated meteorologist, M. Mohn, of Christiania, is that it is a phenomenon which should be carefully studied.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Meanwhile they were progressing famously, and John Bunsby was in high hope. The schooner, built for speed and handled by a master of the sea, cut through the waves with impressive agility. The northeast wind, which had been the source of so much anxiety and frustration in Hong Kong, now filled their sails perfectly, pushing the *Tankadère* steadily towards the Japanese coast. The sea was relatively calm, a stark contrast to the tumultuous conditions they had faced on the route to Hong Kong. Phileas Fogg sat on deck, impassive as ever, consulting his watch with mechanical regularity, seemingly as little affected by the motion of the small vessel as by the stationary comfort of his armchair at the Reform Club. Aouda, though still recovering from her recent ordeal, seemed invigorated by the fresh sea air and the promise of reaching a new shore. She often looked out at the vast expanse of the Pacific, occasionally exchanging a quiet word with Mr. Fogg or simply watching the porpoises play in the schooner's wake. Passepartout, relieved to be back on a moving ship after the brief, stressful interlude in Hong Kong, found himself enjoying the voyage. He conversed with Bunsby and his small crew, curious about their lives and the sea. Bunsby, a man of few words but profound nautical knowledge, would grunt his replies or point to a detail of the rigging or the horizon, his eyes constantly scanning the elements. He was clearly proud of his schooner and its performance, and he reassured Fogg that, barring unforeseen circumstances, they would make excellent time. The average speed maintained was well over nine knots, a respectable clip for a vessel of that size on such a long run. They left the countless islands and hidden dangers of the China Sea behind and ventured into the open Pacific, guided only by Bunsby's charts and the stars. The days were long and filled with the rhythmic sound of the waves against the hull and the wind in the sails. At night, under a sky thick with stars, the schooner felt like a tiny speck in an immense universe, yet it carried the fate of Phileas Fogg's colossal wager. Each mile gained was a step closer to Yokohama, then America, and finally, London. Bunsby calculated their position meticulously each day, and his estimates consistently confirmed their good progress. The hope that filled the captain was contagious, and even Fogg, though he showed no outward sign, must have felt the tide turning in his favour. The crucial delay in Hong Kong seemed less disastrous with each successful hour of sailing. The possibility of still making the connection in Yokohama, which had appeared so slim just days before, now began to seem like a genuine probability. The voyage became a race against time, measured not in hours or days, but in the precise coordinates traced across the charts. The determination of Fogg, the loyalty of Passepartout, the gentle presence of Aouda, and the skill of John Bunsby combined to make the small schooner a vessel of destiny, speeding across the world's largest ocean.

events.title: Battling the Typhoon's Fury
detailed_summary: The pilot takes immediate storm precautions: reefing sails, removing poles, and positioning the crew at the bows.
A small, strong triangular storm-jib is hoisted to maintain some control.
Bunsby advises passengers to go below, but Fogg, Fix, and Aouda refuse, disliking the confinement and preferring to stay on deck despite the danger.
Around 8 o'clock, the storm hits with intense rain and wind, tossing the 'Tankadere' like a feather at incredible speed.
The boat is driven northward all day by monstrous waves, managing to keep pace with them.
It narrowly avoids being swamped multiple times due to the pilot's skillful maneuvering.
The passengers are frequently soaked by spray but endure it; Fix is inwardly frustrated, Aouda observes Fogg's calmness with admiration, and Fogg remains unfazed, treating the typhoon as expected.
Towards evening, the wind shifts to the north-west, causing the boat to roll violently in the wave troughs.
As darkness falls, the storm intensifies further, filling Bunsby with dread.
After consulting his crew, Bunsby suggests to Fogg that they should seek shelter in a coastal port.
Fogg agrees with the idea of heading to a port.
When Bunsby asks which port, Fogg calmly and resolutely insists on continuing towards their original destination: Shanghai.
The pilot is initially stunned by Fogg's determination but ultimately agrees, directing the 'Tankadere' back onto its northward course despite the severe conditions.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The pilot took his precautions in advance.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So the “Tankadere” kept steadily on her northward track.

events.text_segment:
The pilot took his precautions in advance. He reefed all sail, the pole-masts were dispensed with; all hands went forward to the bows. A single triangular sail, of strong canvas, was hoisted as a storm-jib, so as to hold the wind from behind. Then they waited.
John Bunsby had requested his passengers to go below; but this imprisonment in so narrow a space, with little air, and the boat bouncing in the gale, was far from pleasant. Neither Mr. Fogg, Fix, nor Aouda consented to leave the deck.
The storm of rain and wind descended upon them towards eight o’clock. With but its bit of sail, the “Tankadere” was lifted like a feather by a wind, an idea of whose violence can scarcely be given. To compare her speed to four times that of a locomotive going on full steam would be below the truth.
The boat scudded thus northward during the whole day, borne on by monstrous waves, preserving always, fortunately, a speed equal to theirs. Twenty times she seemed almost to be submerged by these mountains of water which rose behind her; but the adroit management of the pilot saved her. The passengers were often bathed in spray, but they submitted to it philosophically. Fix cursed it, no doubt; but Aouda, with her eyes fastened upon her protector, whose coolness amazed her, showed herself worthy of him, and bravely weathered the storm. As for Phileas Fogg, it seemed just as if the typhoon were a part of his programme.
Up to this time the “Tankadere” had always held her course to the north; but towards evening the wind, veering three quarters, bore down from the north-west. The boat, now lying in the trough of the waves, shook and rolled terribly; the sea struck her with fearful violence. At night the tempest increased in violence. John Bunsby saw the approach of darkness and the rising of the storm with dark misgivings. He thought awhile, and then asked his crew if it was not time to slacken speed. After a consultation he approached Mr. Fogg, and said, “I think, your honour, that we should do well to make for one of the ports on the coast.”
“I think so too.”
“Ah!” said the pilot. “But which one?”
“I know of but one,” returned Mr. Fogg tranquilly.
“And that is—”
“Shanghai.”
The pilot, at first, did not seem to comprehend; he could scarcely realise so much determination and tenacity. Then he cried, “Well—yes! Your honour is right. To Shanghai!”
So the “Tankadere” kept steadily on her northward track.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The pilot took his precautions in advance. All the sails were reefed, and the poles were removed from the masts and the bowsprit. The hatchways were carefully closed. The crew, previously reduced to four men, went into the interior of the boat. The sheet of the jib was carefully fastened, and a double rudder-band was provided. All these operations were skilfully and rapidly executed. About one o’clock, rain began to fall, and the wind, which blew thus far from the north-west, went round to the north, and blew hard. This, however, was a trifle. But the wind rapidly grew into a gale, which soon developed into a hurricane, and between two and three, the Tankadere was completely dismasted. Luckily, the cargo was not a heavy one, and the boat was furnished with ballast, which with the lightness of its framework, enabled it to ride the waves. A sheet of the triangular sail was hoisted on the bowsprit, and with this it made way. The boat could not stand it with a whole sail, but with the jib, it held its own against the waves, and sometimes went through them. They were often dashed upon the deck, sweeping over it with great force, but the vessel always righted itself. The passengers were often drenched, but they bore it gallantly. Fix cursed the typhoon inwardly, but put on a cheerful countenance. Aouda watched Mr Fogg with admiration, and pressed his hand from time to time. As for Mr Fogg, he did not seem to notice the storm. He looked upon it as an incident of the journey, which he had foreseen. Fix had reason to be afraid. The storm was growing worse and worse. Towards evening, the wind went round to the north-east, and the sea became very high. The boat tossed and rolled fearfully. Bunsby was uneasy, and consulted his crew, who shared his fears. He then went to Mr Fogg and said, "Sir, we are in a bad way. The storm is increasing, and we are driven to the north. If we go on, we shall be lost. I think we ought to put in somewhere." "I think so too," said Mr Fogg. "Where shall we put in?" asked the pilot. "Shanghai," said Mr Fogg. Bunsby was thunderstruck. "Shanghai!" he cried. "Yes, Shanghai," said Mr Fogg, calmly. "But, sir, Shanghai is two hundred miles from here." "Two hundred miles?" said Mr Fogg. "Yes, sir," said Bunsby. "Then," said Mr Fogg, "we must make two hundred miles." Bunsby looked at Mr Fogg for a moment. He saw that he was resolved to go on. "Very well, sir," he said. "We will go on." The pilot went back to his post, and directed the Tankadere to the north-east, towards Shanghai.

This was enough to hold the wind, and to keep the boat from being tossed about by the waves. The pilot advised the passengers to go below; but Phileas Fogg, Fix, and Aouda preferred to remain on deck, not caring to be shut up in the cabin. At about eight o'clock the storm burst upon them with frightful violence. It was a typhoon. The rain fell in torrents, and the wind blew with hurricane force, coming from the north-west, and driving the Tankadere with a speed equal to that of a locomotive. If she had had all her sails set, she would have been carried away. But the little jib held her to the wind, and she kept on her course, keeping pace with the waves. The boat was often buried in the spray, but she always rose again. The passengers were often drenched, but they bore it patiently. Fix cursed the typhoon inwardly, but put on a cheerful countenance. Aouda watched Mr Fogg with admiration, and pressed his hand from time to time. As for Mr Fogg, he did not seem to notice the storm. He looked upon it as an incident of the journey, which he had foreseen. Towards evening, the wind veered three quarters, and the sea became very high. "I think so too," said Mr Fogg. "Where shall we put in?" asked the pilot. "Shanghai," said Mr Fogg. Bunsby was thunderstruck. He did not know what to say. He looked at Mr Fogg, who was as calm as ever. "Shanghai!" he cried. "Yes, Shanghai," said Mr Fogg. "But, sir, Shanghai is two hundred miles from here." "Two hundred miles?" said Mr Fogg. "Yes, sir," said Bunsby. "Then," said Mr Fogg, "we must make two hundred miles." Bunsby looked at Mr Fogg for a moment. He saw that he was resolved to go on. "Very well, sir," he said. "We will go on." The pilot went back to his post, and directed the Tankadere to the north, towards Shanghai.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_2.text: The pilot took his precautions in advance. All the sails were reefed, the poles removed from the masts and the bowsprit, and the crew were stationed at the bows. A small, strong triangular sail, the storm-jib, was hoisted at the bowsprit. The pilot advised the passengers to go below; but Phileas Fogg, Fix, and Aouda preferred to remain on deck, not caring to be shut up in the cabin. At about eight o'clock the storm burst upon them with frightful violence. It was a typhoon. The rain fell in torrents, and the wind blew with hurricane force, coming from the north-west, and driving the Tankadere with a speed equal to that of a locomotive, and even more. If she had had all her sails set, she would have been carried away. But the little jib held her to the wind, and she kept on her course, keeping pace with the waves. The boat was often buried in the spray, but she always rose again. Several times she was nearly submerged, but the pilot's skill saved her. The passengers were often drenched, but they bore it patiently. Fix cursed the typhoon inwardly, Aouda watched Mr Fogg with admiration, and Mr Fogg, as calm as ever, did not seem to notice the storm. He looked upon it as an incident of the journey, which he had foreseen. Towards evening, the wind veered three quarters, and the sea became very high. The boat lay in the trough of the waves, and rolled fearfully. As darkness came on, the storm increased in violence. Bunsby was uneasy, and consulted his crew, who shared his fears. He then went to Mr Fogg and said, "Sir, we are in a bad way. The storm is increasing, and we are driven to the north. If we go on, we shall be lost. I think we ought to put in somewhere." "I think so too," said Mr Fogg. "Where shall we put in?" asked the pilot. "Shanghai," said Mr Fogg. Bunsby was thunderstruck. He did not know what to say. He looked at Mr Fogg, who was as calm as ever. "Shanghai!" he cried. "Yes, Shanghai," said Mr Fogg. Bunsby looked at Mr Fogg for a moment. He saw that he was resolved to go on. "Very well, sir," he said. "We will go on." The pilot went back to his post, and directed the Tankadere to the north, towards Shanghai.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The pilot took his precautions in advance. Navigating the Hooghly River, a notoriously tricky waterway leading from Calcutta to the vastness of the Bay of Bengal, demanded meticulous planning and an intimate knowledge of its ever-shifting currents and sandbars. Captain Balthazar, a man whose weathered face seemed etched with the wisdom of a thousand tidal shifts, stood on the bridge, his gaze sweeping across the complex confluence of river traffic – steamships, dhows, fishing boats, all vying for passage. He checked his charts again, even though he knew every depth and buoy marker by heart. The monsoon season, though not at its peak, still left the weather unpredictable; dark clouds loomed on the horizon, a constant reminder of the potential for sudden squalls that could churn the bay into a tempest in minutes. He consulted the tide tables, calculating the optimal window for departure, factoring in the draft of the 'Rangoon,' the steamer he was piloting out to the open sea this morning. A slight delay had already occurred due to loading issues downriver, and the passengers, particularly the Englishman Mr. Phileas Fogg, were known to be under considerable time pressure. Captain Balthazar felt the weight of responsibility; not just for the safety of the ship and its crew, but for ensuring a swift, unimpeded journey that would keep the steamer on schedule. He conversed briefly with the 'Rangoon's' own captain, confirming the route and expected conditions once they cleared the river mouth. The engines below deck hummed with readiness, the deckhands were coiled ropes and secured cargo, and a palpable sense of anticipation hung in the humid air. Balthazar felt the subtle sway of the ship as the tide began to strengthen. He ordered the final moorings to be cast off, his voice calm but firm, cutting through the clamour of the port. This stretch of river, he knew, was often more perilous than the open ocean, requiring unwavering concentration until the ship finally met the boundless, less forgiving expanse of the Bay of Bengal. Every sounding, every course correction, every glance at the compass was a measured step in the intricate dance of guiding the vessel safely from the bustling port to the freedom of the sea lane, a vital leg of a journey whose stakes, for at least one passenger on board, were incredibly high.

events.title: Surviving the Night and Storm Abates
detailed_summary: The night is horrific, and the boat survives only through the crew's constant vigilance and near-miraculous escapes from foundering.
Aouda is exhausted but remains stoic, receiving protection from Fogg against the waves multiple times.
Daylight reveals the tempest continuing unabated, but the wind shifts back to the south-east, which is advantageous.
The 'Tankadere' resumes its rapid progress, though battered by crossing waves.
They spot the coast occasionally through mist but see no other ships.
Around noon, the storm begins to show signs of calming, which become more apparent as the sun sets.
The intense but brief storm passes, allowing the exhausted passengers to eat and rest.
The night becomes relatively calm, allowing more sails to be hoisted, increasing the boat's speed.
By the next morning's dawn, they sight the coast, and Bunsby estimates they are less than 100 miles from Shanghai.
They have only one day left to cover the remaining distance to catch the Yokohama steamer that evening.
The time lost during the storm means they are further behind schedule than they would have been.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The night was really terrible; it would be a miracle if the craft did not founder.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Had there been no storm, during which several hours were lost, they would be at this moment within thirty miles of their destination.

events.text_segment:
The night was really terrible; it would be a miracle if the craft did not founder. Twice it could have been all over with her if the crew had not been constantly on the watch. Aouda was exhausted, but did not utter a complaint. More than once Mr. Fogg rushed to protect her from the violence of the waves.
Day reappeared. The tempest still raged with undiminished fury; but the wind now returned to the south-east. It was a favourable change, and the “Tankadere” again bounded forward on this mountainous sea, though the waves crossed each other, and imparted shocks and counter-shocks which would have crushed a craft less solidly built. From time to time the coast was visible through the broken mist, but no vessel was in sight. The “Tankadere” was alone upon the sea.
There were some signs of a calm at noon, and these became more distinct as the sun descended toward the horizon. The tempest had been as brief as terrific. The passengers, thoroughly exhausted, could now eat a little, and take some repose.
The night was comparatively quiet. Some of the sails were again hoisted, and the speed of the boat was very good. The next morning at dawn they espied the coast, and John Bunsby was able to assert that they were not one hundred miles from Shanghai. A hundred miles, and only one day to traverse them! That very evening Mr. Fogg was due at Shanghai, if he did not wish to miss the steamer to Yokohama. Had there been no storm, during which several hours were lost, they would be at this moment within thirty miles of their destination.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The night was really terrible; it would be a miracle if the craft did not founder. The wind blew a hurricane, and there was a heavy sea. The “Tankadere,” stripped nearly to her mast, was tossed about like a feather. The strain upon her timbers was frightful. It seemed as if they must part asunder. John Bunsby held his own, however, and with body bent double, eye fixed, and hand fast, stood firm at the helm. Aouda, enervated by fatigue, lay upon the settee in the cabin. Phileas Fogg sat beside her, and held her hand. He encouraged her with a calm voice, and sheltered her from the waves which broke over the deck. In the morning, the situation was unchanged. The wind howled, and the sea was violently agitated. The cutter was not able to hold her course, and Bunsby steered her half-so as to offer the least possible hold to the waves. This was a perilous situation, and they owed their safety only to the sturdy build of the craft, and the consummate skill of the master. At noon, the storm abated, and the wind shifted to the south-east. It was a favourable change, and the “Tankadere” resumed her course at a speed of twelve miles an hour. At four o'clock, the captain sighted the coast of China. In the evening, the wind fell almost to a calm, and the sea became smooth. Aouda revived, and was able to eat. The passengers and crew were all greatly relieved. At ten o'clock, the “Tankadere” was off the port of Shanghai. The distance was about a hundred miles, and they had but twelve hours to accomplish it if they were to catch the steamer for Yokohama. They had lost a whole day.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The night was really terrible; it would be a miracle if the craft did not founder. The waves rose like moving mountains in the inky blackness, crashing down upon the deck with a deafening roar. The wind shrieked through the rigging, tearing at the sails which, if they had not been prudently furled, would have been ripped to shreds. Every timber of the steamship *Henrietta* groaned in protest, a symphony of stressed wood and metal against the fury of the storm. Water poured over the bulwarks, swamping the deck, requiring constant bailing by the weary crew. Phileas Fogg remained, as ever, imperturbable. He sat in the cabin, occasionally consulting his watch, his face showing no trace of the anxiety that gripped his companions. Passepartout, however, was a study in abject terror. He clung to whatever was fixed, his eyes wide with fright, convinced that each tremendous lurch of the vessel would be their last. Poor Aouda, though showing more composure than the servant, was clearly apprehensive, her gaze fixed on Fogg, seeking reassurance from his unshakeable calm. Captain Speedy, usually gruff and defiant, was pacing the bridge, his face grim as he directed the helmsman and assessed the damage. The small vessel was utterly at the mercy of the elements, tossed about like a cork on the enraged sea. For hours, the ordeal continued, the darkness only amplifying the terror, the spray stinging their faces even within the relative shelter of the cabin. They seemed suspended between the raging abyss below and the tumultuous sky above, the dawn appearing a distant, perhaps unattainable, hope. Yet, through it all, the *Henrietta* stubbornly fought on, battling the ocean's wrath with desperate resilience, a testament to the builder's skill and the sheer force of will steering her through the tempest.

events.title: Race Against Time and Last-Minute Signal
detailed_summary: The wind progressively weakens, and the sea calms down.
All available sails are hoisted to maximize speed.
By noon, they are 45 miles from Shanghai with only six hours remaining.
Concern grows among everyone (except Fogg) about whether they can make it in time, as an average speed of nine miles per hour is needed while the wind continues to drop.
The breeze becomes light and inconsistent, coming from the coast.
Despite the weak wind, the lightweight 'Tankadere' with its large sails manages to catch the gusts effectively, aided by currents.
By 6 o'clock, Bunsby finds they are only ten miles from the river mouth, but Shanghai itself is another twelve miles upstream.
At 7 o'clock, they are still three miles short of Shanghai.
The pilot expresses frustration, fearing he will lose the substantial reward.
He observes Fogg, who remains completely calm despite his entire fortune being at risk.
Just then, the smoke plume of the American steamer bound for Yokohama is seen departing on schedule.
Bunsby reacts with despair, but Fogg calmly orders him to signal the ship.
A small cannon used for fog signals is prepared.
Before firing, Fogg instructs them to hoist their flag at half-mast as a distress signal, hoping the steamer will alter course to assist.
Fogg then commands them to fire the cannon.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The wind grew decidedly calmer, and happily the sea fell with it.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And the booming of the little cannon resounded in the air.

events.text_segment:
The wind grew decidedly calmer, and happily the sea fell with it. All sails were now hoisted, and at noon the “Tankadere” was within forty-five miles of Shanghai. There remained yet six hours in which to accomplish that distance. All on board feared that it could not be done, and every one—Phileas Fogg, no doubt, excepted—felt his heart beat with impatience. The boat must keep up an average of nine miles an hour, and the wind was becoming calmer every moment! It was a capricious breeze, coming from the coast, and after it passed the sea became smooth. Still, the “Tankadere” was so light, and her fine sails caught the fickle zephyrs so well, that, with the aid of the currents John Bunsby found himself at six o’clock not more than ten miles from the mouth of Shanghai River. Shanghai itself is situated at least twelve miles up the stream. At seven they were still three miles from Shanghai. The pilot swore an angry oath; the reward of two hundred pounds was evidently on the point of escaping him. He looked at Mr. Fogg. Mr. Fogg was perfectly tranquil; and yet his whole fortune was at this moment at stake.
At this moment, also, a long black funnel, crowned with wreaths of smoke, appeared on the edge of the waters. It was the American steamer, leaving for Yokohama at the appointed time.
“Confound her!” cried John Bunsby, pushing back the rudder with a desperate jerk.
“Signal her!” said Phileas Fogg quietly.
A small brass cannon stood on the forward deck of the “Tankadere,” for making signals in the fogs. It was loaded to the muzzle; but just as the pilot was about to apply a red-hot coal to the touchhole, Mr. Fogg said, “Hoist your flag!”
The flag was run up at half-mast, and, this being the signal of distress, it was hoped that the American steamer, perceiving it, would change her course a little, so as to succour the pilot-boat.
“Fire!” said Mr. Fogg. And the booming of the little cannon resounded in the air.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The wind grew decidedly calmer, and happily the sea fell with it. All sails were set, and the Tankadere merrily ploughed through the waves, which were now much less boisterous. By a little past noon, the boat was forty-five miles from Shanghai. An excellent position, and, if the wind held, the steamer would reach the port by six o’clock. All were visibly sanguine. Mr. Fogg, to be sure, did not betray the least excitement; but Aouda confessed to the pilot more hope than she had ever felt before. As for Passepartout, he fairly glowed with pleasure, and chatted with the pilot, told him the history of Mr. Fogg’s journey, and congratulated him heartily on the great reward he was about to receive. The pilot Bunsby listened with a placid smile, and could not forbear now and then shaking his head with an air of doubt. And in fact, the wind, which had hitherto been in the south-east, and had been driving them forward at a most desirable speed, now veered and became an uncertain breeze from the south-west. The currents, too, were adverse, and instead of aiding the Tankadere, as was expected, they hindered her. It became necessary to resort to tacking, which lengthened the way; the coast, moreover, was indented with capes, which it was necessary to double, and the breeze as it came from the land, was broken by the obstacles upon the shore, and was besides exceedingly irregular. The Tankadere was a light craft, it is true, and with her great sails caught all the fitful gusts; but at eight o’clock, Bunsby reckoned that he had made but nine miles in three hours. At this rate, Mr. Fogg would not reach Shanghai until after midnight, and the steamer to Yokohama would consequently be gone. The worthy pilot grew anxious. Aouda was not less disturbed, though she evinced not her fear. Passepartout was beside himself, and wanted to help the sailors. He was on the point of addressing the pilot, when Mr. Fogg, cutting him short, requested Bunsby to be good enough to say how many miles he still had to make to reach Shanghai. The pilot calculated, and replied: “Twenty-two miles, Mr. Fogg.” “And we have been three hours doing nine.” “Yes, sir. And if this continues, we shall not get to Shanghai tomorrow afternoon.” “There is nothing to do but keep on,” said Mr. Fogg, quietly. The wind did not increase, and the Tankadere was not abundantly provided with auxiliary power, and there was no remedy. She was still twenty-two miles from Shanghai, when the Yokohama steamer left the port at the regular hour, that is, at seven in the evening. “There she goes!” cried Bunsby, giving a wild screech, and unfurling the signals to call attention to the Tankadere. “Boom!” went the little cannon, but the steamer, quickly as she was going, was already out of range. “Cut the halyards!” cried John Bunsby, in a rage. “No,” said Mr. Fogg, placidly. “Let them wave the flag at half-mast. That is a sign of distress. Perhaps the steamer will come back.” Bunsby, though beside himself with rage, hoisted the flag at half-mast. It was well known that Mr. Fogg was a gentleman of great resources. Perhaps the steamer would come back. At any rate, the cannon was loaded again, and fired, but with no more success than before.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The wind grew decidedly calmer, and happily the sea fell with it. For days, the *General Grant* had wrestled with a formidable gale off the coasts of Japan, waves like moving mountains assaulting her sides, the deck constantly awash with icy spray. Passengers had been confined below, battling nausea and the ship's violent pitching. But now, the fury had abated. The wind, which had shrieked through the rigging, softened to a gentle sigh. The enormous swells flattened into manageable undulations. The ship's motion became a smooth, rhythmic rise and fall. A palpable sense of relief spread through the vessel. Passepartout, who had spent the worst of the storm green-faced and miserable, ventured onto the deck, blinking in the returning sunlight. Aouda showed her gratitude for the cessation of the violent tossing. Mr. Fogg, ever unperturbed by the elements, merely consulted his watch and his log, noting the precise moment the speed began to improve. The crew, weary from their battle with the storm, worked with renewed vigour. The sails, which had been furled or reefed down, could be set to their full extent, catching the favourable breeze. The *General Grant* surged forward with a steadier, more confident stride across the vast Pacific. The sky cleared to a brilliant blue, the horizon reappeared, sharp and distinct. The oppressive grey of the storm clouds was replaced by scattered white puffballs. Gulls, which had vanished during the tempest, reappeared, circling the ship. This return to fair weather was more than just comfort; it was a blessing for their tight schedule. Every knot gained now meant a better chance of reaching San Francisco on time to catch the train east. Passepartout breathed deeply of the fresh, salty air, a faint smile replacing his recent grimace. America was still many days away, but the worst of the Pacific seemed, at least for the moment, behind them. The journey felt possible again.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXII. IN WHICH PASSEPARTOUT FINDS OUT THAT, EVEN AT THE ANTIPODES, IT IS CONVENIENT TO HAVE SOME MONEY IN ONE’S POCKET

events.title: Passepartout Awakens Alone on the Carnatic
detailed_summary: The steamship 'Carnatic' leaves Hong Kong for Japan precisely on schedule, carrying cargo and passengers, but Phileas Fogg's reserved cabins remain empty.
The following day, Passepartout appears on deck looking dazed, unsteady, and dishevelled.
A flashback explains that after Fix departed the opium den, waiters carried the unconscious Passepartout to a bed designated for smokers.
Three hours later, haunted by his duty, Passepartout managed to wake up, fighting the lingering effects of the drug.
Driven by the need to fulfill his responsibilities, he left the opium den.
He stumbled through the streets, relying on walls for support, repeatedly falling and getting up, instinctively calling out the name of the ship, 'Carnatic'.
Reaching the quay just as the steamer was about to leave, Passepartout rushed onto the plank and collapsed unconscious on the deck.
Sailors, apparently familiar with such incidents, carried him down to the second cabin.
Passepartout did not fully awaken until the ship was 150 miles away from the Chinese coast.
Finding himself on the deck the next morning, he breathes in the refreshing sea air.
The clean air helps to clear his mind, allowing him to slowly piece together the previous evening's events: Fix's confession and his time in the opium den.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The “Carnatic,” setting sail from Hong Kong at half-past six on the 7th of November, directed her course at full steam towards Japan.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The opium-house.

events.text_segment:
The “Carnatic,” setting sail from Hong Kong at half-past six on the 7th of November, directed her course at full steam towards Japan. She carried a large cargo and a well-filled cabin of passengers. Two state-rooms in the rear were, however, unoccupied—those which had been engaged by Phileas Fogg.
The next day a passenger with a half-stupefied eye, staggering gait, and disordered hair, was seen to emerge from the second cabin, and to totter to a seat on deck.
It was Passepartout; and what had happened to him was as follows: Shortly after Fix left the opium den, two waiters had lifted the unconscious Passepartout, and had carried him to the bed reserved for the smokers. Three hours later, pursued even in his dreams by a fixed idea, the poor fellow awoke, and struggled against the stupefying influence of the narcotic. The thought of a duty unfulfilled shook off his torpor, and he hurried from the abode of drunkenness. Staggering and holding himself up by keeping against the walls, falling down and creeping up again, and irresistibly impelled by a kind of instinct, he kept crying out, “The ‘Carnatic!’ the ‘Carnatic!’”
The steamer lay puffing alongside the quay, on the point of starting. Passepartout had but few steps to go; and, rushing upon the plank, he crossed it, and fell unconscious on the deck, just as the “Carnatic” was moving off. Several sailors, who were evidently accustomed to this sort of scene, carried the poor Frenchman down into the second cabin, and Passepartout did not wake until they were one hundred and fifty miles away from China. Thus he found himself the next morning on the deck of the “Carnatic,” and eagerly inhaling the exhilarating sea-breeze. The pure air sobered him. He began to collect his sense, which he found a difficult task; but at last he recalled the events of the evening before, Fix’s revelation, and the opium-house.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The “Carnatic,” setting sail from Hong Kong at half-past six on the 7th of November, directed her course at full steam towards Japan. She carried a full cargo and a complete list of passengers. Phileas Fogg and Sir Francis Cromarty were, it is true, enrolled on the list of passengers, but their cabins remained empty. The next day, a passenger, the worse for drink or opium, with a bewildered look, tottering, and with his hair in disorder, was seen to stagger about the deck. He was Passepartout. What had happened to him was as follows: Shortly after Fix left the opium den, two waiters carried the unconscious Passepartout to the bed reserved for the smokers. Three hours later, haunted by the thought of his duty, Passepartout awoke, and struggled against the stupefying influence of the drug. The thought of the “Carnatic,” of his master, of the journey so near its fatal termination, gave him energy. He arose in the midst of the smokers, who were just falling into or coming out of the embrace of sleep. He steadied himself, his head still giddy, and passed into the street, crying out, “The ‘Carnatic’! the ‘Carnatic’!” The steamer was there, at the quay, ready to set sail. Passepartout rushed upon the plank, crossed it, and fell unconscious on the deck, just as the “Carnatic” was moving off. The sailors, accustomed to this sort of scene, carried the poor fellow down to the second cabin, and Passepartout did not wake until he was one hundred and fifty miles out at sea, off the coast of China. The next morning, on the 8th of November, Passepartout found himself on the deck, breathing in the fresh sea air. The lively breeze refreshed his mind and enabled him to some degree to collect his thoughts, which is what he proceeded to do. He remembered Fix, and his confession of his being a detective, and the trap which he had laid for him and which he had himself fallen into; for the opium den, entered for the purpose of escaping the detective, had prevented his warning his master.
