LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The “Carnatic,” setting sail from Hong Kong at half-past six on the 7th of November, directed her course at full steam towards Japan. She had on board a throng of passengers, among whom was none that interested the reader more than poor Passepartout, though it must be confessed he was not in a state to be greatly interested himself. Having been drugged by the detective Fix the previous evening, he had slept soundly, missing the crucial rendezvous with his master, Mr. Fogg, and thus missing the intended earlier vessel that Fogg had to take. Passepartout awoke aboard the speeding steamer only to find his head swimming and his pockets empty, having been relieved of his watch and some money by Fix during his stupor. The dreadful realization dawned upon him: he was on the correct ship bound for Japan, but he was utterly alone, separated from the eccentric and punctual master whom he had sworn to serve and follow around the world. He was without resources, without a plan, and adrift in a foreign sea, speeding towards an unknown land. A profound despair seized his soul. Where in the world was Mr. Fogg? Had he left without him? How could he possibly continue the journey, or even survive, penniless, in a country whose language he did not speak and whose customs were alien? The long days at sea were torture, filled with anxiety and regret. Finally, after a voyage of several days, the shores of Japan appeared on the horizon. The Carnatic entered the harbour of Yokohama, and Passepartout disembarked, a solitary, forlorn figure amidst the bustling crowd, utterly penniless and lost.

events.title: Realization of Fogg's Absence and Fix's Treachery
detailed_summary: Passepartout berates himself for getting drunk and worries about his master's potential reaction.
He comforts himself with the thought that at least he didn't miss the ship, viewing this as paramount.
His thoughts turn to Fix; he hopes the detective is not on board and hasn't followed them as threatened.
He reaffirms his belief in Mr. Fogg's innocence regarding the bank robbery charge.
He considers whether he should reveal Fix's true purpose to Mr. Fogg.
He contemplates waiting until they return to London to share the information about the pursuing detective, perhaps turning it into a humorous anecdote.
He decides his immediate priority is to find Mr. Fogg and apologize for his state the previous night.
Passepartout gets up and searches the after-deck but doesn't find his master or Aouda.
He assumes Aouda is still resting and that Fogg might be playing cards.
He descends to the saloon, but Fogg isn't there either.
Passepartout asks the purser for the location of Mr. Fogg's cabin.
The purser states there is no passenger registered under the name Fogg.
Passepartout insists, describing his master and mentioning the young lady.
The purser firmly denies any young lady being on board and presents the passenger list as proof.
Passepartout examines the list and confirms his master's name is absent.
A sudden thought makes him ask if he is truly on the 'Carnatic' heading to Yokohama, which the purser confirms.
Though relieved he's on the correct ship, the terrible truth sinks in: his master is not aboard.
He collapses onto a seat, suddenly understanding everything.
He recalls the crucial detail about the earlier departure time, which he failed to relay to Fogg.
He accepts the blame for Fogg and Aouda missing the steamer.
He then assigns greater culpability to the treacherous Fix, who deliberately intoxicated him to separate him from Fogg and ensure Fogg was delayed in Hong Kong.
He fully grasps the detective's ploy and its consequences: Mr. Fogg is likely ruined, his wager lost, and he might even face arrest.
Distraught at this thought, Passepartout feels immense anger towards Fix and anticipates a future confrontation.

events.text_segment:
“It is evident,” said he to himself, “that I have been abominably drunk! What will Mr. Fogg say? At least I have not missed the steamer, which is the most important thing.”
Then, as Fix occurred to him: “As for that rascal, I hope we are well rid of him, and that he has not dared, as he proposed, to follow us on board the “Carnatic.” A detective on the track of Mr. Fogg, accused of robbing the Bank of England! Pshaw! Mr. Fogg is no more a robber than I am a murderer.”
Should he divulge Fix’s real errand to his master? Would it do to tell the part the detective was playing? Would it not be better to wait until Mr. Fogg reached London again, and then impart to him that an agent of the metropolitan police had been following him round the world, and have a good laugh over it? No doubt; at least, it was worth considering. The first thing to do was to find Mr. Fogg, and apologise for his singular behaviour.
Passepartout got up and proceeded, as well as he could with the rolling of the steamer, to the after-deck. He saw no one who resembled either his master or Aouda. “Good!” muttered he; “Aouda has not got up yet, and Mr. Fogg has probably found some partners at whist.”
He descended to the saloon. Mr. Fogg was not there. Passepartout had only, however, to ask the purser the number of his master’s state-room. The purser replied that he did not know any passenger by the name of Fogg.
“I beg your pardon,” said Passepartout persistently. “He is a tall gentleman, quiet, and not very talkative, and has with him a young lady—”
“There is no young lady on board,” interrupted the purser. “Here is a list of the passengers; you may see for yourself.”
Passepartout scanned the list, but his master’s name was not upon it. All at once an idea struck him.
“Ah! am I on the ‘Carnatic?’”
“Yes.”
“On the way to Yokohama?”
“Certainly.”
Passepartout had for an instant feared that he was on the wrong boat; but, though he was really on the “Carnatic,” his master was not there.
He fell thunderstruck on a seat. He saw it all now. He remembered that the time of sailing had been changed, that he should have informed his master of that fact, and that he had not done so. It was his fault, then, that Mr. Fogg and Aouda had missed the steamer. Yes, but it was still more the fault of the traitor who, in order to separate him from his master, and detain the latter at Hong Kong, had inveigled him into getting drunk! He now saw the detective’s trick; and at this moment Mr. Fogg was certainly ruined, his bet was lost, and he himself perhaps arrested and imprisoned! At this thought Passepartout tore his hair. Ah, if Fix ever came within his reach, what a settling of accounts there would be!

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“It is evident,” said he to himself, “that I have been abominably drunk! My confounded folly makes Mr. Fogg lose the steamer, the only one he could take! And all because I must go and drink gin, as if I hadn’t had enough rum, and that Swedish punch, and what not! It is lucky, at least, that I did not miss the boat!”

This said, he sprang to his feet, and his tottering limbs not yet having recovered their steadiness, he found himself standing in the open air, on the rear deck of the Carnatic.

The steamer was speeding at full steam, and the coast of China had already disappeared in the west. Passepartout proceeded to the fore part of the steamer, and found himself by the jib-boom. He was not at all surprised to find himself on board, though his waking was so sudden. A good servant caught in the act, was sure to be sent aboard by his master. This thought consoled him. He did not do himself the injustice of imagining that Mr. Fogg would discharge him or reprimand him. The phlegmatic gentleman would simply say, “Go,” and that would be all.

Now, in what part of the steamer was Mr. Fogg? Passepartout resolved to search for him, and went forward. He ascended the poop, and saw Aouda, who was sleeping in one of the deck cabins. Mr. Fogg was not there. He went to the saloon, and saw only passengers wrapped in their rugs. He descended to the second cabin, and found no one but officers of the vessel on duty. He went back on deck, and inquired of the purser, who was at his post in the grand saloon, how Mr. Fogg’s cabin could be found.

“Mr. Fogg?” said the purser; “I do not know any passenger of that name.”

“Excuse me, sir, it is a gentleman silent and very particular, accompanied by a young lady.”

“There is not in the steamer,” replied the purser, “a person answering to your description. Here is the list of passengers; you can examine it.”

Passepartout scanned the list, but the name of Fogg was not upon it. His eyes went from the first to the last name, but in vain.

Then a sudden idea struck him. “Why, I am at Hong Kong!” said he.

“No,” replied the purser; “we are out at sea.”

“I understand; but I am sure I sailed from Hong Kong?”

“Certainly; the Carnatic left Hong Kong yesterday, October 25th, at half-past six P.M.”

Passepartout did not know what to think. He remembered that he had gone to the opium-house, that he had drunk, that he had been put to bed, and that, on waking, he found himself on board the Carnatic. But Mr. Fogg and Aouda were not on board. This terrible truth struck him like a thunderbolt. It was clear that his master had missed the steamer. And whose fault was it?—his own, his fatal folly! He now understood it all. The Carnatic, instead of sailing for Yokohama the next morning, October 26th, had weighed anchor upon the evening of the 25th. And he, Passepartout, had not advised his master of this change! He remembered, too, that Fix had urged him to remain and drink gin with him. It was evidently for the purpose of separating him from his master. To delay Mr. Fogg’s departure from Hong Kong, and prevent his following the Carnatic, was clearly the detective’s design. Fogg was consequently ruined, seventy-nine days having passed since he set out, and of course his wager was lost! And Fix was here, and had only to arrest him! At this thought, Passepartout tore his hair. Ah! the villain Fix! he did not know the terrible vengeance that awaited him. When Passepartout should meet him, and he would certainly do so, he would not fail to make the detective repent the game he had played.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
“It is evident,” said he to himself, “that I have been abominably drunk! I must have gone to bed, and forgotten to tell my master that the Carnatic would sail at that hour! It is all my fault, and Fix’s too; but, at least, I am on board, which is the principal thing.”

He then began to think of Fix. “I hope he has not followed us on the Carnatic,” said he. “But, after all, what could I tell Mr. Fogg about him? That the detective was tracking him? Mr. Fogg knew that already. And that he had lent me his help in getting drunk? It is true that the fellow’s object was to separate me from my master, and prevent Mr. Fogg from leaving Hong Kong. But Mr. Fogg would have gone in spite of him, and would have been here by this time. At the worst, I can tell Mr. Fogg that the agent of police, whom he knew, was on board, and shall see what he thinks of the matter. But, no; perhaps it would be better not to say anything about it. If I were to tell him of Fix’s conduct, it would alarm him; and, besides, it would put him on the scent of this affair of the bank robbery, and he would perhaps think that the detective was on his track on that account. And, then, Mr. Fogg is so proud and self-contained that it is impossible to make him understand anything; and, with his ideas, he would perhaps think that the whole thing was a joke. I will wait till we get to London, and then I will tell him all. It will be a good joke to tell him how the detective followed him all round the world, and how I helped the detective to get drunk.”

While thus soliloquizing, he had reached the forward part of the steamer, and, looking over the side, he saw that the vessel was under full steam. “Good,” said he; “we are going at a good rate.”

He then went to the after part of the vessel, and looked about for Mr. Fogg and Aouda. He did not see them. “Mr. Fogg is probably in his cabin,” said he; “and as for the young lady, she is no doubt asleep.”

He went down to the saloon, and saw that it was full of passengers. He looked for Mr. Fogg, but did not see him. He then went to the cabins, and knocked at the door of the one which he supposed to be Mr. Fogg’s. No answer. He knocked again, but still no answer. He then opened the door, and saw that the cabin was empty. He went to the next cabin, and knocked, but no answer. He went to the next, and the next, and so on, till he had gone through all the cabins. They were all empty.

“This is very strange,” said he to himself. “Mr. Fogg is not in his cabin, nor is the young lady. Where can they be?”

He went back to the saloon, and asked the purser if he knew where Mr. Fogg’s cabin was.

“Mr. Fogg?” said the purser; “I do not know any passenger of that name.”

“Excuse me, sir,” said Passepartout; “he is a gentleman, very tall, with a fair complexion, and a light moustache. He is accompanied by a young lady.”

“There is no passenger answering to that description on board,” said the purser.

“But there must be,” said Passepartout; “he is Mr. Fogg, and he is going to Yokohama.”

“I tell you there is no such passenger on board,” said the purser. “Here is the list of passengers; you can examine it.”

Passepartout took the list, and examined it carefully. He went over it name by name, but the name of Fogg was not upon it. He looked again, but in vain.

Then a sudden idea struck him. “Why, I am at Hong Kong!” said he.

“No,” replied the purser; “we are out at sea.”

“I understand; but I am sure I sailed from Hong Kong?”

“Certainly; the Carnatic left Hong Kong yesterday, October 25th, at half-past six P.M.”

Passepartout did not know what to think. He remembered that he had gone to the opium-house, that he had drunk, that he had been put to bed, and that, on waking, he found himself on board the Carnatic. But Mr. Fogg and Aouda were not on board. This terrible truth struck him like a thunderbolt. It was clear that his master had missed the steamer. And whose fault was it?—his own, his fatal folly! He now understood it all. The Carnatic, instead of sailing for Yokohama the next morning, October 26th, had weighed anchor upon the evening of the 25th. And he, Passepartout, had not advised his master of this change! He remembered, too, that Fix had urged him to remain and drink gin with him. It was evidently for the purpose of separating him from his master. To delay Mr. Fogg’s departure from Hong Kong, and prevent his following the Carnatic, was clearly the detective’s design. Fogg was consequently ruined, seventy-nine days having passed since he set out, and of course his wager was lost! And Fix was here, and had only to arrest him! At this thought, Passepartout tore his hair. Ah! the villain Fix! he did not know the terrible vengeance that awaited him. When Passepartout should meet him, and he would certainly do so, he would not fail to make the detective repent the game he had played.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: “It is evident,” said he to himself, “that I have been abominably drunk! To miss the Carnatic! And at this hour!” He rose, dressed himself, and quitted the hotel. His brain was clear, but his rage was terrible, cold, and condensed. The ship had sailed four hours before. He was out of time, and he felt certain who was responsible. It was that detective, Fix! He had recognized him on the Mongolia, and knew instinctively that the man was following him. Now he understood: Fix had drugged him, incapacitating him just long enough to miss the connecting steamer, the one crucial link in his tight schedule. His plan, so meticulously constructed, had been shattered by the connivance of this agent of the law. Yet, Phileas Fogg was not a man given to outward displays of emotion. The cold fury that consumed him was hidden beneath his usual impassive mask. Time was lost, precious time, but he must retrieve it. His first thought was of Aouda. He returned to the hotel to find her. He found her awake, anxious, and ready. “We must find another means of passage,” he informed her, his voice betraying nothing of the turmoil within. “The Carnatic has sailed.” Aouda, who had implicitly placed her fate in his hands, did not question him. She simply gathered her things, ready to accompany him wherever he went. Fogg did not waste a second on recriminations or despair. His mind was already assessing the possibilities, calculating routes, and considering every available vessel in the harbour. Hong Kong was an important port, but finding a ship specifically bound for Yokohama, and one that would sail immediately, was not a simple matter. He spent the morning scouring the docks, visiting shipping offices, and questioning captains. Everywhere he met with disappointment. Ships were bound for various destinations, but none for Japan that would depart in time to keep him on schedule. The clock was ticking relentlessly. Each hour lost made the impossible task of winning his wager even more improbable. Yet, his determination did not waver. He refused to admit defeat. He even contemplated chartering a vessel, no matter the cost, but even private ships available for hire were scarce and unsuitable for the long Pacific crossing. Just when hope seemed at its lowest ebb, he learned of a small schooner, the Tankadere, a fast boat used for pilot services, that was due to sail that very evening for Shanghai. Shanghai was not Yokohama, but it was a step in the right direction. From Shanghai, perhaps he could find a ship bound for the American coast, skipping the Japan leg altogether, or at least find faster passage across the Pacific. It was a risky deviation, one that added uncertainty to his already precarious journey, but it was the only viable option. He quickly secured passage for himself and Aouda on the Tankadere. The captain, John Bunsby, a sturdy old seaman, agreed to take them on board, primarily interested in Fogg's offer of a generous sum. Fogg did not haggle over the price; speed and certainty were his only concerns. With Aouda and Passepartout’s share of the money (assuming Passepartout was indeed gone, perhaps also a victim of Fix, or worse, in league with him – Fogg’s thoughts briefly touched on this, though he dismissed it as unlikely given Passepartout’s nature), they boarded the schooner, ready to leave Hong Kong behind, along with the bitter taste of treachery and missed connections. The unexpected delay had cost him valuable time, pushed his schedule to the brink, and confirmed his suspicion of the relentless, cunning adversary who pursued him. But Phileas Fogg, though inconvenienced and angered, was not defeated. His resolve hardened; he would find a way to regain the lost ground. The wager was still on.

events.title: Facing Dire Straits Alone
detailed_summary: Following his initial shock and anger, Passepartout calms down and evaluates his predicament.
He acknowledges his unenviable position: alone, en route to Japan, with no money.
His passage is already paid, which grants him five or six days to determine his course of action.
He decides to eat heartily during the voyage, consuming meals with vigor, as if eating for Fogg and Aouda too, anticipating potential food scarcity upon arrival.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: After his first depression, Passepartout became calmer, and began to study his situation.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He helped himself as generously as if Japan were a desert, where nothing to eat was to be looked for.

events.text_segment: After his first depression, Passepartout became calmer, and began to study his situation. It was certainly not an enviable one. He found himself on the way to Japan, and what should he do when he got there? His pocket was empty; he had not a solitary shilling, not so much as a penny. His passage had fortunately been paid for in advance; and he had five or six days in which to decide upon his future course. He fell to at meals with an appetite, and ate for Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and himself. He helped himself as generously as if Japan were a desert, where nothing to eat was to be looked for.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: After his first depression, Passepartout became calmer, and began to study his situation. It was not an enviable one. He found himself en route for Japan, and from thence to America, without a farthing in his pocket, and with no means of procuring one. His passage, it is true, was paid, and his food and shelter assured on board the steamer; but there were forty days still between him and Bombay, and a hundred and twenty between there and London. He naturally thought of Mr. Fogg, and the predicament in which his sudden disappearance might have involved him. What should he say to him when he met him? Would Fogg be pleased at his return, which fate seemed to be rendering an absolute impossibility? He did not know. But he did know that he was himself in a most distressful condition, and that he had been guilty of a flagrant piece of stupidity. And a Frenchman, M. Passepartout flattered himself, ought never to be guilty of stupidity. And this thought buoyed him up a little. During the first few days, which he passed on board, he ate and slept alternately, and found it was not so unpleasant after all. He thought he would not bother himself about the future, and that he would continue his journey, so unhappily commenced, as tranquilly as possible. As for eating, he did his part manfully. He ate with as much energy as if he were eating for Mr. Fogg and Aouda, as well as himself; and the commissary of the Messes, delighted with his sharp appetite, furnished him with an unlimited supply, as Passepartout had been set down on the ship’s register as belonging to the rich and lavish passenger in cabin number eleven.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: After his first depression, Passepartout became calmer, and began to study his situation. He was on board the Mongolia, a magnificent steamer, ploughing the waves towards Bombay. He, the quiet, methodical Passepartout, was circumnavigating the globe with a man of ice, driven by a wager of twenty thousand pounds! He thought of the comfortable house in Savile Row, the regular routine, the life he had just left behind. He looked at his master, so cool and unperturbed, reading his paper as if on a suburban train journey. Gradually, the sheer audacity of the undertaking began to appeal to him, replacing fear with a kind of bewildered excitement. He was truly an integral part of this madcap adventure.

events.title: Arrival in Yokohama and Exploring the European Quarter
detailed_summary: On November 13th at dawn, the 'Carnatic' reaches the port of Yokohama.
Yokohama is identified as a key Pacific port near Yeddo (Tokyo), the former residence of the Tycoon.
The ship anchors at the quay among many international vessels.
Passepartout cautiously steps ashore onto the unfamiliar Japanese land.
Lacking a plan, he wanders aimlessly through Yokohama's streets.
He first finds himself in a district with European-style architecture, featuring low-fronted houses with verandas.
This area, situated between the 'promontory of the Treaty' and the river, includes streets, squares, docks, and warehouses.
He observes a diverse crowd similar to Hong Kong and Calcutta, comprising Americans, English, Chinese, and Dutch merchants.
Despite the bustling international presence, Passepartout feels utterly isolated.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At dawn on the 13th the “Carnatic” entered the port of Yokohama.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The Frenchman felt himself as much alone among them as if he had dropped down in the midst of Hottentots.

events.text_segment:
At dawn on the 13th the “Carnatic” entered the port of Yokohama. This is an important port of call in the Pacific, where all the mail-steamers, and those carrying travellers between North America, China, Japan, and the Oriental islands put in. It is situated in the bay of Yeddo, and at but a short distance from that second capital of the Japanese Empire, and the residence of the Tycoon, the civil Emperor, before the Mikado, the spiritual Emperor, absorbed his office in his own. The “Carnatic” anchored at the quay near the custom-house, in the midst of a crowd of ships bearing the flags of all nations.
Passepartout went timidly ashore on this so curious territory of the Sons of the Sun. He had nothing better to do than, taking chance for his guide, to wander aimlessly through the streets of Yokohama. He found himself at first in a thoroughly European quarter, the houses having low fronts, and being adorned with verandas, beneath which he caught glimpses of neat peristyles. This quarter occupied, with its streets, squares, docks, and warehouses, all the space between the “promontory of the Treaty” and the river. Here, as at Hong Kong and Calcutta, were mixed crowds of all races, Americans and English, Chinamen and Dutchmen, mostly merchants ready to buy or sell anything. The Frenchman felt himself as much alone among them as if he had dropped down in the midst of Hottentots.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: At dawn on the 13th the “Carnatic” entered the port of Yokohama. This is an important port of call in the Pacific, where all the great steam-vessels between China, America, Japan, and the Malay Islands touch. This city, which is at once a commercial town and a seaport, is situated on the Bay of Yeddo, and but a short distance from that second capital of the Japanese Empire, formerly the residence of the Tycoon, and now that of the Mikado. The “Carnatic” anchored at the quay near the custom-house, in the midst of a crowd of ships bearing the flags of all nations. Passepartout recognized some American and French vessels, those of the Packet-Boats of the Pacific, and, near them, the steamer Henry IV., with which he had been twinned in the dock at Hong Kong. As soon as the gangway was lowered, Passepartout hastened ashore, for he knew that he ought to do so, and that the Hong Kong difficulty was now happily past. He had no idea how he was going to find his master, and, before attempting to search for him, he resolved to wander around the city. He found himself at first in an utterly European quarter, with low houses, ornamented with verandas, and having on their fronts the charming originality of Japanese architecture. This district occupied, between the promontory of the Treaty and the river, a large number of streets, squares, docks, and warehouses, and everything in it had a prosperous air, worthy of London or Liverpool. In the midst of the town, also, Passepartout observed some genuine Japanese streets, where there was a perfect swarming of almond-eyed and yellow-skinned inhabitants, wearing coats of silk, long tunics, and frequently crape. He saw also some Bhuttes, with their conical hats, and priests, who went about singing and beating resounding tambourines. There were soldiers, too—silent, unmoving—in cotton clothing, carrying swords of fine temper; and finally, beggars, monks, and long-haired people, who seemed to be half caste between the human and monkey races. Passepartout gazed upon all this living picture, with eyes and mouth wide open, and it seemed to him that he was in the land of the “Arabian Nights.” The crowd, however, with the exception of the European types, were carrying on business in their own way, in quaint-looking shops, the interiors of which a juggler would not disdain for a stage. These shops were like stalls at a fair, and were piled with all sorts of second-hand goods—trumpery Japanese curiosities, porcelain, puffed rice, mixed with charcoal—crackers, revolvers, of which the barrels and locks were of copper, and finally, provisions of all sorts, of which he dared not ask the use or origin. He saw the barbers, who are the most important people in Japan, operating upon the black heads of their customers, and kneading their chins with a horrible ointment. He met with palanquins, carried by porters, and drawn by horses, with one single shaft, in the rear, like the shafts of our wheelbarrows. Finally, he beheld the famous jinrikishas—light carriages, imported from America, with two wheels, and drawn, like a hackney-coach, by a man, upon salary. A good number of these vehicles were manoeuvring in the streets, and Passepartout would have been by no means disinclined to take a trip in one, had he been less preoccupied by the thought of his master. As he was strolling along without any definite object, he at last came to the docks. There he saw a number of fine steamers, of French, Dutch, English, and American nationality, besides the war-vessels of these various powers. Passepartout experienced a moment of lively emotion on beholding some English flags, and he began to search among the crews and officers, who were either on the decks or the quays. But he recognized no one. Passepartout then entered the European quarter, and passed along the delightful promenade of the Bund, where were the banks, the warehouses, and the magazines. As he walked, he met some Frenchmen and Englishmen, to whom he would have been very glad to speak, but he did not dare to do so, as he was quite ignorant of English. In fact, either from bashfulness or lack of knowledge, he called out to no one. At the expiration of an hour or two, Passepartout found that he had gone over the entire city, without having met a single person of whom he was in search. It is true, that Fix, if he had been in Yokohama, would have been the last man with whom he would have wished to meet. Passepartout felt thoroughly discouraged, and began to despair of finding Mr. Fogg. With head down, he wandered about, aimlessly dropping into the seamen’s taverns, and gazing into the grog-shops, which were crowded with sailors of all nationalities—English, French, American, Dutch, Indian. These fellows were singing, fighting, drinking, and smoking, and it seemed as if they had neither country nor master, nor home, nor God. Passepartout passed by them, without being so much as perceived, and he felt as lonely as if he had been in the midst of the Desert of Sahara. Anacharsis Cloots’ idea of a human species was doubtless realised in Yokohama, if not in the whole world. It occurred to Passepartout that he had better avail himself of the resources of the city, and, of the country as well. This enterprising young man, who had formerly been a valet de chambre, then dancer, was not at all abashed before a foreign public. He knew that since his old grandmother’s time, the Japanese were passionately fond of acrobatic feats. He therefore resolved to offer his services as an acrobat to some manager in the Japanese theatrical world.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: At dawn on the 13th the “Carnatic” entered the port of Yokohama. Phileas Fogg, accompanied by Aouda and Passepartout, disembarked as quickly as possible. Fogg’s primary concern was immediately securing passage on the steamer bound for San Francisco, the next crucial leg of his incredible journey. Without delay, he headed directly to the offices of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, maintaining his characteristic composure and precision. Aouda, ever observant and grateful, remained silently by his side, adapting remarkably well to the strange new world around them. Meanwhile, Passepartout, recovered and curious, was distracted from logistics. The exotic sights and sounds of Yokohama captivated him. He wandered off freely, eager to explore the city. This wandering led him towards the less respectable districts, a predictable course for the adventurous valet. This separation created an immediate complication. Fogg, ascertaining the next ship, the 'General Grant,' would not sail for several days, found unexpected time he instantly dedicated to finding his missing servant. Continuing the journey without Passepartout was unthinkable, despite his usual demeanour. He enlisted Aouda's help, and together they began a systematic search through the port city streets. Their search, however, proved more difficult than anticipated, as Passepartout had stumbled into an unusual predicament.

events.title: Venturing into Native Yokohama (Benten)
detailed_summary: Passepartout considers seeking aid from the French and English consuls but is reluctant to reveal his story, intertwined as it is with his master's situation.
He resolves to try other avenues first and moves from the European quarter into the native Japanese section.
He enters the Japanese quarter known as Benten, named for a sea goddess worshipped locally.
He takes in the distinctive sights: beautiful fir and cedar groves, unique sacred gates, picturesque bridges among bamboo, shaded temples, and Buddhist/Confucian retreats.
He observes the lively streets filled with children resembling figures from Japanese art, playing amidst small poodles and cats.

The streets are crowded with various people: priests in procession with tambourines, distinctively dressed police and customs officers carrying two sabres, soldiers in blue cotton uniforms, the Mikado's guards in silk and mail, and numerous military figures, reflecting the high status of the military in Japan compared to China.
He also sees begging friars, pilgrims, and ordinary civilians with characteristic Japanese physical features (hair, head shape, stature, complexion) that differentiate them from the Chinese.
He notes the unique local transportation methods like carriages, palanquins, barrows with sails, and bamboo litters.

He observes the local women, whom he doesn't find particularly attractive, noting their gait, footwear (canvas shoes, straw sandals, clogs), blackened teeth, flat chests, and kimonos tied with large knots at the back, drawing a parallel to contemporary Parisian fashion.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He had, at least, one resource,—to call on the French and English consuls at Yokohama for assistance.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: An ornament which the modern Parisian ladies seem to have borrowed from the dames of Japan.

events.text_segment:
He had, at least, one resource,—to call on the French and English consuls at Yokohama for assistance. But he shrank from telling the story of his adventures, intimately connected as it was with that of his master; and, before doing so, he determined to exhaust all other means of aid. As chance did not favour him in the European quarter, he penetrated that inhabited by the native Japanese, determined, if necessary, to push on to Yeddo.
The Japanese quarter of Yokohama is called Benten, after the goddess of the sea, who is worshipped on the islands round about. There Passepartout beheld beautiful fir and cedar groves, sacred gates of a singular architecture, bridges half hid in the midst of bamboos and reeds, temples shaded by immense cedar-trees, holy retreats where were sheltered Buddhist priests and sectaries of Confucius, and interminable streets, where a perfect harvest of rose-tinted and red-cheeked children, who looked as if they had been cut out of Japanese screens, and who were playing in the midst of short-legged poodles and yellowish cats, might have been gathered.
The streets were crowded with people. Priests were passing in processions, beating their dreary tambourines; police and custom-house officers with pointed hats encrusted with lac and carrying two sabres hung to their waists; soldiers, clad in blue cotton with white stripes, and bearing guns; the Mikado’s guards, enveloped in silken doubles, hauberks and coats of mail; and numbers of military folk of all ranks—for the military profession is as much respected in Japan as it is despised in China—went hither and thither in groups and pairs. Passepartout saw, too, begging friars, long-robed pilgrims, and simple civilians, with their warped and jet-black hair, big heads, long busts, slender legs, short stature, and complexions varying from copper-colour to a dead white, but never yellow, like the Chinese, from whom the Japanese widely differ. He did not fail to observe the curious equipages—carriages and palanquins, barrows supplied with sails, and litters made of bamboo; nor the women—whom he thought not especially handsome—who took little steps with their little feet, whereon they wore canvas shoes, straw sandals, and clogs of worked wood, and who displayed tight-looking eyes, flat chests, teeth fashionably blackened, and gowns crossed with silken scarfs, tied in an enormous knot behind an ornament which the modern Parisian ladies seem to have borrowed from the dames of Japan.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: He had, at least, one resource,—to call on the French and English consuls at Yokohama for assistance. But he was reluctant to explain his situation, tangled as it was with that of his master; and, before resolving on this, he determined to exhaust other means. As chance had brought him into the Japanese quarter of the town, he entered a tea-house, and went in, with the air of a person as much at home as possible. He found himself in a low-roofed room, with mats for flooring, and supplied with a few cushions, on which sat some natives drinking saké or rice-beer from porcelain cups. A few delicate-looking screens, of fanciful design, and great richness, were in the corners. Passepartout bowed profoundly to the company, and then seated himself on a mat, indicating to the waitress, who forthwith made her appearance, that he wanted something to eat. She brought him in a box-like convenience, divided into several compartments, in which were rice, fish, and some succulent plants, the whole seasoned with kararaski, a strong condiment made from mustard and vegetables. He ate heartily, and, having paid his score by a few pieces of silver he had about him, he left the tea-house. He wandered through the streets, his eyes and nose on the alert. He found himself in the Benten quarter, where the theatres are, and beheld some astonishing performances by tumblers and jugglers. The Japanese make curious acrobats. They are of supple, but not muscular build, and are able to perform the most singular feats with equilibrium. One, for example, would balance himself on two bamboos, on the edge of a running fan; another would walk on a wire or a thread, with a spinning top attached to his toe; others, again, would juggle with several tops at once; and some would even perform the celebrated feat of the butterflies, using only the breath of their lungs. Passepartout saw others, on a plate, turn around a lighted candle, and, with the help of a mirror, make it appear to be extinguished at a thousand different points. The spectacle was not uninteresting, and the worthy Passepartout was on the point of giving way to his natural jollity, but, remembering that he was out of work, he set about seriously searching for it. He walked from the Japanese quarter, and came to the port. He saw some thirty vessels at anchor, among which were American, English, and French men-of-war, and commercial steamers of all flags. He inquired about the steamers going to America, and found that the "General Grant," of the Pacific Mail Company, was to leave for San Francisco the next day. There were no less than ten departures a month of the vessels of this company, which run between Yokohama, San Francisco, and Hong Kong. Passepartout felt a ray of hope. If his master could but cross that great expanse of sea, he would be safe! But, as he was penniless, he could not take his passage, nor even ask for information about the fare. He was quite discouraged, and was about to give up all hope, when he saw an advertisement for an acrobat troupe, who were to go to America with their performance. He read the name of the company, which was "The Long Noses," and found that they were going to San Francisco by the next steamer. He said to himself, "This is my chance! I will offer myself to this troupe. They are probably in need of a servant or an assistant. At any rate, I shall get to America, and I will manage the rest there." He went to the address indicated, and found a troupe of Japanese, whose heads were covered with long, flowing hair. Their chief, named Batulcar, received him in a most polite manner, and invited him to sit down on a mat. Passepartout explained to him that he was a French servant, out of place, and that he was looking for work. Batulcar listened attentively, and then, after a moment of reflection, he said, "We are going to America, and we are looking for a servant. You seem to be a strong young man, and you speak French. That is a great advantage. Will you accept to accompany us?" Passepartout was delighted. He accepted immediately, and Batulcar explained to him that he would have to assist in the performances, and that he would be paid in proportion to his services. The next day, Passepartout presented himself at the port, with his new master. He helped to embark the luggage, and the company, with all their paraphernalia. At the moment of departure, Batulcar called Passepartout, and said to him, "Here is your pay in advance, as well as a present for your diligence." And he put into his hand a handful of kobangs, or Japanese gold coins. Passepartout was overjoyed. He thanked Batulcar, and went on board. The "General Grant" sailed at the appointed hour, and directed her course across the Pacific. Passepartout was so happy, that he did not even feel the motion of the ship. He thought of his master, and said to himself, "I am going to America! I will find Mr. Fogg, and I will explain everything to him. He will be so glad to see me!" And thus it was that Passepartout, thanks to his ingenuity and his good luck, found himself on the way to America, while his master was still at Yokohama, wondering what had become of him.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: He had, at least, one resource,—to call on the French and English consuls at Yokohama for assistance. But he was reluctant to explain his situation, tangled as it was with that of his master; and, before resolving on this, he determined to exhaust other means. As chance had brought him into the Japanese quarter of the town, he entered it, and found himself in the midst of a wholly Oriental scene. Beautiful firs and cedars, sacred gates of a singular architecture, picturesque bridges among the bamboo, shaded temples, and peaceful retreats, were scattered here and there among the narrow streets, where a crowd of children, with red cheeks and in gay costumes, were playing in the midst of small poodles and cats, which had a meditative air. The streets were full of people of all classes, priests in long robes, proceeding in processions, beating tambourines; officers of police and customs, with two sabres in their belts, and an imposing air; soldiers in blue cotton uniforms, with white stripes; the Mikado’s guards, with their silk and mail coats, and a species of cuirass; and numbers of military folk of all ranks—for in Japan the military profession is as much considered as it is despised in China. There were begging friars, long-haired, and carrying a sort of rosary; pilgrims, in conical hats, of lacquered paper; and ordinary civilians, with their black hair, half-shaved, and gathered in a tuft on the top of the head, with large heads, long busts, slender legs, and short stature—a race which M. Edmond About justly compares to the caricatures of the Japanese drawn by their own artists. Passepartout walked about among this crowd, observing the curious and fantastic types, and seeing with wonder the shops, filled with all sorts of Japanese trinkets, the restaurants, ornamented with streamers and banners, the tea-houses, where they were drinking the hot beverage with saké, or rice-beer. He saw also the public-houses, where he might have found a bed, but for the exorbitant price asked for it. He noticed carriages, palanquins, barrows with sails, and bamboo litters; and, finally, women—whom he did not find particularly handsome—with their eyes half shut, their cheeks painted, their mouths without colour, their teeth blackened, their chests flat, and their bodies long and slender. They were dressed in silk kimonos, with a broad sash tied at the back, which to a Parisian taste did not seem to be an improvement on the original costume. Passepartout, who had been in the European quarter, was struck with the difference between the two populations. He had left a town of merchants and sailors, and he found himself in a town of soldiers and priests. He had seen the English and French, the Dutch and Americans, and he saw now the Japanese, with their peculiar features, their singular costumes, and their strange customs. He had seen the European women, with their fair complexions, their light hair, and their graceful figures, and he saw now the Japanese women, with their dark complexions, their black hair, and their flat chests. He had seen the European houses, with their regular architecture, their large windows, and their comfortable interiors, and he saw now the Japanese houses, with their irregular architecture, their small windows, and their bare interiors. In short, he was in a new world, and he was so absorbed in his observations, that he forgot for a moment his sad situation.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_2.text: He had, at least, one resource,—to call on the French and English consuls at Yokohama for assistance. But he was reluctant to explain his situation, tangled as it was with that of his master; and, before resolving on this, he determined to exhaust other means. As chance had brought him into the Japanese quarter of the town, he entered it, and found himself in the midst of a wholly Oriental scene. He found himself in the Benten quarter, where the goddess of the sea is worshipped. Beautiful firs and cedars, sacred gates of a singular architecture, picturesque bridges among the bamboo, shaded temples, and peaceful retreats, were scattered here and there among the narrow streets, where a crowd of children, with red cheeks and in gay costumes, were playing in the midst of small poodles and cats, which had a meditative air. The streets were full of people of all classes, priests in long robes, proceeding in processions, beating tambourines; officers of police and customs, with two sabres in their belts, and an imposing air; soldiers in blue cotton uniforms, with white stripes; the Mikado’s guards, with their silk and mail coats, and a species of cuirass; and numbers of military folk of all ranks—for in Japan the military profession is as much considered as it is despised in China. There were begging friars, long-haired, and carrying a sort of rosary; pilgrims, in conical hats, of lacquered paper; and ordinary civilians, with their black hair, half-shaved, and gathered in a tuft on the top of the head, with large heads, long busts, slender legs, and short stature—a race which M. Edmond About justly compares to the caricatures of the Japanese drawn by their own artists. He noticed carriages, palanquins, barrows with sails, and bamboo litters; and, finally, women—whom he did not find particularly handsome—with their eyes half shut, their cheeks painted, their mouths without colour, their teeth blackened, their chests flat, and their bodies long and slender. They walked with short steps, dragging their canvas shoes, their straw sandals, or their wooden clogs. They were dressed in silk kimonos, with a broad sash tied at the back, which to a Parisian taste did not seem to be an improvement on the original costume.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: He had, at least, one resource,—to call on the French and English consuls at Yokohama for assistance. But this step could not be taken, till he had ascertained that Passepartout did not embark in the Carnatic, and it was now too late to make the inquiry. The steamer was at sea. Mr. Fogg repaired to the agency of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, and ascertained that the Carnatic had sailed the previous evening for San Francisco, and that Passepartout had not been among the passengers. This was only too evident. Phileas Fogg and Aouda were consequently left in Japan. Mr. Fogg, thus decided, directed his steps towards the French consulate, and there found the required information. The French consul, M. Simon, was in fact able to ascertain the fate of the worthy Passepartout. Mr. Fogg, after thanking the consul, and begging him to notify the police, went to the English consulate, where he received no information concerning his servant. While a search was being set on foot, Mr. Fogg and Aouda went towards the foreign quarter. This was a sort of street or wide square, containing dwelling-houses and warehouses, imported from Europe, as in Shanghai and Hong Kong. The whole was shaded by fine large trees. In the rear stood the town proper, with its tortuous streets, its houses with low, sombre gables, and the everlasting crowd which ebbs and flows through them. Mr. Fogg and Aouda walked through the public thoroughfares, Phileas Fogg, with his habitual composure, not betraying by a single sign the trouble he was in. He had spent a part of the day in the foreign quarter, and was now walking along the port. Aouda, with a sweet feminine grace, thanked him repeatedly for what he was doing for her. He simply replied that it was 'nothing.' To him, this trip was purely executory; he was simply attending to a programme that had to be carried out. What interested him was not the Aouda but the return. As he was thus walking, he observed some Japanese following a placard which a sort of clown was carrying. The clown, a long, lean, flexible fellow, was capering and making grimaces, and his performance, which was excellent, was evidently appreciated by the spectators. Mr. Fogg, followed by Aouda, ascended the narrow street which opened upon the port. While he was going up, he saw the placard, and was able to read the words 'Long Noses' in large letters. He saw also the clown, who was making his way through the crowd. This clown was Passepartout.

events.title: Hunger, Countryside Exploration, and Nightfall
detailed_summary: Passepartout continues his wandering for hours, observing various establishments: shops with curious goods, jewelry stores, decorated restaurants, tea-houses serving sake alongside tea, and smoking lounges offering fine tobacco instead of opium.
His walk leads him out into the countryside, surrounded by expansive rice fields.
He admires vibrant camellias blooming on trees, along with cherry, plum, and apple trees cultivated primarily for their flowers, guarded by oddly shaped scarecrows.

He observes the local wildlife: eagles on cedars, herons standing solemnly in willows, and numerous crows, ducks, hawks, wild birds, and cranes, learning the latter are considered sacred symbols of longevity and prosperity.
He spots some violets but discovers they lack fragrance, disappointing his hope for finding something edible.
Despite having eaten a substantial breakfast before leaving the ship, his day of walking makes him increasingly hungry.
He notices the absence of mutton, goat, or pork at butcher stalls and recalls that cattle are sacred and used only for farming, concluding meat is scarce.
He yearns for game or fish, common Japanese staples alongside rice, but realizes he must endure his hunger until the next day.
As night arrives, Passepartout returns to the native quarter.
He wanders through streets illuminated by colorful lanterns, watching dancers perform skillful steps and astrologers working outdoors with telescopes.
He reaches the harbor area, lit by the resin torches of fishermen in their boats.
Eventually, the streets grow quiet, and the bustling crowds are replaced by patrols.
He observes the patrols, noting the officers' splendid costumes and entourages, finding their formality amusing and likening each passing group to a departing European embassy.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Passepartout wandered for several hours in the midst of this motley crowd, looking in at the windows of the rich and curious shops, the jewellery establishments glittering with quaint Japanese ornaments, the restaurants decked with streamers and banners, the tea-houses, where the odorous beverage was being drunk with “saki,” a liquor concocted from the fermentation of rice, and the comfortable smoking-houses, where they were puffing, not opium, which is almost unknown in Japan, but a very fine, stringy tobacco.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Each time a company passed, Passepartout chuckled, and said to himself: “Good! another Japanese embassy departing for Europe!”

events.text_segment:
Passepartout wandered for several hours in the midst of this motley crowd, looking in at the windows of the rich and curious shops, the jewellery establishments glittering with quaint Japanese ornaments, the restaurants decked with streamers and banners, the tea-houses, where the odorous beverage was being drunk with “saki,” a liquor concocted from the fermentation of rice, and the comfortable smoking-houses, where they were puffing, not opium, which is almost unknown in Japan, but a very fine, stringy tobacco. He went on till he found himself in the fields, in the midst of vast rice plantations. There he saw dazzling camellias expanding themselves, with flowers which were giving forth their last colours and perfumes, not on bushes, but on trees, and within bamboo enclosures, cherry, plum, and apple trees, which the Japanese cultivate rather for their blossoms than their fruit, and which queerly-fashioned, grinning scarecrows protected from the sparrows, pigeons, ravens, and other voracious birds. On the branches of the cedars were perched large eagles; amid the foliage of the weeping willows were herons, solemnly standing on one leg; and on every hand were crows, ducks, hawks, wild birds, and a multitude of cranes, which the Japanese consider sacred, and which to their minds symbolise long life and prosperity.
As he was strolling along, Passepartout espied some violets among the shrubs.
“Good!” said he; “I’ll have some supper.”
But, on smelling them, he found that they were odourless.
“No chance there,” thought he.
The worthy fellow had certainly taken good care to eat as hearty a breakfast as possible before leaving the “Carnatic;” but, as he had been walking about all day, the demands of hunger were becoming importunate. He observed that the butchers stalls contained neither mutton, goat, nor pork; and, knowing also that it is a sacrilege to kill cattle, which are preserved solely for farming, he made up his mind that meat was far from plentiful in Yokohama—nor was he mistaken; and, in default of butcher’s meat, he could have wished for a quarter of wild boar or deer, a partridge, or some quails, some game or fish, which, with rice, the Japanese eat almost exclusively. But he found it necessary to keep up a stout heart, and to postpone the meal he craved till the following morning. Night came, and Passepartout re-entered the native quarter, where he wandered through the streets, lit by vari-coloured lanterns, looking on at the dancers, who were executing skilful steps and boundings, and the astrologers who stood in the open air with their telescopes. Then he came to the harbour, which was lit up by the resin torches of the fishermen, who were fishing from their boats.
The streets at last became quiet, and the patrol, the officers of which, in their splendid costumes, and surrounded by their suites, Passepartout thought seemed like ambassadors, succeeded the bustling crowd. Each time a company passed, Passepartout chuckled, and said to himself: “Good! another Japanese embassy departing for Europe!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Passepartout wandered for several hours in the midst of this motley crowd, looking in at the windows of the rich and curious shops, the jewellery establishments glittering with quaint Japanese ornaments, the restaurants decked with streamers and banners, the tea-houses, where the odorous beverage was being drunk with “saki,” a liquor concocted from the fermentation of rice, and the comfortable smoking-houses, where they were puffing, not opium, which is almost unknown in Japan, but a very fine, stringy tobacco. He went along from the native quarter to the European, and, without perceiving it, found himself in the fields. There he saw magnificent rice-fields in full bloom, and radiantly-flowering camellias, forming little copses, and blooming on cherry, plum, and apple trees, which the Japanese cultivate rather for their flowers than for their fruit, and which figure largely in their landscapes, guarded by awkward-looking scarecrows. He met with some fine eagles on the cedars, herons standing solemnly on one leg in the marshy streams, wild ducks and teal, hawks, open-billed storks, and a great number of crows. On a branch of a tree he espied a pheasant, which he would have gladly shot, a proceeding, however, which the most highly-polished Englishman would have been scandalised at, and which the Japanese themselves make no account of, saving when the sport is indulged in by the Emperor. The crows in question struck Passepartout as exceedingly familiar, and perched quite near to the passers-by, proving that they were either favoured birds, or else, by reason of some superstition, were unafraid of men. The symbol of longevity and prosperity in Japan is the crane, and Passepartout saw some fine specimens, borne on the wings of their great white pinions in the air. At the sight of these birds, some of which are regarded as sacred, while others are hunted like ordinary game, he thought of his master. They have the same difference for him, thought he, as for the Japanese: he is not sacred, but he is hunted. Passepartout passed along by streams and over a number of little bridges, noting here and there a few violets in bloom, but scentless, this being one of the peculiarities of Japan, which, though it boasts a flora as rich as that of Europe, does not excel in fragrance. He sniffed at them from politeness, but they had no smell. In the country Passepartout was tormented by hunger. He had left the Aretusa, which was being victualled, a few hours before, and had eaten nothing since morning. He, however, found nothing edible. He might, indeed, have had recourse to the butcher’s stalls, but he would not find there either mutton, goat, or pork, though there was beef, which is used only for farming, and is considered sacred. Passepartout was therefore in the plight of the Brahmin, who has been forbidden the use of meat, and for whom fish, with rice, is the staple food. He would have been glad to do as the Japanese did, but he did not know how to get any game, or any wild fowl, or any fish. He was therefore condemned to wait till the morrow. As night came on, Passepartout re-entered the native quarter. The streets were lit up with multi-coloured lanterns, and were gay with singers, dancers, and players. The astrologers were at their posts on the squares and at the street corners, and were doing a thriving business with their telescopes. Passepartout felt a great longing for some supper, and he saw some savoury dishes being carried from the restaurants, but he had no money in his pocket, and he could only look on at the dainty viands as they disappeared down the throats of the hungry natives. Passepartout went down to the harbour, which was lit up by the resin torches of the fishermen. These, too, were well-fed, and they were enjoying their supper. Passepartout felt that he must be the only hungry man in Yokohama. The day wore on, and Passepartout, who had gone over the whole city, felt himself much fatigued. As the night deepened, the streets became quiet, and the bustling crowd was replaced by patrols. These patrols were dressed in splendid costumes, and were accompanied by bands of musicians. They marched in single file, with a sort of solemnity, and with a certain air of mystery about them. Passepartout found this very amusing, and he compared each patrol to a European embassy, which was leaving the city and was being escorted by a guard of honour.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Passepartout wandered for several hours in the midst of this motley crowd, looking in at the windows of the rich and curious shops, the jewellery establishments glittering with quaint Japanese ornaments, the restaurants decked with streamers and banners, the tea-houses, where the odorous beverage was being drunk with “saki,” a liquor concocted from the fermentation of rice, and the comfortable smoking-houses, where they were puffing, not opium, which is almost unknown in Japan, but a very fine, stringy tobacco. The hours wore on. Where were Mr. Fogg and Mr. Fix? Had they left without him? He had lost his master and his companions. His small purse contained only a few yen – barely enough for a meal. He needed to find them, and quickly. He tried asking people, showing gestures, but no one understood his French. He wandered towards the port, hoping to see them disembarking from the *Carnatic*, but neither figure was in sight amongst the bustling activity. Despair began to creep in. How could he possibly survive in this strange land with no money and no contacts? He realised he couldn't just wander indefinitely. He needed food and shelter; he needed to earn money, somehow. The idea of finding work, any work, began to form in his mind. He was strong, willing, and adaptable, or so he told himself. As he continued his aimless trek, he came upon a group of people gathered around a makeshift stage in a public square. There were acrobats, jugglers, and musicians. It was the celebrated Japanese troupe of Mr. Batulcar. Passepartout stopped, drawn by the spectacle and perhaps a flicker of hope. He saw the performers, many of them Westerners, looking tired but determined. An idea struck him. He approached the leader, Mr. Batulcar. With gestures and the few words he knew, he indicated his plight and his willingness to work. Batulcar, assessing the sturdy physique of the Frenchman, seemed to understand; he needed strong men for some of the pyramid acts and lifts. A deal was quickly struck – food and lodging, in exchange for joining the troupe as an acrobat. So it was that Passepartout, the next day, found himself in a strange costume, practicing balancing acts. It was hard work, physically demanding, often humiliating, but it provided him with food and lodging. He performed in the squares and gardens of Yokohama with the troupe, balancing on human pyramids, tumbling, and attempting feats of strength. He, the former valet of Phileas Fogg, was now a public entertainer. He kept a constant eye out for his master or Mr. Fix, hoping they might pass by and recognise him amidst the spectacle, a most unexpected turn of events in his extraordinary journey around the world.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXIII. IN WHICH PASSEPARTOUT’S NOSE BECOMES OUTRAGEOUSLY LONG

events.title: Passepartout's Desperate Morning: Exchanging Clothes for Survival
detailed_summary: Waking up exhausted and starving, Passepartout resolved to find food immediately.
He considered selling his watch but dismissed the idea, deciding instead to use his singing voice, hoping the Japanese appreciate music.
Realizing it was too early for a performance and his attire was too fine for a street artist, he decided to wait.
The idea struck him to exchange his European clothes for Japanese ones, which would both suit his planned performance and provide immediate funds for food.
After searching, he found a dealer of old clothes.
The dealer accepted the exchange, liking the European outfit.
Passepartout emerged dressed in old Japanese garments, including a coat and faded turban, with a small amount of money acquired from the transaction.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The next morning poor, jaded, famished Passepartout said to himself that he must get something to eat at all hazards, and the sooner he did so the better.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: A few small pieces of silver, moreover, jingled in his pocket.

events.text_segment:
The next morning poor, jaded, famished Passepartout said to himself that he must get something to eat at all hazards, and the sooner he did so the better. He might, indeed, sell his watch; but he would have starved first. Now or never he must use the strong, if not melodious voice which nature had bestowed upon him. He knew several French and English songs, and resolved to try them upon the Japanese, who must be lovers of music, since they were for ever pounding on their cymbals, tam-tams, and tambourines, and could not but appreciate European talent.
It was, perhaps, rather early in the morning to get up a concert, and the audience prematurely aroused from their slumbers, might not possibly pay their entertainer with coin bearing the Mikado’s features. Passepartout therefore decided to wait several hours; and, as he was sauntering along, it occurred to him that he would seem rather too well dressed for a wandering artist. The idea struck him to change his garments for clothes more in harmony with his project; by which he might also get a little money to satisfy the immediate cravings of hunger. The resolution taken, it remained to carry it out.
It was only after a long search that Passepartout discovered a native dealer in old clothes, to whom he applied for an exchange. The man liked the European costume, and ere long Passepartout issued from his shop accoutred in an old Japanese coat, and a sort of one-sided turban, faded with long use. A few small pieces of silver, moreover, jingled in his pocket.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The next morning poor, jaded, famished Passepartout said to himself that he must get something to eat at all hazards, and the sooner he did so the better. He might, it is true, sell his watch; but he would have starved to death first. An idea struck him that he would hire out his singing talent, which was not a bad one. The Japanese, he knew, were great lovers of music, and were not above striking up some national airs in their theatres. Passepartout hummed a few tunes, and convinced himself that he was in good voice. “Yes,” thought he, “I will sing, sing at the street corners, like a veritable fakir. It may be a little early yet; and I don’t want to wake up the inhabitants.” But before long he reflected that his European costume would be hardly suitable for a Japanese minstrel; and that he ought to hit upon some national dress. This thought he did not abandon; and he began to search for clothes dealers, who could furnish him with a Japanese outfit. He at last found one, and boldly entered. The dealer, who was at work in his shop, evidently looked upon Passepartout as an eccentric foreigner, and the Frenchman, after saluting him with a most gracious bow, said, that he wished to exchange his European clothes for a Japanese costume. The dealer saw that the suit was an old one, and therefore of little value; but as he was anxious to have the set of clothes in question, that he might afterwards offer them to some amateur of oddities, he consented to the proposed transaction. Passepartout was transferred to a room where he was given a Japanese dress and a few rags. He arrayed himself in the costume, a coat with ample sleeves and a turban-like headdress; and a few pieces of silver money were placed in his hand.

events.title: Seeking Passage and Discovering an Opportunity
detailed_summary: Pleased with the outcome of the clothes exchange, Passepartout momentarily embraced his new guise, comparing it to being at Carnival.
His first action was to find a modest tea-house.
He ate a small meal of bird and rice, aware that his next meal was uncertain.
After eating, he focused on his predicament: needing to leave Japan quickly, as he couldn't resell his current costume and held no fond memories of the country.
He considered seeking work as a cook or servant on a steamer bound for America to pay for his passage.
He acknowledged the immense distance across the Pacific to San Francisco.
Determined, he headed towards the docks.
As he approached, doubts surfaced about the feasibility of his plan: his appearance might arouse suspicion, and he lacked references.
While contemplating, he noticed a large placard carried by a clown.
The placard advertised the final Japanese performances of an acrobatic troupe owned by William Batulcar, before their departure to the United States.
Reading about the troupe's destination, Passepartout immediately saw it as his opportunity.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Good!” thought he.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “The United States!” said Passepartout; “that’s just what I want!”

events.text_segment:
“Good!” thought he. “I will imagine I am at the Carnival!”
His first care, after being thus “Japanesed,” was to enter a tea-house of modest appearance, and, upon half a bird and a little rice, to breakfast like a man for whom dinner was as yet a problem to be solved.
“Now,” thought he, when he had eaten heartily, “I mustn’t lose my head. I can’t sell this costume again for one still more Japanese. I must consider how to leave this country of the Sun, of which I shall not retain the most delightful of memories, as quickly as possible.”
It occurred to him to visit the steamers which were about to leave for America. He would offer himself as a cook or servant, in payment of his passage and meals. Once at San Francisco, he would find some means of going on. The difficulty was, how to traverse the four thousand seven hundred miles of the Pacific which lay between Japan and the New World.
Passepartout was not the man to let an idea go begging, and directed his steps towards the docks. But, as he approached them, his project, which at first had seemed so simple, began to grow more and more formidable to his mind. What need would they have of a cook or servant on an American steamer, and what confidence would they put in him, dressed as he was? What references could he give?
As he was reflecting in this wise, his eyes fell upon an immense placard which a sort of clown was carrying through the streets. This placard, which was in English, read as follows:
ACROBATIC JAPANESE TROUPE,
HONOURABLE WILLIAM BATULCAR, PROPRIETOR,
LAST REPRESENTATIONS,
PRIOR TO THEIR DEPARTURE TO THE UNITED STATES,
OF THE
LONG NOSES! LONG NOSES!
UNDER THE DIRECT PATRONAGE OF THE GOD TINGOU!
GREAT ATTRACTION!
“The United States!” said Passepartout; “that’s just what I want!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: “Good!” thought he. “I am like the wandering Jew, but the wandering Frenchman is still better!” Having secured his meal of bird and rice, eaten it, and paid his modest bill, Passepartout turned towards the docks. He had a vague idea of hiring himself as a servant on board some steamer, and so crossing the Pacific. He was sure that his appearance, in the long, close-fitting, brown overcoat which he had bought, would not be objectionable. He walked along the quays, attentively examining the vessels. Several were ready to sail, among others the American steamer, the “Carnatic,” bound for San Francisco. Passepartout, though he could not pay for his passage, did not despair of getting to America. He thought of offering himself in the capacity of cook or servant. He went on board the “Carnatic,” and asked for the steward. The steward, after receiving him coolly, told him that they did not need a cook or servant. Passepartout was disheartened, but not discouraged. He would look elsewhere. As he passed along the docks, he saw a large placard carried by a clown. The placard announced that the renowned troupe of acrobats of William Batulcar would give their last performances in Japan on the following day, before their departure for the United States. “To the United States!” exclaimed Passepartout; “that’s exactly where I want to go!”
