LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The rajah’s offer had been providential. The railway had abruptly terminated at Kholby, but the jungle, impassable by ordinary means in the time available, could be traversed with the aid of this noble beast. It was an unforeseen expense, certainly – two thousand pounds was a considerable sum, even for Mr. Fogg – but time was of the essence, and this elephant, large and powerful, seemed perfectly capable of maintaining the necessary speed. Kiouni, the guide had called him. A good name, suggesting reliability. Mr. Fogg adjusted his cravat, his gaze fixed on the preparations. Passepartout, though initially dismayed by the abrupt halt of the train and the prospect of an elephant ride, was now watching the mahout with an air of fascinated curiosity, his earlier apprehension replaced by the sheer novelty of the situation. Mr. Fogg, however, felt no novelty, only calculation. The distance to Allahabad was roughly fifty miles. At an average speed of eight miles per hour, factoring in necessary brief halts, they should arrive within six hours. The next train to Calcutta would depart shortly after their projected arrival. The connection was tight, but feasible. This detour, while disruptive to the meticulously planned route, presented an alternative that fit within the overall timetable. The railway officials had been apologetic, explaining the incomplete section of track, but their regrets were irrelevant to Mr. Fogg. Facts were what mattered, and the fact was that the railway ended here. An alternative *must* be found. And an alternative *had* been found. The elephant. It was logical. It was efficient under the circumstances. The additional cost was a variable easily absorbed. The journey was not derailed, merely adjusted. He consulted his notebook, confirming the distance and the required speed. Everything added up. Yes, ‘good’ was the precisely correct assessment of the situation. The delay, though regrettable, was minimal, and the chosen method of transport, while unusual, offered a means to regain the lost time, or at least prevent further slippage. The mahout, perched on the elephant's head, gave a sharp cry. It was time to depart. Mr. Fogg nodded, his expression one of calm assurance. The great beast lowered itself, a vast, patient mountain of muscle and hide, ready to receive its unusual passengers. Passepartout, with a mixture of trepidation and excitement, prepared to mount. Mr. Fogg followed, his movement precise and unhurried, as always.

events.title: Joining Batulcar's Acrobatic Troupe
detailed_summary: Passepartout followed the placard-bearer back into the Japanese district.
He arrived at a large cabin decorated with streamers and painted depictions of jugglers, identifying it as Batulcar's establishment.
He learned Batulcar was the director of a diverse troupe of performers giving final shows before heading to the U.S.
Passepartout entered and requested to see Mr. Batulcar, who appeared.
Batulcar initially mistook Passepartout for a native Japanese person.
Passepartout inquired about a servant position.
Batulcar rejected the offer, stating he already had two perfectly capable 'servants' – his own arms.
Passepartout expressed his strong desire to travel to the Pacific with the troupe.
Batulcar recognized Passepartout was not Japanese and questioned his attire.
Passepartout identified himself as a Parisian.
Batulcar, associating French nationality with making faces, asked if Passepartout could grimace.
Passepartout affirmed, slightly annoyed, adding Americans were equally adept.
Batulcar offered Passepartout a position as a clown instead of a servant, noting the international appeal of French clowns.
He confirmed Passepartout's physical strength and singing ability (even in acrobatic positions).
Satisfied with Passepartout's recalled skills from his youth, Batulcar hired him on the spot.
Passepartout secured employment with the Japanese troupe.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He followed the clown, and soon found himself once more in the Japanese quarter.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He was engaged to act in the celebrated Japanese troupe.

events.text_segment:
He followed the clown, and soon found himself once more in the Japanese quarter. A quarter of an hour later he stopped before a large cabin, adorned with several clusters of streamers, the exterior walls of which were designed to represent, in violent colours and without perspective, a company of jugglers.
This was the Honourable William Batulcar’s establishment. That gentleman was a sort of Barnum, the director of a troupe of mountebanks, jugglers, clowns, acrobats, equilibrists, and gymnasts, who, according to the placard, was giving his last performances before leaving the Empire of the Sun for the States of the Union.
Passepartout entered and asked for Mr. Batulcar, who straightway appeared in person.
“What do you want?” said he to Passepartout, whom he at first took for a native.
“Would you like a servant, sir?” asked Passepartout.
“A servant!” cried Mr. Batulcar, caressing the thick grey beard which hung from his chin. “I already have two who are obedient and faithful, have never left me, and serve me for their nourishment and here they are,” added he, holding out his two robust arms, furrowed with veins as large as the strings of a bass-viol.
“So I can be of no use to you?”
“None.”
“The devil! I should so like to cross the Pacific with you!”
“Ah!” said the Honourable Mr. Batulcar. “You are no more a Japanese than I am a monkey! Who are you dressed up in that way?”
“A man dresses as he can.”
“That’s true. You are a Frenchman, aren’t you?”
“Yes; a Parisian of Paris.”
“Then you ought to know how to make grimaces?”
“Why,” replied Passepartout, a little vexed that his nationality should cause this question, “we Frenchmen know how to make grimaces, it is true but not any better than the Americans do.”
“True. Well, if I can’t take you as a servant, I can as a clown. You see, my friend, in France they exhibit foreign clowns, and in foreign parts French clowns.”
“Ah!”
“You are pretty strong, eh?”
“Especially after a good meal.”
“And you can sing?”
“Yes,” returned Passepartout, who had formerly been wont to sing in the streets.
“But can you sing standing on your head, with a top spinning on your left foot, and a sabre balanced on your right?”
“Humph! I think so,” replied Passepartout, recalling the exercises of his younger days.
“Well, that’s enough,” said the Honourable William Batulcar.
The engagement was concluded there and then.
Passepartout had at last found something to do. He was engaged to act in the celebrated Japanese troupe.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: He followed the clown, and soon found himself once more in the Japanese quarter. Some very sturdy persons with highly coloured faces and gilded signs were coming out of a tea-house. This was the honourable M. Batulcar, the director of a troupe of mountebanks, who, in his peregrinations around the world, was now giving his last performances before leaving for the United States.Passepartout, without knowing why, found himself with the crowd of Japanese, and paid out his money for admission, going into the great enclosure built of bamboos, where platforms had been raised for the spectators. The show was about to begin. On the platforms and parquet were many natives in variegated costumes, some of whom were beating drums, others blowing trumpets, and others producing discords on a kind of banjo.The performers were in the open air, on a wide square stage. The performance was acrobatic and pantomimic. Passepartout, with his hands in his pockets, felt a tender curiosity as he gazed at these mountebanks, whose contortions were often mingled with real grace.There was a ring of men and women dressed in silk and brocade, with their faces fantastically painted, and a great length of hair dressed up on the top of their heads with metallic pins and tortoiseshell combs. They performed evolutions with wonderful bamboo poles, balancing themselves, or spinning around on top of them with surprising dexterity.There were also others who performed balancing feats with top-spinning, with the cigarette and fan tricks, and other jugglers.There were clowns, too, with white faces, singularly agile and elastic. One of them, the one who had guided Passepartout, was particularly clever. His strength of limb was prodigious, and his stiffness and suppleness seemed to be combined in him.It was plain, at any rate, that this Japanese troupe was highly skilled, and, in his own language, they were 'first-class.'Passepartout found himself filled with admiration.The performance ended at half-past eleven with a grand finale of balancing on the top of a pile of persons, which Passepartout felt like joining himself, he was so carried away by his enthusiasm.The Japanese orchestra, with its clangour of cymbals and drums, accompanied the whole with a deafening din.Passepartout had watched with intense interest; his thoughts had run away to his younger days, when he too had been a mountebank. He had then been as agile as these Japanese, and might have taken part in their performances without fear of being out of place.He left the bamboo enclosure and wandered through the streets. For what purpose? He did not know. He was walking mechanically, his thoughts full of Batulcar, the director of the troupe, and the idea that he might be able to obtain a position with him.He was, in fact, in such a melancholy frame of mind that he was about to give up hope, when he suddenly found himself in the vicinity of the bamboo enclosure again.He entered it, and saw Batulcar. The director was standing by a booth, talking to a man in a long silk coat.Passepartout went up to him, took off his hat, and bowed.M. Batulcar looked at him and, seeing that he was not a native, said: 'What do you want?''I want to speak to you, sir,' replied Passepartout, timidly.'Who are you?' asked Batulcar.'I am a servant, sir.'A servant? We have no need of servants here,' said Batulcar, roughly.'But,' said Passepartout, without being discouraged, 'I want to travel with you.'To travel with us? And where do you come from?' demanded Batulcar, scanning him from head to foot.'From Paris,' replied Passepartout.'From Paris!' exclaimed Batulcar. 'And you want to come with us? You must be joking! You don't look like a Japanese.'No, sir, I am not Japanese.'And what are you?'A Frenchman.'A Frenchman? Ah, I see!' said Batulcar, with a strange look in his eyes. 'You are a French mountebank?'I am not a mountebank,' said Passepartout, rather annoyed. 'I am a servant.'Yes, yes, a servant who can make faces!' replied Batulcar, winking. 'Well, a Frenchman who can make faces is always a welcome addition to a troupe. Can you grimace?'Passepartout felt his indignation rise. 'Yes, I can grimace,' he said, 'and so can Americans!'That's good!' said Batulcar. 'And you can sing?'Yes, I can sing.'And dance?'Yes, I can dance.'And juggle?'Yes, I can juggle.'And you are strong?'Yes, I am strong.'Good! good! good!' cried Batulcar. 'Then you are just the man I want. You can take the place of the clown who has just left.'Passepartout was so surprised that he could not say a word. He had come to ask for a place as a servant, and he was offered a place as a clown!But, on reflection, he said to himself that it was a position, after all, and that he would be able to leave Yokohama and go to America with the troupe.He therefore accepted the offer with thanks.Batulcar immediately gave him the costume of the clown who had left, and told him that he would make his first appearance that evening.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: He followed the clown, and soon found himself once more in the Japanese quarter. A large cabin, adorned with streamers and banners, and on the front of which were painted in flaming colours a perfect living panorama of jugglers, mountebanks, and acrobats, with a company of gymnasts, was Batulcar's establishment. This Batulcar was the director of a troupe of mountebanks, who, in their peregrinations around the world, were now giving their last performances before leaving for the United States. Passepartout entered and asked for Mr. Batulcar, who appeared. 'What do you want?' he asked, taking Passepartout for a native. 'I want a situation as servant, sir.' 'A servant!' cried Batulcar; 'I have two excellent servants, who never leave me and who serve me without pay. Here they are,' added he, holding up his two arms. 'So you don't want me?' 'No.' 'But I should like to travel with you.' 'In what capacity?' 'As a servant.' 'Ah! but you are not a Japanese.' 'No; I am a Frenchman.' 'A Frenchman! You can make faces, then?' 'Yes,' replied Passepartout, a little vexed that his nationality should suggest that accomplishment. 'I can make faces; and the Americans, too, are good at making faces!' 'Are you strong?' asked Batulcar. 'Yes, if you take me by the collar.' 'And can you sing?' 'Yes,' said Passepartout, who had formerly been a street singer. 'Can you sing while turning on your back on the top of a ladder?' 'In the French fashion?' 'Yes.' 'I can,' replied Passepartout, who was not going to let slip this opportunity of getting to America. 'Batulcar at once engaged him. It is well known that the French clowns are highly appreciated in foreign countries. Passepartout's engagement was concluded for a simply nominal sum, on condition that he should take the place of a clown who had just left.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_2.text: He followed the clown, and soon found himself once more in the Japanese quarter. A large cabin, adorned with streamers and banners, and on the front of which were painted in flaming colours a perfect living panorama of jugglers, mountebanks, and acrobats, with a company of gymnasts, was Batulcar's establishment. The figures were drawn without perspective, and with a total disregard of the rules of proportion, like those the Japanese draw on fans. This Batulcar was the director of a troupe of mountebanks, who, in their peregrinations around the world, were now giving their last performances before leaving for the States of the Union. Passepartout entered and asked for Mr. Batulcar, who appeared. "What do you want?" he asked, taking Passepartout for a native. "I want a situation as servant, sir." "A servant!" cried Batulcar; "I have two excellent servants, who never leave me and who serve me without pay. Here they are," added he, holding up his two arms, as supple as the strings of a violin. "So you don't want me?" "No." "But I should like to travel with you." "In what capacity?" "As a servant." "Ah! but you are not a Japanese." "No; I am a Frenchman." "A Frenchman! You can make faces, then?" "Yes," replied Passepartout, a little vexed that his nationality should suggest that accomplishment. "I can make faces; and the Americans, too, are good at making faces!" "Are you strong?" asked Batulcar. "Yes, if you take me by the collar." "And can you sing?" "Yes," said Passepartout, who had formerly been a street singer. "Can you sing while turning on your back on the top of a ladder?" "In the French fashion?" "Yes." "Can you perform tricks with rings and balls?" "Yes." "Can you balance yourself on a bottle, or on the point of a sword?" "Yes." "Ah! you are a mountebank, then?" cried Batulcar. "Well, a Frenchman who is a mountebank is always welcome. I will engage you as a clown." Passepartout was so surprised that he could not say a word. He had come to ask for a place as a servant, and he was offered a place as a clown! But, on reflection, he said to himself that it was a position, after all, and that he would be able to leave Yokohama and go to America with the troupe. He therefore accepted the offer with thanks.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
He followed the clown, and soon found himself once more in the Japanese quarter. The narrow, lantern-lit streets were a confusing maze of unfamiliar sights and sounds. The charm of his earlier visit with Mr. Fogg was gone, replaced by crushing isolation. He was hungry, exhausted, alone, and penniless in the sprawling, foreign city.

His disastrous circus performance attempt gnawed at him. He'd hoped to earn passage money by joining a troupe for a ridiculous human pyramid act that collapsed. The clown, a fellow performer, vanished after they received a pittance for their efforts. Passepartout's pocket held only worthless coins.

Anxiety for Mr. Fogg consumed him. Had his master reached the Carnatic? The ship was bound for America, the next vital stage. But Passepartout didn't know the port location or if the vessel had sailed. The thought of being left behind was unbearable. Every moment felt like a lifetime, the distance between them growing vast.

He wandered through the bustling quarter, the vibrant life a stark contrast to his despair. Tea houses, market stalls, and workshops offered no comfort. He tried asking locals for help, repeating "Fogg" and "Carnatic," but met only incomprehension. The language barrier was absolute. Self-reproach burned; his carelessness led him here. His failures in India and Hong Kong seemed minor now.

He sank onto a cold stone bench. The sharp evening air seeped through his worn clothes. He buried his face in his hands, crushed by his situation. He felt like a complete failure, a hindrance to the wager. But then he looked up. Towards the harbor, faint lights and dark masts were visible against the night sky. That was his only hope. The docks. He had to get there. Perhaps amidst the port activity, he might find someone who knew about the Carnatic.

With desperate resolve, he stood, ignoring aching legs. He breathed deeply, smelling salt and the city. He straightened his shoulders. He would walk to the harbor. He had to find Mr. Fogg. The wager's fate, his master's honour, his own future depended on it. He set off through the unfamiliar, teeming streets, determination a fragile light against the darkness, driven solely by the imperative to return to the impossible journey.

events.title: The Acrobatic Spectacle Begins
detailed_summary: Passepartout accepted the less-than-dignified role, focused on reaching San Francisco within the week.
The performance, heavily advertised by Batulcar, was set for three o'clock, heralded by loud Japanese instruments.
Without rehearsal, Passepartout was assigned to use his strength in the 'human pyramid' finale featuring the 'Long Noses of the god Tingou'.
Before the start time, the venue filled with a diverse audience of Europeans, natives, Chinese, and Japanese.
Musicians positioned themselves inside, playing various traditional instruments energetically.
The show commenced with typical acrobatic displays, showcasing the exceptional skills of Japanese equilibrists.
Acts included manipulating paper butterflies with a fan, creating smoke calligraphy, juggling lit candles extinguished and relit with the mouth, and complex spinning top tricks.
The tops performed incredible feats, moving across various surfaces and objects, demonstrating apparent autonomy and creating musical sounds.
Jugglers interacted with the spinning tops in complex ways.
The general acrobatic and gymnastic feats involving ladders, poles, and balls were performed with remarkable precision.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was not a very dignified position, but within a week he would be on his way to San Francisco.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The turning on ladders, poles, balls, barrels, &c., was executed with wonderful precision.

events.text_segment:
It was not a very dignified position, but within a week he would be on his way to San Francisco.
The performance, so noisily announced by the Honourable Mr. Batulcar, was to commence at three o’clock, and soon the deafening instruments of a Japanese orchestra resounded at the door. Passepartout, though he had not been able to study or rehearse a part, was designated to lend the aid of his sturdy shoulders in the great exhibition of the “human pyramid,” executed by the Long Noses of the god Tingou. This “great attraction” was to close the performance.
Before three o’clock the large shed was invaded by the spectators, comprising Europeans and natives, Chinese and Japanese, men, women and children, who precipitated themselves upon the narrow benches and into the boxes opposite the stage. The musicians took up a position inside, and were vigorously performing on their gongs, tam-tams, flutes, bones, tambourines, and immense drums.
The performance was much like all acrobatic displays; but it must be confessed that the Japanese are the first equilibrists in the world.
One, with a fan and some bits of paper, performed the graceful trick of the butterflies and the flowers; another traced in the air, with the odorous smoke of his pipe, a series of blue words, which composed a compliment to the audience; while a third juggled with some lighted candles, which he extinguished successively as they passed his lips, and relit again without interrupting for an instant his juggling. Another reproduced the most singular combinations with a spinning-top; in his hands the revolving tops seemed to be animated with a life of their own in their interminable whirling; they ran over pipe-stems, the edges of sabres, wires and even hairs stretched across the stage; they turned around on the edges of large glasses, crossed bamboo ladders, dispersed into all the corners, and produced strange musical effects by the combination of their various pitches of tone. The jugglers tossed them in the air, threw them like shuttlecocks with wooden battledores, and yet they kept on spinning; they put them into their pockets, and took them out still whirling as before.
It is useless to describe the astonishing performances of the acrobats and gymnasts. The turning on ladders, poles, balls, barrels, &c., was executed with wonderful precision.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: It was not a very dignified position, but within a week he would be on his way to San Francisco. This week must be got through; and Passepartout meditated that his master, not having made any allusions to the matter, could not have been unwilling for him to accept the engagement. The performance, so noisily heralded by Batulcar, was to commence at three o'clock. The announcement called in the Japanese instruments, consisting of tam-tams, drums, and cymbals. These were played in a fantastic manner, and the din was something infernal. Passepartout, though he had not been able to learn anything, had been told that he was to make himself generally useful. It was to be part of the 'human pyramid,' so famous among Japanese gymnasts, and which was to be crowned by the 'Long Noses of the god Tingou.' At half-past two the theatre was nearly full. There were Europeans and natives, Chinese and Japanese, men, women, and children, who thronged the benches, balconies, and boxes. The orchestra took its place within, composed of a perfect battery of drums, tam-tams, cymbals, bones, and tambourines. The performance was under the direction of the conductor, who beat the measure with a large baton, and the artistes thumped away with energy. At a quarter past three, the curtain, instead of rising, was lowered, and the performance commenced. This was a series of pantomimes, in the style of the Chinese and Japanese acrobats, and which consisted of balancing feats upon bamboos, ladders, tops, and other objects. The equilibrists were wonderfully clever. One of them, with a fan on his nose, kept a number of paper butterflies fluttering in the air; another drew with smoke from his mouth the most grotesque figures; a third, with a lighted candle, extinguished and relighted the flame with his mouth, twenty times in succession. Then came the top-spinners. The tops spun on the edge of a sword, on the rim of a glass, on the point of a needle; they seemed to be alive, and went through the most extraordinary performances. They hummed, they talked, they fanned themselves; they created the most extraordinary musical sounds. They performed in groups, or alone, and the jugglers seemed to have no control over them. They rolled over lacquered tables, and then caught them on the ends of sticks; they threw them into the air, and caught them as they came down; they made them roll over wires, and even disappear into their mouths. The exhibition concluded with the feats of the acrobats, who, with the help of ladders, poles, and balls, performed the most difficult exercises with perfect precision.

It was to be part of the 'human pyramid,' so famous among Japanese gymnasts, and which was to be crowned by the 'Long Noses of the god Tingou.' At half-past two the theatre was nearly full. There were Europeans and natives, Chinese and Japanese, men, women, and children, who thronged the benches, balconies, and boxes. The orchestra took its place within, composed of a perfect battery of drums, tam-tams, cymbals, bones, and tambourines. The performance was under the direction of the conductor, who beat the measure with a large baton, and the artistes thumped away with energy. At a quarter past three, the curtain, instead of rising, was lowered, and the performance commenced. This was a series of pantomimes, in the style of the Chinese and Japanese acrobats, and which consisted of balancing feats upon bamboos, ladders, tops, and other objects. The equilibrists were wonderfully clever. One of them, with a fan on his nose, kept a number of paper butterflies fluttering in the air; another drew with smoke from his mouth the most grotesque figures; a third, with a lighted candle, extinguished and relighted the flame with his mouth, twenty times in succession. Then came the top-spinners. The tops spun on the edge of a sword, on the rim of a glass, on the point of a needle; they seemed to be alive, and went through the most extraordinary performances. They hummed, they talked, they fanned themselves; they created the most extraordinary musical sounds. They performed in groups, or alone, and the jugglers seemed to have no control over them. They rolled over lacquered tables, and then caught them on the ends of sticks; they threw them into the air, and caught them as they came down; they made them roll over wires, and even disappear into their mouths. The exhibition concluded with the feats of the acrobats, who, with the help of ladders, poles, and balls, performed the most difficult exercises with perfect precision.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: It was not a very dignified position, but within a week he would be on his way to San Francisco. They were stalled. A mechanical issue or a schedule disruption, typical of the burgeoning American railway system. The waiting room of the station, if one could call it that, was a scene of democratic chaos foreign to Fogg's orderly existence. Passengers lounged on hard benches, spoke loudly, and scattered remnants of their provisions upon the floor. Dust, thick and pervasive, seemed to be the primary architectural feature. For Phileas Fogg, accustomed to the quietude of the Reform Club, the plush comfort of ocean liners, and the reserved service of global hotels, this idleness in such vulgar surroundings was indeed far from dignified. He stood, aloof from the general throng, his waterproof coat buttoned, his hat perfectly level, inspecting the planks of the floor as if searching for some anomaly. His valise sat neatly beside him, a small island of English precision in a sea of American disorder. His watch, naturally, had been consulted several times, though the tardiness of the train was a fact established beyond doubt, rendering further consultation merely a matter of form. There was no outward sign of impatience, only that subtle tightening around his eyes that Passepartout had learned to interpret as intense, though silent, vexation. Passepartout, less disciplined in his discomfort, fidgeted openly. He paced the short length of the 'waiting room', peered out the grimy window at the uninspiring platform, and sighed frequently, a sound that seemed swallowed by the general clamour. He missed the predictable routine of the steamer, the exotic novelty of foreign lands, even the quiet, measured tension of their previous journeys. This formless waiting felt particularly trying. "Really, Monsieur," he muttered under his breath, though Fogg gave no indication of hearing him, "One could travel around the world, but one cannot travel around America without encountering... this!" He gestured vaguely at the scene of unrefined humanity. Aouda sat gracefully on a corner of the bench, her features revealing only mild weariness. She watched Mr. Fogg with quiet concern, understanding that this discomfort, while perhaps tolerable for others, was a significant imposition upon his meticulous nature. She offered no complaint, her presence itself a small oasis of calm amidst the surrounding disarray. Yet, through the dust and the noise, the unwavering objective remained. The delay was an irritation, a calculation error introduced into the otherwise perfect equation of their journey, but it was surmountable. Every minute lost here would need to be clawed back, perhaps by some daring or unorthodox means later on the westward route. But the route itself was clear. San Francisco was the gateway, the threshold to the final ocean crossing. And within a week, despite this temporary, undignified halt, the steamship from the Golden Gate would be cleaving the Pacific waves, carrying Phileas Fogg one step closer to his impossible deadline. The thought, though unexpressed, was a steady beacon in the temporary gloom of the railway station.

events.title: The Human Pyramid and Unexpected Recognition
detailed_summary: The main event featured the 'Long Noses,' performers associated with the god Tingou, unknown in Europe.
They wore medieval-style costumes with wings and distinctively long bamboo noses (five to ten feet) attached to their faces.
These noses, varying in shape and decoration, were used for gymnastic exercises.
Performers lay on their backs while others balanced and performed acrobatics on their elongated noses.
The finale was advertised as a 'human pyramid' representing the Car of Juggernaut, formed not on shoulders, but on the noses.
The usual base performer had left the troupe.
Passepartout, possessing the needed strength and dexterity, was chosen as the new base.
Reluctantly donning the costume with wings and a six-foot false nose, Passepartout felt a twinge of melancholy recalling his youth, but consoled himself that it earned him food.
He took his position on stage with others forming the pyramid's base, lying down with noses pointed upward.
Successive tiers of performers balanced on the noses below them, constructing a human monument reaching the theatre's ceiling.
Amid loud applause and orchestral music, the pyramid suddenly became unstable.
The balance was lost as one of the base noses (Passepartout's) disappeared.
The entire structure collapsed dramatically.
Passepartout was responsible; abandoning his post, he leaped over the footlights and scrambled into the right-hand gallery.
He landed at the feet of a spectator, exclaiming in recognition.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: But the principal attraction was the exhibition of the Long Noses, a show to which Europe is as yet a stranger.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Ah, my master! my master!”

events.text_segment:
But the principal attraction was the exhibition of the Long Noses, a show to which Europe is as yet a stranger.
The Long Noses form a peculiar company, under the direct patronage of the god Tingou. Attired after the fashion of the Middle Ages, they bore upon their shoulders a splendid pair of wings; but what especially distinguished them was the long noses which were fastened to their faces, and the uses which they made of them. These noses were made of bamboo, and were five, six, and even ten feet long, some straight, others curved, some ribboned, and some having imitation warts upon them. It was upon these appendages, fixed tightly on their real noses, that they performed their gymnastic exercises. A dozen of these sectaries of Tingou lay flat upon their backs, while others, dressed to represent lightning-rods, came and frolicked on their noses, jumping from one to another, and performing the most skilful leapings and somersaults.
As a last scene, a “human pyramid” had been announced, in which fifty Long Noses were to represent the Car of Juggernaut. But, instead of forming a pyramid by mounting each other’s shoulders, the artists were to group themselves on top of the noses. It happened that the performer who had hitherto formed the base of the Car had quitted the troupe, and as, to fill this part, only strength and adroitness were necessary, Passepartout had been chosen to take his place.
The poor fellow really felt sad when—melancholy reminiscence of his youth!—he donned his costume, adorned with vari-coloured wings, and fastened to his natural feature a false nose six feet long. But he cheered up when he thought that this nose was winning him something to eat.
He went upon the stage, and took his place beside the rest who were to compose the base of the Car of Juggernaut. They all stretched themselves on the floor, their noses pointing to the ceiling. A second group of artists disposed themselves on these long appendages, then a third above these, then a fourth, until a human monument reaching to the very cornices of the theatre soon arose on top of the noses. This elicited loud applause, in the midst of which the orchestra was just striking up a deafening air, when the pyramid tottered, the balance was lost, one of the lower noses vanished from the pyramid, and the human monument was shattered like a castle built of cards!
It was Passepartout’s fault. Abandoning his position, clearing the footlights without the aid of his wings, and, clambering up to the right-hand gallery, he fell at the feet of one of the spectators, crying, “Ah, my master! my master!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: But the principal attraction was the exhibition of the Long Noses, a show to which Europe is as yet a stranger. The troupe of performers were patentees of a kind of Hindoo Providence, the god Tingou. They were dressed in loose robes of silk and gold, and wore on their heads mitres adorned with feathers. They were, above all, distinguished by the long, cylindrical cases, made of bamboo, which were fixed to their noses. Some were five feet long, others ten, and they were all carefully polished and ornamented with various designs. A specially selected troupe of these "Long Noses" executed gymnastic exercises. They lay on their backs, and upon their noses, which were kept upright by means of braces, others balanced themselves, and performed different evolutions. The finale of the performance was announced as a representation of the Car of Juggernaut, which was to be executed by the whole troupe of "Long Noses," and form a pyramid of human bodies, not upon shoulders, but on noses. But the usual performer who formed the base of the pyramid, having a cold, was unable to appear. Passepartout, with his great strength and dexterity, was chosen to take his place. With some hesitation, he consented to don the costume, with wings and a six-foot false nose attached to it. He felt a twinge of melancholy as he recalled the pleasant days of his youth, but consoled himself that he was earning a livelihood. He took his place on the stage with those who were to constitute the foundation of the Car of Juggernaut. They all lay upon their backs, their noses pointing upward. Upon these structures of bamboo, the performers of the second tier balanced themselves; upon the latter, those of the third were arranged, and so on, until the human monument reached the ceiling of the theatre. The spectators were in raptures. The orchestra played triumphal music. But suddenly, the pyramid began to totter; the equilibrium was lost. One of the noses forming the base of the pyramid disappeared. The entire structure fell with a frightful crash. Passepartout had abandoned his post, and, leaping over the footlights, scrambled into the right-hand gallery. He landed at the feet of a spectator, who uttered a cry of surprise. Passepartout, recognising him, cried out in return: "Ah, my master, you here!"

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: But the principal attraction was the exhibition of the Long Noses, a show to which Europe is as yet a stranger. This curious spectacle unfolded within a spacious, low-lying edifice, whose walls were adorned with intricate carvings depicting scenes from Parsi mythology. Here, the renowned ‘Long Noses’ officiated – not with artificially elongated features as Passepartout had half-expected, but rather the revered priests of the Zoroastrian faith, clad in spotless white garments and wearing veils over their mouths and noses, ostensibly to prevent their breath from polluting the sacred fire. This veil, perhaps, was the origin of the curious moniker, rendering their natural noses more prominent beneath the opaque cloth. They moved with a solemn grace, tending to the perpetual flame that burned brightly upon a large, elevated altar – the very heart of their worship. The air was thick with the scent of sandalwood and other aromatic woods used to feed the fire, mingled with a peculiar, sweet fragrance. Low, resonant chants filled the space, emanating from the veiled figures who performed their ancient rites with meticulous precision. It was a scene steeped in centuries of tradition, a glimpse into a faith vastly different from those common in Europe. Passepartout, his eyes wide with astonishment, nudged Fogg gently. “Monsieur,” he whispered, “look at them! Like figures from a dream. And the fire! It never goes out?” Mr. Fogg, ever the observer of facts rather than fancies, nodded curtly. “A sacred fire, Passepartout. A central tenet of their belief. The Parsees are descendants of Persians who fled Muslim persecution, preserving their ancient faith here in India.” Sir Francis Cromarty, who accompanied them, added, “Indeed. They are a prosperous and respected community in Bombay. Their charitable institutions are numerous. This temple, a ‘fire temple’, is the focus of their spiritual life. Only adherents are usually permitted within the inner sanctuary, but this particular exhibition seems designed to offer outsiders a controlled view of certain rituals.” The priests continued their measured movements, adding fragrant fuel to the flame, reciting prayers in Avestan, their ancient liturgical language. The fire crackled and roared softly, casting dancing shadows upon the walls. Despite the exotic nature of the performance, Mr. Fogg remained impassive, his mind likely already calculating the time required to witness this spectacle and the distance to the railway station. Passepartout, however, was captivated, finding the blend of solemnity, mystery, and the ever-present, vibrant flame profoundly impressive. He wondered about the meaning behind the gestures, the significance of the chants. It was a world away from the familiar churches of France. They spent perhaps half an hour observing this unique ceremony, absorbing the strange, compelling atmosphere. While utterly foreign, there was a palpable sense of devotion and history in the air. Passepartout felt a shiver of something akin to awe. Fogg merely consulted his watch. It was time to depart. The train for Calcutta was scheduled to leave that evening, and there were still arrangements to be made, including securing their passage and hiring the necessary conveyances to reach the station with their luggage. The glimpse into the world of the ‘Long Noses’ was fascinating, certainly, a curious note in the symphony of their journey, but it was merely a brief pause in the relentless forward momentum of their race against time. They politely thanked Sir Francis for his guidance and prepared to leave the temple grounds, heading back into the bustling, noisy streets of Bombay, where the practicalities of travel immediately reasserted themselves over the exotic marvels they had just witnessed. Their objective was clear: the train station. The eighty days were passing, and every minute counted.

events.title: Reunion, Resolution, and Departure for America
detailed_summary: Phileas Fogg recognized Passepartout despite his outlandish costume.
Passepartout confirmed his identity.
Fogg immediately instructed him to come to the steamer.
Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout exited the theatre through the lobby.
Outside, they were confronted by a furious William Batulcar.
Batulcar demanded compensation for the collapsed pyramid.
Phileas Fogg placated him by giving him a handful of banknotes.
Precisely at the scheduled departure time of 6:30 PM, Fogg and Aouda boarded the American steamer.
Passepartout followed them, still wearing his wings and the six-foot nose in his haste.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “You here?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: At half-past six, the very hour of departure, Mr. Fogg and Aouda, followed by Passepartout, who in his hurry had retained his wings, and nose six feet long, stepped upon the American steamer.

events.text_segment:
“You here?”
“Myself.”
“Very well; then let us go to the steamer, young man!”
Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout passed through the lobby of the theatre to the outside, where they encountered the Honourable Mr. Batulcar, furious with rage. He demanded damages for the “breakage” of the pyramid; and Phileas Fogg appeased him by giving him a handful of banknotes.
At half-past six, the very hour of departure, Mr. Fogg and Aouda, followed by Passepartout, who in his hurry had retained his wings, and nose six feet long, stepped upon the American steamer.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
You here?” cried Phileas Fogg, recognising his servant despite his mountebank’s disguise.
“Myself, sir!” replied Passepartout, joyfully.
“But, my poor fellow, how you are dressed!”
“Thus dressed, yes, sir; it is the result of a superb idea!”
“Go at once to the steamer, the *Carnatic*,” said Mr. Fogg. “You will find my trunks in your cabin.”
“But I have no cabin, sir; and as for trunks, I haven’t any more than I have clothes on my back!”
“Never mind,” said Phileas Fogg; “we will arrange that. Come!”


Aouda and the Frenchman followed Mr. Fogg, who hurried out of the theatre.
On arriving at the port, they found William Batulcar, the director, standing on the quay. He was enraged, and he demanded compensation for the ruin of his establishment. Phileas Fogg appeased him by giving him a bundle of bank-notes.
At half-past six, the moment of departure, Mr. Fogg and Aouda boarded the *Carnatic*, followed by Passepartout, who, in his haste, and having had no time to change his mountebank’s dress, still wore his wings and his six-foot nose.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: “You here?” he exclaimed, seeing the young woman on the deck of the steamer Mongolia. “You, Madame Aouda, in this country?” He had left her safely ensconced with the Parsi cousin in Bombay, and her unexpected presence so far from India astonished him greatly. He stepped forward, taking her hand with a gentle firmness. Passepartout, who had been following his master, stopped dead in his tracks, his mouth agape. He had believed they had parted company forever, and here she was, beautiful and serene, sailing alongside them towards Hong Kong. It was a most unforeseen complication to their already precarious journey around the globe.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXIV. DURING WHICH MR. FOGG AND PARTY CROSS THE PACIFIC OCEAN

events.title: Arrival in Shanghai and Transfer to Yokohama Steamer
detailed_summary: The arrival of the pilot-boat 'Tankadere' near Shanghai was anticipated.
Its signals were observed by the captain of the Yokohama-bound steamer.
Seeing the flag flown at half-mast, the steamer altered its course to approach the smaller vessel.
Phileas Fogg settled his payment with John Busby, the pilot-boat's captain.
Fogg gave Busby a substantial reward of five hundred and fifty pounds beyond the agreed price.
Fogg, along with Aouda and Fix, boarded the larger steamer.
The steamer immediately departed for its destinations, Nagasaki and Yokohama.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: What happened when the pilot-boat came in sight of Shanghai will be easily guessed.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: and they started at once for Nagasaki and Yokohama.

events.text_segment: What happened when the pilot-boat came in sight of Shanghai will be easily guessed. The signals made by the “Tankadere” had been seen by the captain of the Yokohama steamer, who, espying the flag at half-mast, had directed his course towards the little craft. Phileas Fogg, after paying the stipulated price of his passage to John Busby, and rewarding that worthy with the additional sum of five hundred and fifty pounds, ascended the steamer with Aouda and Fix; and they started at once for Nagasaki and Yokohama.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: What happened when the pilot-boat came in sight of Shanghai will be easily guessed. The signals of the “Tankadere” were seen by the captain of the Yokohama steamer, who altered his course and bore down towards the smaller craft. Phileas Fogg, with Aouda and Fix, went on board, having paid the master of the “Tankadere” the stipulated price for the trip, plus a bonus of five hundred and fifty pounds. To the great astonishment of Captain Busby, the crew, and the worthy John Bunsby, Phileas Fogg shook hands with them all. Fix felt a sudden pang, but he concealed it, as was his habit. Accordingly, the “Mongolia,” steamer, five hundred tons, belonging to the Peninsular and Oriental Company, built of iron, and sailing with a screw, set off at eleven in the morning of the 11th for Nagasaki and Yokohama.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: What happened when the pilot-boat came in sight of Shanghai will be easily guessed. They saw the harbour in the distance and felt a surge of hope. Their sole thought was to board the waiting steamer, the *Carnatic*, bound for Yokohama. As the pilot-boat drew nearer, however, the terrible truth became clear. The large vessel was already moving away from the docks, her paddles churning. She had started for Japan fully twelve hours before Fogg arrived. It was a crushing blow, seemingly undoing all their recent efforts and forcing Fogg to contemplate how to regain the lost time. He had missed his connection.

events.title: Reaching Yokohama and Locating Passepartout
detailed_summary: The group arrived in Yokohama on November 14th.
Phileas Fogg promptly went aboard the 'Carnatic'.
He learned that Passepartout, identified as a Frenchman, had arrived the previous day, much to Aouda's relief and possibly Fogg's, though he showed no emotion.
The steamer to San Francisco was scheduled to leave the same evening.
Finding Passepartout quickly became urgent.
Fogg unsuccessfully sought help from the French and English consulates.
After a lengthy and fruitless search through the city streets, Fogg began to lose hope.
Either by luck or intuition, he entered the theatre belonging to the Honourable Mr. Batulcar.
Fogg wouldn't have recognized his servant in the strange performer's attire.
However, Passepartout, performing on his back, spotted his master in the audience gallery.
His surprise caused an involuntary movement that dislodged his artificial nose, causing the human pyramid act to collapse.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: They reached their destination on the morning of the 14th of November.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He could not help starting, which so changed the position of his nose as to bring the “pyramid” pell-mell upon the stage.

events.text_segment:
They reached their destination on the morning of the 14th of November. Phileas Fogg lost no time in going on board the “Carnatic,” where he learned, to Aouda’s great delight—and perhaps to his own, though he betrayed no emotion—that Passepartout, a Frenchman, had really arrived on her the day before.
The San Francisco steamer was announced to leave that very evening, and it became necessary to find Passepartout, if possible, without delay. Mr. Fogg applied in vain to the French and English consuls, and, after wandering through the streets a long time, began to despair of finding his missing servant. Chance, or perhaps a kind of presentiment, at last led him into the Honourable Mr. Batulcar’s theatre. He certainly would not have recognised Passepartout in the eccentric mountebank’s costume; but the latter, lying on his back, perceived his master in the gallery. He could not help starting, which so changed the position of his nose as to bring the “pyramid” pell-mell upon the stage.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: They reached their destination on the morning of the 14th of November. This was the date mentioned in the programme, and Phileas Fogg was neither twenty-four hours behind time, nor was he ahead of it. They landed at Yokohama. This town, with its excellent harbour, is one of the ports where the Pacific steamers call, and into which enter the great mail steamers from San Francisco, bound for the South Sea, and the land of the Mikado. These vessels belong to the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, and the Occidental and Oriental Steamship Company. As soon as he got ashore, Mr. Fogg repaired to the agent of the Pacific Mail Company, and learned that the Carnatic, a steamer as large, and as fast as the Mongolia, left the preceding evening for San Francisco, and that she would not arrive at Yokohama again until the 14th of December, the time of her next departure. This was a great misfortune. The Carnatic was to take on the Japanese and Chinese mails, and Mr. Fogg counted on leaving in her. But she was gone, and her next departure was not till a month later. Phileas Fogg was perceptibly annoyed. But this feeling, whatever it might have been, did not betray itself, and Miss Aouda, who was with him, did not observe it. "We will inquire," said he, "for other vessels." He turned towards the agent, who said, "In a few days, sir, a steamer from the Oriental Company is due; she is going to San Francisco." "When does she sail?" "On the 18th, at four in the afternoon. It is the General Grant." "Good," said Mr. Fogg. "There is nothing to be done, then," said Aouda, "but to wait till the 18th?" "Yes, my dear," returned Mr. Fogg; "but as we are not at the end of our resources, I will, if you please, take advantage of the four days' delay which is granted us, to seek for Passepartout." Aouda's face brightened. It was evident that she owed Passepartout no grudge for his desertion. "Yes, we must find him," said she; "we must not abandon him, after all he has done for us." "I will search for him, Miss Aouda," returned Phileas Fogg, "even if it costs me the delay of another day." And, true to his word, he began to search. He inquired in the ships and on the wharves, among the sailors, and in the shops and tea-houses. He interrogated the police, and searched the consulates of the French and English. But Passepartout was not to be found. It was clear that if he had reached Yokohama, he had left it again. Mr. Fogg was beginning to despair. Was Passepartout, who had rendered him so many services, and whose devotion he had so often proved, really lost to him? He must have reached Nagasaki, or Kobe, and gone on further; or perhaps, having been shipwrecked, he was lost. Phileas Fogg did not give up the search, however. He went through the streets, and inquired at every turn, without allowing himself to be discouraged. Yokohama is a sort of European town, with very little Japanese character, but with a large foreign population, including English, French, Americans, and Dutch. In the evening, Mr. Fogg and Miss Aouda were returning to the hotel, when, as they passed through the Japanese quarter, they heard a noise, and saw a crowd collecting. Curiosity led them to the place. It was a performance by a band of jugglers and mountebanks, at the theatre of the Honourable Mr. Batulcar, the Japanese Barnum, who was at the head of a company of tumblers, equilibristes, jugglers, and other performers. Phileas Fogg and Aouda entered the theatre, and took seats. The performance was just beginning. It consisted of a series of complicated feats of strength and dexterity. The performers were dressed in grotesque costumes, and were painted in strange colours. They performed their feats with great skill and agility, and the audience applauded them loudly. But Mr. Fogg and Aouda paid little attention to the performance. They were still occupied with their search for Passepartout. At length, a new performance began. It was an act of equilibristes. The performers were poised on each other's shoulders, forming a sort of pyramid. The one at the top of the pyramid was a young man, dressed in a bizarre costume, and whose face was painted in a manner that made him unrecognisable. He was balancing himself on his back, with his legs in the air. On the top of his feet, he balanced a fan, which he kept in constant motion. Mr. Fogg was looking at him attentively, when suddenly, the young man at the top of the pyramid made a movement, and the whole structure collapsed. The performers fell to the ground, and the audience was in an uproar. The young man who had caused the catastrophe was none other than Passepartout! He had arrived at Yokohama on the Carnatic the preceding evening. Having no money, he had been obliged to join this band of mountebanks, and to perform this hazardous feat, in order to earn his living. He was covered with paint, and dressed in a ridiculous costume, but Mr. Fogg recognised him at once. Passepartout, for his part, recognised his master, who was looking at him from the gallery. Surprise caused him to make the involuntary movement which had resulted in the collapse of the pyramid. In falling, he had dislodged his artificial nose, and his face was now visible. Mr. Fogg sprang from his seat, and rushed towards the stage, followed by Aouda. The performers, who had been picking themselves up, were astonished at the sight of this gentleman, who was running towards them, followed by a lady. They were still more astonished when they saw the lady embrace one of the performers. Passepartout was delighted to see his master and Miss Aouda again, but he was so embarrassed by his costume and his painted face that he did not know what to say. Mr. Fogg, as phlegmatic as ever, said to him, "Well, Passepartout, you are found, I see."

simple_agent_extraction_refined_0.text: They reached their destination on the morning of the 14th of November. This was the date mentioned in the programme, and Phileas Fogg was neither twenty-four hours behind time, nor was he ahead of it. They landed at Yokohama. This town, with its excellent harbour, is one of the ports where the Pacific steamers call, and into which enter the great mail steamers from San Francisco, bound for the South Sea, and the land of the Mikado. These vessels belong to the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, and the Occidental and Oriental Steamship Company. LLM_completions.prefix-probing: They reached their destination on the morning of the 14th of November. This was Hong Kong, the fourth stop on their improbable journey around the world. Aboard the *Carnatic*, Phileas Fogg, accompanied by the rescued Aouda and his momentarily reliable valet, Passepartout, disembarked into the bustling port city. Their immediate task was to locate the relative of Aouda who resided there, a mission Phileas Fogg undertook with his usual punctuality and precision. However, the relative had moved away years prior, leaving no trace. While Fogg handled this setback stoically, Sergeant Fix, the relentless detective, saw his opportunity. He encountered Passepartout in a tavern and, desperate to delay Fogg until the elusive warrant arrived, plied the poor Frenchman with alcohol and opium, rendering him unconscious. Consequently, Passepartout failed to inform Mr. Fogg that the *Carnatic* was departing early and missed the ship himself. Fogg, finding no trace of Passepartout and assuming he would rejoin him later, quickly sought alternative passage to Yokohama with Aouda, locating a pilot boat named the *Tankadere* willing to take them to Shanghai, from where they could catch a steamer.

events.title: Passepartout's Explanation and Reintegration
detailed_summary: Aouda informed Passepartout about their journey from Hong Kong to Shanghai aboard the 'Tankadere', including Fix's presence.
Passepartout showed no outward reaction upon hearing Fix's name.
He decided it wasn't the right moment to reveal his interactions with the detective to Fogg.
When explaining his absence, he attributed it solely to being overcome by opium intoxication at a Hong Kong tavern.
Mr. Fogg listened to the explanation impassively, without comment.
He then gave Passepartout money to buy clothes suitable for his role.
In less than an hour, Passepartout had removed his costume components (nose and wings) and no longer resembled the performer.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: All this Passepartout learned from Aouda, who recounted to him what had taken place on the voyage from Hong Kong to Shanghai on the “Tankadere,” in company with one Mr. Fix.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Within an hour the Frenchman had cut off his nose and parted with his wings, and retained nothing about him which recalled the sectary of the god Tingou.

events.text_segment:
All this Passepartout learned from Aouda, who recounted to him what had taken place on the voyage from Hong Kong to Shanghai on the “Tankadere,” in company with one Mr. Fix.
Passepartout did not change countenance on hearing this name. He thought that the time had not yet arrived to divulge to his master what had taken place between the detective and himself; and, in the account he gave of his absence, he simply excused himself for having been overtaken by drunkenness, in smoking opium at a tavern in Hong Kong.
Mr. Fogg heard this narrative coldly, without a word; and then furnished his man with funds necessary to obtain clothing more in harmony with his position. Within an hour the Frenchman had cut off his nose and parted with his wings, and retained nothing about him which recalled the sectary of the god Tingou.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: All this Passepartout learned from Aouda, who recounted to him what had taken place on the voyage from Hong Kong to Shanghai on the “Tankadere,” in company with one Mr. Fix. Passepartout made no sign of surprise, and showed no other sentiment on hearing the detective's name. He saw at once that it was not the time to tell Mr. Fogg of the relations of the agent of the Bank of England with himself. As to the explanation of his absence, Passepartout confined himself to regretting his misfortune, and stating that, overcome by opium intoxication, he had been carried to the opium den from which he had been with difficulty rescued. This explanation was perfectly in accord with the facts, and besides, Mr. Fogg did not urge him for farther particulars. He contented himself with saying that the accident could not be helped, and that the most important thing was his having arrived in time to take the train for New York. Then he gave Passepartout instructions to purchase him some clothing, of which he was absolutely in need. Provided with the money, Passepartout went to the first shop, and speedily arrayed himself in an acceptable travelling suit. An hour after, and with the nose and wings of the god Juggernaut carefully packed in his trunk, there was nothing left of the opera-dancer.

events.title: Departure on the 'General Grant' for San Francisco
detailed_summary: The vessel for the Yokohama to San Francisco leg was the 'General Grant', operated by the Pacific Mail Steamship Company.
It was described as a large, 2,500-ton paddle-wheel steamer, well-appointed and fast.
Details of its engine mechanism, including the walking-beam, piston-rod, and connecting-rod driving the paddles, were noted.
The ship had three masts and substantial sail capacity to supplement its steam engine.
With a speed of twelve miles per hour, it was expected to complete the Pacific crossing in twenty-one days.
This schedule gave Phileas Fogg confidence in reaching San Francisco by December 2nd, New York by December 11th, and London by December 20th.
This timeline potentially offered a buffer of several hours before his December 21st deadline.

events.text_segment: The steamer which was about to depart from Yokohama to San Francisco belonged to the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, and was named the “General Grant.” She was a large paddle-wheel steamer of two thousand five hundred tons; well equipped and very fast. The massive walking-beam rose and fell above the deck; at one end a piston-rod worked up and down; and at the other was a connecting-rod which, in changing the rectilinear motion to a circular one, was directly connected with the shaft of the paddles. The “General Grant” was rigged with three masts, giving a large capacity for sails, and thus materially aiding the steam power. By making twelve miles an hour, she would cross the ocean in twenty-one days. Phileas Fogg was therefore justified in hoping that he would reach San Francisco by the 2nd of December, New York by the 11th, and London on the 20th—thus gaining several hours on the fatal date of the 21st of December.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The steamer which was about to depart from Yokohama to San Francisco belonged to the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, and was named the “General Grant.” It was a large paddle-wheel steamer of two thousand five hundred tons, well appointed and a rapid sailer. Its engine was of the walking-beam type; its piston-rod crossed the bulwarks, and worked perpendicularly on a beam supported by a strong standard; and the connecting-rod, in its turn, transmitted the motion to the shaft of the paddles. The “General Grant” had three masts and a large top-sail, and was capable of a high speed. Its speed was twelve miles an hour, and it was not doubted that the Pacific would be crossed in twenty-one days. Phileas Fogg was therefore confident that he would reach San Francisco by the 2nd of December: he would arrive in New York by the 11th, and London by the 20th of December, thus gaining several hours on the twenty-first, the famous date of his arrival in London, and consequently of his winning or losing the wager.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The steamer which was about to depart from Yokohama to San Francisco belonged to the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, and was named the “General Grant.” It was a magnificent vessel, widely known for its speed and capacity, deemed perfectly suited for the lengthy trans-Pacific voyage that lay ahead. Phileas Fogg, ever punctual and composed, had already secured his first-class cabin, a compact yet luxurious space that met his exacting standards precisely. Passepartout, though still reeling from his recent escapades in Japan, was equally prepared to board, eager to leave behind the unpredictable adventures and return to the more predictable rhythm of Fogg’s remarkable journey. The quayside buzzed with activity; porters rushed with luggage, families bid emotional goodbyes, and the ship's crew completed their final preparations. The air was thick with the smell of coal smoke and saltwater, a potent mix signalling the imminent departure across the vast Pacific Ocean towards the American continent. Fogg and Passepartout, accompanied by Fix, who remained stubbornly attached to their heels, watched the final cargo being loaded, anticipation quietly building for the long, challenging crossing that lay ahead, the next major leg of their extraordinary race against time.

events.title: Smooth Pacific Crossing and Developing Relationships
detailed_summary: The 'General Grant' carried a diverse group of passengers, including British, American, Chinese laborers heading to California, and East Indian officers on a world tour.
The voyage across the Pacific was uneventful.
The large paddle steamer remained stable, experiencing little rolling, living up to the ocean's peaceful reputation.
Mr. Fogg maintained his usual calm and reserved demeanor.
Aouda found her feelings for Fogg deepening beyond simple gratitude.
His quiet generosity made a strong impression on her, leading to developing emotions she acted upon almost unconsciously, which seemed unnoticed by him.
Aouda became deeply invested in Fogg's travel plans, growing anxious about any potential delays.
She frequently conversed with Passepartout.
Passepartout recognized Aouda's growing affection for Fogg.
As a loyal servant, he consistently praised Fogg's positive qualities: integrity, generosity, and dedication.
He actively sought to alleviate Aouda's anxieties about the journey's success, assuring her the hardest parts were over.
He expressed confidence that crossing America by train and the Atlantic by steamer would ensure they met the deadline.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was a full complement of passengers on board, among them English, many Americans, a large number of coolies on their way to California, and several East Indian officers, who were spending their vacation in making the tour of the world.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: A railway train from San Francisco to New York, and a transatlantic steamer from New York to Liverpool, would doubtless bring them to the end of this impossible journey round the world within the period agreed upon.

events.text_segment:
There was a full complement of passengers on board, among them English, many Americans, a large number of coolies on their way to California, and several East Indian officers, who were spending their vacation in making the tour of the world. Nothing of moment happened on the voyage; the steamer, sustained on its large paddles, rolled but little, and the “Pacific” almost justified its name. Mr. Fogg was as calm and taciturn as ever. His young companion felt herself more and more attached to him by other ties than gratitude; his silent but generous nature impressed her more than she thought; and it was almost unconsciously that she yielded to emotions which did not seem to have the least effect upon her protector. Aouda took the keenest interest in his plans, and became impatient at any incident which seemed likely to retard his journey.
She often chatted with Passepartout, who did not fail to perceive the state of the lady’s heart; and, being the most faithful of domestics, he never exhausted his eulogies of Phileas Fogg’s honesty, generosity, and devotion. He took pains to calm Aouda’s doubts of a successful termination of the journey, telling her that the most difficult part of it had passed, that now they were beyond the fantastic countries of Japan and China, and were fairly on their way to civilised places again. A railway train from San Francisco to New York, and a transatlantic steamer from New York to Liverpool, would doubtless bring them to the end of this impossible journey round the world within the period agreed upon.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: There was a full complement of passengers on board, among them English, many Americans, a large number of coolies on their way to California, and several East Indian officers, who were spending their vacation in making the tour of the world. The crossing of the Pacific was accomplished under excellent conditions. The great steamer, propped up on its large paddles, ploughed the waves well. The "General Grant" rolled but little, and was rarely tossed by the billows. The Pacific, well justified its name. Mr. Fogg was as calm and taciturn as ever. Aouda became more and more attached to her-uncommon protector. She admired his imperturbable coolness, and the generosity which she knew, though he carefully concealed it, was the spring of his actions. She often conversed with Passepartout, who lost no opportunity of chanting his master's praise; he informed her of the Frenchman's courage and honesty, and magnified his merits, in order that he might more fully impress Aouda with the importance of the service which she owed to his employer. As the honest fellow had surmised, Aouda's heart was touched; her gratitude towards Fogg was less and less of a duty, and became a feeling which his sweet and noble nature inspired. She unconsciously dwelt upon the kind attention he had bestowed upon her, his inexhaustible good will, and the brave man's silence, which rendered the service the more flattering, as it seemed the less ostentatious. These were the elements which she was constantly distilling, and which were busily preparing the liquid fusion. Aouda was not aware of the consequences of her entirely new sensations. When Passepartout vaunted the master's integrity, his nobility, his devotion, and his generosity, Aouda listened with marked interest, and her fine eyes shone with unwonted lustre. Mr. Fogg, meanwhile, preserved his habitual silence. He talked but little, and seemed not to notice the new sentiments which were developing in Aouda. He was present at the daily card-parties, and played his rubber of whist, according to his invariable habit. Aouda came regularly to watch him play, and grew daily more and more interested in his luck. She would fain have ventured to advise him when he seemed to be in danger, and blushes overspread her cheeks when she thought, that in a few days the tour of the world would be finished, and that then she would have to thank the gentleman and say farewell. Passepartout saw what was going on, and heartily approved of it, for he thought his master the best of men. It was on this account that he was not in the least alarmed at the sudden caprice which had taken possession of Mr. Fogg of occupying himself on board with Aouda's future. He knew that Mr. Fogg's heart was in the right place, and that, for a man so generous and honourable, whatever he did would be well done. Passepartout endeavoured by a thousand attentions to lighten the tedium of the voyage, for both Mr. Fogg and Aouda. He told them the most astonishing stories about his own life, and adventures without end. He sang songs to Aouda, who was not insensible to the great compliment which the good fellow's vocal talents paid her; and finally he interested himself in the cuisine on board, and made great friends with the steward, an excellent Frenchman, who was both cook and purser. Between the meals and the rubbers of whist, the hours glided by, swift on account of the rapid rate of the steamer. On the 6th of December, the day before landing at San Francisco, Mr. Fogg was engaged in working out the number of miles run, and Passepartout stood by, looking on. "Is it that you are counting, Mr. Fogg, that we are going right?" asked Passepartout. "Provided that the engine keeps on in this way, we shall arrive at San Francisco on the 7th, at eleven a.m." "And you do not doubt it?" "Not in the least." Passepartout would have liked to ask if he was sure about the journey across America, and the Atlantic, but he knew that Mr. Fogg did not like to be questioned. He was, however, sure that the hardest part of the journey was over, since they had crossed the oceans. The vast American continent would be easy travelling, and the railway from San Francisco to New York would doubtless be finished. And after that there was a steamer from New York to Liverpool, and then the railway from Liverpool to London, which would be in good time for the 21st of December, the famous date. The 7th of December, about half-past ten a.m., the coast of America was signalled, and twenty minutes later the steamer was entering the Bay of San Francisco. At eleven o'clock the vessel was at the quay, and Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout were at last upon American soil, having made the tour from London in eighty-five days.
