LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Aouda, leaning upon Mr. Fogg’s arm, observed the tumultuous scene with surprise, while Fix asked a man near him what the cause of it all was. The man, a stout fellow with a breathless face, turned to Fix. "It's Mr. Fogg!" he exclaimed, his voice almost lost in the general din. "Phileas Fogg! The gentleman who's gone around the world! He's expected back any minute! Everyone's here to see if he's done it!" Fix, ever the detective, pressed further. "Around the world?" he feigned ignorance, though his heart hammered against his ribs. "Why this commotion, then?" "Why?" the man repeated, eyes wide. "He wagered twenty thousand pounds! Twenty thousand! On travelling around the globe in eighty days! News arrived by telegraph – he was in Ireland yesterday! They say he's coming straight here, to the Reform Club, to claim his prize! The papers have been full of it! Some say he's a hero, others a madman!" Aouda glanced at Fogg, who, despite the pandemonium, remained as impassive as a statue. His face showed no trace of triumph, no anxiety, only the usual calm determination. For her part, the excitement of the crowd seemed utterly foreign and bewildering. She had shared the long journey, the dangers, the quiet companionship, but this public spectacle, this fervent interest in a man who seemed to shun all attention, was beyond her comprehension. "He is a man of his word," Aouda said softly to Fix, though her gaze was fixed on Fogg. Fix merely nodded, a knot tightening in his stomach. He knew better than anyone else the true cost of Fogg's unexpected day's delay in Liverpool – the day he had apprehended him. That single, disastrous setback seemed to have irrevocably ruined Fogg's chances, despite the seemingly triumphant return. He watched Fogg navigate the throng with surprising ease, his presence commanding a strange respect that forced gaps in the crowd. Each step towards the Reform Club was a step closer to the deadline, a deadline Fix was certain Fogg would miss, perhaps by mere minutes. The cheering, the shouting, the sheer weight of expectation from the multitude felt like a physical pressure. They were reaching the end of a journey unlike any other, and the outcome, Fix believed with grim certainty, was failure. The crowd, unaware of the critical delay, pushed and surged, eager for a glimpse of the famous, or infamous, Phileas Fogg, oblivious to the fact that the final, crucial race against time was happening in these last desperate moments on the streets of London. Fogg, however, strode on, the seconds ticking away towards 8:45 P.M., the appointed hour.

events.title: Aftermath and Attire Repair
detailed_summary: The crowd moved past, knocking Fix down momentarily; he quickly recovered, though his clothes were torn.
Fix was bruised but not seriously injured; his coat was ripped, and his trousers damaged.
Aouda remained unharmed.
Fogg thanked Fix for his intervention.
Fix dismissed the thanks and suggested they find a tailor.
The visit was necessary as both Fogg's and Fix's clothing were in tatters.
They spent an hour getting suitably re-dressed before returning with Aouda to the hotel.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The human tide now swept by, after overturning Fix, who speedily got upon his feet again, though with tattered clothes.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: An hour after, they were once more suitably attired, and with Aouda returned to the International Hotel.

events.text_segment:
The human tide now swept by, after overturning Fix, who speedily got upon his feet again, though with tattered clothes. Happily, he was not seriously hurt. His travelling overcoat was divided into two unequal parts, and his trousers resembled those of certain Indians, which fit less compactly than they are easy to put on. Aouda had escaped unharmed, and Fix alone bore marks of the fray in his black and blue bruise.
“Thanks,” said Mr. Fogg to the detective, as soon as they were out of the crowd.
“No thanks are necessary,” replied Fix; “but let us go.”
“Where?”
“To a tailor’s.”
Such a visit was, indeed, opportune. The clothing of both Mr. Fogg and Fix was in rags, as if they had themselves been actively engaged in the contest between Camerfield and Mandiboy. An hour after, they were once more suitably attired, and with Aouda returned to the International Hotel.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The human tide now swept by, after overturning Fix, who speedily got upon his feet again, though with tattered clothes. He was not however injured, and, hastening back to Mr. Fogg, he said, “You are not hurt, sir?” “Not in the least, Mr. Fix.” “And Madame?” “Is safe and sound. You were roughly handled, but I hope not seriously injured.” “Not at all, Mr. Fogg; it's of no consequence. But your clothes—” “Ah, my clothes!” Mr. Fogg observed that his own garments were torn to ribbons. His honourable companion's pantaloons were even without a leg, and a portion of his coat-sleeve was carried away. There were many others in the crowd in as poor a plight as themselves. “I see, Mr. Fix,” said Mr. Fogg, “that we are as badly off. A visit to a tailor's is indispensable.” “I’ll make you one with pleasure, Mr. Fogg. There’s a good deal of cotton here, and we shall no doubt find a tailor.” “And that, too, immediately.” This was a happy inspiration of Fix’s, and they immediately set out in search of a tailor, and found one who was not unwilling to furnish them with complete suits. When they had dressed, they returned to the International Hotel, and Fix had the satisfaction of perceiving that Mr. Fogg and Aouda were still safe and sound.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: The human tide now swept by, after overturning Fix, who speedily got upon his feet again, though with tattered clothes. He was bruised, but not seriously injured; his coat was ripped in two, and his trousers, which were of a peculiar make, were torn to rags. His overcoat was also in a pitiable condition. Happily, Aouda had escaped unharmed, and Fix alone bore the marks of the fray. "You are a brave fellow," said Mr. Fogg, as soon as they were out of the crowd. "Thanks, Mr. Fogg," replied Fix; "don't mention it. Let us get to a tailor's." This was a necessary precaution, for both gentlemen's garments were in tatters, having been almost torn from their backs in the contest between the two parties. An hour having been spent in repairing their wardrobes, they returned with Aouda to the International Hotel.

- The completion implies both gentlemen's garments were almost torn from their backs in the contest, which is a slight exaggeration compared to the original's description.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_3.text: The human tide now swept by, after overturning Fix, who speedily got upon his feet again, though with tattered clothes. He was bruised, but not seriously injured; he had a black and blue bruise, and his trousers, which were of a peculiar make, were torn to rags. His coat was torn in two, and his overcoat was divided into two unequal parts. Happily, Aouda had escaped unharmed, and Fix alone bore the marks of the fray. “Thanks,” said Mr. Fogg to the detective, as soon as they were out of the crowd. “No thanks are necessary, Mr. Fogg,” replied Fix. “Let us get to a tailor's.” “To a tailor's?” cried Fix. “Precisely. An opportune idea. Come.” This was a necessary precaution, for both gentlemen's garments were in rags, as if they had themselves been actively engaged in the contest between Camerfield and Mandiboy. An hour having been spent in thus clothing themselves anew, they returned with Aouda to the International Hotel.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The human tide now swept by, after overturning Fix, who speedily got upon his feet again, though with tattered clothes. He smoothed his hat, adjusted his coat, his face grim. The brief delay had merely strengthened his purpose. Fix saw Fogg and the others heading for the platforms and the waiting train, its engine hissing loudly, quite ready to depart. He couldn't afford to lose them now. Plunging back into the dense crowd, he pushed and elbowed, muttering apologies. The station was a chaotic din of steam, whistles, and shouts. Fix fought the multitude, eyes fixed ahead. He had to get on that train. Failure was not an option. Driven by desperation and the thought of reward, he scrambled forward relentlessly, determined to reach the carriages before departure, hoping the warrant would arrive soon.

events.title: Reconciliation, Departure Preparations, and Boarding the Train
detailed_summary: Passepartout awaited Fogg at the hotel, having acquired several revolvers.
He initially frowned upon seeing Fix with his master.
Aouda quickly explained the events of the political rally and Fix's actions.
Hearing this, Passepartout's demeanor changed, accepting Fix as an ally who was upholding his promise.
After dinner, a coach arrived to take them to the train station.
As they boarded, Fogg asked Fix if he had encountered Colonel Proctor again, which Fix denied.
Fogg calmly stated his intention to return to America specifically to find Proctor and retaliate for the insult.
Fix smiled silently, recognizing Fogg's adherence to a code of honor regarding such confrontations abroad.
At 5:45 p.m., they reached the station where the train was ready.
Before boarding, Fogg asked a porter about the day's disturbance in San Francisco.
The porter explained it was just a political meeting for an election.
Fogg inquired if it was for a high office like general-in-chief.
The porter clarified it was only for the election of a justice of the peace.
Fogg boarded the train, which immediately departed at high speed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Passepartout was waiting for his master, armed with half a dozen six-barrelled revolvers.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Phileas Fogg got into the train, which started off at full speed.

events.text_segment:
Passepartout was waiting for his master, armed with half a dozen six-barrelled revolvers. When he perceived Fix, he knit his brows; but Aouda having, in a few words, told him of their adventure, his countenance resumed its placid expression. Fix evidently was no longer an enemy, but an ally; he was faithfully keeping his word.
Dinner over, the coach which was to convey the passengers and their luggage to the station drew up to the door. As he was getting in, Mr. Fogg said to Fix, “You have not seen this Colonel Proctor again?”
“No.”
“I will come back to America to find him,” said Phileas Fogg calmly. “It would not be right for an Englishman to permit himself to be treated in that way, without retaliating.”
The detective smiled, but did not reply. It was clear that Mr. Fogg was one of those Englishmen who, while they do not tolerate duelling at home, fight abroad when their honour is attacked.
At a quarter before six the travellers reached the station, and found the train ready to depart. As he was about to enter it, Mr. Fogg called a porter, and said to him: “My friend, was there not some trouble to-day in San Francisco?”
“It was a political meeting, sir,” replied the porter.
“But I thought there was a great deal of disturbance in the streets.”
“It was only a meeting assembled for an election.”
“The election of a general-in-chief, no doubt?” asked Mr. Fogg.
“No, sir; of a justice of the peace.”
Phileas Fogg got into the train, which started off at full speed.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Passepartout was waiting for his master, armed with half a dozen six-barrelled revolvers. When Mr. Fogg returned, he was accompanied by Aouda and Fix. Fix came and went as usual, but Passepartout would have been glad to have done without his company. It was very evident that he had not got over the feeling caused by the events at Calcutta. As Aouda, however, informed him of what had occurred on the quay, and that Fix had acted like a man of honour, Passepartout's countenance resumed its usual expression, and he consented to ignore the detective's presence. The dinner was good, and served at a most liberal rate, at the Grand Hotel; and afterwards a carriage conveyed the travellers to the station. On the way, Mr. Fogg asked Fix if he had observed Colonel Proctor's presence in San Francisco. "No, sir," replied Fix; "but I've had no time to poke about." "And yet it is likely that I may meet him," returned Mr. Fogg; "he dare not attempt to track me in a country where I am free." "If I were he," said Passepartout, "I would humbly ask your pardon." "That would be for him to determine," replied Phileas Fogg, "but he would not dare return to America, where I am going to return." The train was about to start when Mr. Fogg and his companions reached the station. Passepartout sprang into a car, and his fellow-travellers followed him. Just as Mr. Fogg was about to enter, he accosted a porter and asked him, "My friend, was there not some trouble in San Francisco to-day? A political meeting, I suppose?" "It was an election," replied the porter; "and there was a lively row about it. The 'Honourable' Mr. Mandiboy was a little roughly handled." "Nevertheless," resumed Mr. Fogg, "the presence of the troops did not prevent the disturbance?" "Indeed," replied the porter; "but there was no obligation on the soldiers' part to interfere. The citizens were contending among themselves." "And what was the subject of the discussion?" asked Mr. Fogg. "Only about an election for a justice of the peace." Phileas Fogg concluded that the disturbance was purely local, and went into the car. The train left at 5:45 p.m.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Passepartout was waiting for his master, armed with half a dozen six-barrelled revolvers. He paced the pavement near the Reform Club, his heart pounding a frantic rhythm against his ribs. It was Sunday, December 21st, the very last day. The air was thick with tension, not just for him, but for the small crowd that had gathered, drawn by the incredible drama of Mr. Fogg's audacious journey. Every stroke of the clock seemed to hammer the nail of fate. He checked his watch again; it was nearing nine o'clock. The deadline was 8:45 p.m. Had they missed it? Had all their perils, the storms, the delays, the encounters with Fix and the Sioux, been in vain? His master, usually so calm and imperturbable, had shown signs of distress in the last few hours, especially after his confrontation with Fix in Liverpool. Passepartout cursed the detective under his breath. If not for that unjust arrest, they would surely be within the club's doors by now, Mr. Fogg presenting his passport and winning the seemingly impossible wager. He clutched one of the heavy revolvers more tightly, ready to defend his master against any further interference, though who he expected to fight in the streets of London on a Sunday evening, he wasn't entirely sure. His master's honour, and indeed, his immense fortune, hung in the balance. A low murmur went through the crowd. Passepartout strained his eyes, searching for the familiar, precise figure of Phileas Fogg. The minutes ticked by, each one a lifetime. Was it over? Had they lost? The thought was unbearable. He couldn't imagine life after this adventure if it ended in defeat and ruin for his master. Then, a ripple of excitement from the crowd...

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXVI. IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG AND PARTY TRAVEL BY THE PACIFIC RAILROAD

events.title: The Great American Railway Network
detailed_summary: The term "From ocean to ocean" signifies the primary railway line spanning the United States.
This Pacific Railroad system is composed of two main sections: the Central Pacific (San Francisco to Ogden) and the Union Pacific (Ogden to Omaha).
Omaha connects to New York via five principal railway lines.
An unbroken railway line of 3,786 miles connects New York and San Francisco.
The section between Omaha and the Pacific crosses territories inhabited by Indigenous peoples and wildlife, as well as lands settled by Mormons after their expulsion from Illinois in 1845.
The railway drastically reduced the coast-to-coast journey time from a minimum of six months to just seven days.
The decision to build the railway between the 41st and 42nd parallels was made in 1862, despite opposition from Southern representatives advocating a more southern route.
President Lincoln designated Omaha, Nebraska, as the line's terminus.
Construction commenced immediately with notable American speed and efficiency, achieving roughly 1.5 miles of track laid per day on the prairies.
Locomotives used the newly laid tracks to transport materials for the next day's construction.
The Pacific Railroad integrates with several branch lines across Iowa, Kansas, Colorado, and Oregon.

The route from Omaha follows the Platte River, crosses the Laramie territory and Wahsatch Mountains, skirts the Great Salt Lake reaching Salt Lake City, traverses the Tuilla Valley, American Desert, Cedar and Humboldt Mountains, and the Sierra Nevada, finally descending through Sacramento to the Pacific.
The railway's grade, even through the Rocky Mountains, does not exceed 112 feet per mile.
This seven-day railway journey was essential for Phileas Fogg's plan to reach New York by December 11th to board the steamer for Liverpool.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “From ocean to ocean”—so say the Americans; and these four words compose the general designation of the “great trunk line” which crosses the entire width of the United States.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Such was the road to be traversed in seven days, which would enable Phileas Fogg—at least, so he hoped—to take the Atlantic steamer at New York on the 11th for Liverpool.

events.text_segment:
“From ocean to ocean”—so say the Americans; and these four words compose the general designation of the “great trunk line” which crosses the entire width of the United States. The Pacific Railroad is, however, really divided into two distinct lines: the Central Pacific, between San Francisco and Ogden, and the Union Pacific, between Ogden and Omaha. Five main lines connect Omaha with New York.
New York and San Francisco are thus united by an uninterrupted metal ribbon, which measures no less than three thousand seven hundred and eighty-six miles. Between Omaha and the Pacific the railway crosses a territory which is still infested by Indians and wild beasts, and a large tract which the Mormons, after they were driven from Illinois in 1845, began to colonise.
The journey from New York to San Francisco consumed, formerly, under the most favourable conditions, at least six months. It is now accomplished in seven days.
It was in 1862 that, in spite of the Southern Members of Congress, who wished a more southerly route, it was decided to lay the road between the forty-first and forty-second parallels. President Lincoln himself fixed the end of the line at Omaha, in Nebraska. The work was at once commenced, and pursued with true American energy; nor did the rapidity with which it went on injuriously affect its good execution. The road grew, on the prairies, a mile and a half a day. A locomotive, running on the rails laid down the evening before, brought the rails to be laid on the morrow, and advanced upon them as fast as they were put in position.
The Pacific Railroad is joined by several branches in Iowa, Kansas, Colorado, and Oregon. On leaving Omaha, it passes along the left bank of the Platte River as far as the junction of its northern branch, follows its southern branch, crosses the Laramie territory and the Wahsatch Mountains, turns the Great Salt Lake, and reaches Salt Lake City, the Mormon capital, plunges into the Tuilla Valley, across the American Desert, Cedar and Humboldt Mountains, the Sierra Nevada, and descends, viâ Sacramento, to the Pacific—its grade, even on the Rocky Mountains, never exceeding one hundred and twelve feet to the mile.
Such was the road to be traversed in seven days, which would enable Phileas Fogg—at least, so he hoped—to take the Atlantic steamer at New York on the 11th for Liverpool.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: “From ocean to ocean”—so say the Americans; and these four words compose the general designation of the “great trunk line” which crosses the entire width of the United States. The Pacific Railroad is, in effect, the shortest highway, uniting the Atlantic and the Pacific, and must inevitably be of still greater importance in the future, by the development of the rich territories which it crosses. The Rocky Mountains are already pierced by this great鐵道, and will soon be surmounted by others, connecting the great cities of the East with the valley of the Mississippi, and San Francisco. This grand railway is composed of two parts: the Central Pacific, between San Francisco and Ogden, and the Union Pacific, between Ogden and Omaha. Five railways connect Omaha with New York. The railway line, passing through thirteen counties, which are Colorado, Utah, Nevada, California, etc., is 3,786 miles long, and is traversed in seven days. The trains of the Pacific Railroad started from Omaha on the 26th of October, 1868, and from San Francisco on the 8th of November of the same year; and the roads were joined on the 10th of May, 1869. The line from Omaha to the Pacific traverses territories still frequented by Indians and wild beasts, and in which the Mormons, after their expulsion from Illinois in 1845, founded a colony, with their chief city at Salt Lake City. Before the railway was built, the journey from New York to San Francisco occupied at least six months. It is now accomplished in seven days. It is true that the building of this great railway was attended with difficulties, and that the Southern delegates in Congress contended in vain for a more southern route; but in 1862, after much discussion, the present line was adopted between the 41st and 42nd parallels. President Lincoln himself fixed the terminus of the line at Omaha, in Nebraska. The work was at once commenced with that American energy and rapidity which neither financial difficulties nor obstacles of soil or climate can check. On the prairies, the work went on at the rate of a mile and a half a day. Locomotives, running on the rails as they were laid, brought up the rails and sleepers for the next day’s work, and advanced as the track advanced. The Pacific Railroad connects with several branch lines, in Iowa, Kansas, Colorado, and Oregon. At Omaha, it is connected with Chicago by the Chicago and Rock Island Railroad, and with St. Louis by the Pacific Railroad of Missouri. It follows the left bank of the Platte River to the Laramie plains, crosses the Wahsatch Mountains and the Great Salt Lake, skirts the desert of alkali, crosses the Tuilla Valley, the American Desert, the Cedar and Humboldt Mountains, the Sierra Nevada, descends through Sacramento to the Pacific, and reaches San Francisco on the southern shore of the bay. The grade of the railway is not excessive, even in the Rocky Mountains; and the trains reach the highest altitude, 112 feet per mile, in crossing the Wahsatch Mountains. This railway journey, by the swiftest trains, was what Mr. Fogg intended to make use of for his journey to New York, where he hoped to arrive on the 11th of December, in time for the Liverpool steamer.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: “From ocean to ocean”—so say the Americans; and these four words compose the general designation of the “great trunk line” which crosses the entire width of the United States. From San Francisco to New York, the measurement is three thousand seven hundred and eighty-six miles. From New York to San Francisco, the railway company has calculated that four trains per day suffice for the travel, and that the transit is accomplished in seven days. The company has published a time-table, with the details for each day, the halts at the stations, and the number of miles accomplished. This great artery of communication begins at the city of New York, and passes through the states of New Jersey and Pennsylvania, touches Philadelphia, traverses Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, touches Chicago, goes through Iowa, crosses the Missouri at Council Bluffs, goes through Nebraska, touches Omaha, skirts the territory of Utah and the Great Salt Lake, goes through Wyoming and Nevada, by the Pacific, enters California, and reaches the terminus at San Francisco—in fine, connecting five large cities and ten states.The road was commenced in 1862, and finished on the 8th of May, 1869, having cost one hundred million dollars.It is the grandest work, and the most useful one, as well as the greatest railway on the globe. The emigrants, until this period, were compelled to embark at New York on board of ships bound around Cape Horn, or the Isthmus of Panama.The railway now carries them from one ocean to the other in seven days, which before occupied six months.Upon the Pullman cars, which are provided with every convenience, and luxurious at the same time, passengers live as if they were on shipboard. They are provided with dining-cars, smoking-cars, library-cars; and the train is supplied with baggage-cars, the post-office car, and the car set apart for the use of the conductor. In this way, and at moderate prices, for the fare is low, the public can travel more than three thousand seven hundred miles from New York to San Francisco.

events.title: Aboard the Transcontinental Train
detailed_summary: The train car Phileas Fogg traveled in resembled a lengthy, open-plan bus mounted on eight wheels.
Inside, seats were arranged in two rows along the sides, separated by a central aisle leading to platforms at both ends.
These platforms were standard throughout the train, permitting passengers to move freely between cars.
The train boasted various amenities, including saloon cars, balcony cars, restaurants, and smoking cars; only theatre cars were absent, though anticipated in the future.
Vendors selling books, newspapers, food, beverages, and cigars constantly moved through the aisles, finding many buyers.
The train departed from Oakland station at 6:00 PM.
The evening was cold and gloomy, with overcast skies suggesting imminent snow.
The train proceeded at a moderate pace, averaging about twenty miles per hour including stops, deemed sufficient to arrive in Omaha on schedule.
Conversation among passengers was minimal, and many quickly drifted off to sleep.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The car which he occupied was a sort of long omnibus on eight wheels, and with no compartments in the interior.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: There was but little conversation in the car, and soon many of the passengers were overcome with sleep.

events.text_segment:
The car which he occupied was a sort of long omnibus on eight wheels, and with no compartments in the interior. It was supplied with two rows of seats, perpendicular to the direction of the train on either side of an aisle which conducted to the front and rear platforms. These platforms were found throughout the train, and the passengers were able to pass from one end of the train to the other. It was supplied with saloon cars, balcony cars, restaurants, and smoking-cars; theatre cars alone were wanting, and they will have these some day.
Book and news dealers, sellers of edibles, drinkables, and cigars, who seemed to have plenty of customers, were continually circulating in the aisles.
The train left Oakland station at six o’clock. It was already night, cold and cheerless, the heavens being overcast with clouds which seemed to threaten snow. The train did not proceed rapidly; counting the stoppages, it did not run more than twenty miles an hour, which was a sufficient speed, however, to enable it to reach Omaha within its designated time.
There was but little conversation in the car, and soon many of the passengers were overcome with sleep.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The car which he occupied was a sort of long omnibus on eight wheels, and with no compartments in the interior. Seats were arranged along the sides, and the central aisle led to the platforms without. These platforms were provided with a railing, and they allowed passengers to pass from one end of the train to the other. It was long, like a street, and comfortably warmed, and in it travellers could buy the various wares of vendors. Saloon cars, with balconies, restaurant-cars, smoking-cars, were all hauled by the same locomotive. It went without saying that enterprising Americans had thought of everything for securing comfort on the railway. There were hairdressers' shops, baths, smoking-rooms, libraries. One could even get married by telegraph from one end of the continent to the other. It was indeed a moving village, supplied with everything, not missing theatre-cars, though these are expected soon. Vendors passed through the cars, selling to the travellers journals, periodicals, novels, the latest works of the most celebrated authors; while others offered carminatives, travelling-caps, and every kind of article for the traveller's comfort. Food, drinks, and cigars; it seemed a veritable hotel on wheels; and indeed it was supplied with every imaginable luxury. At six o'clock the train started on time. The weather was cold and gloomy; it was snowing slightly, and the snow was quickly changing into sleet. The train did not run very rapidly. Including stoppages, it did not go faster than twenty miles an hour, a speed, however, which would enable it to cross the States within the fixed time. The conversation soon ceased, and the travellers wrapped themselves in their rugs and went to sleep.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The car which he occupied was a sort of long omnibus on eight wheels, and with no compartments in the interior. It was provided with comfortable seats, placed lengthwise, and the passengers consisted of a miscellaneous company of Europeans, mostly officers of the army, and wealthy natives. Mr. Fogg and Aouda took their seats near the door, while Passepartout installed himself opposite them. The train started punctually at half-past eight. The country traversed by the railway was a vast plain, cultivated in part, and watered by numerous small rivers. Further on, they passed through thick forests of palms, which were replaced by cotton-trees, sugar-canes, and indigo plantations. The scenery was monotonous at first, but gradually became more varied and interesting as they approached the mountainous region towards the north-east. They caught glimpses of scattered villages, whose inhabitants, though differing in race and customs, were uniformly dressed in white turbans and robes. The train proceeded at a good speed, though not excessive, averaging about twenty miles an hour. Passepartout found the journey somewhat dull after the excitement of Bombay, but Mr. Fogg seemed perfectly content, observing the landscape with his usual imperturbable calm, occasionally consulting his Bradshaw. Aouda, for her part, watched the passing scenery with a mixture of curiosity and apprehension, still recovering from the ordeal she had recently faced. The rhythmic clatter of the wheels on the rails was the principal sound, occasionally interrupted by the whistle of the locomotive or the shouts of railway workers at the small stations they passed without stopping.

events.title: Nightfall, Tension, and Transformation
detailed_summary: Passepartout was seated near Detective Fix, but avoided conversation due to the cooling of their relations after recent incidents.
Any previous mutual understanding or closeness between them had dissipated.
While Fix's outward behavior remained unchanged, Passepartout adopted a reserved stance, feeling hostile towards his former acquaintance.
About an hour into the journey, a fine snow began to fall, but it wasn't heavy enough to hinder the train's progress.
Visibility through the windows was limited to a vast expanse of white, against which the locomotive's smoke appeared greyish.
At 8:00 PM, a steward announced it was time to prepare for bed.
The car rapidly transformed into a sleeping compartment.
Seatbacks were adjusted, cleverly stored bedsteads were deployed, and berths were quickly set up.
Each traveler soon had access to a comfortable bed equipped with clean sheets, soft pillows, and thick curtains for privacy.
Passengers settled in for the night as the train continued its journey through California.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Passepartout found himself beside the detective; but he did not talk to him.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It only remained to go to bed and sleep which everybody did—while the train sped on across the State of California.

events.text_segment:
Passepartout found himself beside the detective; but he did not talk to him. After recent events, their relations with each other had grown somewhat cold; there could no longer be mutual sympathy or intimacy between them. Fix’s manner had not changed; but Passepartout was very reserved, and ready to strangle his former friend on the slightest provocation.
Snow began to fall an hour after they started, a fine snow, however, which happily could not obstruct the train; nothing could be seen from the windows but a vast, white sheet, against which the smoke of the locomotive had a greyish aspect.
At eight o’clock a steward entered the car and announced that the time for going to bed had arrived; and in a few minutes the car was transformed into a dormitory. The backs of the seats were thrown back, bedsteads carefully packed were rolled out by an ingenious system, berths were suddenly improvised, and each traveller had soon at his disposition a comfortable bed, protected from curious eyes by thick curtains. The sheets were clean and the pillows soft. It only remained to go to bed and sleep which everybody did—while the train sped on across the State of California.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Passepartout found himself beside the detective; but he did not talk to him. Their relations had cooled singularly within the past twenty-four hours; Fix’s freely expressed aversion to the tour, the unlucky accident which had happened to the minister, the detective’s participation in it, all had tended to dissolve the imperfect acquaintance which had been established between them. Passepartout was by nature anything but revengeful, but at present he felt an almost irresistible desire to pull Fix’s nose. Fix regarded this cooling of intercourse with an entirely serene air. He did not betray the least vexation at the sudden recoil, which he knew was inevitable. For the rest, he did not cease to dog Passepartout, and awaited an opportunity to renew his pursuit of the master through the servant. An hour after leaving Sacramento, a fine snow began to fall, but it was only a powdery dust, and did not in the least obstruct the train’s progress. Nothing was to be seen from the windows but a vast, monotonous plain, the immense Plains of California, till the summits of the Sierra Nevada began to show themselves in the distance. The car was comfortably fitted up, and the car was full of passengers, many of whom were English, and there were some American officers. At eight o’clock the steward announced that it was time to go to bed. The car was speedily transformed into a dormitory. The backs of the seats were doubled over, and ingeniously-contrived beds were pulled down from the roof. In a few moments the car became a series of little chambers, separated by curtains; and each traveller had at his disposal a comfortable bed, with clean sheets, and warm coverings, while thick curtains shut out the view of the car itself. The passengers slipped into their berths, and went to sleep, while the train sped on through California with the speed of forty miles an hour.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Passepartout found himself beside the detective; but he did not talk to him. He had long since divined the purpose of this persistent follower. The questions, the coincidences, the sudden appearances – all pointed to a relentless, silent pursuit. Passepartout, loyal to Mr. Fogg and increasingly wary, had chosen silence as his weapon. He would reveal nothing, not even an inadvertent clue, that might jeopardize his master's incredible wager. Fix, on his part, watched the Frenchman with narrowed eyes. He knew Passepartout held secrets, whether intentionally or not. He hoped the strain of the journey, the proximity, the sheer tension of the situation, would eventually break down the servant's reserve. He tried leading questions, feigned casual interest in Mr. Fogg's habits, but Passepartout remained frustratingly impassive, answering only in monosyllables or simply averting his gaze. This silent war of nerves continued day after day aboard the hasty steamer. The air between them was thick with unspoken suspicion and caution. Passepartout felt like a mouse being stalked by a cat, constantly aware of the predator's presence, even when the detective seemed preoccupied. He yearned for the journey's end, for the moment they would step ashore and this uncomfortable, dangerous proximity would cease. He trusted in Mr. Fogg's genius to see them through, but the detective’s shadow was a constant, chilling reminder of the stakes involved. He resolved to remain vigilant and silent until they reached England.

events.title: Through California and the Sierra Nevada
detailed_summary: The landscape between San Francisco and Sacramento featured gentle hills.
The Central Pacific line originates in Sacramento and extends eastward.
The route from San Francisco to Sacramento followed a north-easterly path along the American River.
This 120-mile stretch was covered in six hours.
Passengers passed through Sacramento, the state capital, around midnight while asleep, thus seeing none of its notable features like quays, streets, hotels, or public buildings.
Departing Sacramento, the train travelled through several junctions and towns (Roclin, Auburn, Colfax) before ascending into the Sierra Nevada mountain range.
The train reached Cisco at 7:00 AM.
An hour later, the sleeping car was converted back into a regular passenger car.
Travelers could then admire the striking mountain scenery.

The railway track navigated the mountain passes, sometimes running close to slopes, sometimes overhanging precipices, using bold curves to manage sharp angles and passing through narrow, seemingly dead-end defiles.
The locomotive, with its distinctive light, bell, and cow-catcher, produced loud sounds that echoed alongside the noises of mountain streams, its smoke drifting among large pine trees.
The route featured few bridges or tunnels, instead winding along the contours of the mountains rather than taking more direct, nature-altering paths.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The country between San Francisco and Sacramento is not very hilly.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The railway turned around the sides of the mountains, and did not attempt to violate nature by taking the shortest cut from one point to another.

events.text_segment:
The country between San Francisco and Sacramento is not very hilly. The Central Pacific, taking Sacramento for its starting-point, extends eastward to meet the road from Omaha. The line from San Francisco to Sacramento runs in a north-easterly direction, along the American River, which empties into San Pablo Bay. The one hundred and twenty miles between these cities were accomplished in six hours, and towards midnight, while fast asleep, the travellers passed through Sacramento; so that they saw nothing of that important place, the seat of the State government, with its fine quays, its broad streets, its noble hotels, squares, and churches.
The train, on leaving Sacramento, and passing the junction, Roclin, Auburn, and Colfax, entered the range of the Sierra Nevada. ’Cisco was reached at seven in the morning; and an hour later the dormitory was transformed into an ordinary car, and the travellers could observe the picturesque beauties of the mountain region through which they were steaming. The railway track wound in and out among the passes, now approaching the mountain-sides, now suspended over precipices, avoiding abrupt angles by bold curves, plunging into narrow defiles, which seemed to have no outlet. The locomotive, its great funnel emitting a weird light, with its sharp bell, and its cow-catcher extended like a spur, mingled its shrieks and bellowings with the noise of torrents and cascades, and twined its smoke among the branches of the gigantic pines.
There were few or no bridges or tunnels on the route. The railway turned around the sides of the mountains, and did not attempt to violate nature by taking the shortest cut from one point to another.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The country between San Francisco and Sacramento is not very hilly. The Central Pacific line traverses it by passing Cascade City and Crossville and cutting across the Sierra Nevada by way of the Carson Valley. It must be confessed that the engineers had to contend with difficulties in cutting this road, the line being 120 miles long, and in some places the gradients not being less than one hundred and five feet to the mile. The train from San Francisco was composed of elegant cars, provided with every comfort and, among other things, with smoking-cars, library-cars, and even restaurant-cars. At six o'clock P.M. it reached Sacramento, and the passengers were able to take supper there. Then, at midnight, the train, having gone 120 miles farther, stopped at the foot of the Sierra Nevada, the route crossing by the pass at an altitude of 7,017 feet above the level of the sea. During the night, the passengers slept soundly, and saw nothing of the landscape as the train whizzed past Roclin, Auburn, and Colfax. They did not perceive the pretty little capital of California, with its fine quays, its broad streets, its splendid hotels, and its Capitol, provided with a dome thirty yards in circumference; nor the pine forests of which the train ran alongside; nor the Sierra Nevada, where Phileas Fogg was soon to experience the effects of snow. Indeed, it was in vain to open the windows: nothing was to be seen but a white sheet, which went by like a flash. When the train stopped, at seven in the morning, at Cisco, there was a fall of snow, and the passengers descended into a station built in a forest of pine trees. An hour afterwards, the sleeping-car was converted into an ordinary passenger-car, and the passengers were able to look about them. The train was now in the heart of the Sierra Nevada; its bold curves sometimes hugged the steep sides of the mountains, sometimes skirted frightful precipices, and sometimes seemed to bury themselves in narrow defiles, out of which it seemed impossible to escape. The locomotive, with its bright head-light, its bell, and its cow-catcher, seemed to rage through the air, its smoke trailing behind it like a black banner. The train did not seem to be moving, but rather to be projected, like a projectile, by some irresistible force. There were few bridges or tunnels on the route, for the engineers had preferred to wind about the slopes rather than to cut through them. The mountain streams roared alongside the railway, their waters, swelled by the melting snows, forming torrents which sometimes threatened to submerge the track; but the train sped on, regardless of danger, its pace only slightly lessened by the steep gradients.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_5.text: The country between San Francisco and Sacramento is not very hilly. The Central Pacific line runs east from Sacramento and is to meet the road from Omaha at Ogden. The route from San Francisco to Sacramento followed a north-easterly path along the American River, which empties into San Pablo Bay, a distance of 120 miles, which was accomplished in six hours. The passengers passed through Sacramento, the seat of the State government, towards midnight, while fast asleep, and saw nothing of its notable features, such as its quays, streets, squares, churches, and hotels. Leaving Sacramento, the train passed through several junctions and towns, including Roclin, Auburn, and Colfax, before beginning the ascent into the Sierra Nevada mountain range. The train reached Cisco at seven o'clock in the morning. An hour later, the dormitory was converted into an ordinary car, and the travellers could now observe the mountain region. The railway track wound among the passes, sometimes approaching the mountain-sides, sometimes suspended over precipices, avoiding sharp angles by bold curves, and plunging into narrow defiles which seemed to have no outlet. The locomotive, with its great funnel emitting a weird light, its bell, and its cow-catcher, whistled and roared, its sounds mingling with the noises of the torrents and cascades, and its smoke curling among the branches of the gigantic pines. There were few bridges or tunnels on the route. The railway wound along the sides of the mountains, not seeking to violate nature by the shortest cut.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The country between San Francisco and Sacramento is not very hilly. Indeed, after leaving Oakland, across the bay, the train traversed a remarkably level landscape. This section, part of the great Central Valley, offered smooth passage. The track stretched across broad plains, where vast fields, prepared for cultivation or showing early growth, dominated the view. There were no steep ascents or deep valleys to impede the train's progress, maintaining speed. Scattered trees and small settlements dotted the scenery, but the impression was expansive, open country. The journey felt swift and comfortable across this flat terrain, a stark contrast to the topography further east. Reaching Sacramento, the capital city, marked the end of this easy portion of the route. It was here that the true ascent would begin. While the path eastward from San Francisco Bay had been one of effortless speed across gentle lands, the landscape was about to change dramatically. The slight undulations would soon give way to steep gradients and formidable mountain ranges, making this initial, level stretch seem a mere prelude to the arduous Sierra Nevada crossing that awaited the travellers.

events.title: Buffalo Herd Causes Major Delay
detailed_summary: Around 9:00 AM, the train crossed into Nevada via the Carson Valley, continuing its northeast trajectory.
At noon, it arrived in Reno, pausing for a twenty-minute breakfast stop.
From Reno, the railway followed the Humboldt River north for some distance before turning eastward, staying near the river until reaching the Humboldt Range at Nevada's eastern edge.
After breakfast, Mr. Fogg and his companions returned to their seats, observing the changing scenery of prairies, distant mountains, and streams.
Occasionally, immense herds of buffalo appeared in the distance like moving barriers.
These vast herds frequently posed significant obstacles to trains, sometimes halting them for hours as thousands of animals crossed the tracks in dense formations.
Around midday, the train encountered such an obstacle: a massive herd of ten to twelve thousand buffalo blocking the way.
The locomotive reduced speed and attempted to nudge the animals aside with its cow-catcher, but the sheer number of buffalo made this impossible.
The animals proceeded calmly, occasionally letting out loud bellows, their movement seemingly unstoppable like a 'torrent of living flesh'.
Passengers observed this unusual sight from the train's platforms.
Phileas Fogg, despite having the most pressing schedule, remained seated, calmly and philosophically awaiting the herd's passage.
Passepartout grew increasingly agitated by the delay, expressing a desire to use his revolvers on the animals.
He exclaimed about the absurdity of mere cattle halting trains and wondered aloud if Fogg had factored such an event into his plans.
He also criticized the train's engineer for not attempting to force a passage through the herd.

The engineer, however, acted prudently by not confronting the buffalo, understanding that while the initial impact might clear some animals, the locomotive would quickly be overwhelmed, leading to derailment and immobilization.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The train entered the State of Nevada through the Carson Valley about nine o’clock, going always northeasterly; and at midday reached Reno, where there was a delay of twenty minutes for breakfast.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He would have crushed the first buffaloes, no doubt, with the cow-catcher; but the locomotive, however powerful, would soon have been checked, the train would inevitably have been thrown off the track, and would then have been helpless.

events.text_segment:
The train entered the State of Nevada through the Carson Valley about nine o’clock, going always northeasterly; and at midday reached Reno, where there was a delay of twenty minutes for breakfast.
From this point the road, running along Humboldt River, passed northward for several miles by its banks; then it turned eastward, and kept by the river until it reached the Humboldt Range, nearly at the extreme eastern limit of Nevada.
Having breakfasted, Mr. Fogg and his companions resumed their places in the car, and observed the varied landscape which unfolded itself as they passed along the vast prairies, the mountains lining the horizon, and the creeks, with their frothy, foaming streams. Sometimes a great herd of buffaloes, massing together in the distance, seemed like a moveable dam. These innumerable multitudes of ruminating beasts often form an insurmountable obstacle to the passage of the trains; thousands of them have been seen passing over the track for hours together, in compact ranks. The locomotive is then forced to stop and wait till the road is once more clear.
This happened, indeed, to the train in which Mr. Fogg was travelling. About twelve o’clock a troop of ten or twelve thousand head of buffalo encumbered the track. The locomotive, slackening its speed, tried to clear the way with its cow-catcher; but the mass of animals was too great. The buffaloes marched along with a tranquil gait, uttering now and then deafening bellowings. There was no use of interrupting them, for, having taken a particular direction, nothing can moderate and change their course; it is a torrent of living flesh which no dam could contain.
The travellers gazed on this curious spectacle from the platforms; but Phileas Fogg, who had the most reason of all to be in a hurry, remained in his seat, and waited philosophically until it should please the buffaloes to get out of the way.
Passepartout was furious at the delay they occasioned, and longed to discharge his arsenal of revolvers upon them.
“What a country!” cried he. “Mere cattle stop the trains, and go by in a procession, just as if they were not impeding travel! Parbleu! I should like to know if Mr. Fogg foresaw this mishap in his programme! And here’s an engineer who doesn’t dare to run the locomotive into this herd of beasts!”
The engineer did not try to overcome the obstacle, and he was wise. He would have crushed the first buffaloes, no doubt, with the cow-catcher; but the locomotive, however powerful, would soon have been checked, the train would inevitably have been thrown off the track, and would then have been helpless.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The train entered the State of Nevada through the Carson Valley about nine o’clock, going always northeasterly; and at midday reached Reno, where there was a delay of twenty minutes for breakfast. From that station the railway, crossing the Humboldt River, went up northward for some miles, following the course of that stream, then it turned eastward, and kept near it until it reached the Humboldt Mountains, at the eastern confines of Nevada. After breakfast, the travellers resumed their seats, and observed the varied landscape which unfolded itself before them - prairies, mountains, cañons. The prairies were spotted with herds of buffalo, like shifting dams. These innumerable multitudes of bovines are often an insurmountable obstacle to the passage of the trains, thousands of them thronging across the track in dense array. About midday, a herd of ten or twelve thousand came thundering across the line. The locomotive was obliged to slacken its speed and finally to stop, for it was impossible to make way through this living barrier. The buffaloes trotted along with placid indifference, having occasionally recourse to a loud bellow, and none could stop their march. It was then a torrent of living flesh moving onward with resistless power. The travellers gazed on the spectacle from the platforms. But Phileas Fogg, who had the most reason of all to be in a hurry, remained in his seat, a stoic, philosophising on the matter without so much as an extra word. Passepartout was furious at the delay, and longed to discharge his battery of revolvers upon the beasts, which would not so much as condescend to open a passage. 'What a country!' cried he. 'Herds of cattle stop the trains, and go quietly on, the lords of the road! Well, I should like to know if Mr. Fogg foresaw this obstruction of buffaloes in his programme! And what does the engineer mean by not putting on steam, and crashing into this bestial mob!' The engineer dared not, and with reason. He knew that to attempt to overcome this obstacle would be to court disaster. The locomotive, in crushing the first beasts, would be itself thrown off the track, and wrecked. There was nothing to do but patiently to wait till the caravan had passed over the track.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The train entered the State of Nevada through the Carson Valley about nine o’clock, going always northeasterly; and at midday reached Reno, where there was a delay of twenty minutes for breakfast. From this point the road, running along the Humbolt River, mounted northerly for some dozens of miles, then turned eastward, and followed the river itself up to the foot of the Rocky Mountains, - a distance of several hundred miles, which would be accomplished in the night. By observing the map, Mr. Fogg ascertained that after leaving the territory of Utah, they would pass through the territory of Wyoming, which is rich in cañons, but in general destitute of habitations, and then would traverse Nebraska, in which the railway followed the valley of the Platte River as far as Omaha. That night, the 3rd of December, the train ran over a distance of about two hundred miles, which did not prevent the travellers from sleeping soundly, save Passepartout, who took a nap at intervals, and woke with a start.At eight o’clock in the morning, the train stopped at the little station of Lodge Pole creek, in Nebraska. An Indian of the Sioux tribe, a tall, strong fellow, sprang upon the platform, and in broken English, and in a voice that carried far, exclaimed: "Prisoners! Train attacked by Sioux! Forty miles west, at Red Creek canyon! Stop the train! Prisoners!""You just keep quiet!" cried the conductor, running up."Prisoners!" repeated the Indian. "Train taken, thirty-nine prisoners. Roll back!"The train was full of excited passengers. Some of them had firearms, and were anxious to use them. Others were more timid, and wanted to get out. The conductor tried to restore order, and then asked the Indian: "Are the Sioux coming this way?""Yes," replied the Indian. "They are coming this way. A hundred of them. They have already taken three trains.""What do they want?""They want to rob the trains, and scalp the passengers.""What are we going to do?""We are going to fight," said the Indian."We are not armed," said the conductor."We have rifles and pistols," said the Indian. "We will fight them.""But we are not soldiers.""We are men," said the Indian. "We will fight them."The conductor hesitated for a moment, and then said, "All right, we will fight them."

events.title: Resuming the Journey into Utah
detailed_summary: The most sensible approach was to wait for the obstruction to clear and then make up the lost time by increasing the train's speed.
The buffalo procession continued for three full hours.
The railway track was finally clear as night began to fall.
The last of the buffalo herd crossed the rails just as the front ranks disappeared over the southern horizon.
At 8:00 PM, the train navigated through the narrow passages of the Humboldt Range.
By 9:30 PM, it had entered the territory of Utah, noted as the area of the Great Salt Lake and the distinctive Mormon settlement.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The best course was to wait patiently, and regain the lost time by greater speed when the obstacle was removed.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was eight o’clock when the train passed through the defiles of the Humboldt Range, and half-past nine when it penetrated Utah, the region of the Great Salt Lake, the singular colony of the Mormons.

events.text_segment:
The best course was to wait patiently, and regain the lost time by greater speed when the obstacle was removed. The procession of buffaloes lasted three full hours, and it was night before the track was clear. The last ranks of the herd were now passing over the rails, while the first had already disappeared below the southern horizon.
It was eight o’clock when the train passed through the defiles of the Humboldt Range, and half-past nine when it penetrated Utah, the region of the Great Salt Lake, the singular colony of the Mormons.

The best course was to wait patiently, and regain the lost time by greater speed when the obstacle was removed.
The procession of buffaloes lasted three full hours, and it was not until the shades of night began to fall that the track was clear. The leading herds had crossed the Union Pacific line, and were now disappearing in the south, diminished to specks on the horizon.
At eight o’clock in the evening, the train entered the narrow passes of the Humboldt Range, and at half-past nine it wound along the southern extremity of the Great Salt Lake, the immense inland sea on which reposes the singular Mormon territory, the country of the Saints of the Last Days.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXVII. IN WHICH PASSEPARTOUT UNDERGOES, AT A SPEED OF TWENTY MILES AN HOUR, A COURSE OF MORMON HISTORY

events.title: Passepartout Encounters a Mormon Missionary
detailed_summary: The train altered course, heading towards the Great Salt Lake.
Around 9 AM, Passepartout went onto the platform for fresh air, noting the cold, grey weather and the sun appearing as a large golden ring through the mist.
He was distracted from estimating the sun's value by the appearance of a peculiar man.
This man, who boarded at Elko, was tall, dark, and dressed entirely in black, resembling a clergyman.
He moved through the train, posting handwritten notices on each car door.
Passepartout read a notice announcing a lecture on Mormonism by Elder William Hitch in car No. 117.
The notice invited those interested in learning about the 'Latter Day Saints' to attend.
Intrigued and knowing little about Mormonism beyond polygamy, Passepartout decided he would go.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: During the night of the 5th of December, the train ran south-easterly for about fifty miles; then rose an equal distance in a north-easterly direction, towards the Great Salt Lake.

events.text_segment:
During the night of the 5th of December, the train ran south-easterly for about fifty miles; then rose an equal distance in a north-easterly direction, towards the Great Salt Lake.
Passepartout, about nine o’clock, went out upon the platform to take the air. The weather was cold, the heavens grey, but it was not snowing. The sun’s disc, enlarged by the mist, seemed an enormous ring of gold, and Passepartout was amusing himself by calculating its value in pounds sterling, when he was diverted from this interesting study by a strange-looking personage who made his appearance on the platform.
This personage, who had taken the train at Elko, was tall and dark, with black moustache, black stockings, a black silk hat, a black waistcoat, black trousers, a white cravat, and dogskin gloves. He might have been taken for a clergyman. He went from one end of the train to the other, and affixed to the door of each car a notice written in manuscript.
Passepartout approached and read one of these notices, which stated that Elder William Hitch, Mormon missionary, taking advantage of his presence on train No. 48, would deliver a lecture on Mormonism in car No. 117, from eleven to twelve o’clock; and that he invited all who were desirous of being instructed concerning the mysteries of the religion of the “Latter Day Saints” to attend.
“I’ll go,” said Passepartout to himself. He knew nothing of Mormonism except the custom of polygamy, which is its foundation.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
During the night of the 5th of December, the train ran south-easterly for about fifty miles; then rose an equal distance in a north-easterly direction, towards the Great Salt Lake.

From Ogden the road lay directly westward, across the arid Steppe of Utah. On the north of the road might be seen the large Salt Lake, an inland sea, about one hundred miles long and thirty broad, whose waters, containing a great quantity of mineral elements, are perfectly, useless, and so impregnated with salt that the density is far greater than that of the Red Sea, and that salt is deposited on the shore.

To the south-east of the lake rose the highest peaks of the Wasatch Mountains, which bar the way to the south, and are covered with snow, in spite of their comparatively moderate elevation. Around the Great Salt Lake extends a fertile section of country, where the Mormons, who have made this region their home, cultivate wheat and maize, the soil being admirably adapted to the raising of cereals.

At about nine in the morning Passepartout went upon the platform to take the air. The weather was cold, the sky grey, but the mist had disappeared. The sun's disc might be seen like a ring of gold in the midst of a silvery halo. He was about to estimate the value of this sun, when he was diverted from the contemplation by the appearance of a rather peculiar personage.

This personage, who had taken the train at Elko, was tall and dark, with black whiskers, and wore a black silk hat, a long black coat, black trowsers, and a white cravat: in a word, he looked like a clergyman. He went from one end of the train to the other, and on the door of each car he fastened a notice, written in manuscript.

Passepartout went up to one of these notices, and read that Elder William Hitch, of the Mormon Church, took advantage of the opportunity offered by his journey on the railway to lecture upon Mormonism, and that such of the passengers as were desirous of being instructed as to the mysteries of the religion of the "Latter-Day Saints" were invited to attend, on car No. 117, at 11 a.m.

“I'm sure to go,” said Passepartout to himself. He knew nothing about Mormonism, except that it permitted polygamy, which is the taking of several wives at once—an entirely American custom, it appears.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: During the night of the 5th of December, the train ran south-easterly for about fifty miles; then rose an equal distance in a north-easterly direction, towards the Great Salt Lake. The line crossed rugged, arid terrain, traversing desolate plains dotted with sagebrush. As they ascended, the air grew colder, and the distant Wasatch Mountains gleamed under morning light. Phileas Fogg read, indifferent to the view. Passepartout marveled at the West's scale and solitude from the window, seeing distant bison herds and antelopes fleeing the train. The journey was a rapid charge through wilderness. As they neared the lake, the land showed habitation signs. Scattered farms and buildings appeared, announcing proximity to Mormon territory. The approach to Salt Lake City, Deseret's capital, brought anticipation. This unique community might delay their global itinerary, a risk Fogg considered, but one that worried Passepartout.

events.title: Elder Hitch's Fiery Lecture Begins
detailed_summary: Word of the lecture circulated among the train's approximately 100 passengers.
About thirty passengers gathered in car No. 117 for the lecture.
Passepartout secured a seat near the front.
Mr. Fogg and Fix chose not to attend the lecture.
Elder William Hitch began speaking at the scheduled time, his voice immediately irritated.
He proclaimed Joe and Hiram Smith as martyrs and suggested Brigham Young would also become one due to government persecution, challenging anyone to disagree.
No one contradicted him; his agitated tone seemed unusual for his calm appearance, likely stemming from the Mormons' recent struggles with the US government.

The narrative explains the government's recent subjugation of Utah and imprisonment of Brigham Young, leading to increased verbal resistance from Mormons like Elder Hitch, who sought converts on trains.

Using a loud voice and animated gestures, the Elder recounted Mormon history, starting from biblical times and the supposed discovery and translation of ancient religious texts by Joseph Smith, Jr. in 1825.
He described a divine messenger appearing to Smith in a forest with the sacred annals.
Some audience members lost interest and departed during this historical account.

Undeterred, Elder Hitch continued, describing the founding of the church, its international growth, the establishment of a colony and temple in Ohio, and Smith's venture into banking, including acquiring an ancient papyrus.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The news quickly spread through the train, which contained about one hundred passengers, thirty of whom, at most, attracted by the notice, ensconced themselves in car No. 117.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Several of the audience, not being much interested in the missionary’s narrative, here left the car; but Elder Hitch, continuing his lecture, related how Smith, junior, with his father, two brothers, and a few disciples, founded the church of the “Latter Day Saints,” which, adopted not only in America, but in England, Norway and Sweden, and Germany, counts many artisans, as well as men engaged in the liberal professions, among its members; how a colony was established in Ohio, a temple erected there at a cost of two hundred thousand dollars, and a town built at Kirkland; how Smith became an enterprising banker, and received from a simple mummy showman a papyrus scroll written by Abraham and several famous Egyptians.

events.text_segment:
The news quickly spread through the train, which contained about one hundred passengers, thirty of whom, at most, attracted by the notice, ensconced themselves in car No. 117. Passepartout took one of the front seats. Neither Mr. Fogg nor Fix cared to attend.
At the appointed hour Elder William Hitch rose, and, in an irritated voice, as if he had already been contradicted, said, “I tell you that Joe Smith is a martyr, that his brother Hiram is a martyr, and that the persecutions of the United States Government against the prophets will also make a martyr of Brigham Young. Who dares to say the contrary?”
No one ventured to gainsay the missionary, whose excited tone contrasted curiously with his naturally calm visage. No doubt his anger arose from the hardships to which the Mormons were actually subjected. The government had just succeeded, with some difficulty, in reducing these independent fanatics to its rule. It had made itself master of Utah, and subjected that territory to the laws of the Union, after imprisoning Brigham Young on a charge of rebellion and polygamy. The disciples of the prophet had since redoubled their efforts, and resisted, by words at least, the authority of Congress. Elder Hitch, as is seen, was trying to make proselytes on the very railway trains.
Then, emphasising his words with his loud voice and frequent gestures, he related the history of the Mormons from Biblical times: how that, in Israel, a Mormon prophet of the tribe of Joseph published the annals of the new religion, and bequeathed them to his son Mormon; how, many centuries later, a translation of this precious book, which was written in Egyptian, was made by Joseph Smith, junior, a Vermont farmer, who revealed himself as a mystical prophet in 1825; and how, in short, the celestial messenger appeared to him in an illuminated forest, and gave him the annals of the Lord.
Several of the audience, not being much interested in the missionary’s narrative, here left the car; but Elder Hitch, continuing his lecture, related how Smith, junior, with his father, two brothers, and a few disciples, founded the church of the “Latter Day Saints,” which, adopted not only in America, but in England, Norway and Sweden, and Germany, counts many artisans, as well as men engaged in the liberal professions, among its members; how a colony was established in Ohio, a temple erected there at a cost of two hundred thousand dollars, and a town built at Kirkland; how Smith became an enterprising banker, and received from a simple mummy showman a papyrus scroll written by Abraham and several famous Egyptians.

- The completion inaccurately describes the government's actions as a 'vigorous war' and suggests the disciples are scattered over the whole earth, which is not the focus in the original at this point.
- There are inaccuracies in the sequence of events, such as the order in which the church's founding, international growth, and professions of its members are discussed.
- The completion attributes certain reflections and explanations to the Elder that are not present in the original, such as the content of the sacred book and the adventures of Israelite families.
- The list of nationalities of church members is expanded and includes some not mentioned in the original passage.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The news quickly spread through the train, which contained about one hundred passengers, thirty of whom, at most, attracted by the notice, ensconced themselves in car No. 117. The car was a sort of drawing-room on wheels, provided with comfortable seats, which could be converted into beds, and furnished with a supply of necessaries of life – to wit, comforts – as if the travellers had been in a first-class hotel. The party from the steamer occupied seats together: Fogg, Aouda, Passepartout, and Fix. Other passengers included Englishmen, Americans, military officers, merchants, and even some of those emigrants who were colonizing the vast territories of the West. It was a motley but quiet assembly, all sharing the common goal of reaching the Pacific coast. The train started at full speed, crossing the State of Nebraska. The country was slightly undulating, well cultivated in its lower part, and covered with vast forests. The track ran for a long time parallel to the winding course of the Platte River. The locomotive whistled loudly and often, as if impatient of the monotonous landscape, though it was hardly monotonous to the eager eyes of Passepartout, who devoured the scenery with the speed at which it unfolded. This powerful iron horse seemed capable of conquering any distance. Meals were served on board, in a dining-car splendidly decorated, and provided with excellent food; and the sleeping cars were comfortable and clean. Everything was so well arranged that Passepartout might have fancied he was travelling at the expense of the government of the United States, experiencing the ultimate in transatlantic railway travel. During the first day, the train ran through fertile plains, broken by occasional woods and streams. The passengers conversed, read, or gazed out of the windows. Aouda was particularly interested in the changing views. Fix remained largely in his seat, observing Fogg, ever watchful for an opportunity or a signal to act. Mr. Fogg, as usual, was perfectly calm, reading a book or simply sitting in his corner, his eyes fixed on the passing scene, yet seemingly detached from it, secure in his schedule. As evening approached, the scenery began to change. The plains gave way to higher ground, and distant blue lines on the horizon suggested the approach of mountains. The air grew cooler. Passepartout marvelled at the speed with which they traversed such immense distances. He calculated that if the train maintained this average, they would easily reach San Francisco by the date and hour fixed. The rhythm of the wheels on the track became a steady lullaby, accompanying the journey into the night. The train slowed occasionally at stations, but the stops were brief, just long enough to take on water or fuel, or exchange a few passengers. Then the whistle would blow again, and they would resume their swift, westward course, leaving the settled regions behind and plunging deeper into the vast, wild heart of the continent, propelled by steam towards their destination.

events.title: Lecture Audience Dwindles as Smith's Story Continues
detailed_summary: The lecture grew tedious, causing the audience to shrink to twenty people.
The Elder, unaffected by the departures, recounted Joseph Smith's bankruptcy in 1837 and subsequent tarring and feathering by creditors.
He described Smith's comeback years later, leading a large community in Independence, Missouri, before being driven out and heading west.
The audience dwindled further to only ten listeners, including Passepartout, who remained attentive.
Passepartout learned about Smith's later life: his return after persecutions, founding the large Nauvoo community in Illinois in 1839 where he held multiple leadership roles.
He heard about Smith's 1843 presidential candidacy.
Finally, the Elder recounted Smith's capture in Carthage, imprisonment, and assassination by masked attackers.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The Elder’s story became somewhat wearisome, and his audience grew gradually less, until it was reduced to twenty passengers.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Thus he learned that, after long persecutions, Smith reappeared in Illinois, and in 1839 founded a community at Nauvoo, on the Mississippi, numbering twenty-five thousand souls, of which he became mayor, chief justice, and general-in-chief; that he announced himself, in 1843, as a candidate for the Presidency of the United States; and that finally, being drawn into ambuscade at Carthage, he was thrown into prison, and assassinated by a band of men disguised in masks.

events.text_segment:
The Elder’s story became somewhat wearisome, and his audience grew gradually less, until it was reduced to twenty passengers. But this did not disconcert the enthusiast, who proceeded with the story of Joseph Smith’s bankruptcy in 1837, and how his ruined creditors gave him a coat of tar and feathers; his reappearance some years afterwards, more honourable and honoured than ever, at Independence, Missouri, the chief of a flourishing colony of three thousand disciples, and his pursuit thence by outraged Gentiles, and retirement into the Far West.
Ten hearers only were now left, among them honest Passepartout, who was listening with all his ears. Thus he learned that, after long persecutions, Smith reappeared in Illinois, and in 1839 founded a community at Nauvoo, on the Mississippi, numbering twenty-five thousand souls, of which he became mayor, chief justice, and general-in-chief; that he announced himself, in 1843, as a candidate for the Presidency of the United States; and that finally, being drawn into ambuscade at Carthage, he was thrown into prison, and assassinated by a band of men disguised in masks.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The Elder’s story became somewhat wearisome, and his audience grew gradually less, until it was reduced to twenty passengers. Still, William Hitch continued his lecture, and recounted the vicissitudes of the Mormon religion from the time of Joseph Smith. He described the bank failure of 1837, the ruin of the creditors, and the tarring and feathering of Smith and his partner Rigdon by the populace of Ohio. He told of the exodus to Independence, in Missouri, which the Mormons called the City of Zion, and of the bloody struggles which broke out there. He described the Mormons as driven from the county of Jackson, and taking refuge in the county of Clay, whence they again fled to Nauvoo, in Illinois, on the Mississippi, and founded a city which counted twenty-five thousand souls, and had a temple and a college. He related the political career of Smith, who became a candidate for the presidency in 1843; and the schism which arose in 1845, after the assassination of the Prophet, the election of Brigham Young as his successor, and the final exodus of the Mormons, who abandoned Nauvoo in 1846, and took refuge in the midst of the western deserts. Passepartout listened attentively, and followed the Elder’s narrative with interest. The audience dwindled to a dozen, and then to ten, and at last there were only Passepartout and four others left.
