events.title: The Engineer's Dangerous Proposal
detailed_summary: The problematic structure was identified as a suspension bridge spanning rapids, located roughly a mile ahead.
The signal-man reiterated its dilapidated state, citing broken iron wires that made crossing extremely hazardous.
The text notes that American prudence, being rare, usually signifies genuine cause for concern.
Passepartout listened, paralyzed with tension, reluctant to inform his master of this new delay.
Colonel Proctor belligerently demanded to know if they were simply expected to remain stranded in the snow.
The conductor reported that a replacement train had been summoned from Omaha but wasn't expected for at least six hours.
Passepartout reacted with dismay to the lengthy delay.
The conductor further clarified that walking to Medicine Bow station would also take about six hours.
When a passenger noted the station was only a mile away, the conductor explained it was inaccessible due to being on the opposite side of the river.
Proctor inquired about using a boat, but the conductor dismissed this, explaining the creek was dangerously swollen and rapid, necessitating a ten-mile detour to find a safe crossing point (ford).
Enraged, Proctor swore at the railway company and conductor; Passepartout, equally furious, felt a moment of solidarity, realizing money couldn't solve this problem.
Widespread disappointment arose among passengers facing the prospect of a fifteen-mile walk through snow; their complaints didn't disturb the engrossed Fogg.
Just as Passepartout resolved to tell Fogg the bad news, the train's engineer, Forster, interjected, proposing a potential, alternative way to get across.
When questioned, Forster confirmed he meant crossing the damaged bridge itself, using their current train.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: This was a suspension-bridge thrown over some rapids, about a mile from the place where they now were.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “With our train.”

events.text_segment:
This was a suspension-bridge thrown over some rapids, about a mile from the place where they now were. According to the signal-man, it was in a ruinous condition, several of the iron wires being broken; and it was impossible to risk the passage. He did not in any way exaggerate the condition of the bridge. It may be taken for granted that, rash as the Americans usually are, when they are prudent there is good reason for it.
Passepartout, not daring to apprise his master of what he heard, listened with set teeth, immovable as a statue.
“Hum!” cried Colonel Proctor; “but we are not going to stay here, I imagine, and take root in the snow?”
“Colonel,” replied the conductor, “we have telegraphed to Omaha for a train, but it is not likely that it will reach Medicine Bow in less than six hours.”
“Six hours!” cried Passepartout.
“Certainly,” returned the conductor, “besides, it will take us as long as that to reach Medicine Bow on foot.”
“But it is only a mile from here,” said one of the passengers.
“Yes, but it’s on the other side of the river.”
“And can’t we cross that in a boat?” asked the colonel.
“That’s impossible. The creek is swelled by the rains. It is a rapid, and we shall have to make a circuit of ten miles to the north to find a ford.”
The colonel launched a volley of oaths, denouncing the railway company and the conductor; and Passepartout, who was furious, was not disinclined to make common cause with him. Here was an obstacle, indeed, which all his master’s banknotes could not remove.
There was a general disappointment among the passengers, who, without reckoning the delay, saw themselves compelled to trudge fifteen miles over a plain covered with snow. They grumbled and protested, and would certainly have thus attracted Phileas Fogg’s attention if he had not been completely absorbed in his game.
Passepartout found that he could not avoid telling his master what had occurred, and, with hanging head, he was turning towards the car, when the engineer, a true Yankee, named Forster called out, “Gentlemen, perhaps there is a way, after all, to get over.”
“On the bridge?” asked a passenger.
“On the bridge.”
“With our train?”
“With our train.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: This was a suspension-bridge thrown over some rapids, about a mile from the place where they now were. The signal-man had explained to the conductor that the iron wires were broken, and that it was impossible to cross. He added, that with American prudence, he had telegraphed to Omaha for a train, and that they might expect one in six hours. "Six hours!" cried Passepartout; "but that will not get us to New York this evening." "Begone, sir!" said Colonel Proctor; "why do you meddle? It is for these gentlemen to decide whether they will find some means of getting over." "I propose to go afoot," said one of the passengers. "In about six hours we can reach Medicine Bow station." "But it is on the other side of the river," said the conductor. "No doubt," replied the passenger, "but we can cross it by boat." "By boat, in this rapid, ten miles around, in the present state of the creek!" cried Colonel Proctor. "I will not allow it, I will not risk my life, and that of my companions, in this fashion." "It is of no use talking," said the conductor; "the bridge is not safe, and we must wait for another train." "Oh, the rascals!" cried Passepartout. "There's not a day but there's some accident. I wish I had not come!" It is true that money could not be of any service in this case. Phileas Fogg was as cool as ever. He heard all that passed, but did not budge from his place. Passepartout could not contain himself. "Master," cried he, "this is a bad business!" "What is the matter?" asked Mr. Fogg. "We are stopped by a broken bridge!" "Indeed! how do we get over?" "We don't get over." "But the railway company is bound to carry us." "No doubt, but it can't pass over this bridge." "Hum!" thought Mr. Fogg, and added, without raising his voice, "We will wait for a train." Passepartout was in despair. He saw that his master was about to be taken in again by some delay, and his hopes of reaching New York on the 11th, and so getting to Liverpool on the 21st, were vanishing. All at once, a passenger, a railway engineer, named Forster, said, "Perhaps there is a way, after all, to get over." "On the bridge?" asked a number of voices. "On the bridge." "With our train?" "With our train."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: This was a suspension-bridge thrown over some rapids, about a mile from the place where they now were. They reached it on foot, and on the other side were a dozen vehicles, palanquins, ponies, etc., waiting for them. Mr. Fogg and Sir Francis Cromarty took a car, and Fix and Passepartout a sort of four-wheeled cart drawn by two oxen. The whole party were soon in motion, and the travellers passed through a country full of tigers, which fled at the noise of the cart, save when they were in such numbers that the drivers had to use their revolvers. This happened frequently, and Sir Francis Cromarty, who knew the country well, advised Mr. Fogg to keep his revolver in readiness. Phileas Fogg coolly replied that he had no revolver, but that he would buy one when they reached Allahabad. He was not a man to be caught unprepared, and he was resolved to be ready for anything that might happen. The travellers proceeded at a slow rate, making but a short distance on their way. At ten osquo;clock they arrived at the village of Kallian, where they stopped for the night, at a comfortable bungalow. Sir Francis Cromarty, who was a perfect gentleman, offered to share his room with Mr. Fogg, but the latter preferred to occupy a separate apartment, and he took care to pay for it beforehand. The next morning, they resumed their journey at six osquo;clock, and arrived at Allahabad at four in the afternoon. The train for Calcutta was not to leave till the evening, so they had time to dine and walk about the town. Allahabad is one of the principal cities of India, and is situated at the confluence of the Ganges and the Jumna, two of the largest rivers in the country. It is a sacred city for the Hindoos, who come in great numbers to bathe in the holy waters. Mr. Fogg, who was not a religious man, did not seem to be impressed by the sanctity of the place, but he was interested in its commerce and industry, and he visited the principal markets and factories. He also went to the post office, to see if there were any letters for him, but there were none. While Mr. Fogg was thus employed, Fix and Passepartout were exploring the city in their own way. Fix, who was still suspicious of Mr. Fogg, was trying to find out something about him,

events.title: Recklessness vs. Caution
detailed_summary: Passepartout paid close attention to the engineer's unfolding idea.
The conductor stressed the bridge's precarious condition.
Forster brushed off the warning, theorizing that reaching maximum speed might allow the train to clear the bridge before it failed.
Passepartout mentally exclaimed in disbelief at the sheer risk.
However, the engineer's audacious proposal quickly gained support among passengers, especially Colonel Proctor, who found it highly appealing.
Proctor recounted tales of engineers making similar leaps over rivers.
Passenger sentiment shifted towards accepting the gamble, with estimates of success ranging wildly.
Passepartout, despite his desire to continue the journey, considered the plan excessively risky, labeling it 'too American'.
He felt a simpler, safer method was being ignored.
He tried voicing his concerns to fellow passengers, suggesting the engineer's plan was dangerous.
One passenger rebuffed him, focusing on the optimistic odds.
Another dismissed the need for alternative ideas since the engineer vouched for his plan.
Passepartout attempted to advocate for prudence.
This term enraged Colonel Proctor, who insisted on 'full speed'.
Passepartout tried rephrasing, suggesting a 'more natural' approach, not necessarily 'prudent'.
His attempts at discussion were met with confusion and hostility.
Proctor challenged Passepartout, asking if he was scared.
Provoked, Passepartout declared he would prove a Frenchman could match their recklessness.
The conductor then ordered everyone back onto the train.
Passepartout boarded, privately maintaining his belief that the logical solution was for passengers to cross on foot, followed by the empty train.

events.text_segment:
Passepartout stopped short, and eagerly listened to the engineer.
“But the bridge is unsafe,” urged the conductor.
“No matter,” replied Forster; “I think that by putting on the very highest speed we might have a chance of getting over.”
“The devil!” muttered Passepartout.
But a number of the passengers were at once attracted by the engineer’s proposal, and Colonel Proctor was especially delighted, and found the plan a very feasible one. He told stories about engineers leaping their trains over rivers without bridges, by putting on full steam; and many of those present avowed themselves of the engineer’s mind.
“We have fifty chances out of a hundred of getting over,” said one.
“Eighty! ninety!”
Passepartout was astounded, and, though ready to attempt anything to get over Medicine Creek, thought the experiment proposed a little too American. “Besides,” thought he, “there’s a still more simple way, and it does not even occur to any of these people! Sir,” said he aloud to one of the passengers, “the engineer’s plan seems to me a little dangerous, but—”
“Eighty chances!” replied the passenger, turning his back on him.
“I know it,” said Passepartout, turning to another passenger, “but a simple idea—”
“Ideas are no use,” returned the American, shrugging his shoulders, “as the engineer assures us that we can pass.”
“Doubtless,” urged Passepartout, “we can pass, but perhaps it would be more prudent—”
“What! Prudent!” cried Colonel Proctor, whom this word seemed to excite prodigiously. “At full speed, don’t you see, at full speed!”
“I know—I see,” repeated Passepartout; “but it would be, if not more prudent, since that word displeases you, at least more natural—”
“Who! What! What’s the matter with this fellow?” cried several.
The poor fellow did not know to whom to address himself.
“Are you afraid?” asked Colonel Proctor.
“I afraid? Very well; I will show these people that a Frenchman can be as American as they!”
“All aboard!” cried the conductor.
“Yes, all aboard!” repeated Passepartout, and immediately. “But they can’t prevent me from thinking that it would be more natural for us to cross the bridge on foot, and let the train come after!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Passepartout stopped short, and eagerly listened to the engineer. The conductor, a brave,্দ old fellow, was there.  “We might, perhaps,” said the engineer, “by putting on all steam, get across.” “You are forgetting that the bridge is shaky, and that there is a precipice below.” “No doubt; but with a full head of steam, we might have a chance of getting over.” “Granted; but if we do not get over?” “If you don’t get over, you will come down,” responded the engineer curtly. It was a terrible alternative, but it seemed to Passepartout, who was listening with all his ears, that the engineer’s reasons were unanswerable. It seemed to him, indeed, that the engineer was right, and that the only feasible plan was to get on with all speed, and if the train did go over, why, it did go over! The passengers, hearing the discussion, had collected around. Colonel Proctor was there, and took a lively part in the debate. He proposed to the engineer that they should get out of the train, and pass the bridge on foot. But the engineer said, “That would take three hours, and we have only an hour to spare. If we don’t get across in an hour, we shall be too late.” “But the bridge is shaky,” persisted the conductor. “Yes, I know it,” replied the engineer; “but I think it will hold.” “I don’t,” said the conductor. “I think it will be a great risk to attempt to pass it.” “I agree with you,” said Passepartout. “I think it is very dangerous.” “Nonsense!” cried Colonel Proctor. “Let us get on. We have no time to lose.” “But,” said Passepartout, “if the bridge gives way, we shall all be smashed to atoms.” “That is true,” said the conductor. “But if we don’t get over, we shall lose the train, and all our time and money will be lost.” “That is true, too,” said Passepartout; “but it is better to lose our time and money than to lose our lives.” “But we shall get over,” said Colonel Proctor. “We have a chance of getting over, and we ought to take the chance.” “That is a true American way of looking at the matter,” said Passepartout. “But I think we ought to be prudent.” “Prudent!” cried Colonel Proctor. “I think you are a coward.” “I am not a coward,” said Passepartout. “But I think we ought to be careful.” “We will be careful,” said Colonel Proctor; “but we will not be cowards.” “Let us get on,” said the engineer. “There is no time to be lost.” “But,” said Passepartout, “I think we ought to consider.” “We have considered,” said Colonel Proctor. “Let us get on.” “I think,” said Passepartout, “that it would be better for the passengers to get out and cross the bridge on foot, and let the train go over empty.” “That is a very good idea,” said the conductor. “But it would take too long.” “Not so long as if we are all killed,” said Passepartout. “Come, come,” said Colonel Proctor. “We have no time to lose. Let us get on.” The engineer and the conductor had come to an understanding. It was decided that the train should attempt the passage of the bridge, and that, at all events, they should put on a full head of steam. The signal for starting was given. The engine-driver whistled, and the train started. Passepartout had no time to reflect. He was seized, lifted up, and pushed into the carriage. He had just time to murmur, “After all, I must confess that the Americans are very bold.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Passepartout stopped short, and eagerly listened to the engineer. The engineer, a sinewy man clad in oil-stained overalls, gestured emphatically towards the track ahead. "She's broken down, son," he declared, his voice thick with a Texan drawl. "A section of the suspension bridge over the Platte River is unstable. Been inspected this mornin', deemed unfit for traffic. We gotta wait for the repair crew to shore her up." Passepartout's heart sank into his boots. Wait? The word was poison to his ears, a threat to the sacred timeline Mr. Fogg had so meticulously planned. "Wait?" he echoed, his voice barely above a whisper, then growing louder. "But we cannot wait! We are on a journey... a vital journey! Every hour is precious!" The engineer regarded him with mild amusement, clearly unimpressed by the Frenchman's urgency. "Now, now, take it easy," he drawled. "Ain't nobody crossin' that bridge till it's safe. Could be a few hours, could be till sundown. These things take time." He squinted at the horizon. "Repair crew's on their way, they say. But we're stuck here till they give the all-clear." Stuck! The word reverberated in Passepartout's head. Hours lost! He envisioned the world map in Mr. Fogg's mind, the precise lines and dates suddenly blurring, the carefully calculated trajectory veering disastrously off course. His master, the epitome of punctuality, reliant on transport schedules, was about to face an unavoidable delay imposed by a faulty bridge in the American wilderness. How would Mr. Fogg react? Would he maintain his imperturbable calm, or would this unforeseen obstacle finally crack his veneer of stoicism? Passepartout felt a wave of anxious responsibility wash over him. His job was to assist his master, to smooth the path, not to witness it being blocked by structural failures. He paced restlessly on the gravel beside the tracks, kicking at loose stones, his hands clasped behind his back, a picture of worried desperation. The vast prairie stretched around them, indifferent to their plight, the sun beating down relentlessly. He could hear the murmur of discontented passengers, the hiss of steam from the idling locomotive, but all he could truly perceive was the relentless ticking of his internal clock, counting down the precious seconds slipping away. The eighty days felt suddenly much shorter, the goal incredibly distant. He glanced towards Mr. Fogg's carriage, wondering if his master was aware of the situation, or if he was calmly immersed in his game of whist, oblivious to the potential disaster unfolding outside. The thought added another layer to his already considerable anxiety. He sighed deeply, feeling utterly helpless.

events.title: The Leap Across the Chasm
detailed_summary: Passepartout's more cautious idea remained unspoken and would likely have been ignored anyway.
All passengers re-boarded the train cars.
Passepartout returned to his seat near the whist players without detailing the perilous plan; Fogg, Aouda, and Fix remained oblivious, engrossed in their game.
The locomotive let out a powerful whistle.
The engineer reversed the train for approximately a mile, building up potential energy like an athlete before a jump.
A second whistle signaled the charge forward.
The train rapidly gained speed until it reached a terrifying velocity.
A sustained scream came from the engine as its pistons worked at incredible speed.
Moving at an estimated one hundred miles per hour, the train seemed to barely skim the rails.
The crossing occurred almost instantaneously, like a flash of light.
The bridge itself was not visible during the brief passage.
The train effectively vaulted from one riverbank to the other.
The engineer struggled to brake, finally stopping the train five miles beyond the Medicine Bow station.
Almost immediately after the train cleared the river, the compromised bridge collapsed completely and dramatically into the churning rapids below.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: But no one heard this sage reflection, nor would anyone have acknowledged its justice.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But scarcely had the train passed the river, when the bridge, completely ruined, fell with a crash into the rapids of Medicine Bow.

events.text_segment:
But no one heard this sage reflection, nor would anyone have acknowledged its justice. The passengers resumed their places in the cars. Passepartout took his seat without telling what had passed. The whist-players were quite absorbed in their game.
The locomotive whistled vigorously; the engineer, reversing the steam, backed the train for nearly a mile—retiring, like a jumper, in order to take a longer leap. Then, with another whistle, he began to move forward; the train increased its speed, and soon its rapidity became frightful; a prolonged screech issued from the locomotive; the piston worked up and down twenty strokes to the second. They perceived that the whole train, rushing on at the rate of a hundred miles an hour, hardly bore upon the rails at all.
And they passed over! It was like a flash. No one saw the bridge. The train leaped, so to speak, from one bank to the other, and the engineer could not stop it until it had gone five miles beyond the station. But scarcely had the train passed the river, when the bridge, completely ruined, fell with a crash into the rapids of Medicine Bow.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: But no one heard this sage reflection, nor would anyone have acknowledged its justice. All the passengers were in the cars. Passepartout, re-entering his own, sat down without a word to Fogg, Aouda, or Fix, who were still absorbed in their whist. The locomotive whistled, and the train began to back up, going nearly a mile. Then its speed was checked, and it suddenly started forward with a powerful bound, gaining in rapidity as it went. A prolonged screech came from the locomotive, the piston working with an incredible velocity. The whole train was but a blur, in which the cars seemed only linked to each other by the rapid motion. They were going at the rate of a hundred miles an hour. It was an infernal speed, and the passengers felt as if they were suspended in the air rather than rolling on the earth. A frightful tremor shot through the train, and there was a grinding of the wheels as they grazed the rails. The bridge was reached and passed in a flash. It was like a streak of lightning darting across. No one could see the bridge. The train vaulted, so to speak, from one bank to the other, and the engineer, not being able to stop it for five miles beyond the station, did not receive the slightest shock. But, scarcely had the train passed, when the ill-fated bridge tumbled with a crash into the torrent below the chasm.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: But no one heard this sage reflection, nor would anyone have acknowledged its justice. The general sentiment, expressed loudly and frequently in the clubs, on the Stock Exchange, and in drawing-rooms, was that Mr. Phileas Fogg was mad. The eighty days were considered a laughable impossibility. Calculations were made and published, demonstrating conclusively that the proposed itinerary, even assuming no delays whatsoever—a ridiculously optimistic assumption for travel through remote and undeveloped parts of the world—required a speed and precision of connections that simply did not exist. Experts cited breakdowns of machinery, unexpected storms at sea, native uprisings, missing train connections, and a thousand other potential hindrances that could easily consume the entire allotted time. The notion of traversing continents and oceans with the regularity of clockwork was deemed absurd. Every hour gained in one leg of the journey, it was argued, could be lost twice over by an unforeseen incident in the next. The vastness of the world, so easily encompassed by a line on a map, was a formidable reality when confronted by inadequate infrastructure and the capriciousness of elements and human affairs. Consequently, the wager was not merely doubted; it was universally condemned as the folly of an eccentric gentleman, and everyone waited with certainty for the inevitable news of his premature return or complete failure.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXIX. IN WHICH CERTAIN INCIDENTS ARE NARRATED WHICH ARE ONLY TO BE MET WITH ON AMERICAN RAILROADS

events.title: Transcontinental Progress and a Historical Pause
detailed_summary: The train journey proceeded smoothly, reaching the highest point of the route at Evans Pass before beginning its descent towards the Atlantic.
A branch line to Denver, the capital of gold- and silver-rich Colorado, was noted.
After three days and nights from San Francisco, 1382 miles had been covered, with four more days expected to reach New York, keeping Phileas Fogg on schedule.
The train passed Camp Walbach, followed Lodge Pole Creek marking the Wyoming-Colorado border, and entered Nebraska.
It passed near Sedgwick and stopped at Julesburg on the Platte River.
A flashback describes the Union Pacific Railroad's inauguration at Julesburg on October 23, 1867, attended by officials like General Dodge and Thomas C. Durant.
The inauguration involved celebrations including speeches, an imitation Indian battle, fireworks, and the printing of the first 'Railway Pioneer' newspaper on the train.
The railroad is portrayed as a powerful tool for progress, destined to connect future cities across the American landscape.
The journey continued past Fort McPherson towards Omaha, following the Platte River.
The train reached the town of North Platte, situated between two merging arms of the river.
The crossing of the one hundred and first meridian was noted.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The train pursued its course, that evening, without interruption, passing Fort Saunders, crossing Cheyne Pass, and reaching Evans Pass.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The one hundred and first meridian was passed.

events.text_segment:
The train pursued its course, that evening, without interruption, passing Fort Saunders, crossing Cheyne Pass, and reaching Evans Pass. The road here attained the highest elevation of the journey, eight thousand and ninety-two feet above the level of the sea. The travellers had now only to descend to the Atlantic by limitless plains, levelled by nature. A branch of the “grand trunk” led off southward to Denver, the capital of Colorado. The country round about is rich in gold and silver, and more than fifty thousand inhabitants are already settled there.
Thirteen hundred and eighty-two miles had been passed over from San Francisco, in three days and three nights; four days and nights more would probably bring them to New York. Phileas Fogg was not as yet behind-hand.
During the night Camp Walbach was passed on the left; Lodge Pole Creek ran parallel with the road, marking the boundary between the territories of Wyoming and Colorado. They entered Nebraska at eleven, passed near Sedgwick, and touched at Julesburg, on the southern branch of the Platte River.
It was here that the Union Pacific Railroad was inaugurated on the 23rd of October, 1867, by the chief engineer, General Dodge. Two powerful locomotives, carrying nine cars of invited guests, amongst whom was Thomas C. Durant, vice-president of the road, stopped at this point; cheers were given, the Sioux and Pawnees performed an imitation Indian battle, fireworks were let off, and the first number of the Railway Pioneer was printed by a press brought on the train. Thus was celebrated the inauguration of this great railroad, a mighty instrument of progress and civilisation, thrown across the desert, and destined to link together cities and towns which do not yet exist. The whistle of the locomotive, more powerful than Amphion’s lyre, was about to bid them rise from American soil.
Fort McPherson was left behind at eight in the morning, and three hundred and fifty-seven miles had yet to be traversed before reaching Omaha. The road followed the capricious windings of the southern branch of the Platte River, on its left bank. At nine the train stopped at the important town of North Platte, built between the two arms of the river, which rejoin each other around it and form a single artery, a large tributary, whose waters empty into the Missouri a little above Omaha.
The one hundred and first meridian was passed.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The train pursued its course, that evening, without interruption, passing Fort Saunders, crossing Cheyne Pass, and reaching Evans Pass. The route here attained its highest elevation, two thousand one hundred and forty-four yards above the level of the sea, one of the most elevated points of the globe, and whence the Union Pacific Railway will descend, by a constant lessening of the gradient, towards the Atlantic. There was a branch line from Evans Pass to Denver, the capital of Colorado, a new state, singularly rich in gold and silver mines, which has but lately been constituted. Thus far the train had passed over thirteen hundred and eighty-two miles from San Francisco, in three days and three nights. It is true that the trip had been a rapid one, but it must be remembered that the locomotive is not impeded by snow during the summer. The four days and nights still remaining, according to the estimates, were sufficient for the attainment of New York. Phileas Fogg was therefore still on time. The train, having passed Camp Walbach at half-past nine, left the Black Hills and entered upon the vast plains of Nebraska, by the valley of Lodge Pole Creek, which runs directly north and south. After a few moments they saw a creek, the veritable frontier of the two territories, indicated by a single house, around which a few trees were scattered. This was Lodge Pole Creek, about which the summary speaks. The train passed near Sedgwick, and came to Julesburg, a town on the Platte River, a large tributary of the Missouri. It was at Julesburg, which they reached at ten P.M., that the railway was inaugurated on the 23rd October, 1867. The locomotives, decorated with streamers, had brought from Omaha, the capital of Nebraska, crowds of officials, among whom was Thomas C. Durant, vice-president of the road, and a number of special journalists. At that time a large town was about to spring up around the station, supplied with hotels, restaurants, and saloons, and was already anticipating the prosperity that the branch railway to Denver would bring it. The inauguration was a grand affair, and the programme included speeches, an imitation Indian battle, fireworks, and the first number of the Railway Pioneer, a newspaper printed on the train. It was from this wild spot, at the twenty-third mile-post from Omaha, that the road, having reached the summit of the Rocky Mountains, was to descend towards the Atlantic by gradually lessening gradients; and the Union Pacific Railroad, which had cost such vast sums, and had required such unheard-of efforts, was to be the most potent factor in the development of the American landscape. In truth, without it, the vast plains beyond the Rockies would have been almost inaccessible. At ten P.M., the train stopped at Julesburg, and started again across the dark plains of Nebraska, following the Platte River. At midnight, it passed near Fort McPherson, and, towards morning, it reached the town of North Platte, situated between the two arms of the river of the same name, the South Fork and the North Fork. Here, at the hundred and first meridian, they were entering a region where the snow falls and piles up to a considerable depth during the winter.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The train pursued its course, that evening, without interruption, passing Fort Saunders, crossing Cheyne Pass, and reaching Evans Pass. At this point, the track reached its highest altitude, 8,000 feet above sea level. The air thinned, and the cold bit sharper, despite the enclosed carriages. Outside, the vast, desolate landscape of the Rocky Mountains unfolded, a panorama of snow-capped peaks, deep ravines, and stunted pine forests. The train, a marvel of modern engineering, seemed a fragile thread against the immensity of nature. The gradient became less severe after Evans Pass, but the curves grew more frequent and abrupt as the line wound its way down the eastern slope towards the vast plains. Inside the carriage, the passengers, bundled against the cold, conversed in low tones or gazed out at the rapidly darkening scenery. Phileas Fogg remained impassive, his eyes fixed on the hands of his watch, meticulously noting their progress. Passepartout, however, found it impossible not to be captivated by the wild grandeur outside. He pressed his face against the glass, marveling at the sheer scale of the mountains and the silence of the wilderness, broken only by the rhythmic clatter of the wheels on the track and the whistle of the locomotive echoing through the valleys. They passed through small, isolated stations – mere clusters of wooden buildings surrounded by emptiness – where brief stops were made to take on water or wood for the engine. Each stop was a reminder of the isolation of this frontier region. The night wore on, and the mountainous terrain gradually gave way to rolling hills and then, almost imperceptibly, to the endless flatness of the Great Plains. The stars emerged in a brilliant, unpolluted sky, offering a dazzling spectacle above the dark, featureless land. The speed of the train increased slightly as the gradients eased. Passengers settled down to sleep, rocked by the motion of the carriage. Fogg, ever vigilant, seemed merely to rest his eyes, ready to consult his timetable at the slightest deviation. Passepartout, after hours of watching the passing landscape, eventually succumbed to sleep, dreaming of prairie dogs and buffalo. By morning, they were well into the plains, the mountains a distant memory on the western horizon. The landscape was monotonous but vast, stretching to infinity under a pale dawn sky. The train continued its relentless journey eastward, carrying its passengers towards their varied destinations, none perhaps as pressing or as extraordinary as that of the quiet English gentleman and his devoted French valet, hurrying towards Omaha and the next stage of their incredible race against time around the world.

events.title: A Tense Game of Whist Leads to Conflict
detailed_summary: Phileas Fogg and his companions were engaged in a whist game, undisturbed by the journey's duration.
Fix, initially winning, found his luck turning but remained as focused a player as Fogg.
Chance favored Fogg during the morning, dealing him strong hands.
As Fogg prepared to make a bold play using a spade, a voice from behind advised playing a diamond instead.
Fogg, Aouda, and Fix looked up to identify the speaker as Colonel Proctor.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Fogg and his partners had resumed their game; no one—not even the dummy—complained of the length of the trip.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and Fix raised their heads, and beheld Colonel Proctor.

events.text_segment:
Mr. Fogg and his partners had resumed their game; no one—not even the dummy—complained of the length of the trip. Fix had begun by winning several guineas, which he seemed likely to lose; but he showed himself a not less eager whist-player than Mr. Fogg. During the morning, chance distinctly favoured that gentleman. Trumps and honours were showered upon his hands.
Once, having resolved on a bold stroke, he was on the point of playing a spade, when a voice behind him said, “I should play a diamond.”
Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and Fix raised their heads, and beheld Colonel Proctor.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Mr. Fogg and his partners had resumed their game; no one—not even the dummy—complained of the length of the trip. Fix held the cards, and was very lucky; up to this point, he had won a considerable number of pounds, which he was getting into his pocket when his luck turned. Aoudah was not less skilful than Mr. Fogg, and distinguished herself by her graceful and unerring play. From time to time the conductor came in, and conversed with Colonel Proctor upon the train, which was going at a speed of forty miles an hour, a speed, however, which did not prevent the cows from lying down on the track, obstructing the passage of the train. This happened two or three times. The locomotive had to stop, and the conductor, running to the cattle, simply knocked them off the track with a blow of his fist. Thus the trip across the American continent was accomplished without more accidents. The train arrived at Laramie at eleven, and stopped for twenty minutes. Union Pacific railroad. Laramie, 1716 miles from Omaha. The conductor cried, “Twenty minutes’ stop!” Mr. Fogg and his partners did not think it necessary to leave the car, and continued their game. With the most scrupulous exactness, Mr. Fogg was about to play a spade, when a voice behind him said: "I should play a diamond." Mr. Fogg, Aoudah, and Fix, lifted up their heads and saw Colonel Proctor.

events.title: Insults Exchanged and a Duel Agreed Upon
detailed_summary: Proctor and Fogg instantly recognized each other.
Proctor aggressively questioned Fogg's intended play of a spade.
Fogg calmly confirmed his move by playing the ten of spades.
Proctor insolently declared his preference for diamonds and reached for the card, accusing Fogg of incompetence at whist.
Fogg rose, asserting he might be as skilled as anyone.
Proctor issued a belligerent challenge.
Aouda grew pale and tried to restrain Fogg, while Passepartout prepared to confront Proctor.
Fix intervened, reminding Proctor of their previous altercation where Proctor had struck him.
Fogg politely asserted that this new insult was his affair alone and demanded satisfaction from Proctor.
Proctor readily agreed to a duel at Fogg's convenience regarding time, place, and weapon.
Aouda and Fix's attempts to prevent the duel failed; Passepartout was halted by a sign from Fogg.
Fogg and Proctor stepped onto the car platform to arrange the duel.
Fogg stated his urgent need to return to Europe and suggested meeting in six months, citing his prior intention to seek Proctor out after finishing business in England.
Proctor dismissed this as evasion and demanded the duel happen immediately.
When Fogg confirmed he wasn't going to New York or Chicago, Proctor suggested Plum Creek, the next station stop, as a suitable location for a quick revolver duel during the ten-minute halt.
Fogg calmly agreed to stop at Plum Creek.
Proctor ended the exchange with a threatening remark implying Fogg would not leave Plum Creek.

events.text_segment:
Stamp Proctor and Phileas Fogg recognised each other at once.
“Ah! it’s you, is it, Englishman?” cried the colonel; “it’s you who are going to play a spade!”
“And who plays it,” replied Phileas Fogg coolly, throwing down the ten of spades.
“Well, it pleases me to have it diamonds,” replied Colonel Proctor, in an insolent tone.
He made a movement as if to seize the card which had just been played, adding, “You don’t understand anything about whist.”
“Perhaps I do, as well as another,” said Phileas Fogg, rising.
“You have only to try, son of John Bull,” replied the colonel.
Aouda turned pale, and her blood ran cold. She seized Mr. Fogg’s arm and gently pulled him back. Passepartout was ready to pounce upon the American, who was staring insolently at his opponent. But Fix got up, and, going to Colonel Proctor said, “You forget that it is I with whom you have to deal, sir; for it was I whom you not only insulted, but struck!”
“Mr. Fix,” said Mr. Fogg, “pardon me, but this affair is mine, and mine only. The colonel has again insulted me, by insisting that I should not play a spade, and he shall give me satisfaction for it.”
“When and where you will,” replied the American, “and with whatever weapon you choose.”
Aouda in vain attempted to retain Mr. Fogg; as vainly did the detective endeavour to make the quarrel his. Passepartout wished to throw the colonel out of the window, but a sign from his master checked him. Phileas Fogg left the car, and the American followed him upon the platform. “Sir,” said Mr. Fogg to his adversary, “I am in a great hurry to get back to Europe, and any delay whatever will be greatly to my disadvantage.”
“Well, what’s that to me?” replied Colonel Proctor.
“Sir,” said Mr. Fogg, very politely, “after our meeting at San Francisco, I determined to return to America and find you as soon as I had completed the business which called me to England.”
“Really!”
“Will you appoint a meeting for six months hence?”
“Why not ten years hence?”
“I say six months,” returned Phileas Fogg; “and I shall be at the place of meeting promptly.”
“All this is an evasion,” cried Stamp Proctor. “Now or never!”
“Very good. You are going to New York?”
“No.”
“To Chicago?”
“No.”
“To Omaha?”
“What difference is it to you? Do you know Plum Creek?”
“No,” replied Mr. Fogg.
“It’s the next station. The train will be there in an hour, and will stop there ten minutes. In ten minutes several revolver-shots could be exchanged.”
“Very well,” said Mr. Fogg. “I will stop at Plum Creek.”
“And I guess you’ll stay there too,” added the American insolently.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Stamp Proctor and Phileas Fogg recognised each other at once.

“Ah! it is you, is it, Mr. Fogg?” cried the colonel, half-mad with rage. “It was you who prevented my fighting the other ruffian—that Fix!”

“Colonel,” replied Mr. Fogg, coolly, “I observed that you were out of temper, and I intervened to prevent bloodshed.”

“It’s an ill look-out for him that you did; for I’m not done with him yet. But as to you, who can’t play cards, you were not afraid to hinder my fighting a duel!”

“I play whist tolerably well, sir,” said Mr. Fogg.

“You are bluffing,” cried Proctor. “I have the spades, and you play a ten of spades. You cannot but have the ten to make up the thirteen.”

“Monsieur,” replied Mr. Fogg, playing the ten, “my turn to play a spade having come, I played it.”

“That is your game, is it, you confounded Englishman!” cried Proctor. “You do not play according to the rules. You are bluffing. I’d rather play with a Hottentot!”

“You insult me, sir,” said Mr. Fogg, getting up. “I am an Englishman, and I do not bluff, and I am able to play as well as anyone.”

“That is what I propose to see, you confounded Briton!” cried Proctor, rising in turn. “You shall give me satisfaction for your impertinence.”

Aouda turned pale, and held back Mr. Fogg; Passepartout was ready to spring upon the American, who was glaring at his opponent.

“Colonel,” said Fix, with a slight tremor in his voice, “you have insulted me, and struck me when I was not armed. You owe me satisfaction.”

“And you, too, shall have it, as soon as I have done with this gentleman,” replied the American. “On my word, I’ll put you all through!”

“No one shall prevent my dealing with Colonel Proctor,” said Mr. Fogg, indicating Passepartout and Fix by a look. “Sir, I am at your disposal, and you can choose the time, place, and weapons.”

Aouda and Fix attempted to interpose, but a sign from Mr. Fogg stopped them. Passepartout, in his anxiety, nearly fainted away.

“All right,” said the colonel, “Plum Creek, the next station. We shall have ten minutes there. We can fight with revolvers.”

“I will stop at Plum Creek,” replied Mr. Fogg.

“And I guess you’ll stay there!” added the American, passing out into the passage to make his preparations.

“I’m not going to wait ten days,” said Proctor; “you shall give me satisfaction now.”

“Where?”

“On the train.”

“I think this is very inconvenient,” replied Mr. Fogg. “If you will step out on the platform, we can arrange matters.”

They stepped out, and the American continued, “I am not going to New York or Chicago; I am going to Plum Creek.”

“Is Plum Creek a station?” asked Mr. Fogg.

“Yes, it is a station,” replied Proctor. “We shall have ten minutes there. We can fight with revolvers.”

“I will stop at Plum Creek,” replied Mr. Fogg.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Stamp Proctor and Phileas Fogg recognised each other at once. It was the American who had been involved in the tumultuous meeting in San Francisco, whom Fogg had unhesitatingly and coolly thrashed with his cane. Proctor, seeing Fogg in the lobby of the St. Nicholas Hotel, felt the old rage resurface, hot and immediate. He strode forward, his face flushed with anger. Phileas Fogg, meanwhile, having just disembarked from the wretched *Henrietta* after its fiery, coal-consuming voyage and brief transformation into a purely sailing vessel, was preoccupied with securing passage to Europe. He had arrived at the hotel with Passepartout and the lovely Aouda, weary but driven by the relentless ticking of the clock. He had perhaps half an hour to settle his affairs before hastening to the Cunard pier. Proctor’s voice boomed, cutting through the quiet bustle of the hotel lobby. “Mr. Fogg!” he roared, stopping the Englishman in his tracks. “We meet again!” Fogg turned, his expression as calm and unruffled as ever, acknowledging the man he had last seen under very different circumstances. "Sir?" he inquired, his tone polite but distant. Proctor stepped closer, his fists clenched. "You remember San Francisco, do you? And my face?" he challenged. "I have not forgotten it, sir," Fogg replied evenly, as if discussing a minor business transaction. "I recall our previous encounter." "And you recall the insult you offered me?" Proctor pressed, his voice rising. "An insult," Fogg confirmed, without apology or change of countenance. "Well, I demand satisfaction!" Proctor declared loudly. "You will fight me, here and now!" Aouda looked on with apprehension, and Passepartout shifted nervously, anticipating trouble. Fogg, however, remained perfectly still. "I am quite willing to give you satisfaction, sir," Fogg stated, his gaze steady. "But not at this precise moment. I have urgent business to attend to. I am arranging my departure for Europe." Proctor was taken aback by the composed response. He had expected denial, or perhaps a show of fear. But Fogg’s tranquil acceptance threw him off balance. "Departure? To Europe?" Proctor scoffed. "Do you intend to run away?" "By no means," Fogg answered. "I am simply bound by a schedule. I will fight you, sir, but it must be after I have secured my passage and made the necessary arrangements. Say, in two hours? I will be at the Cunard pier. You may find me there." Proctor hesitated, weighing the unusual proposal. Fogg’s perfect calmness somehow disarmed his fury, though it did not extinguish it. "Very well," Proctor conceded, though reluctantly. "In two hours. At the Cunard pier. Don’t fail to be there." "You may rely upon it," Fogg assured him. With that, Fogg turned his attention back to his pressing matters. He instructed Passepartout to see to the luggage and Madame Aouda, and then briskly approached the hotel clerk to inquire about the fastest way to reach the Cunard Line office and secure cabins on the next steamer bound for Liverpool. The duel, it seemed, would have to wait for travel arrangements to be finalised, a perfectly logical ordering of priorities in Fogg’s meticulously organised mind.

events.title: Duel Plans Thwarted by Train Schedule
detailed_summary: Fogg returned to the carriage with his usual composure.
He reassured Aouda, dismissing Proctor as a mere blusterer.
Fogg asked Fix to be his second for the duel, a request Fix could not refuse.
Fogg calmly resumed the interrupted whist game.
The train whistle signaled their approach to Plum Creek station.
Fogg rose and went to the platform, followed by Fix and Passepartout, who carried revolvers.
Aouda remained inside, overcome with anxiety.
Colonel Proctor and his second emerged from the next car onto the platform.
As the duellists prepared to disembark, the conductor hurried over.
The conductor announced that they could not get off because the train was twenty minutes late and would not be stopping.
Proctor protested, explaining his intention to fight a duel.
The conductor apologized but stated the train was leaving immediately, pointing out the departure bell was ringing.
The train started moving.
The conductor expressed regret again but suggested they could fight while traveling.
Proctor sarcastically questioned if this arrangement suited Fogg.
Fogg replied that it was perfectly convenient.
Passepartout reflected with amusement on the accommodating nature of the American conductor and followed Fogg.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Who knows?” replied Mr. Fogg, returning to the car as coolly as usual.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So muttering, he followed his master.

events.text_segment:
“Who knows?” replied Mr. Fogg, returning to the car as coolly as usual. He began to reassure Aouda, telling her that blusterers were never to be feared, and begged Fix to be his second at the approaching duel, a request which the detective could not refuse. Mr. Fogg resumed the interrupted game with perfect calmness.
At eleven o’clock the locomotive’s whistle announced that they were approaching Plum Creek station. Mr. Fogg rose, and, followed by Fix, went out upon the platform. Passepartout accompanied him, carrying a pair of revolvers. Aouda remained in the car, as pale as death.
The door of the next car opened, and Colonel Proctor appeared on the platform, attended by a Yankee of his own stamp as his second. But just as the combatants were about to step from the train, the conductor hurried up, and shouted, “You can’t get off, gentlemen!”
“Why not?” asked the colonel.
“We are twenty minutes late, and we shall not stop.”
“But I am going to fight a duel with this gentleman.”
“I am sorry,” said the conductor; “but we shall be off at once. There’s the bell ringing now.”
The train started.
“I’m really very sorry, gentlemen,” said the conductor. “Under any other circumstances I should have been happy to oblige you. But, after all, as you have not had time to fight here, why not fight as we go along?”
“That wouldn’t be convenient, perhaps, for this gentleman,” said the colonel, in a jeering tone.
“It would be perfectly so,” replied Phileas Fogg.
“Well, we are really in America,” thought Passepartout, “and the conductor is a gentleman of the first order!”
So muttering, he followed his master.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“Who knows?” replied Mr. Fogg, returning to the car as coolly as usual. “And besides,” added he, “this eventuality, not having been foreseen, does not invalidate my scheme in the least.”

“But, Mr. Fogg,” said Aouda, “you cannot let this man insult you with impunity; you ought to fight.”

“I am going to fight,” returned Mr. Fogg, coldly. “I have already engaged Fix as my second.”

“I could not refuse him,” muttered Fix, between his teeth, with a certain vexation. “After all, this duel does not violate the regulations.”

“But,” resumed Mrs. Aouda, endeavouring to take Mr. Fogg’s hand and retain him, “on the cars, in America, a duel! it is impossible!”

“It is my duty,” responded Mr. Fogg. “So, pray do not disturb me. Passepartout,” added he, “you will accompany me.”

“Your honour is too good,” returned Passepartout, nonplussed. “But if you are going to fight, might it not have been better to wait till you got to England? What a wild man this Colonel Proctor is! and what a time he has chosen for coming to look for you; just at the moment you are about to…”

The train now blew its whistle, and slackened its speed.

“Plum Creek!” cried the conductor.

Mr. Fogg and Fix, followed by Passepartout, alighted on the ground, having in their hands their revolvers, which they had purchased at New York. Aouda remained in the car, as pale as death. The door was already a little way open upon the platform, and Colonel Proctor was there, too, with his second, a stout, husky fellow, who had an enormous moustache, and wore spectacles.

But just as Mr. Fogg was about to step from the step of the car, the conductor ran up and called out, “You can’t get off, gentleman!”

“Why not?” asked Mr. Fogg.

“We are twenty minutes behind time, and we are not going to stop.”

“But I am going to fight a duel with this gentleman,” said Colonel Proctor.

“I am very sorry,” replied the conductor, “but we are going right on. The train is whistling for starting.”

The train started, in fact, with increased speed.

“The conductor is right,” said Mr. Fogg, calmly; “I cannot get off.”

“I am sorry, gentlemen,” said the conductor, “the next station is ten minutes off, and we shall stop there twenty minutes.”

“Well, we will fight there,” said Mr. Fogg, with his imperturbable air.

“We will be there at noon,” observed Colonel Proctor, with the same coolness.

“Till noon, then,” replied Mr. Fogg.

“Passepartout,” said the Colonel’s second, “we will see you then.”

“I will be there,” said Passepartout.

The train sped onward, and soon reached the station where they were to stop for twenty minutes. Passepartout, who had not had an opportunity of observing his master since the affair of the duel, now looked at him with intense curiosity. Mr. Fogg was as calm as ever, and Fix, who saw him pull out his watch, and heard him remark, “Two minutes past noon,” felt a strange misgiving.

But Colonel Proctor and his second were not there. The train went on.

“Mr. Proctor has not come,” said Passepartout.

“He is probably on the next train,” replied Mr. Fogg, imperturbably.

“He will be a long time coming, then,” said Passepartout, "for the next train won't be along for six hours."

Mr. Fogg did not reply. He resumed his game of whist with Fix. Passepartout, however, was ill at ease. He went to the door, and looked along the line. He saw nothing. He returned to his place, and sat down, saying to himself, "This is not a duel that I can understand. It is a duel of the future, perhaps."

The train continued its course. At two o'clock in the afternoon, Mr. Fogg laid down his cards, and said, "I must go to the station."

He went, followed by Passepartout. They found the station empty. Mr. Fogg returned to the car. “It is impossible to find him,” he said.

“But what are you going to do, sir?” asked Passepartout.

“Wait,” replied Mr. Fogg. “I have telegraphed to Omaha.”

At three o'clock, a telegram arrived. Mr. Fogg opened it, and read it.

“He is at Omaha,” he said. “We must go on.”

The train set out at once. It arrived at Omaha at six o'clock in the evening. Mr. Fogg went to the station. He found that Colonel Proctor had left by the train for Chicago at one o'clock.

“We must go on,” said Mr. Fogg.

“But we have lost six hours,” said Passepartout.

“No matter,” replied Mr. Fogg, calmly. “We must make up for it.”

The train for Chicago started at seven o'clock. Mr. Fogg and Passepartout took their places. Fix was with them.

“Chicago!” cried the conductor.

Mr. Fogg alighted with his two companions. They went to the telegraph office. Mr. Fogg telegraphed to Liverpool, ordering a steamer for the next day.

“Now,” said Mr. Fogg, “we must find Colonel Proctor.”

They found him at the principal hotel. Mr. Fogg went to his room.

“Colonel Proctor,” said Mr. Fogg, “I have come to fight a duel with you.”

“This room will do,” said Mr. Fogg. “We are alone.”

“But there are others here,” said the Colonel.

“Let them stay,” replied Mr. Fogg. “They can be witnesses.”

The Colonel hesitated for a moment. Then he said, “Very well.”

Mr. Fogg and the Colonel drew their revolvers. Fix and Passepartout stood by, pale and trembling.

“Are you ready, sir?” asked Mr. Fogg.

“I am,” replied the Colonel.

“Fire!” cried Mr. Fogg.

The two men fired at the same moment. The Colonel fell, struck in the forehead.

Mr. Fogg went up to him. He put his hand on his heart. It had ceased to beat.

“He is dead,” said Mr. Fogg.

He turned to Fix and Passepartout. “Let us go,” he said.

They left the hotel, and went to the station. The train for New York was about to start. They took their places.

“We will embark at once,” said Mr. Fogg.

Mr. Fogg and his companions landed. They went to the custom-house. They had no trouble with the customs.

They went to a hotel. Mr. Fogg ordered supper.

After supper, he said to Fix and Passepartout, “We must go to London.”

“But the train does not start till ten o'clock,” said Fix.

“We will go by special train,” replied Mr. Fogg.

He ordered a special train. It started at once. It arrived at London at five o'clock in the morning.

“Is it you, sir?” cried the butler.

“It is I, indeed,” replied Mr. Fogg. “I have come back.”

“And what about the wager?” asked the butler.

“I have won it,” replied Mr. Fogg.

“But you have lost five days,” said the butler.

“No matter,” replied Mr. Fogg. “I have saved the lady.”

“This is Mrs. Fogg,” said Mr. Fogg.

“It is true, nevertheless,” replied Mr. Fogg. “I have gained five days.”

He showed them his log-book. It confirmed his statement.

“Who knows?” replied Mr. Fogg, returning to the car as coolly as usual. “And besides,” added he, “this eventuality, not having been foreseen, does not invalidate my scheme in the least.”

“But, Mr. Fogg,” said Aouda, “you cannot let this man insult you with impunity; you ought to fight.”

“I am going to fight,” returned Mr. Fogg, coldly. “I have already engaged Fix as my second.”

“I could not refuse him,” muttered Fix, between his teeth, with a certain vexation. “After all, this duel does not violate the regulations.”

“But,” resumed Mrs. Aouda, endeavouring to take Mr. Fogg’s hand and retain him, “on the cars, in America, a duel! it is impossible!”

“It is my duty,” responded Mr. Fogg. “So, pray do not disturb me. Passepartout,” added he, “you will accompany me.”

“Your honour is too good,” returned Passepartout, nonplussed. “But if you are going to fight, might it not have been better to wait till you got to England? What a wild man this Colonel Proctor is! and what a time he has chosen for coming to look for you; just at the moment you are about to…”

The train now blew its whistle, and slackened its speed.

“Plum Creek!” cried the conductor.

Mr. Fogg and Fix, followed by Passepartout, alighted on the ground, having in their hands their revolvers, which they had purchased at New York. Aouda remained in the car, as pale as death. The door was already a little way open upon the platform, and Colonel Proctor was there, too, with his second, a stout, husky fellow, who had an enormous moustache, and wore spectacles.

But just as Mr. Fogg was about to step from the step of the car, the conductor ran up and called out, “You can’t get off, gentleman!”

“Why not?” asked Mr. Fogg.

“We are twenty minutes behind time, and we are not going to stop.”

“But I am going to fight a duel with this gentleman,” said Colonel Proctor.

“I am very sorry,” replied the conductor, “but we are going right on. The train is whistling for starting.”

The train started, in fact, with increased speed.

“The conductor is right,” said Mr. Fogg, calmly; “I cannot get off.”

“I am sorry, gentlemen,” said the conductor, as the train rolled past the station, “but the next station is ten minutes off, and we shall stop there twenty minutes.”

“Good,” said Mr. Fogg. “We will fight there.”

“I’ll be there,” said Colonel Proctor.

And the train, increasing its speed, soon passed out of sight of Plum Creek station. Passepartout was reflecting, with a chuckle, that the American conductor, with his excessive politeness, would not have been a bit surprised if, in response to his obliging offer, Colonel Proctor and Mr. Fogg had proceeded to blow each other's brains out on the platform of the cars, and were now about to engage in that diversion. “It is really a very accommodating country,” thought Passepartout. “And conductors here are very civilised.” He followed his master, quite ready for whatever was to come.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: “Who knows?” replied Mr. Fogg, returning to the car as coolly as usual. The news that the railway line stopped forty miles short of Allahabad, at the village of Kholby, had spread like wildfire. It was a severe, unforeseen obstacle to the journey. While other passengers fretted and grumbled, Mr. Fogg showed no sign of agitation. He simply consulted his timetable again, verifying the precise location of Kholby and the gap. Passepartout, on the other hand, was beside himself. The faithful valet had believed the railway complete, and this sudden halt threatened the entire wager. He paced nervously, throwing despairing glances at his master. "But Monsieur Fogg, the train! We were counting on the train!" he exclaimed, wringing his hands. Fogg merely listened, his gaze scanning the bustling crowd and the various forms of transport available – or rather, unavailable – for such a distance. "We must find another means of conveyance," he stated calmly, as if discussing a minor itinerary change. "We need to reach Allahabad. The Express train for Calcutta departs tomorrow morning." His tone admitted no possibility of failure. He stepped out onto the platform, his eyes fixed on something in the distance. He spoke briefly to a station official, then to a local man. It quickly became clear that ordinary transport was non-existent for such a journey through the jungle. Carriages, carts, nothing suitable was available. But then, a rumour, a possibility began to circulate. There was talk of an elephant. An animal, someone suggested, that might be hired, if its owner could be found and persuaded. An elephant! The idea was audacious, unconventional, precisely the sort of solution that might appeal to Mr. Fogg's peculiar genius. He turned back to Passepartout, a glint in his eye, the first hint of animation the valet had seen in hours. "Passepartout," he said, his voice quiet but firm, "we need an elephant."

events.title: Duel Arrangements Abruptly Halted by Sioux Attack
detailed_summary: Fogg, Proctor, their seconds, and the conductor moved through the train to the last car.
The conductor politely requested the dozen passengers in the rear car to vacate it for the duel, which they did promptly.
The car, about fifty feet long, was deemed suitable, allowing the adversaries space to advance and fire.
Fogg and Proctor, each holding two six-barrelled revolvers, entered the car.
The seconds remained outside and shut the doors.
The plan was for firing to begin at the first locomotive whistle, with the outcome assessed after two minutes.
The simplicity of the arrangement heightened the tension for Fix and Passepartout waiting outside.
As they listened for the whistle, sudden savage cries and gunfire erupted along the train, clearly not from the duellists' car.
Cries of terror arose from within the train cars.
Fogg and Proctor, revolvers ready, quickly left the designated duel car and rushed towards the commotion.
They realized the train was under attack by a band of Sioux Indians.
The narrative notes that such attacks were not uncommon, with the Sioux adept at boarding moving trains.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The two combatants, their seconds, and the conductor passed through the cars to the rear of the train.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: A hundred of them had, according to their habit, jumped upon the steps without stopping the train, with the ease of a clown mounting a horse at full gallop.

events.text_segment:
The two combatants, their seconds, and the conductor passed through the cars to the rear of the train. The last car was only occupied by a dozen passengers, whom the conductor politely asked if they would not be so kind as to leave it vacant for a few moments, as two gentlemen had an affair of honour to settle. The passengers granted the request with alacrity, and straightway disappeared on the platform.
The car, which was some fifty feet long, was very convenient for their purpose. The adversaries might march on each other in the aisle, and fire at their ease. Never was duel more easily arranged. Mr. Fogg and Colonel Proctor, each provided with two six-barrelled revolvers, entered the car. The seconds, remaining outside, shut them in. They were to begin firing at the first whistle of the locomotive. After an interval of two minutes, what remained of the two gentlemen would be taken from the car.
Nothing could be more simple. Indeed, it was all so simple that Fix and Passepartout felt their hearts beating as if they would crack. They were listening for the whistle agreed upon, when suddenly savage cries resounded in the air, accompanied by reports which certainly did not issue from the car where the duellists were. The reports continued in front and the whole length of the train. Cries of terror proceeded from the interior of the cars.
Colonel Proctor and Mr. Fogg, revolvers in hand, hastily quitted their prison, and rushed forward where the noise was most clamorous. They then perceived that the train was attacked by a band of Sioux.
This was not the first attempt of these daring Indians, for more than once they had waylaid trains on the road. A hundred of them had, according to their habit, jumped upon the steps without stopping the train, with the ease of a clown mounting a horse at full gallop.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The two combatants, their seconds, and the conductor passed through the cars to the rear of the train. The conductor politely requested the dozen passengers in the rear car to vacate it for the use of the gentlemen, to whom it was surrendered. The car was an obliging one, a sort of smoking-car, no doubt. The passengers, quite surprised, got out, and ranged themselves on the platforms, or along the track. The car, which was fifty feet long, was well adapted to the purpose. The adversaries could advance on each other in a straight line, and fire at their ease. Mr. Fogg and Colonel Proctor, provided with two six-barrelled revolvers each, entered the car. Their seconds, remaining outside, shut them in. At the first whistle of the locomotive, the firing was to begin. After that, at the expiration of two minutes, the duelists would be called upon to open the doors. What passed inside, during the interval, was left to conjecture. Nothing could be more simple than this arrangement; and, for this very reason, it was all the more terrible. Fix and Passepartout, outside the door, waited in impatient anxiety. A few moments only separated them from the dreaded signal. Suddenly, above the distinct sound of the locomotive's whistle, a succession of savage cries were heard, followed by an explosion of fire-arms, on the forward end of the train. There was a great tumult on the cars, and the train stopped. Colonel Proctor and Mr. Fogg, revolvers in hand, hurried from the car and ran forward to the baggage-car, where the noise was most clamorous. Sioux Indians! they cried. They were indeed a band of Sioux, who had attacked the train, and at the moment they made their assault, were going through it like tigers, not by way of the doors, but by clambering upon the roofs of the cars, and leaping from one to another. These savages were armed with muskets, from which they fired with inconceivable rapidity; and to this were added their pistols and their terrible tomahawks.
