The car, which was fifty feet long, was well adapted to the purpose. The adversaries could advance on each other in a straight line, and fire at their ease. Mr. Fogg and Colonel Proctor, provided with two six-barrelled revolvers each, entered the car. Their seconds, remaining outside, shut them in. At the first whistle of the locomotive, the firing was to begin. After that, at the expiration of two minutes, the duelists would be called upon to open the doors. What passed inside, during the interval, was left to conjecture. Nothing could be more simple than this arrangement; and, for this very reason, it was all the more terrible. Fix and Passepartout, outside the door, waited in impatient anxiety. A few moments only separated them from the dreaded signal. Suddenly, above the distinct sound of the locomotive's whistle, a succession of savage cries were heard, followed by an explosion of fire-arms, on the forward end of the train. There was a great tumult on the cars, and the train stopped. Colonel Proctor and Mr. Fogg, revolvers in hand, hurried from the car and ran forward to the baggage-car, where the noise was most clamorous. Sioux Indians! they cried. They were indeed a band of Sioux, who had attacked the train, and at the moment they made their assault, were going through it like tigers, not by way of the doors, but by clambering upon the roofs of the cars, and leaping from one to another. These savages were armed with muskets, from which they fired with inconceivable rapidity; and to this were added their pistols and their terrible tomahawks.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The two combatants, their seconds, and the conductor passed through the cars to the rear of the train. They moved quickly, almost grimly, down the narrow aisles. Heads turned as they passed, eyes wide with a mixture of curiosity and alarm. The rumour of a duel on a moving train had spread with astonishing speed amongst the passengers, transforming the tedious journey into a scene of dramatic, if rather absurd, tension. Ladies shrank back, gentlemen peered over the tops of their newspapers, and children, sensing the unusual excitement, pressed their faces against the windows or clung to their mothers. The conductor, looking thoroughly vexed by this interruption to his routine schedule, led the way, occasionally barking an instruction to clear a path. Phileas Fogg, impeccably dressed as always, moved with the calm, methodical step of a man about to transact a piece of business. Colonel Proctor, his face flushed and eyes blazing, strode behind him, his hand occasionally straying towards his side as if impatient to begin the violent encounter. Sir Francis Cromarty, Fogg's chosen second, followed closely, his expression one of grave concern. Passepartout, though desperately worried for his master, managed to maintain a semblance of composure, his natural good humour momentarily eclipsed by apprehension. They reached the last passenger car and stepped out onto the small, open platform at the very end of the train. The wind whipped around them, carrying the roar of the engine and the rhythmic clatter of the wheels over the rails. It was a precarious, exposed spot, but one that offered a clear space, away from the terrified gaze of the other travellers. "Here, gentlemen," announced the conductor, gesturing towards the limited area. "This is the best I can offer. Mind your footing. And for heaven's sake, be quick about it before someone gets hurt or, worse, falls off!" Phileas Fogg gave a curt nod of acknowledgement. Colonel Proctor merely glared, his eyes fixed on his opponent. The seconds conferred briefly, verifying the pistols and agreeing on the necessary distance, though the confines of the platform made a lengthy separation impossible. It was agreed they would stand just a few paces apart, turning to fire on the count of three. The air crackled with anticipation, the mechanical pounding of the train only amplifying the human tension. Passepartout watched, heart in his mouth, ready to leap forward if necessary, praying for a miraculous intervention. This was madness, a duel of honour fought hurtling through the American wilderness at fifty miles an hour. The seconds stepped back, pistols were loaded, and the conductor reluctantly prepared to give the signal, his face a mask of official disapproval and private anxiety. The train rattled onward, oblivious to the drama unfolding on its rear platform.

events.title: Desperate Defense and Passepartout's Gamble
detailed_summary: The armed Sioux exchanged fire with the passengers, most of whom were also armed.
Indians attacked the engine crew, stunning the engineer and stoker.
A Sioux chief tried to stop the train but, unfamiliar with the controls, accidentally opened the steam valve fully, causing the locomotive to accelerate violently.
Simultaneously, Sioux fighters swarmed the cars, climbing over roofs, forcing doors, and engaging in close combat with passengers.
They looted the baggage car, throwing luggage off the speeding train.
Amidst continuous cries and gunfire, the travelers fought back bravely.
Some cars were barricaded, becoming mobile forts enduring the siege at high speed.
Aouda displayed remarkable courage, using a revolver effectively against attackers appearing at broken windows.
The battle resulted in casualties on both sides: twenty Sioux fell dead, some crushed by the wheels, while several passengers lay wounded.
After ten minutes, it became clear the Sioux would win if the train wasn't stopped soon.
Fort Kearney station and its garrison were close, but if passed, the train would be entirely vulnerable.
The conductor, fighting near Fogg, was shot and fell, warning they had only five minutes to stop the train or be lost.
Fogg prepared to take action himself.
Passepartout intervened, declaring he would go.
Before Fogg could stop him, Passepartout slipped out a door unnoticed by the attackers and got under the train.
Leveraging his past acrobatic skills, he navigated the dangerous space beneath the cars amidst the ongoing firefight, moving towards the engine.
Reaching the front, hanging between the tender and the baggage car, he managed to loosen the safety chains.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The Sioux were armed with guns, from which came the reports, to which the passengers, who were almost all armed, responded by revolver-shots.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: There, suspended by one hand between the baggage-car and the tender, with the other he loosened the safety chains; but, owing to the traction, he would never have succeeded in unscrewing the yoking-bar, had not a violent concussion jolted this bar out.

events.text_segment:
The Sioux were armed with guns, from which came the reports, to which the passengers, who were almost all armed, responded by revolver-shots.
The Indians had first mounted the engine, and half stunned the engineer and stoker with blows from their muskets. A Sioux chief, wishing to stop the train, but not knowing how to work the regulator, had opened wide instead of closing the steam-valve, and the locomotive was plunging forward with terrific velocity.
The Sioux had at the same time invaded the cars, skipping like enraged monkeys over the roofs, thrusting open the doors, and fighting hand to hand with the passengers. Penetrating the baggage-car, they pillaged it, throwing the trunks out of the train. The cries and shots were constant. The travellers defended themselves bravely; some of the cars were barricaded, and sustained a siege, like moving forts, carried along at a speed of a hundred miles an hour.
Aouda behaved courageously from the first. She defended herself like a true heroine with a revolver, which she shot through the broken windows whenever a savage made his appearance. Twenty Sioux had fallen mortally wounded to the ground, and the wheels crushed those who fell upon the rails as if they had been worms. Several passengers, shot or stunned, lay on the seats.
It was necessary to put an end to the struggle, which had lasted for ten minutes, and which would result in the triumph of the Sioux if the train was not stopped. Fort Kearney station, where there was a garrison, was only two miles distant; but, that once passed, the Sioux would be masters of the train between Fort Kearney and the station beyond.
The conductor was fighting beside Mr. Fogg, when he was shot and fell. At the same moment he cried, “Unless the train is stopped in five minutes, we are lost!”
“It shall be stopped,” said Phileas Fogg, preparing to rush from the car.
“Stay, monsieur,” cried Passepartout; “I will go.”
Mr. Fogg had not time to stop the brave fellow, who, opening a door unperceived by the Indians, succeeded in slipping under the car; and while the struggle continued and the balls whizzed across each other over his head, he made use of his old acrobatic experience, and with amazing agility worked his way under the cars, holding on to the chains, aiding himself by the brakes and edges of the sashes, creeping from one car to another with marvellous skill, and thus gaining the forward end of the train.
There, suspended by one hand between the baggage-car and the tender, with the other he loosened the safety chains; but, owing to the traction, he would never have succeeded in unscrewing the yoking-bar, had not a violent concussion jolted this bar out.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The Sioux were armed with guns, from which came the reports, to which the passengers, who were almost all armed, responded by revolver-shots. The Indians did not approach the car itself, but shot at it from a distance; and the windows, which were of too fragile glass, were soon broken into a thousand pieces. The balls poured in, cracking the woodwork of the cars, and flattening themselves upon the frames. The travellers, though surprised, were not wanting in presence of mind. Barricades of seats, mattresses, and packages were speedily put up at the windows, and behind these the besieged parties, firing when the Sioux came near. The latter, however, were not peaceable citizens, not agriculturists who cultivate the soil and live by the sale of their produce. They were terrible savages, very often man-eaters, and always formidable. At a given signal, a frightful yell was heard, and the Indians threw themselves upon the train, with the agility of serpents, climbing over the roofs, and crawling along the steps, gaining a footing on the platforms, and forcing open the doors. It was a hand-to-hand struggle, defending themselves with revolvers and hatchets, fighting with desperation. The Sioux had surprised the engineer and stoker, and, a moment after, the train stopped, not having been uncoupled. The whole band then rushed into the cars, overrunning them like a torrent, bellowing, howling, brandishing their tomahawks, and looting the baggage-vans, throwing the trunks out of the train. The travellers resisted heroically, many of them armed with repeating rifles, defending their cars foot by foot. The cars were drenched with blood. There were frightful cries, intermingled with the reports of the guns and revolvers, and the shrill whistle of the locomotive, whose steam was still on and which was tearing through space. The most formidable band of the Sioux had rushed upon the engine, and a chief, hatchet in hand, had ordered the engineer and stoker to descend. They refused to obey, and were instantly struck down and killed. The next moment the chief, not comprehending the working of the machinery, increased the pressure of the steam, and the locomotive then started forward with terrific speed, levelling as if it were a battering-ram the Sioux who still clung to the sides of the cars. The greater number of the Indians had followed the chief into the train, and were fighting hand to hand with the passengers. The latter were gradually giving ground, and the issue of the struggle was becoming every moment more uncertain. The train was not uncoupled, and the Indians were masters of the engine. The locomotive was proceeding at fearful speed, and it was impossible to jump off without almost certain death. One heroic deed, however, saved the train. Passepartout saw that the struggle was going on under the most unfavourable circumstances. The Indians were gaining ground, and the passengers were nearly all wounded or killed. It was only a question of minutes before the train would be completely at the mercy of the savages. He therefore conceived the idea of uncoupling the train. It was a dangerous undertaking, but he was resolved to accomplish it. He crept under the cars, and, crawling along from one to another, he succeeded in reaching the coupling-chains, which were attached to the rear of the engine. He then, with the aid of a knife, cut the chains, and the train became instantly separated from the locomotive. The latter continued its headlong course, carrying with it the corpses of the engineer and stoker, and the chief of the Sioux, who, clinging to the throttle, was carried away with the engine. The train, freed from the engine, gradually slackened its speed, and the passengers, though exhausted and bleeding, breathed a sigh of relief. It was not a moment too soon. The train stopped within a hundred yards of the station of Fort Kearney. The soldiers of the fort, hearing the noise of the firing, had rushed out, and were coming towards the train. They arrived just as the Indians, finding themselves abandoned by the engine, and seeing the soldiers coming, were preparing to beat a retreat. The soldiers opened fire, and the Sioux, seeing that they were caught between two fires, and having lost their chief, fled in disorder. They disappeared as quickly as they had come, leaving behind them about twenty of their dead, and a considerable quantity of plunder. The passengers, on alighting from the train, presented a sorry spectacle. Many of them were wounded, and several were dead. Mr. Fogg and Sir Francis Cromarty were among the wounded, but fortunately their wounds were not serious. Aouda had displayed a courage worthy of a heroine. With a revolver in her hand, she had fought like a lioness, and had killed several of the savages. Passepartout had escaped without a scratch. He was received by Mr. Fogg with a hearty handshake, and by Sir Francis Cromarty with a warm embrace. The conductor, who had been wounded in the shoulder, informed Mr. Fogg that the next train would not pass for twelve hours, and that, as they were in front of the fort, they could safely wait there. Mr. Fogg, however, was not disposed to wait. He was anxious to make up for lost time. He therefore ordered a special train, and, having taken leave of Sir Francis Cromarty, who remained at the fort, he continued his journey.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The Sioux were armed with guns, from which came the reports, to which the passengers, who were almost all armed, responded by revolver-shots. The train was going at full speed. The engine-driver could not be pardoned if he did not cross the stations, though they were not expected to stop at them. He saw the danger, and kept on. The savages knew the stations where the Union Pacific passed. For example, a hundred miles west of this they would have had to stop. But here they were in the wilderness. The railway was not guarded. They could attack at any time, and they did. The passengers fired their revolvers out the windows. The air was filled with the smell of powder and the whizz of bullets. The Sioux warriors, in their war paint, galloped alongside the train on their ponies. Some tried to board the cars. Others were content to fire from a distance. The conductor, a brave man, went from car to car, encouraging the passengers and organizing the defense. But what could he do? He had a few men under his orders, but the savages were numerous. They were two hundred at least, maybe more. It was a desperate situation. Fogg remained perfectly calm in his compartment. Aouda was pale but silent. Passepartout, however, was in a frenzy. He could not stand still. He wanted to do something. He saw a young man, Mr. Mudge, a brave and energetic American, organizing a resistance in his car. Passepartout joined him. They distributed arms to those who had none and showed them how to use them. The train continued its headlong rush. The noise was deafening: the roar of the train, the reports of the guns, the war cries of the Indians. It seemed impossible to escape. But the train was reaching a fort, Fort Kearney, where there was a detachment of soldiers. If they could only hold out until they reached it! The fight was fierce. The Sioux were persistent. They were not afraid of death. Some even managed to climb onto the roof of the cars. It was then that a terrible thing happened. Passepartout, in his zeal, saw a number of savages who were trying to uncouple the cars from the engine. If they succeeded, the engine would escape, but the cars, full of passengers, would be left at the mercy of the Indians. Passepartout did not hesitate. He crawled along under the cars, at the risk of being crushed, and succeeded in preventing the uncoupling just in time. It was a brave act, a foolish act, but it saved the train. The Sioux, seeing their attempt foiled and the fort approaching, finally gave up the attack and galloped away into the plains. The train reached Fort Kearney, battered and scarred, but safe. The passengers were exhausted but relieved. Many were wounded, but fortunately, no one had been killed. Passepartout was hailed as a hero, though he felt he had only done his duty. Fogg simply remarked that it was fortunate the uncoupling had been prevented. It was just another incident on the long journey, a reminder of the dangers of the wild West, a test of courage and resourcefulness. The journey continued, but the memory of the Sioux attack would remain with them, a vivid and terrifying experience.

events.title: Engine Detached, Train Saved, Hero Missing
detailed_summary: A sudden jolt dislodged the coupling bar, separating the engine from the train cars.
The locomotive sped off, while the detached cars continued moving forward due to momentum.
The brakes were applied, bringing the train cars to a halt less than a hundred feet from Kearney station.
Soldiers from the fort, alerted by the gunfire, approached rapidly.
Caught by surprise at the soldiers' arrival, the Sioux warriors fled before the train came to a complete stop.
As the passengers gathered on the station platform, a headcount revealed several missing individuals.
Among the missing was Passepartout, the courageous Frenchman whose actions had resulted in their rescue.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The train, now detached from the engine, remained a little behind, whilst the locomotive rushed forward with increased speed.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But when the passengers counted each other on the station platform several were found missing; among others the courageous Frenchman, whose devotion had just saved them.

events.text_segment:
The train, now detached from the engine, remained a little behind, whilst the locomotive rushed forward with increased speed.
Carried on by the force already acquired, the train still moved for several minutes; but the brakes were worked and at last they stopped, less than a hundred feet from Kearney station.
The soldiers of the fort, attracted by the shots, hurried up; the Sioux had not expected them, and decamped in a body before the train entirely stopped.
But when the passengers counted each other on the station platform several were found missing; among others the courageous Frenchman, whose devotion had just saved them.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The train, now detached from the engine, remained a little behind, whilst the locomotive rushed forward with increased speed. Its momentum, however, was sufficient to carry it on for some hundreds of feet further. The detached cars had brakes, which were instantly worked, and the train was stopped not more than a hundred feet from the station. Almost at the same moment a troop of soldiers, attracted by the firing, hurried up from the fort. The Sioux had not expected this reinforcement, and fled in a body before the train had quite reached the station. When the passengers were able to come to a stand-still, several were found to be missing; and among the rest the courageous Frenchman to whom they owed their safety.

This audacious maneuver, proposed by the quick-witted Passepartout, was a desperate gamble to test the integrity of the suspended bridge over the precipice before risking the entire company. The engineer, though hesitant, ultimately yielded to the urgent necessity and Phileas Fogg's calm assurance. With a final whistle, the iron horse leaped onto the fragile structure, its wheels biting into the wooden planks. The watchers held their breath, straining their eyes as the engine roared across the chasm, a race against collapse.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXX. IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG SIMPLY DOES HIS DUTY

events.title: Aftermath of the Sioux Attack and Fogg's Resolve
detailed_summary: Three individuals, including Passepartout, were unaccounted for following the Sioux attack, their fate unknown.
Numerous passengers were wounded, with Colonel Proctor suffering a serious injury after fighting valiantly.
The injured were transported to the station for medical care.
Aouda remained unharmed, and Phileas Fogg, despite being in the center of the conflict, was unscathed. Fix had a minor arm wound.
Passepartout's absence deeply distressed Aouda.
Passengers exited the blood-stained train, witnessing gruesome remnants of the battle and observing the retreating Sioux in the distance.
Phileas Fogg stood silently, contemplating a significant choice.
Aouda observed him wordlessly, conveying her unspoken plea for Passepartout's rescue.
Fogg understood her concern regarding his imprisoned servant and the necessity of risking everything for him.
He firmly declared to Aouda his intention to find Passepartout, whether alive or deceased.
Aouda emotionally expressed her gratitude, clutching his hands.
Fogg emphasized the urgency, stating they must act immediately to find Passepartout alive.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Three passengers including Passepartout had disappeared.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Living,” added Mr. Fogg, “if we do not lose a moment.”

events.text_segment:
Three passengers including Passepartout had disappeared. Had they been killed in the struggle? Were they taken prisoners by the Sioux? It was impossible to tell.
There were many wounded, but none mortally. Colonel Proctor was one of the most seriously hurt; he had fought bravely, and a ball had entered his groin. He was carried into the station with the other wounded passengers, to receive such attention as could be of avail.
Aouda was safe; and Phileas Fogg, who had been in the thickest of the fight, had not received a scratch. Fix was slightly wounded in the arm. But Passepartout was not to be found, and tears coursed down Aouda’s cheeks.
All the passengers had got out of the train, the wheels of which were stained with blood. From the tyres and spokes hung ragged pieces of flesh. As far as the eye could reach on the white plain behind, red trails were visible. The last Sioux were disappearing in the south, along the banks of Republican River.
Mr. Fogg, with folded arms, remained motionless. He had a serious decision to make. Aouda, standing near him, looked at him without speaking, and he understood her look. If his servant was a prisoner, ought he not to risk everything to rescue him from the Indians? “I will find him, living or dead,” said he quietly to Aouda.
“Ah, Mr.—Mr. Fogg!” cried she, clasping his hands and covering them with tears.
“Living,” added Mr. Fogg, “if we do not lose a moment.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Three passengers including Passepartout had disappeared. Were they prisoners or dead? It was not yet known. Several passengers were wounded, amongst them Colonel Proctor, who had fought valiantly, and received a severe injury in the shoulder. There was no doubt that if the Sioux had not been checked, the train, with the greater portion of the travellers, would have been carried off and massacred. Colonel Proctor’s wound was carefully dressed and he was placed in the waiting-room of the station. Aouda was safe, and, in spite of the emotions she had suffered, had sustained the daring assault with a heroism which was admirable. Phileas Fogg had not betrayed the least emotion. He was there, outwardly calm, stimulating the agents of the company, and lending a hand to the wounded. Fix was by his side, and assisted him in his efforts. He had had a narrow escape, having been slightly wounded in the arm. But Passepartout was not there. Passepartout was not to be seen. Passepartout was not among the wounded. Passepartout was not in the waiting-room. Passepartout was not in the station. Passepartout, the poor fellow, whom Fogg had thought so little about, was, however, the subject of the keenest anxiety to the detective. But Aouda did not betray the least discomfiture. "Where is Passepartout?" asked Fogg. "We must find him," replied Aouda, her eyes fixed upon his. And Phileas Fogg, without a word, darted from the station. He was accompanied by half a dozen passengers, and set out upon the track of the Sioux. He knew that it would be a dangerous undertaking, but he did not hesitate. "We must find Passepartout," repeated Aouda, taking his hand. "We will find him," replied Fogg. "Alive or dead," he added, with a solemnity which made Aouda shudder. "We must be quick," said Fogg. "The trail is fresh. We must find him before the Sioux reach their hiding-place."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Three passengers including Passepartout had disappeared. Aboard the steamer Carnatic, which had just sailed from Yokohama for San Francisco, the loyal valet was nowhere to be found. This alarming absence created a ripple of concern, particularly for the stoic Phileas Fogg, though he showed little outward sign of distress. Passepartout, after a night spent rather indiscreetly involved with a troupe of Japanese acrobats, known as the Long Noses, whose human pyramid he had unfortunately joined, had completely lost track of the sailing schedule. He had missed the Carnatic's departure by a matter of minutes, a catastrophic oversight that left him utterly stranded in a foreign port, without funds or any means of contacting his master. His heart sank as the grim reality of his predicament settled upon him. He had failed Mr. Fogg in spectacular fashion, potentially jeopardizing the entire extraordinary race against time around the world. Meanwhile, Phileas Fogg and Aouda, after a brief inquiry, had proceeded with the voyage as planned. With characteristic resolve, Fogg trusted in Passepartout's resourcefulness and assumed their servant would manage to make his way to America and rejoin them there. Little did they know, Passepartout was in utter despair, wandering the unfamiliar streets of Yokohama, contemplating his bleak fate. He had even signed on with the acrobatic troupe for a meagre wage just to survive. It was by a stroke of incredible luck, during a public performance at a tea-house, that Fogg and Aouda unexpectedly stumbled upon the troupe and recognized their lost valet amidst the performers. The reunion was marked by immense relief, a brief moment of emotional release amidst their otherwise relentless dash across the globe. Passepartout was safe, but valuable time and resources had been consumed by this delay, adding yet another significant complication to their audacious gamble. The eighty-day clock continued its inexorable tick-tock, every second now more critical than ever.

events.title: Organizing the Rescue Mission
detailed_summary: Fogg's decision to rescue Passepartout meant sacrificing his journey and likely losing his wager due to the unavoidable delay.
Despite the personal cost, Fogg felt it was his duty and did not waver.
The commander of Fort Kearney was present with a hundred soldiers prepared to defend the station.
Fogg informed the captain about the three missing passengers, unsure if they were dead or captured.
He asked if the captain planned to pursue the Sioux.
The captain hesitated, citing the risk of the Sioux retreating far beyond reach and the need to protect the fort.
Fogg pressed the issue, emphasizing the importance of the three missing lives.
The captain questioned the wisdom of risking fifty soldiers to save three.
Fogg countered that while he couldn't dictate the captain's decision, he believed it was the right thing to do.
The captain asserted his authority, stating no one could tell him his duty.
Fogg coolly declared he would pursue the Sioux alone.
Fix, surprised, questioned Fogg's intention to go alone.
Fogg argued he couldn't abandon Passepartout, to whom everyone owed their lives.
Moved by Fogg's bravery, the captain changed his mind and called for thirty volunteers.
The entire company stepped forward, and the captain selected thirty men led by an old sergeant.
Fogg thanked the captain.
Fix asked to join the rescue party.
Fogg permitted him but requested, as a favor, that Fix stay with Aouda in case anything happened to him.
The detective turned pale at the thought of being separated from Fogg and leaving him to venture into the wilderness.
Fix observed Fogg closely and, despite his internal conflict and suspicions, felt compelled by Fogg's calm demeanor to agree.
He promised to stay.
Fogg briefly took Aouda's hand, entrusted his valuable carpet-bag to her, and departed with the sergeant and soldiers.
Before leaving, he offered the soldiers a $5,000 reward if the prisoners were saved.
The rescue party departed shortly after midday.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Phileas Fogg, by this resolution, inevitably sacrificed himself; he pronounced his own doom.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was then a little past noon.

events.text_segment:
Phileas Fogg, by this resolution, inevitably sacrificed himself; he pronounced his own doom. The delay of a single day would make him lose the steamer at New York, and his bet would be certainly lost. But as he thought, “It is my duty,” he did not hesitate.
The commanding officer of Fort Kearney was there. A hundred of his soldiers had placed themselves in a position to defend the station, should the Sioux attack it.
“Sir,” said Mr. Fogg to the captain, “three passengers have disappeared.”
“Dead?” asked the captain.
“Dead or prisoners; that is the uncertainty which must be solved. Do you propose to pursue the Sioux?”
“That’s a serious thing to do, sir,” returned the captain. “These Indians may retreat beyond the Arkansas, and I cannot leave the fort unprotected.”
“The lives of three men are in question, sir,” said Phileas Fogg.
“Doubtless; but can I risk the lives of fifty men to save three?”
“I don’t know whether you can, sir; but you ought to do so.”
“Nobody here,” returned the other, “has a right to teach me my duty.”
“Very well,” said Mr. Fogg, coldly. “I will go alone.”
“You, sir!” cried Fix, coming up; “you go alone in pursuit of the Indians?”
“Would you have me leave this poor fellow to perish—him to whom every one present owes his life? I shall go.”
“No, sir, you shall not go alone,” cried the captain, touched in spite of himself. “No! you are a brave man. Thirty volunteers!” he added, turning to the soldiers.
The whole company started forward at once. The captain had only to pick his men. Thirty were chosen, and an old sergeant placed at their head.
“Thanks, captain,” said Mr. Fogg.
“Will you let me go with you?” asked Fix.
“Do as you please, sir. But if you wish to do me a favour, you will remain with Aouda. In case anything should happen to me—”
A sudden pallor overspread the detective’s face. Separate himself from the man whom he had so persistently followed step by step! Leave him to wander about in this desert! Fix gazed attentively at Mr. Fogg, and, despite his suspicions and of the struggle which was going on within him, he lowered his eyes before that calm and frank look.
“I will stay,” said he.
A few moments after, Mr. Fogg pressed the young woman’s hand, and, having confided to her his precious carpet-bag, went off with the sergeant and his little squad. But, before going, he had said to the soldiers, “My friends, I will divide five thousand dollars among you, if we save the prisoners.”
It was then a little past noon.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Phileas Fogg, by this resolution, inevitably sacrificed himself; he pronounced his own doom. An unavoidable delay would render his arrival at London impossible, and as a consequence, he would lose the wager. But he did not hesitate. He had given his word, and he must keep it. And, besides, his duty was plain. He was not a man to abandon to their fate either his servant, after he had rendered him so much service, or the Sioux, who had risked their lives for him.
The commanding officer of Fort Kearney was then present with about a hundred soldiers. They were prepared for an attack, and were not to be surprised. The Sioux could not get possession of the station, yet they might besiege it.
Upon Fogg’s making known the situation of affairs, the commander, Captain Murcheson, could not conceal his surprise. “Three passengers missing? You don’t say so?” he cried. “Neither dead nor prisoners, perhaps?”
“Neither dead nor prisoners,” replied Fogg, “but captives, carried off by the Sioux.”
“And do you propose to pursue this band?”
“I do.”
“Ah! that’s a bold thing.”
“Not at all. The Indians are allies of the Americans, and are not supposed to be at war with them.”
“Ah! but these are brigands, Mr. Fogg, and Sioux brigands are not to be trifled with. Besides, are you sure it was the Sioux of the Salt Lake?”
“No; but I presume so.”
“The Salt Lake Indians are terrible fellows, and to pursue them is a very dangerous undertaking. Are you sure that your men are not prisoners killed by the Indians?”
“Not quite sure; but I hope they were captured alive. My servant, at least, had not time to be killed.”
“There is no doubt that the engine and cars were pillaged,” added Captain Murcheson. “But the train is of little importance compared with the lives of three human beings. Do you think, Captain, that we have any hope of rescuing them?”
“That is difficult to determine.”
“But the lives of three men are at stake, Captain.”
“Doubtless; but can I risk the lives of fifty soldiers to save three?”
“I do not ask you to do that, Captain; but I think that we may attempt a rescue without risking too much.”
“Mr. Fogg,” said the captain, “no one can command me.”
“I know that, Captain, but I ask you, as a man of humanity, to help me.”
“You want to go alone?”
“Yes, alone with a dozen men.”
“Ah! that’s better,” said the captain; “but even a dozen men are not to be risked lightly.”
“I will go alone, then,” said Fogg, coolly.
“Go alone!” cried Fix, in astonishment. “Mr. Fogg, you cannot think of it!”
“I must think of it,” replied Fogg, quietly. “I cannot abandon my servant, who saved my life.”
“But,” said the captain, “you have a wife with you, and she cannot be left unprotected.”
“My wife will remain here, under your protection, Captain.”
“Ah! that’s all very well,” said the captain; “but if you fall into the hands of the Sioux, what will become of her?”
“I shall not fall into the hands of the Sioux,” said Fogg, in the same even tone.
“And I may add,” said Fix, “that if Mr. Fogg fails, I will follow the Sioux, and will not give them a moment’s rest until I have rescued the prisoners.”
“Gentlemen,” said the captain, after a moment’s silence, “I see that you are brave men. I will not say that I will not help you; but I must act according to my orders. I cannot leave the fort without a sufficient garrison.”
“I understand that, Captain; but could you not give me a dozen volunteers?”
“I can give you thirty volunteers,” said the captain; “and I will accompany you myself.”
“Captain, I thank you,” said Fogg, simply.
The captain then called for volunteers, and the entire company stepped forward. From them he chose thirty of the bravest, including a sergeant who was well acquainted with the country. “Here are your men, Mr. Fogg,” said the captain.
“Thank you, Captain,” said Fogg. “And now, gentlemen, I have a word to say to you. You are going to brave great danger, and I think it is only fair that you should be rewarded for your courage and devotion. If we succeed in rescuing the prisoners, I will give each of you five thousand dollars.”
A thrill ran through the ranks of the soldiers. Five thousand dollars! It was a fortune to them. They would have faced the whole Sioux nation for such a sum.
“And now, gentlemen,” said Fogg, turning to Fix and Aouda, “we must start at once.”
“I am ready,” said Fix.
“And I,” said Aouda.
“Ah! you too, Madame?” said the captain. “You are a brave woman.”
“I must accompany Mr. Fogg,” said Aouda.
“But,” said Fogg, “it is impossible. This is a very dangerous expedition, and I cannot expose you to such a peril.”
“But I will not leave you,” said Aouda. “I will follow you wherever you go.”
“Madame,” said Fogg, with a grave air, “it is my duty to protect you. I cannot take you with me.”
“But,” said Aouda, in a pleading tone, “if you should fall into the hands of the Indians, what would become of me?”
“I have already made arrangements for that,” said Fogg. “Captain, I entrust this lady to your care. If I do not return within forty-eight hours, I beg you to conduct her to New York, and there put her in communication with the British consul.”
“I will do as you request,” said the captain. “But I hope that you will return.”
“I hope so too,” said Fogg, quietly. “And now, gentlemen, let us start.”
Before leaving, Fogg took Aouda’s hand. “My dear Aouda,” he said, “if I do not return, you will be quite alone in the world. But you will not be in want. Here is a sum of money which will enable you to live comfortably.” He handed her a heavy carpet-bag.
“Oh! Mr. Fogg,” she cried, “you are leaving me!”
“I must go,” said Fogg, gently. “But I shall return.”
He kissed her hand, and turned to go. “And now, Fix,” he said, “you will remain here, will you not? You will watch over Madame Aouda?”
The detective turned pale. To be left behind! To be separated from the man he had followed so persistently! The thought was terrible to him. And yet, he could not refuse. Fogg’s quiet resolution overawed him. He saw that it was useless to resist.
“I will remain,” he said, in a low voice.
“Thank you,” said Fogg. “And now, Captain, we are ready.”
The captain led the way, and the little band followed. They left the fort shortly after midday.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Phileas Fogg, by this resolution, inevitably sacrificed himself; he pronounced his own doom. There seemed no other course left. The steamer Henrietta lay before them, bound for Bordeaux, not Liverpool or London. Yet, Fogg's calm, mathematical mind calculated the impossible possibility. With the coolness that had seen him through India's perils and America's trials, he approached Captain Speedy. The proposition was audacious, unheard of: charter the vessel, reroute her course towards England, regardless of her original destination or cargo. Captain Speedy, a blustering, stubborn New Englander, was apoplectic. His cargo, his contract, his reputation! He refused vehemently, cursing the Englishman's madness. But Fogg, armed with an offer that transcended mere profit, held firm. He offered not just demurrage, but a price for the ship herself, should the captain not steer her where commanded. It was a pirate's proposition, delivered with a gentleman's poise. Faced with an astronomical sum, far exceeding the Henrietta's value, Speedy's resistance crumbled, though not without a torrent of oaths. The transformation of the transatlantic steamer into a private yacht was swift. Sailors accustomed to a southern route found themselves steering northeast, battling the fierce December gales of the North Atlantic. Passepartout watched, aghast, his master's calculated recklessness surpassing any previous exploit. He saw the mountainous waves, felt the ship groan under the tempest's lash, and knew that this final desperate gamble held more peril than all the preceding adventures combined. Detective Fix, ever present, albeit now sidelined by the sheer absurdity of the situation, could only observe. His warrant was useless here, miles from land, trapped on a vessel controlled by the very man he sought to arrest. The race was now against nature herself. The Henrietta, though stout, was not built for this speed, this relentless push through mountainous seas. Coal reserves dwindled rapidly, consumed by the engines driven to their maximum. Each ton burned represented not just fuel, but minutes, hours, dwindling chances of reaching London by eight forty-five on the evening of December 21st. Fogg, seemingly impervious to the storm or the stakes, remained in the saloon, consulting his charts, tracking their progress with unwavering precision. He was betting his entire fortune, his very existence, on a ship, a crew, and the unpredictable fury of the sea. This final leg was the most desperate, the most dangerous. It was a leap into the abyss, with only eighty days as his parachute, and that parachute was rapidly fraying. Every creak of the ship, every gust of wind, every crashing wave was a reminder of the immense, almost certainly fatal, risk he had taken. He had crossed continents and oceans, outwitted pursuers, and overcome obstacles, but the final enemy was time, and it was relentless, its lead seemingly insurmountable.

events.title: Aouda's Worry and Fix's Inner Turmoil
detailed_summary: Aouda waited by herself in a room, reflecting on Fogg's selfless generosity and calm bravery.
She recognized he had risked his fortune and now his life out of duty, without hesitation or outward display.
Fix experienced different emotions, struggling to hide his agitation.
He paced anxiously before regaining his composure.
He realized his mistake in allowing Fogg to leave alone, permitting the man he tracked globally to separate from him.
Fix reproached himself harshly for his lapse in judgment, feeling foolish.
He berated himself, convinced Fogg wouldn't return and questioning how he, holding an arrest warrant, had become so influenced by Fogg.
As time passed slowly, Fix felt lost.
He considered revealing everything to Aouda but anticipated her likely negative reaction.
He contemplated pursuing Fogg across the plains, noting that footprints were initially visible in the snow but would soon be erased by fresh snowfall.
Discouragement set in, and Fix felt an overwhelming urge to abandon his pursuit entirely.
He recognized he could simply leave the station and return home.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Aouda retired to a waiting-room, and there she waited alone, thinking of the simple and noble generosity, the tranquil courage of Phileas Fogg.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He could now leave Fort Kearney station, and pursue his journey homeward in peace.

events.text_segment:
Aouda retired to a waiting-room, and there she waited alone, thinking of the simple and noble generosity, the tranquil courage of Phileas Fogg. He had sacrificed his fortune, and was now risking his life, all without hesitation, from duty, in silence.
Fix did not have the same thoughts, and could scarcely conceal his agitation. He walked feverishly up and down the platform, but soon resumed his outward composure. He now saw the folly of which he had been guilty in letting Fogg go alone. What! This man, whom he had just followed around the world, was permitted now to separate himself from him! He began to accuse and abuse himself, and, as if he were director of police, administered to himself a sound lecture for his greenness.
“I have been an idiot!” he thought, “and this man will see it. He has gone, and won’t come back! But how is it that I, Fix, who have in my pocket a warrant for his arrest, have been so fascinated by him? Decidedly, I am nothing but an ass!”
So reasoned the detective, while the hours crept by all too slowly. He did not know what to do. Sometimes he was tempted to tell Aouda all; but he could not doubt how the young woman would receive his confidences. What course should he take? He thought of pursuing Fogg across the vast white plains; it did not seem impossible that he might overtake him. Footsteps were easily printed on the snow! But soon, under a new sheet, every imprint would be effaced.
Fix became discouraged. He felt a sort of insurmountable longing to abandon the game altogether. He could now leave Fort Kearney station, and pursue his journey homeward in peace.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Aouda retired to a waiting-room, and there she waited alone, thinking of the simple and noble generosity, the tranquil courage of Phileas Fogg. He had sacrificed his fortune, and was now risking his life, all without hesitation, from duty, and without boasting of it; and she was filled with admiration for this man in whom she discerned, beneath this cold exterior, a noble soul and a warm heart. During this time, Fix was going back and forth in the hall, quite as agitated as Aouda, though under different emotions. He could not make up his mind to leave the station. He felt that Fogg was gone, and that he had allowed him to go. He had failed to do his duty, and he reproached himself bitterly. He had tracked this man around the world, and now, by his own fault, he had lost him. He was ready to tear his hair out with vexation. "Fool that I was!" he muttered. "How could I have let him go? I had him, and I let him slip through my fingers! And now he is gone, and I shall never see him again! He will not come back, of course not. And what am I to do? I have the warrant in my pocket, and I must arrest him. But how? He is gone! How is it that I, who have been following him for so long, have become so interested in him, so captivated by his sangfroid, by his courage? Why did I not arrest him at Bombay? At Calcutta? At Hong Kong? At New York? I could have done it, and I should have done it. But no, I waited, I hesitated. And now it is too late!" As the minutes passed slowly, Fix felt more and more lost. He thought of telling Aouda everything, but he knew that she would not listen to him, that she would despise him. He thought of following Fogg across the plains, but he knew that it was useless, that the footprints would soon be effaced by the snow, which was still falling heavily. Discouragement seized him. He felt an irresistible desire to abandon everything, to go back to England, to give up the pursuit. He could do it, he had only to leave the station, and in a few hours he would be far away, and no one would ever know that he had failed.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Aouda retired to a waiting-room, and there she waited alone, thinking of the simple and noble generosity, the tranquil courage of Phileas Fogg. She reflected on the many dangers they had faced together, from the jungles of India to the prairies of America, and how Mr. Fogg had navigated every crisis with a coolness that defied comprehension. He never showed fear, never complained, always focused on the solution, on the next step of the impossible journey. His logic was flawless, his composure absolute. It was not the courage of a man who was unaware of peril, but that of one who had complete control over his emotions, who saw the path forward where others saw only despair. She owed him everything. He had saved her life, given her sanctuary, and treated her with a respect and dignity she had almost forgotten existed. Unlike the men of her past, Fogg sought nothing from her; his actions were purely altruistic, driven by a peculiar, yet profound, sense of duty. He was an island of serene strength in a world of chaos and uncertainty, a true gentleman in every sense of the word. His precision, his famous punctuality, were merely outward signs of an inner discipline that governed his every move. As she sat there, the minutes ticking by, Aouda felt a warmth bloom in her chest, a feeling that transcended gratitude. It was an admiration so deep it bordered on reverence, a growing affection for this extraordinary man who had appeared like a benevolent spirit to snatch her from the jaws of death and carry her across the world on his incredible, impossible quest.

events.title: Unexpected Return of the Detached Locomotive
detailed_summary: Around 2 PM, amidst heavy snowfall, approaching whistles were heard from the east.
A large, shadowy form with a bright light appeared through the mist, looking fantastical.
No train was scheduled from the east, nor had the requested relief arrived; the next scheduled train wasn't due until the following day.
The mystery was resolved as the approaching locomotive was identified.
It was the engine that had become detached from the train and sped away rapidly with the unconscious engineer and stoker.
It had traveled several miles before slowing and stopping about twenty miles past Fort Kearney as its fire died down.
The engineer and stoker eventually regained consciousness.
Finding himself in the desert with only the locomotive, the engineer understood the train had been left behind.
He guessed the train was in trouble, though unsure how the separation occurred.
He decided against continuing to Omaha, deeming it safer to return despite the risk of encountering Indians.
He rebuilt the fire, raised steam pressure, and drove the locomotive in reverse back towards Fort Kearney.
This returning locomotive was the source of the whistling heard through the mist.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Towards two o’clock in the afternoon, while it was snowing hard, long whistles were heard approaching from the east.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: This it was which was whistling in the mist.

events.text_segment:
Towards two o’clock in the afternoon, while it was snowing hard, long whistles were heard approaching from the east. A great shadow, preceded by a wild light, slowly advanced, appearing still larger through the mist, which gave it a fantastic aspect. No train was expected from the east, neither had there been time for the succour asked for by telegraph to arrive; the train from Omaha to San Francisco was not due till the next day. The mystery was soon explained.
The locomotive, which was slowly approaching with deafening whistles, was that which, having been detached from the train, had continued its route with such terrific rapidity, carrying off the unconscious engineer and stoker. It had run several miles, when, the fire becoming low for want of fuel, the steam had slackened; and it had finally stopped an hour after, some twenty miles beyond Fort Kearney. Neither the engineer nor the stoker was dead, and, after remaining for some time in their swoon, had come to themselves. The train had then stopped. The engineer, when he found himself in the desert, and the locomotive without cars, understood what had happened. He could not imagine how the locomotive had become separated from the train; but he did not doubt that the train left behind was in distress.
He did not hesitate what to do. It would be prudent to continue on to Omaha, for it would be dangerous to return to the train, which the Indians might still be engaged in pillaging. Nevertheless, he began to rebuild the fire in the furnace; the pressure again mounted, and the locomotive returned, running backwards to Fort Kearney. This it was which was whistling in the mist.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Towards two o’clock in the afternoon, while it was snowing hard, long whistles were heard approaching from the east. A large, shadowy form, preceded by a glaring light, loomed in the mist, and advanced rapidly. It was an engine, which was coming towards them backwards with great speed. No train was expected from the east, neither had any relief train been called for. The mystery was soon solved. The engine which had been so heroically detached from the train, and which had sped on alone, returned upon the track. It had run several miles beyond Fort Kearney, when, the fire having died down, the steam had slackened, and it had finally stopped about twenty miles past the station. The engineer and stoker, who were both insensible, were not on board when the engine stopped. They had been thrown off when the engine was detached. They recovered consciousness, however, and the engineer, finding himself in the desert with his engine, understood what had happened. He saw that the train, doubtless, was in peril, and set himself to the task of returning to it. Not knowing but that the Indians might still be at the station, he did not dare approach it; but, making a circuit, and running around it, he re-entered the railway a few miles farther on to the east. It was this engine, running backwards at full speed, which was the cause of the whistling heard through the mist.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Towards two o’clock in the afternoon, while it was snowing hard, long whistles were heard approaching from the east. It was the train. Phileas Fogg and Sir Francis Cromarty, who had been playing whist in the car, heard the puffing engine stop, and saw the conductor put his head in and exclaim, "Charleston!" This was the Charleston station. Passepartout sprang off the train, followed by Fix. Mr. Fogg descended from the railway-car, and accompanied by Passepartout and Fix, directed his steps towards the custom-house. Charleston is a city of eighty-five thousand inhabitants, and is favourably situated; though we will not dwell upon its merits. Mr. Fogg was not one of those travellers who linger on their way. To get to the steamer, he had to pass along a circuitous, and rather complicated street; and he was not without his trouble in finding it. His knowledge of this American city was not over-precise; and the streets, as well as the trains, in the United States, are laid out with mathematical precision, in a manner very different from the tortuous and, as it may be called, fantastic curves of European cities. Mr. Fogg, after crossing the city, found himself upon a pier, where the "Rangoon"—a steamer of the Peninsular Company, built of iron and with a screw—was getting up steam.

events.title: Train Departs, Leaving Aouda and Fix Behind
detailed_summary: The waiting travelers were relieved as the locomotive reconnected with the train, allowing the journey to resume.
Aouda rushed out and asked the conductor if the train was leaving immediately.
The conductor confirmed its imminent departure.
Aouda inquired about the missing prisoners.
The conductor stated he couldn't delay the trip further, as they were already three hours behind schedule.
Aouda asked about the next train from San Francisco, learning it wouldn't arrive until the following evening.
She protested that this would be too late and they should wait.
The conductor declared waiting impossible and told her to board if she wished to travel.
Aouda resolutely refused to leave.
Fix overheard this exchange. Having previously considered leaving, the train's readiness now created an internal conflict.
He felt unable to board the train, rooted to the platform by an irresistible force.
His mental struggle resumed, filled with anger and a sense of failure, yet he felt compelled to see things through.
Meanwhile, other passengers, including the seriously injured Colonel Proctor, boarded the train.
The sound of the boiler and escaping steam signaled departure.
The engineer blew the whistle, and the train departed, its smoke blending with the falling snow.
Fix did not board the train and stayed at the station.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The travellers were glad to see the locomotive resume its place at the head of the train.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The detective had remained behind.

events.text_segment:
The travellers were glad to see the locomotive resume its place at the head of the train. They could now continue the journey so terribly interrupted.
Aouda, on seeing the locomotive come up, hurried out of the station, and asked the conductor, “Are you going to start?”
“At once, madam.”
“But the prisoners, our unfortunate fellow-travellers—”
“I cannot interrupt the trip,” replied the conductor. “We are already three hours behind time.”
“And when will another train pass here from San Francisco?”
“To-morrow evening, madam.”
“To-morrow evening! But then it will be too late! We must wait—”
“It is impossible,” responded the conductor. “If you wish to go, please get in.”
“I will not go,” said Aouda.
Fix had heard this conversation. A little while before, when there was no prospect of proceeding on the journey, he had made up his mind to leave Fort Kearney; but now that the train was there, ready to start, and he had only to take his seat in the car, an irresistible influence held him back. The station platform burned his feet, and he could not stir. The conflict in his mind again began; anger and failure stifled him. He wished to struggle on to the end.
Meanwhile the passengers and some of the wounded, among them Colonel Proctor, whose injuries were serious, had taken their places in the train. The buzzing of the over-heated boiler was heard, and the steam was escaping from the valves. The engineer whistled, the train started, and soon disappeared, mingling its white smoke with the eddies of the densely falling snow.
The detective had remained behind.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The travellers were glad to see the locomotive resume its place at the head of the train. They were now only three hours behind time. Aouda, with her carpet-bag, and Fix, with his portmanteau, were ready to take their places in the car when the conductor called out, "Passengers for the Union Pacific Railroad!" Aouda rushed up and asked, "Are you going to leave immediately?" "Immediately." "And you are not going to wait for the prisoners?" "The prisoners?" replied the conductor. "Nobody has spoken to me of any prisoners. We have three hours' delay already." "And when would be the next train from San Francisco?" "To-morrow evening." "To-morrow evening! But that would be too late! You must wait-" "It is impossible. Madame, please to get in if you are going." "I shall not go," said Aouda. Fix had heard all this. A moment before, when the train was ready to start, he had decided to leave the detested place, and had resumed his old habits as a detective. He felt a sudden accession of energy, the detective returned to him. "I will follow them!" he said, with an irresistible impulse. And he remained on the platform, while Aouda stationed herself in the waiting-room. Colonel Proctor, who was on the point of starting, at this moment perceived Aouda. "You are not going, then, Madame?" he asked. "I am not going," she replied. "Neither am I; I am going to remain with you. They can't carry on a fight without me," said the Colonel. He would no doubt have passed the night at the station, but for a peremptory intervention. The conductor, not satisfied with the answer he had received, came up to Aouda, and said, "This is the second call, Madame; the train is going to start." "I am not going," replied Aouda. "Nor I either," said Fix, who had now approached. "Passengers, forward!" cried the conductor. The locomotive whistled, and the train was off. The snow was still falling, and the vapour from the locomotive, mixing with it, formed around the train a cloud of mist. Fix remained motionless on the platform, and Aouda, her hand pressed upon her heart, had sunk upon a bench in the waiting-room.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The travellers were glad to see the locomotive resume its place at the head of the train. It meant their journey across India was back on track after the unexpected delay. The iron horse snorted, its mighty wheels beginning to turn slowly, gathering speed as it left Allahabad behind. The landscape outside the carriage windows transformed rapidly, shifting from cultivated plains to dense jungles teeming with unseen life. Fogg remained impassive, consulting his timetable with his usual precision, while Passepartout pressed his face against the glass, marveling at the exotic sights. Sir Francis Cromarty, sharing their compartment, offered insights into the country they traversed. Hours passed swiftly, the rhythm of the train a constant companion. However, the smooth progress was not destined to last. As they approached Kholby, the conductor announced, much to their dismay, that the railway line abruptly ended there. Construction was incomplete, leaving a fifty-mile gap before the line resumed at Allahabad. This news was a severe blow to Fogg's meticulously planned itinerary. Passepartout groaned, fearing yet another significant delay. Sir Francis, though surprised, took it in stride, explaining that such interruptions, while frustrating, were not entirely uncommon in the vast, rapidly developing country. Fogg, characteristically, did not waste time in complaint. His mind immediately shifted to finding an alternative means of transport to bridge the gap. The eighty-day clock was ticking relentlessly.

events.title: Anxious Night Vigil at Fort Kearney
detailed_summary: Hours went by under dismal, very cold weather conditions.
Fix remained seated and motionless on a station bench, appearing almost asleep.
Aouda, braving the storm, repeatedly left the waiting-room to scan the snowy landscape from the platform's edge.
She strained to see through the mist and listen for any hopeful sound, but found nothing.
Each time, she returned inside, chilled, only to venture out again shortly after, always without success.
Evening arrived, but the rescue party led by Fogg had not returned.
Concerns grew about their whereabouts: Had they encountered the Sioux? Were they lost in the mist?
The fort's commander was worried but attempted to mask his anxiety.
As night deepened, the snowfall lessened, but the cold intensified dramatically.
An absolute silence settled over the plains, unbroken by wildlife.
Throughout the night, Aouda wandered near the plains, filled with dread and imagining countless dangers.
Her suffering during these long hours was immense.
Fix stayed in the same spot, awake but unresponsive.
When a man approached and spoke to him, Fix only shook his head.
The night continued in this state of anxious waiting.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Several hours passed.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Thus the night passed.

events.text_segment:
Several hours passed. The weather was dismal, and it was very cold. Fix sat motionless on a bench in the station; he might have been thought asleep. Aouda, despite the storm, kept coming out of the waiting-room, going to the end of the platform, and peering through the tempest of snow, as if to pierce the mist which narrowed the horizon around her, and to hear, if possible, some welcome sound. She heard and saw nothing. Then she would return, chilled through, to issue out again after the lapse of a few moments, but always in vain.
Evening came, and the little band had not returned. Where could they be? Had they found the Indians, and were they having a conflict with them, or were they still wandering amid the mist? The commander of the fort was anxious, though he tried to conceal his apprehensions. As night approached, the snow fell less plentifully, but it became intensely cold. Absolute silence rested on the plains. Neither flight of bird nor passing of beast troubled the perfect calm.
Throughout the night Aouda, full of sad forebodings, her heart stifled with anguish, wandered about on the verge of the plains. Her imagination carried her far off, and showed her innumerable dangers. What she suffered through the long hours it would be impossible to describe.
Fix remained stationary in the same place, but did not sleep. Once a man approached and spoke to him, and the detective merely replied by shaking his head.
Thus the night passed.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Several hours passed. The weather was dismal and the cold extreme. Fix remained seated on a bench in the station, not moving, and to all appearance asleep. Aouda, braving the storm, and deeply anxious, went repeatedly to the end of the platform, and peered out into the dense mist and snow. She listened, but heard nothing; she returned to the waiting-room, chilled through, but with her energy unabated. Her suspense was unbearable. If Phileas Fogg had only planned the expedition, so many precious moments would not have been lost! Had he found the Sioux? Had he been able to purchase Mr. Passepartout's life? As the hours rolled on, the commander of the fort grew anxious. He sent out several scouts to the south-east, the direction in which Fogg and the soldiers had gone. But they returned without having discovered any trace of the party. Night came on, and the snow fell less plentifully, but the cold was more intense. An absolute silence reigned over the plains. No sound, not even the wild cry of a bird, disturbed the solemn stillness. Aouda, walking to and fro before the station, and peering out into the darkness, was filled with vague dreads. She suffered everything that could be endured by an imaginative nature. Fix remained in the same position, internally fuming, but impassive without. A man accosted him, and spoke to him, but the detective only shook his head and declined to reply. During the night, the cold increased so much that Fahrenheit fell to below zero. The ravens themselves would have deserted the plains. Anxious thoughts assailed Aouda, and her heart was full of sinister forebodings.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_5.text: Several hours passed. The weather was dismal and the cold extreme. Fix remained seated on a bench in the station, not moving, and to all appearance asleep. Aouda, braving the storm, came out of the waiting-room, and went repeatedly to the end of the platform, and peered out into the dense mist and snow. The horizon was narrowed by the mist. She listened for some sound, but heard nothing; she returned to the waiting-room, chilled through, waited a few moments, and then ventured out again, always in vain. Evening came, and the little band had not returned. Where were they? Had they met the Indians? Were they lost in the mist? The commander of the fort was uneasy, but he tried to conceal his apprehensions. As night deepened, the snow fell less plentifully, but the cold became intense. An absolute silence rested on the plains. No sound, not even the flight of a bird or the passing of a beast, disturbed the solemn stillness. Aouda, wandering on the verge of the plains throughout the night, her heart stifled with anguish, her imagination showed her innumerable dangers. Her imagination carried her far off. It is impossible to describe what Aouda suffered during these long hours. Fix remained in the same position, awake, but not sleeping. A man accosted him, and spoke to him, but the detective only shook his head. Thus the night passed.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Several hours passed. The rhythmic sway of Kiouni, the magnificent hired elephant, became a monotonous lullaby under the relentless Indian sun. Phileas Fogg sat upright in the howdah, his face as impassive as ever, consulting his watch and map with quiet determination. His precise movements contrasted sharply with the slow, deliberate plodding of their mount. Beside him, Passepartout, though initially charmed by the novelty of elephant travel, was finding the pace agonizingly slow compared to the express trains they had abandoned. The jungle pressed in on either side, a dense, emerald wall alive with the chirping of unseen insects and the occasional cry of a monkey. Their guide, a seasoned Parsee named Jejeeh, led the way with quiet confidence, navigating paths that were little more than ancient animal trails. They had left the unfinished railway section far behind, the abrupt end of modern transport replaced by this ancient, slow-moving beast. Each hour that ticked by was precious time slipping away from Fogg's strict schedule, a fact that gnawed at Passepartout, who fidgeted and glanced nervously at the lowering sun. Would they reach Allahabad, their next railway connection, in time? Fogg, however, betrayed no anxiety. He had simply accepted the delay, found the most practical alternative with characteristic speed, and continued his journey with unshakeable calm, trusting in calculation rather than hope. The vast, untamed landscape unfolded around them, a testament to the distance they still had to cover. The elephant plodded onward, a small, determined speck against the immense subcontinent, carrying not just its passengers but the delicate thread of Fogg's wager and the very possibility of victory against the ticking clock.

events.title: Rescue Party Returns; Train Missed
detailed_summary: At sunrise, visibility improved, allowing objects up to two miles away to be seen.
Fogg's party had gone south, but the southern plains remained empty.
By seven o'clock, the captain, now genuinely alarmed, was unsure how to proceed.
He debated sending another rescue detachment, weighing the risk against the low chance of success.
Just as he decided and was about to order a reconnaissance mission by calling a lieutenant, gunshots were heard.
Soldiers rushed out, interpreting the shots as a possible signal.
Half a mile away, a small group was seen returning in formation.
Phileas Fogg led the group, followed closely by Passepartout and the two other travelers rescued from the Sioux.
The rescuers had engaged the Indians ten miles south of the fort.
Just before the soldiers arrived, Passepartout and his fellow captives had started fighting back; Passepartout had incapacitated three captors with his fists when Fogg and the soldiers intervened.
The returning party was met with joyful celebrations.
Fogg paid the promised reward to the soldiers.
Passepartout remarked to himself about the high cost he represented to his master.
Fix observed Fogg silently, his internal thoughts complex and hard to decipher.
Aouda, overwhelmed with emotion, took Fogg's hand and squeezed it, unable to speak.
Passepartout immediately looked for the train, expecting it to be ready for departure and hoping to make up lost time.
He cried out, asking for the train.
Fix informed him that the train had already left.
Phileas Fogg inquired about the next train.
He was told the next one wouldn't arrive until that evening.
Fogg reacted to this significant delay with his typical calm, acknowledging the fact quietly.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At dawn, the half-extinguished disc of the sun rose above a misty horizon; but it was now possible to recognise objects two miles off.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Ah!” returned the impassible gentleman quietly.

events.text_segment:
At dawn, the half-extinguished disc of the sun rose above a misty horizon; but it was now possible to recognise objects two miles off. Phileas Fogg and the squad had gone southward; in the south all was still vacancy. It was then seven o’clock.
The captain, who was really alarmed, did not know what course to take.
Should he send another detachment to the rescue of the first? Should he sacrifice more men, with so few chances of saving those already sacrificed? His hesitation did not last long, however. Calling one of his lieutenants, he was on the point of ordering a reconnaissance, when gunshots were heard. Was it a signal? The soldiers rushed out of the fort, and half a mile off they perceived a little band returning in good order.
Mr. Fogg was marching at their head, and just behind him were Passepartout and the other two travellers, rescued from the Sioux.
They had met and fought the Indians ten miles south of Fort Kearney. Shortly before the detachment arrived, Passepartout and his companions had begun to struggle with their captors, three of whom the Frenchman had felled with his fists, when his master and the soldiers hastened up to their relief.
All were welcomed with joyful cries. Phileas Fogg distributed the reward he had promised to the soldiers, while Passepartout, not without reason, muttered to himself, “It must certainly be confessed that I cost my master dear!”
Fix, without saying a word, looked at Mr. Fogg, and it would have been difficult to analyse the thoughts which struggled within him. As for Aouda, she took her protector’s hand and pressed it in her own, too much moved to speak.
Meanwhile, Passepartout was looking about for the train; he thought he should find it there, ready to start for Omaha, and he hoped that the time lost might be regained.
“The train! the train!” cried he.
“Gone,” replied Fix.
“And when does the next train pass here?” said Phileas Fogg.
“Not till this evening.”
“Ah!” returned the impassible gentleman quietly.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: At dawn, the half-extinguished disc of the sun rose above a misty horizon; but it was now possible to recognise objects two miles off. The vast plains were bare, and the forty miles the detachment had gone south were for the moment fruitless. At seven o'clock the captain, who was really disturbed, knew not what course to take. Should he send another detachment to the rescue? Should he risk other men, whom he would probably lose, without the slightest chance of saving the unfortunate captives? He wavered, unable to decide. But he at last decided to extend the search, and was about to give orders to a lieutenant, when a few shots were heard. Was it a signal? And fired by whom? The soldiers rushed out of the fort, and half a mile off descried a small body of persons returning in order. Mr. Fogg was marching at their head, and just behind him were Passepartout and the other two travellers, released from the Sioux. The detachment sent by the captain had gallantly fulfilled their task. They had come upon the Indians ten miles south, and in the nick of time. The two travellers and Passepartout had been struggling with their captors when the troops came up. The Sioux, at the moment of the attack, had seen the whole three escape, and before they had time to lay hold of them again, Fogg and his soldiers were upon them. They had fought hand to hand, a dozen against fifty; and the fifty had fled, leaving the three prisoners, and carrying off three of their number killed in the fray. Without counting the wounded, who were a great many, though they got off. Passepartout, when delivered, found his master and knelt to him; Mr. Fogg simply pressed his hand, and Aouda was there, who did the same without uttering a word. Fix was present, but could not conceal the mortification that devoured him. As for Passepartout, he was carried off by the soldiers, and passed from hand to hand, to the great delight of every one; and they asked him a thousand questions, to which he pertinently responded. He recounted his adventures in the wigwam, his fight with the Indians, and how he had been saved at the last moment; and when they spoke of Mr. Fogg, he said, "That worthy gentleman is a trump!" Aouda recognised the soldiers who had accompanied Fogg, and lavished upon them her most gracious thanks. A reward was granted them by Mr. Fogg, which they divided amongst themselves as soldiers of the same company. At half-past eight, Passepartout, wishing to make up for lost time, was anxious to set out, and thought that the train would be there, ready to start. But the train was not there. The engine and cars which had waited for them at the station were gone. Mr. Fogg quietly asked when the next train would pass the Pacific Railroad for the East. The time table stated that it would pass at six o'clock that evening. "This is twenty hours lost!" cried Passepartout, in a fury. "I did not anticipate it," said Mr. Fogg, tranquilly.
