LLM_completions.prefix-probing: At dawn, the half-extinguished disc of the sun rose above a misty horizon; but it was now possible to recognise objects two miles off. The sea was less rough, and the wind inclined to quiet down. Passepartout, who had been in a terrible stew about the ship during the past forty-eight hours, recovered some degree of cheerfulness. He now began to hope that they might reach New York in time for the steamer to Liverpool, though the wind was still dead against them. The Henrietta was a fast steamer, however, and, though she had not been able to carry full sail, she made good headway. Phileas Fogg was still as calm as ever. And as for Fix, he was becoming terribly anxious. He had put the electric telegraph in operation as soon as he reached shore, and sent a despatch to London, but as yet he had received no answer. How could he have been arrested if the warrant was not there? And might it not have reached there since he left? This thought ploughed furrow after furrow across his brow. He did not sleep; he did not eat. He was going over the voyage in his mind. They were twenty-four hours behind time, and Fix was the cause of it. How he did execrate himself! Would Fogg get away from him upon his arrival, and how? There was no Philadelphia steamer for Liverpool, neither was there a New York steamer, sailing directly for Liverpool. The steamers to France and London were the only ones which would serve him. Fix was in a most terrible state of mind. If Fogg left him, he was lost. But, supposing Fogg was not the robber, how could he have been arrested? Why should he be arrested? Fix was all at sea; he didn't know what to think. Meanwhile, Phileas Fogg, less disturbed than Fix, was watching the progress of the Henrietta. He longed to reach New York. After reaching America, he was count on two means of transit: namely, railway and packet-boat, or packet-boat and railway. Provided he could get a steamship at New York going to Liverpool, the game was not yet lost. 'Captain,' said Mr. Fogg, to Captain Speedy, 'are you going to New York?' 'Provided I can't go any farther,' replied the captain. 'And when do you expect to arrive there?'

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXXI. IN WHICH FIX, THE DETECTIVE, CONSIDERABLY FURTHERS THE INTERESTS OF PHILEAS FOGG

events.title: Fix Proposes a Sledge Solution
detailed_summary: Phileas Fogg realizes he is significantly behind schedule, causing distress to Passepartout who feels responsible.
Detective Fix approaches Fogg, confirming the critical importance of reaching New York by the evening of the 11th for the Liverpool steamer.
Fix calculates Fogg is twenty hours late due to the Indian attack, leaving only eight hours to make up.
Fix suggests a novel method to regain the lost time: travel via a sail-powered sledge, an idea proposed to him by a local man.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Phileas Fogg found himself twenty hours behind time.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was the man who had spoken to Fix during the night, and whose offer he had refused.

events.text_segment:
Phileas Fogg found himself twenty hours behind time. Passepartout, the involuntary cause of this delay, was desperate. He had ruined his master!
At this moment the detective approached Mr. Fogg, and, looking him intently in the face, said:
“Seriously, sir, are you in great haste?”
“Quite seriously.”
“I have a purpose in asking,” resumed Fix. “Is it absolutely necessary that you should be in New York on the 11th, before nine o’clock in the evening, the time that the steamer leaves for Liverpool?”
“It is absolutely necessary.”
“And, if your journey had not been interrupted by these Indians, you would have reached New York on the morning of the 11th?”
“Yes; with eleven hours to spare before the steamer left.”
“Good! you are therefore twenty hours behind. Twelve from twenty leaves eight. You must regain eight hours. Do you wish to try to do so?”
“On foot?” asked Mr. Fogg.
“No; on a sledge,” replied Fix. “On a sledge with sails. A man has proposed such a method to me.”
It was the man who had spoken to Fix during the night, and whose offer he had refused.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Phileas Fogg found himself twenty hours behind time. Passepartout was in despair. He was the cause of this loss of time. Had he not delayed the steamer, by insisting on leaving the boat, twenty hours would have been gained. This thought haunted him. Fix approached Mr. Fogg, and, without preface, said: "Sir, you are twenty hours behind time." "I know it, sir," replied Mr. Fogg, coldly. "It is in consequence of the attack by the Sioux." "Partly; but you took in the detective who pursued me. Don't try to deny it!" cried Passepartout, who was beside himself. "And what does it matter whether I did or not?" returned Mr. Fogg. "I had my reasons for doing so." "But for this," continued Passepartout, "you would have been at New York this morning." "Why, yes," said Fix, "you would have gained twenty hours." "I do not blame you, Passepartout," said Mr. Fogg; "you are not at fault." "You are generous, sir," replied Passepartout; "but I am to blame." "No doubt," resumed Fix; "and I have an idea which might enable you to make up this time." "I am listening, sir." "The railway stops at Kearney, and the trains do not run any longer on this section. It is because the railway has not been finished. There are at least fifty miles of track to be laid. There is no means of getting over this distance unless by sleighs, unless-" "Unless what?" asked Mr. Fogg, fixing his keen eye on the detective. "Unless a man," continued Fix, "a man I have met here, and who is a Canadian, proposes to take us to Omaha, a distance of fifty miles, in a sail-sledge." "A sail-sledge?" asked Mr. Fogg, not without astonishment. "Yes, a sledge rigged with sails. With a fair wind, it slides over the snow at a prodigious speed. If the ground is frozen, and the wind is strong, we might make Omaha in three hours." "And when can we start?" asked Mr. Fogg. "Immediately. The man is waiting for us." "Let us go," said Mr. Fogg to Passepartout. "But this man is a detective!" said Passepartout, pointing to Fix. "I know it," replied Phileas Fogg; "but he proposes to take us to Omaha."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Phileas Fogg found himself twenty hours behind time. This significant setback occurred after the *Rangoon*, the steamer taking them from Calcutta to Hong Kong, arrived late. Despite the potentially ruinous delay to his audacious wager, Fogg exhibited his characteristic imperturbability. His face remained calm, betraying none of the anxiety that surely gnawed at Passepartout. For his part, the poor valet was beside himself with worry. Every hour lost felt like a nail in the coffin of their ambitious journey. They had encountered unforeseen obstacles: the disrupted railway in India, the necessity of acquiring an elephant, and now this delayed steamer. Fogg, however, simply adjusted his calculations and began planning the next leg. The race was tighter than ever, but his resolve seemed only to harden. The vast Pacific lay ahead, a critical segment where speed would be paramount. Failure meant financial ruin and public humiliation, but Fogg gave no indication of wavering. He trusted in his meticulous planning and his formidable will, facing the daunting challenge with quiet, steely determination, while the clock ticked relentlessly against them.

events.title: Inspecting and Hiring the Sail-Sledge
detailed_summary: After Fix indicates the man who proposed the sledge, Fogg approaches him.
Fogg and the American, Mudge, enter a nearby hut.
Inside, Fogg inspects the vehicle: a frame on sledge runners designed for multiple passengers, equipped with a tall mast, a large brigantine sail, a jib-sail, and a rudder.
These sledges are noted for rapid winter travel across frozen plains when trains are snowbound, often matching or exceeding express train speeds.
Fogg quickly makes a deal with Mudge.
Conditions are favorable: a fresh westerly wind and hardened snow.
Mudge is confident he can reach Omaha in hours, allowing Fogg to catch eastward trains.
Fogg decides to take this chance to potentially recover the lost time.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Phileas Fogg did not reply at once; but Fix, having pointed out the man, who was walking up and down in front of the station, Mr. Fogg went up to him.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was not impossible that the lost time might yet be recovered; and such an opportunity was not to be rejected.

events.text_segment:
Phileas Fogg did not reply at once; but Fix, having pointed out the man, who was walking up and down in front of the station, Mr. Fogg went up to him. An instant after, Mr. Fogg and the American, whose name was Mudge, entered a hut built just below the fort.
There Mr. Fogg examined a curious vehicle, a kind of frame on two long beams, a little raised in front like the runners of a sledge, and upon which there was room for five or six persons. A high mast was fixed on the frame, held firmly by metallic lashings, to which was attached a large brigantine sail. This mast held an iron stay upon which to hoist a jib-sail. Behind, a sort of rudder served to guide the vehicle. It was, in short, a sledge rigged like a sloop. During the winter, when the trains are blocked up by the snow, these sledges make extremely rapid journeys across the frozen plains from one station to another. Provided with more sails than a cutter, and with the wind behind them, they slip over the surface of the prairies with a speed equal if not superior to that of the express trains.
Mr. Fogg readily made a bargain with the owner of this land-craft. The wind was favourable, being fresh, and blowing from the west. The snow had hardened, and Mudge was very confident of being able to transport Mr. Fogg in a few hours to Omaha. Thence the trains eastward run frequently to Chicago and New York. It was not impossible that the lost time might yet be recovered; and such an opportunity was not to be rejected.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Phileas Fogg did not reply at once; but Fix, having pointed out the man, who was walking up and down in front of the station, Mr. Fogg went up to him. This person, a stout man with ruddy countenance, an intelligent air, and active habits, was a character who evidently possessed a good deal of the Yankee in him. He introduced himself as Mudge, a boatman and adventurer, who performed the journey across the plains in winter by the aid of a sledge rigged with sails, at a speed often equal to, if not greater than, that of the railway trains. When the trains were blocked up by snow, and others could not pass, Mudge’s sledges glided over the frozen plains from one station to another, and he made a good living by the transportation of passengers and despatches. Mr. Fogg proposed to Mudge to convey him to Omaha, which is the point where the railway again commences. But Mudge could not undertake to deliver him there in time for him to catch the steamer to Liverpool. It was, in fact, four hundred miles from Fort Kearney to Omaha, which would take a good many hours on the sledge, even with a fair wind. Mudge, however, when Fogg had stated his object, saw a way of helping him. If he could not get him to Omaha in time to catch the steamer for Liverpool, he might carry him so far as to put him in a position to overtake it. “What would you charge to take me to Omaha?” asked Mr. Fogg. “Fifteen dollars a head,” replied Mudge. “I will pay it,” said Mr. Fogg; “but I will allow you two hundred dollars extra, if you get me to Omaha by eleven o’clock to-morrow morning.” Mudge stared at him, thinking that the traveller was a little cracked; but he saw that his eyes were clear, and he took the offer. “I accept,” said he. “Now, please to come and look at my vehicle.” Mr. Fogg went out with Mudge to inspect the sledge. It was a sort of car, mounted on runners, and capable of carrying a dozen persons. It was provided with a tall mast, like that of a brigantine, with a large sail and a jib-sail, and steered by means of a rudder. The wind was fair, blowing due west; the snow was hard, and the ice was in good condition. Mudge was very sanguine. He assured Mr. Fogg that he could reach Omaha in a few hours, and that he would be able to catch the eastward-bound trains. Mr. Fogg determined to take the chance.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Phileas Fogg did not reply at once; but Fix, having pointed out the man, who was walking up and down in front of the station, Mr. Fogg went up to him. Fogg approached the man, who was pacing impatiently. It was Colonel Stamp Proctor, the fiery American officer from the steamer China, who had nearly come to blows with Passepartout and had addressed some rather pointed remarks towards Fogg himself. "Sir," said Fogg, his voice calm but carrying a distinct weight, "you are Colonel Stamp Proctor, I believe?" The Colonel stopped his pacing and turned, scrutinising Fogg. "I am," he replied, his tone abrupt. "And you, sir, are the Englishman from the China, are you not?" "I am," Fogg confirmed. "Mr. Phileas Fogg. And I have a matter to settle with you regarding your conduct aboard that vessel." "Indeed?" Proctor scoffed. "I recall no such matter. Perhaps you refer to that impertinent Frenchman of yours?" "I refer, sir," Fogg said, his eyes steady, "to your remarks directed at me, and to your readiness to engage in fisticuffs with my servant. Such behaviour is uncivilised and intolerable." Proctor’s face flushed. "Are you calling me uncivilised, sir?" he demanded, taking a step forward. "I am stating a fact," Fogg replied coolly. "Then, sir," Proctor bellowed, drawing the attention of passersby, "it seems we have a score to settle, and not with mere words! Your insolence requires satisfaction!" "I agree," Fogg said, entirely unmoved by the Colonel’s display. "When and where do you propose we address this matter?" "Here and now, perhaps?" Proctor suggested, glancing around. "The location is public, and the means uncertain," Fogg observed. "We are awaiting the train to New York. It departs shortly. Shall we postpone this until a more suitable time and place?" "As you wish," Proctor sneered. "But make no mistake, sir, I shall have satisfaction." "You shall," Fogg assured him. "Let us agree to meet at the next convenient stop on the journey east. Is Ogden acceptable?" Proctor considered for a moment. "Ogden it is. On the train's arrival. And weapons?" "Pistols," Fogg stated. "Ten paces." "Agreed," said Proctor. "Until Ogden, then." Fogg nodded curtly and returned to where Fix was waiting. The detective had overheard the entire exchange, his eyes widening slightly at Fogg's unexpected readiness for a duel. Passepartout and Mrs. Aouda, sensing the tension, approached Fogg, their faces etched with concern. "Mr. Fogg, what has happened?" asked Mrs. Aouda. "Nothing untoward as yet, Aouda," Fogg replied, his composure perfect. "Merely a slight arrangement for later." "A slight arrangement?" Passepartout echoed, looking from Fogg to the retreating form of Colonel Proctor. Fix, unable to resist, muttered under his breath, "This fellow Fogg... first a race around the world, now a duel! He's truly extraordinary."

events.title: Aouda's Loyalty and Fix's Ambiguous Resolve
detailed_summary: Concerned about Aouda's comfort during the exposed sledge journey, Fogg suggests she remain at Fort Kearney with Passepartout, who could escort her to Europe later.
Aouda firmly refuses to be separated from Mr. Fogg.
Passepartout is pleased by her decision, as he doesn't want to leave his master alone with Fix.
The narrative notes the uncertainty of Fix's internal state: whether Fogg's return altered his suspicions or if he still saw Fogg as a cunning criminal nearing the end of his scheme.
Despite any potential shift in opinion, Fix remains committed to his duty and getting the group back to England swiftly.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Not wishing to expose Aouda to the discomforts of travelling in the open air, Mr. Fogg proposed to leave her with Passepartout at Fort Kearney, the servant taking upon himself to escort her to Europe by a better route and under more favourable conditions.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Perhaps Fix’s opinion of Phileas Fogg was somewhat modified; but he was nevertheless resolved to do his duty, and to hasten the return of the whole party to England as much as possible.

events.text_segment:
Not wishing to expose Aouda to the discomforts of travelling in the open air, Mr. Fogg proposed to leave her with Passepartout at Fort Kearney, the servant taking upon himself to escort her to Europe by a better route and under more favourable conditions. But Aouda refused to separate from Mr. Fogg, and Passepartout was delighted with her decision; for nothing could induce him to leave his master while Fix was with him.
It would be difficult to guess the detective’s thoughts. Was this conviction shaken by Phileas Fogg’s return, or did he still regard him as an exceedingly shrewd rascal, who, his journey round the world completed, would think himself absolutely safe in England? Perhaps Fix’s opinion of Phileas Fogg was somewhat modified; but he was nevertheless resolved to do his duty, and to hasten the return of the whole party to England as much as possible.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Not wishing to expose Aouda to the discomforts of travelling in the open air, Mr. Fogg proposed to leave her with Passepartout at Fort Kearney, the servant taking upon himself to escort her to Europe by a better route and under more favourable conditions. Aouda refused to separate from Mr. Fogg, and Passepartout was delighted with her decision, like himself, she was unwilling to leave his master alone in the hands of Fix. It is, indeed, difficult to say what passed in the mind of the detective at this moment. Had the return of Fogg modified his views as to his guilt? Was he finally convinced that Fogg was an honest man? Perhaps Fix was bewildered by Mr. Fogg's course of action. He was at his wits' end, not knowing what to do. He was still, however, determined to do his duty, and to hasten the return of the whole party to England.

events.title: The Sledge Journey Begins
detailed_summary: The sledge is prepared for departure at eight o'clock.
The passengers board, bundling themselves in warm travel cloaks.
The two large sails are hoisted.
Propelled by the wind, the sledge glides across the hardened snow at a remarkable forty miles per hour.
The distance to Omaha is about two hundred miles, potentially coverable in five hours if the wind persists.
Barring accidents, arrival in Omaha by one o'clock seems possible.
The narrative remarks on the extraordinary nature of the journey underway.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At eight o’clock the sledge was ready to start.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: What a journey!

events.text_segment:
At eight o’clock the sledge was ready to start. The passengers took their places on it, and wrapped themselves up closely in their travelling-cloaks. The two great sails were hoisted, and under the pressure of the wind the sledge slid over the hardened snow with a velocity of forty miles an hour.
The distance between Fort Kearney and Omaha, as the birds fly, is at most two hundred miles. If the wind held good, the distance might be traversed in five hours; if no accident happened the sledge might reach Omaha by one o’clock.
What a journey!

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: At eight o’clock the sledge was ready to start. The passengers, wrapped in their travelling-cloaks, and muffled in woollen comforters, took their places in the vehicle. These included Phileas Fogg, Aouda, Passepartout, and Fix. Two immense sails were hoisted, and under the impulse of the wind, the sledge glided over the hardened snow with a velocity of forty miles an hour. If there were no obstacles, it would require but five hours to traverse the two hundred miles separating Omaha from the station, and the train would be reached by one o’clock. It was a singular journey, which, the travellers it will be remembered, were making on the surface of a continent, not upon the sea.

The guide, a burly fellow named Mudge, cracked his whip, and the sailing sledge, propelled by the biting wind across the frozen, snow-covered plains, began its rapid journey eastward towards Omaha. It was a desperate gamble against time and distance, a race through the desolate landscape. The cold was intense, the silence broken only by the hiss of the runners and the wind. They sped along, hoping to reach the train that would carry them closer to their deadline, leaving the interrupted railway line behind in the vast, white wilderness.

events.title: High-Speed Sledding Across the Plains
detailed_summary: Bundled together, the travelers find conversation impossible due to the intense cold, which is amplified by their speed.
The sledge moves smoothly, resembling a boat gliding over water.
At times, strong gusts seem to lift the sledge slightly off the ground.
Mudge skillfully steers, maintaining a straight course and correcting any veering tendencies.
All available sails, including a jib and an additional top-mast jib, are deployed to maximize wind power.
The speed is estimated to be at least forty miles per hour.
Mudge expresses confidence in reaching their destination, provided the vehicle doesn't break.
Fogg has incentivized Mudge with a significant reward for timely arrival in Omaha.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The travellers, huddled close together, could not speak for the cold, intensified by the rapidity at which they were going.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mr. Fogg had made it for Mudge’s interest to reach Omaha within the time agreed on, by the offer of a handsome reward.

events.text_segment:
The travellers, huddled close together, could not speak for the cold, intensified by the rapidity at which they were going. The sledge sped on as lightly as a boat over the waves. When the breeze came skimming the earth the sledge seemed to be lifted off the ground by its sails. Mudge, who was at the rudder, kept in a straight line, and by a turn of his hand checked the lurches which the vehicle had a tendency to make. All the sails were up, and the jib was so arranged as not to screen the brigantine. A top-mast was hoisted, and another jib, held out to the wind, added its force to the other sails. Although the speed could not be exactly estimated, the sledge could not be going at less than forty miles an hour.
“If nothing breaks,” said Mudge, “we shall get there!”
Mr. Fogg had made it for Mudge’s interest to reach Omaha within the time agreed on, by the offer of a handsome reward.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The travellers, huddled close together, could not speak for the cold, intensified by the rapidity at which they were going. The sledge glided over the snow as smoothly as a boat over the water, or, as a balloon through the air. The runners gave forth a sharp sound as they rubbed the glistening surface, and the sails, swelled by the wind, towered above the travellers' heads. If the gale was strong, and it kept to the point, it was impossible to estimate the speed, which sometimes reached forty miles an hour, and carried them on as if through the air. When the wind abated, the runners slid less easily over the frozen crust, and Mudge then used his great spurs to prick on the mules, which trotted actively on. Thus they sped across the vast plains, not daring to say a word, but with eyes rendered practically useless by the glaring whiteness. Aouda was wrapped up carefully by Passepartout, who, in spite of the extreme rigour of the temperature, began to feel confident in the result. As for Phileas Fogg, it seemed just as if he were travelling in the "Mongolia." He was as calm as ever, and only disturbed by the thought of the possible accident which might happen to the sledge. If it should break down, it would be impossible to procure another, and it would be twenty-four hours at least before Omaha could be reached. Two hundred miles in four hours! It was a splendid journey, which would long be remembered by Phileas Fogg. The gentleman had spared no pains to ensure the success of the trip. In order to encourage Mudge, he had promised him five hundred dollars, if he arrived at Omaha before nine o'clock that evening. The sledge flew along, and when Mudge, integral part of the vehicle, held the rudder, it did not veer in the slightest. Mr. Fogg and Aouda, warmly wrapped up in rugs and furs, were comfortably sheltered from the force of the gale. As for Passepartout, with his jolly face, he was a sail with a large surface, and caught a 'prodigious' amount of wind. A few variations, however, occurred in the direction of the wind, and some snow fell; but it melted as it came in contact with the runners, and did not in the least retard the progress of the sledge. The only danger was from the formation of 'snow-wreaths,' which were occasioned by the gale. These, when they became condensed, were almost as solid as ice, and to run into them would be as dangerous as coming upon breakers at sea. Mudge was careful to avoid these, and kept the sledge from veering, by means of his rudder, with as much precision as a pilot steering a vessel. In the meantime, Phileas Fogg, with body as rigid as a poker, did not let his eyes stray from the clock, which hung in the saloon; and noticed the slightest variation in the speed. At a quarter past six in the morning, the sun rose. But the cold, instead of diminishing, increased. The thermometer showed 4 degrees below zero, and, in spite of the rapidity of the movement, the cold was intensely felt. Happily, the wind held good, and no great decrease in the rate of speed was to be feared.

The sledge glided over the snow as smoothly as a boat over the water. It seemed to be flying through the air, and sometimes, when the gusts were stronger, it seemed to be lifted from the ground. LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The travellers, huddled close together, could not speak for the cold, intensified by the rapidity at which they were going. The wind tore at their clothing, searing their faces like a thousand needles. The frosted landscape blurred into an indistinct grey and white streak. Each breath was a painful gulp of icy air that burned their lungs. Passepartout shivered violently, his teeth chattering audibly despite his efforts to control them. Even the imperturbable Mr. Fogg seemed to draw his fur collar tighter around his neck, his eyes fixed forward with unwavering determination. Aouda, wrapped in blankets, pressed herself against Fogg, seeking what little warmth she could find. Fix, huddled in the corner, looked utterly miserable, cursing inwardly the chain of events that had led him to this frozen inferno. The speed was breathtaking, the horses, magnificent creatures, pounding across the snow-covered plains as if pursued by demons. The sled skittered and bounced over the uneven terrain, threatening to throw them into the drifts at any moment. There was no thought of comfort, only of sheer, grim endurance, of reaching their destination before the time ran out. The relentless rush, the biting frost, the sheer physical agony of it all combined into an overwhelming ordeal that tested their limits. Yet, driven by the ticking clock and Fogg's unyielding will, they pressed onward into the frozen expanse.

events.title: Prairie Crossing and Passengers' Reflections
detailed_summary: The sledge traverses a vast, flat prairie, described as resembling a frozen sea or lake.
It takes a direct route, shorter than the winding railway line that follows the Platte River.
Mudge isn't concerned about the river as it is frozen solid, presenting no obstacle.
The main risks are identified as potential damage to the sledge or a drop in the wind.
The wind remains strong, causing the mast's metal lashings to vibrate and create a musical sound.
Fogg remarks on the specific musical notes produced by the vibrating lashings, his only words during the trip.
Aouda remains well-protected from the wind within her furs.
Passepartout, face reddened by the cold, starts feeling optimistic about reaching New York in time.
He feels gratitude towards Fix for arranging the sledge but maintains his reserve due to suspicion.
Passepartout deeply reflects on Fogg's selfless act of rescuing him from the Sioux, acknowledging the risk Fogg took with his life and fortune.
While the passengers are lost in their thoughts, the sledge speeds through the deserted, snow-covered landscape.
They pass ghostly trees and encounter wildlife like birds and howling prairie wolves.
Passepartout prepares his revolver as the wolves approach, but the sledge outpaces them, avoiding danger.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The prairie, across which the sledge was moving in a straight line, was as flat as a sea.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Had an accident then happened to the sledge, the travellers, attacked by these beasts, would have been in the most terrible danger; but it held on its even course, soon gained on the wolves, and ere long left the howling band at a safe distance behind.

events.text_segment:
The prairie, across which the sledge was moving in a straight line, was as flat as a sea. It seemed like a vast frozen lake. The railroad which ran through this section ascended from the south-west to the north-west by Great Island, Columbus, an important Nebraska town, Schuyler, and Fremont, to Omaha. It followed throughout the right bank of the Platte River. The sledge, shortening this route, took a chord of the arc described by the railway. Mudge was not afraid of being stopped by the Platte River, because it was frozen. The road, then, was quite clear of obstacles, and Phileas Fogg had but two things to fear—an accident to the sledge, and a change or calm in the wind.
But the breeze, far from lessening its force, blew as if to bend the mast, which, however, the metallic lashings held firmly. These lashings, like the chords of a stringed instrument, resounded as if vibrated by a violin bow. The sledge slid along in the midst of a plaintively intense melody.
“Those chords give the fifth and the octave,” said Mr. Fogg.
These were the only words he uttered during the journey. Aouda, cosily packed in furs and cloaks, was sheltered as much as possible from the attacks of the freezing wind. As for Passepartout, his face was as red as the sun’s disc when it sets in the mist, and he laboriously inhaled the biting air. With his natural buoyancy of spirits, he began to hope again. They would reach New York on the evening, if not on the morning, of the 11th, and there were still some chances that it would be before the steamer sailed for Liverpool.
Passepartout even felt a strong desire to grasp his ally, Fix, by the hand. He remembered that it was the detective who procured the sledge, the only means of reaching Omaha in time; but, checked by some presentiment, he kept his usual reserve. One thing, however, Passepartout would never forget, and that was the sacrifice which Mr. Fogg had made, without hesitation, to rescue him from the Sioux. Mr. Fogg had risked his fortune and his life. No! His servant would never forget that!
While each of the party was absorbed in reflections so different, the sledge flew past over the vast carpet of snow. The creeks it passed over were not perceived. Fields and streams disappeared under the uniform whiteness. The plain was absolutely deserted. Between the Union Pacific road and the branch which unites Kearney with Saint Joseph it formed a great uninhabited island. Neither village, station, nor fort appeared. From time to time they sped by some phantom-like tree, whose white skeleton twisted and rattled in the wind. Sometimes flocks of wild birds rose, or bands of gaunt, famished, ferocious prairie-wolves ran howling after the sledge. Passepartout, revolver in hand, held himself ready to fire on those which came too near. Had an accident then happened to the sledge, the travellers, attacked by these beasts, would have been in the most terrible danger; but it held on its even course, soon gained on the wolves, and ere long left the howling band at a safe distance behind.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The prairie, across which the sledge was moving in a straight line, was as flat as a sea. It seemed an immense frozen lake. The railway followed the Platte River, which runs in the south-easterly direction; but the sledge went directly north, so as to gain the shortest cut to the Omaha station. The river was not to be feared, as it was frozen over, and the chief danger was from the snowdrifts, which the wind at times formed, and which, by consolidating, might stop the sledge. But the vehicle, being light and furnished with broad runners, glided over them easily. The wind was very sharp, and it was with difficulty that one could bear against it; but, fortunately, it came from the north, and drove the sledge forward in the right direction. With her furs and wraps, Aouda was well protected against the cold. Passepartout, enveloped in a travelling-blanket, had only his red nose out of it, and his eyes, which the wind was constantly filling with tears. The travellers were as silent as possible, Abolutely mute was Phileas Fogg. Mudge had skilfully mounted the sail, and was holding the tiller, by the aid of which he directed the sledge’s course over the vast sheet of snow. By noon the Platte River was crossed, and Mudge could recognise by sure marks that he was making a straight cut to the station. He expected to reach it by two o’clock at the latest. During the forenoon, he several times came up to the railway, which wound along the river-bank with innumerable curves. When the river made one of its bends, the sledge cut directly across the chords of the arc, greatly shortening the way. At twelve o’clock, Mudge and his passengers found themselves twenty miles at least from the railway. If no accident happened, they would gain some twenty miles further before reaching the station at Omaha. A bold project, and one which Fix was beginning to consider as very practicable: that of reaching New York and San Francisco in time to make the tour of the world. Passepartout was now hoping with all his heart that the success of the journey might be assured, and that Fix might be deceived and outwitted. Upon his master, who was braving the most terrible dangers, he bestowed unlimited admiration; and as for Aouda, he was not now in the least afraid about her, for she was in safekeeping. He reflected on the scenes which had occurred at the Sioux village, and thought that Mudge was a brave fellow, to whom they owed a great deal. His courage and stoutness had prevented the massacre. And then, when he thought of Phileas Fogg’s generosity, of his devoting his fortune and life to save his servant, when he recalled his calm air, and entire coolness during the trying ordeal, he was filled with respect, with gratitude, and affection for his master. And so, in the midst of the vast prairie, the wind rushing past, the sledge glidding over the snow, he meditated upon the noble and imperturbable character of Phileas Fogg. The bells on the mast, jingling in the cold, wintry air, had a wild and musical effect. They reminded Passepartout of his younger days, and he seemed to be carried back to his native village in Auvergne. The rhythmical jingle passed into his mind as a sort of tune; and he caught himself hummining it, to the great satisfaction of the echoes, which repeated it in the crisp air. “Well, Mr. Passepartout,” said Fix, who was not without a vein of poetry, “we are jingling along capitally.” “Might add a few bells to your own person, Mr. Fix,” replied Passepartout, “that you might have the pleasure of jingling all the way.” “This time, seriously, though,” asked Fix, “do you still hold it against me that I determined to follow Mr. Fogg?” “Yes; and I mean to hold it against you to the end.” “But why? I had my duty to perform; and you, your master’s servant, also had yours. You helped him to get away; I, myself, was hindering him. Thanks to the Sioux, he has saved your life; but like a gentleman, he performed his duty, while I was only performing mine.” “But come now!” said Passepartout; “will you still make out that he is a robber?” “Mr. Passepartout,” returned Fix, “robbers who go about the world to the tune of seventy-seven thousand pounds, are not to be trifled with. I admit that, since I have been following him, he seems a thoroughly honest man; but so rich a gentleman could not be a robber without having some accomplices. All this looks too like a regularly organised band. Besides, I am sure that he has not taken the Union Pacific Railway, and that the money has been carried off in a car of the Golden Car train. But here we are! There is the station of Omaha.” And indeed, a station was in sight, around which were clustered a few houses and a magazine of coal. Passepartout was about to leap out, when Fix caught his arm and said, “Let us wait, my friend. We must not go to the police-station till Mr. Fogg has gone in.” “But what is to prevent Mr. Fogg from going in?” asked Passepartout. “Nothing, of course. He is a man of principle, and he will not go into the station before giving his money.” “But why do you follow him?” “I have no other motive than my duty. The man is a robber, and I am determined to seize him.” Passepartout shook his head and was about to speak, when Mudge shouted, “Now we are out of the wind! The station is just ahead!” Fix, seizing Passepartout’s arm, said, “Do not leave me, my friend, until Mr. Fogg has arrived.” “But what are you going to do?” “Nothing at all; but we must wait.” The sledge stopped near the station, and Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout alighted. They entered the station, and Mr. Fogg inquired at once whether there were any news of the train from San Francisco. The train had not arrived, and the officials could not tell when it would reach Omaha. Mudge had received his fare, and Mr. Fogg was about to pay him, when the detective seized his arm and said, “Mr. Fogg, I arrest you in the Queen’s name!” Phileas Fogg, calm and impassive as ever, stood still. He was a prisoner.

And then, when he thought of Phileas Fogg’s generosity, of his devoting his fortune and life to save his servant, when he recalled his calm air, and entire coolness during the trying ordeal, he was filled with respect, with gratitude, and affection for his master. And so, in the midst of the vast prairie, the wind rushing past, the sledge glidding over the snow, he meditated upon the noble and imperturbable character of Phileas Fogg. The bells on the mast, jingling in the cold, wintry air, had a wild and musical effect. They reminded Passepartout of his younger days, and he seemed to be carried back to his native village in Auvergne. The rhythmical jingle passed into his mind as a sort of tune; and he caught himself hummining it, to the great satisfaction of the echoes, which repeated it in the crisp air. “Well, Mr. Passepartout,” said Fix, who was not without a vein of poetry, “we are jingling along capitally.” “Might add a few bells to your own person, Mr. Fix,” replied Passepartout, “that you might have the pleasure of jingling all the way.” “This time, seriously, though,” asked Fix, “do you still hold it against me that I determined to follow Mr. Fogg?” “Yes; and I mean to hold it against you to the end.” “But why? I had my duty to perform; and you, your master’s servant, also had yours. You helped him to get away; I, myself, was hindering him. Thanks to the Sioux, he has saved your life; but like a gentleman, he performed his duty, while I was only performing mine.” “But come now!” said Passepartout; “will you still make out that he is a robber?” “Mr. Passepartout,” returned Fix, “robbers who go about the world to the tune of seventy-seven thousand pounds, are not to be trifled with. I admit that, since I have been following him, he seems a thoroughly honest man; but so rich a gentleman could not be a robber without having some accomplices. All this looks too like a regularly organised band. Besides, I am sure that he has not taken the Union Pacific Railway, and that the money has been carried off in a car of the Golden Car train. But here we are! There is the station of Omaha.” And indeed, a station was in sight, around which were clustered a few houses and a magazine of coal. Passepartout was about to leap out, when Fix caught his arm and said, “Let us wait, my friend. We must not go to the police-station till Mr. Fogg has gone in.” “But what is to prevent Mr. Fogg from going in?” asked Passepartout. “Nothing, of course. He is a man of principle, and he will not go into the station before giving his money.” “But why do you follow him?” “I have no other motive than my duty. The man is a robber, and I am determined to seize him.” Passepartout shook his head and was about to speak, when Mudge shouted, “Now we are out of the wind! The station is just ahead!” Fix, seizing Passepartout’s arm, said, “Do not leave me, my friend, until Mr. Fogg has arrived.” “But what are you going to do?” “Nothing at all; but we must wait.” The sledge stopped near the station, and Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout alighted. They entered the station, and Mr. Fogg inquired at once whether there were any news of the train from San Francisco. The train had not arrived, and the officials could not tell when it would reach Omaha. Mudge had received his fare, and Mr. Fogg was about to pay him, when the detective seized his arm and said, “Mr. Fogg, I arrest you in the Queen’s name!” Phileas Fogg, calm and impassive as ever, stood still. He was a prisoner.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: The prairie, across which the sledge was moving in a straight line, was as flat as a sea. It seemed an immense frozen lake. The railway followed the Platte River, which runs in the south-easterly direction; but the sledge went directly north, so as to gain the shortest cut to the Omaha station. The river was not to be feared, as it was frozen over, and the chief danger was from the snowdrifts, which the wind at times formed, and which, by consolidating, might stop the sledge. But the vehicle, being light and furnished with broad runners, glided over them easily. The wind was very sharp, and it was with difficulty that one could bear against it; but, fortunately, it came from the north, and drove the sledge forward in the right direction. With her furs and wraps, Aouda was well protected against the cold. Passepartout, enveloped in a travelling-blanket, had only his red nose out of it, and his eyes, which the wind was constantly filling with tears. The travellers were as silent as possible, Abolutely mute was Phileas Fogg. Mudge had skilfully mounted the sail, and was holding the tiller, by the aid of which he directed the sledge’s course over the vast sheet of snow. The mast, firmly stayed, held the sail, which was swelled by the wind like a balloon. The metal lashings of the mast vibrated in the wind with a musical sound. Mr. Fogg, who was listening attentively, remarked, without taking his eyes from the horizon, “Do you hear? It is a B flat.” These were the only words he uttered during the trip. By noon the Platte River was crossed, and Mudge could recognise by sure marks that he was making a straight cut to the station. He expected to reach it by two o’clock at the latest. During the forenoon, he several times came up to the railway, which wound along the river-bank with innumerable curves. When the river made one of its bends, the sledge cut directly across the chords of the arc, greatly shortening the way. At twelve o’clock, Mudge and his passengers found themselves twenty miles at least from the railway. If no accident happened, they would gain some twenty miles further before reaching the station at Omaha. A bold project, and one which Fix was beginning to consider as very practicable: that of reaching New York and San Francisco in time to make the tour of the world. Passepartout was now hoping with all his heart that the success of the journey might be assured, and that Fix might be deceived and outwitted. Upon his master, who was braving the most terrible dangers, he bestowed unlimited admiration; and as for Aouda, he was not now in the least afraid about her, for she was in safekeeping. He reflected on the scenes which had occurred at the Sioux village, and thought that Mudge was a brave fellow, to whom they owed a great deal. His courage and stoutness had prevented the massacre. And then, when he thought of Phileas Fogg’s generosity, of his devoting his fortune and life to save his servant, when he recalled his calm air, and entire coolness during the trying ordeal, he was filled with respect, with gratitude, and affection for his master. And so, in the midst of the vast prairie, the wind rushing past, the sledge glidding over the snow, he meditated upon the noble and imperturbable character of Phileas Fogg. The bells on the mast, jingling in the cold, wintry air, had a wild and musical effect. They reminded Passepartout of his younger days, and he seemed to be carried back to his native village in Auvergne. The rhythmical jingle passed into his mind as a sort of tune; and he caught himself hummining it, to the great satisfaction of the echoes, which repeated it in the crisp air. The vast prairie was absolutely deserted. Not a village, not even a station. The wind swept across it with great rapidity, and the cold was intense, though less so than on the preceding day. In the midst of this great solitude, the travellers were not without anxieties. If the sledge should break down, they would be lost. If the wind should fail, they would be frozen. But the wind held good, and the sledge, swift as a bird, glided over the snow. Towards noon, Mudge pointed out a few black specks on the horizon, which he said were trees. In a few hours, they would reach them. These trees were indeed a welcome sight. They were the first signs of vegetation they had seen since leaving the Rocky Mountains. They were a species of pine, with long, drooping branches, and they looked like phantom trees in the snow. As they approached, they saw that they were not alone. Wild birds rose from the branches, and a pack of prairie-wolves, gaunt and hungry, followed the sledge at a distance. Passepartout instinctively drew his revolver, but Mudge reassured him. “They are not dangerous,” he said, “unless they are in great numbers. And besides, we are going too fast for them.” “Well, Mr. Passepartout,” said Fix, who was not without a vein of poetry, “we are jingling along capitally.” “Might add a few bells to your own person, Mr. Fix,” replied Passepartout, “that you might have the pleasure of jingling all the way.” “This time, seriously, though,” asked Fix, “do you still hold it against me that I determined to follow Mr. Fogg?” “Yes; and I mean to hold it against you to the end.” “But why? I had my duty to perform; and you, your master’s servant, also had yours. You helped him to get away; I, myself, was hindering him. Thanks to the Sioux, he has saved your life; but like a gentleman, he performed his duty, while I was only performing mine.” “But come now!” said Passepartout; “will you still make out that he is a robber?” “Mr. Passepartout,” returned Fix, “robbers who go about the world to the tune of seventy-seven thousand pounds, are not to be trifled with. I admit that, since I have been following him, he seems a thoroughly honest man; but so rich a gentleman could not be a robber without having some accomplices. All this looks too like a regularly organised band. Besides, I am sure that he has not taken the Union Pacific Railway, and that the money has been carried off in a car of the Golden Car train. But here we are! There is the station of Omaha.” And indeed, a station was in sight, around which were clustered a few houses and a magazine of coal. Passepartout was about to leap out, when Fix caught his arm and said, “Let us wait, my friend. We must not go to the police-station till Mr. Fogg has gone in.” “But what is to prevent Mr. Fogg from going in?” asked Passepartout. “Nothing, of course. He is a man of principle, and he will not go into the station before giving his money.” “But why do you follow him?” “I have no other motive than my duty. The man is a robber, and I am determined to seize him.” Passepartout shook his head and was about to speak, when Mudge shouted, “Now we are out of the wind! The station is just ahead!” Fix, seizing Passepartout’s arm, said, “Do not leave me, my friend, until Mr. Fogg has arrived.” “But what are you going to do?” “Nothing at all; but we must wait.” The sledge stopped near the station, and Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout alighted. They entered the station, and Mr. Fogg inquired at once whether there were any news of the train from San Francisco. The train had not arrived, and the officials could not tell when it would reach Omaha. Mudge had received his fare, and Mr. Fogg was about to pay him, when the detective seized his arm and said, “Mr. Fogg, I arrest you in the Queen’s name!” Phileas Fogg, calm and impassive as ever, stood still. He was a prisoner.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The prairie, across which the sledge was moving in a straight line, was as flat as a sea. The snow lay thick and uniform, covering the immense expanse as far as the eye could reach, broken only here and there by the faint undulation of a drift or the dark line of a distant grove of stunted trees. The sky above was a cold, pale grey, and a bitter, biting wind howled across the treeless waste, whipping fine particles of snow into the air. This wind, however, was their engine. The sledge, a light frame on runners, was equipped with a large sail that billowed out, catching the fierce blast and propelling them forward at a remarkable speed.Inside the covered part of the vehicle, huddled together against the intense cold, were the four travellers: Mr. Phileas Fogg, impassive and seemingly unconcerned by the biting air; Mrs. Aouda, her face pale but resolute; Passepartout, shivering despite the furs, his anxiety barely masked by his forced cheerfulness; and Mr. Fix, the detective, watching Fogg with an intensity that neither Fogg nor Aouda seemed to notice. A native American, a man of few words with a weathered face and sharp eyes, stood exposed at the front, managing the sail and steering their precarious craft across the frozen plain with practiced skill.The silence was broken only by the screech of the runners on the hard-packed snow and the relentless moan of the wind. There were no settlements, no signs of human habitation in this desolate region. They were entirely alone, swallowed by the immensity of the landscape and the elements. Mr. Fogg consulted his watch periodically, his movements precise and unhurried, as if he were merely taking a train in London rather than racing across a perilous wilderness. His focus remained solely on the schedule, measuring their progress against the dwindling hours.Passepartout, despite the adventure of it, felt a growing apprehension. This untamed land, so different from the familiar landscapes of Europe or the bustling cities they had passed through, felt hostile. The stories he had heard of the dangers of the American West 
 the harsh weather, the wild animals, and above all, the formidable indigenous tribes 
 echoed in his mind. He peered out from time to time, scanning the horizon for any sign of movement, any shape that might detach itself from the monotonous white.Fix, meanwhile, nursed his frustration. This sudden, desperate dash across the prairie was delaying his plans, making it harder to apprehend Fogg. Yet, he was forced to travel with him, outwardly playing the role of a fellow traveller, while inwardly cursing the circumstances that kept his target just out of legal reach. Every mile they covered was a mile further from where a warrant might be waiting.Aouda, wrapped in her furs, looked at Fogg with a mixture of admiration and concern. His absolute calm in the face of such challenges was extraordinary, yet she worried about the risks he was taking, not just with his fortune, but with his life and the lives of those with him.The driver, an Osage Indian, guided the sledge expertly, his eyes fixed ahead. He knew the prairie, its moods and its dangers. The wind was strong, promising good speed, but the open plain also offered no cover should trouble arise. They were a small, vulnerable speck moving rapidly across a vast, indifferent stage. The hours blended into one another, marked only by the changing angle of the weak sunlight and the increasing numbness of the cold. The world outside the sledge was a blur of white and grey, a relentless, unchanging panorama that seemed designed to test the limits of endurance and will. They pressed on, a tiny vessel driven by the wind, racing against time and the unknown perils of the American frontier.

events.title: Arrival in Omaha
detailed_summary: Around midday, Mudge identifies landmarks indicating they are crossing the Platte River.
He silently calculates they are about twenty miles from Omaha.
Less than an hour later, he releases the rudder and lowers the sails.
The sledge continues for another half-mile due to its momentum before finally stopping.
Mudge points towards snow-covered roofs and announces their arrival.
They have reached the Omaha station, a hub with frequent train connections to the East Coast.
Passepartout and Fix disembark first, stretching, followed by Fogg and Aouda.
Fogg pays Mudge generously, and Passepartout shakes his hand warmly.
The group immediately proceeds towards the Omaha railway station.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: About noon Mudge perceived by certain landmarks that he was crossing the Platte River.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Phileas Fogg generously rewarded Mudge, whose hand Passepartout warmly grasped, and the party directed their steps to the Omaha railway station.

events.text_segment:
About noon Mudge perceived by certain landmarks that he was crossing the Platte River. He said nothing, but he felt certain that he was now within twenty miles of Omaha. In less than an hour he left the rudder and furled his sails, whilst the sledge, carried forward by the great impetus the wind had given it, went on half a mile further with its sails unspread.
It stopped at last, and Mudge, pointing to a mass of roofs white with snow, said: “We have got there!”
Arrived! Arrived at the station which is in daily communication, by numerous trains, with the Atlantic seaboard!
Passepartout and Fix jumped off, stretched their stiffened limbs, and aided Mr. Fogg and the young woman to descend from the sledge. Phileas Fogg generously rewarded Mudge, whose hand Passepartout warmly grasped, and the party directed their steps to the Omaha railway station.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: About noon Mudge perceived by certain landmarks that he was crossing the Platte River. He said nothing, but he knew that he was only about twenty miles from Omaha. An hour after, he left the rudder and lowered the sails, and the sledge glided along for half a mile farther by its acquired momentum. It stopped at last, and Mudge, pointing to a mass of roofs white with snow, said: "We have got there!" It was the Omaha station, the grandest on the line, and the terminus of the Pacific Railroad. Passepartout and Fix were the first to leap off, and they stretched their stiffened limbs. Fogg and Aouda followed them more deliberately. Phileas Fogg had the good idea to pay Mudge generously, who had led them so successfully thus far. Passepartout warmly shook his hand, and the party directed their steps to the Omaha railway station.

events.title: Race Across America by Train and Final Disappointment
detailed_summary: Omaha serves as the terminus for the Pacific Railroad and connects eastward via the Chicago and Rock Island Railroad.
Upon reaching the Omaha station, Fogg and his party find a train ready to depart and board immediately.
They forgo any sightseeing in Omaha, prioritizing speed.
The train travels swiftly through Iowa (Council Bluffs, Des Moines, Iowa City), crosses the Mississippi River at Davenport during the night, and enters Illinois via Rock Island.
They arrive in Chicago, depicted as rebuilt and thriving, on the afternoon of the 10th.
With nine hundred miles remaining to New York, Fogg immediately transfers to the Pittsburgh, Fort Wayne, and Chicago Railway train.
The train speeds through Indiana, Ohio, Pennsylvania, and New Jersey, passing rapidly through towns.
Finally, the Hudson River comes into view.
At 11:15 PM on the evening of the 11th, the train arrives at the New York station, right beside the Cunard line pier.
They learn immediately that the Liverpool steamer, the "China," had departed just 45 minutes earlier.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The Pacific Railroad proper finds its terminus at this important Nebraska town.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The “China,” for Liverpool, had started three-quarters of an hour before!

events.text_segment:
The Pacific Railroad proper finds its terminus at this important Nebraska town. Omaha is connected with Chicago by the Chicago and Rock Island Railroad, which runs directly east, and passes fifty stations.
A train was ready to start when Mr. Fogg and his party reached the station, and they only had time to get into the cars. They had seen nothing of Omaha; but Passepartout confessed to himself that this was not to be regretted, as they were not travelling to see the sights.
The train passed rapidly across the State of Iowa, by Council Bluffs, Des Moines, and Iowa City. During the night it crossed the Mississippi at Davenport, and by Rock Island entered Illinois. The next day, which was the 10th, at four o’clock in the evening, it reached Chicago, already risen from its ruins, and more proudly seated than ever on the borders of its beautiful Lake Michigan.
Nine hundred miles separated Chicago from New York; but trains are not wanting at Chicago. Mr. Fogg passed at once from one to the other, and the locomotive of the Pittsburgh, Fort Wayne, and Chicago Railway left at full speed, as if it fully comprehended that that gentleman had no time to lose. It traversed Indiana, Ohio, Pennsylvania, and New Jersey like a flash, rushing through towns with antique names, some of which had streets and car-tracks, but as yet no houses. At last the Hudson came into view; and, at a quarter-past eleven in the evening of the 11th, the train stopped in the station on the right bank of the river, before the very pier of the Cunard line.
The “China,” for Liverpool, had started three-quarters of an hour before!

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The Pacific Railroad proper finds its terminus at this important Nebraska town. Omaha is on the left bank of the Missouri, and communicates with Chicago by the Chicago and Rock Island Railroad, which runs directly east through Iowa. There was a train ready to start when Mr. Fogg and his companions reached the station, and they at once took their places in a carriage. They had omitted to see Omaha, so they did not regret it; but Passepartout, at least, was glad to set foot upon the soil of America. The train passed rapidly the extreme south-western angle of Iowa, where the Council Bluffs and the Pacific line join. Very little was to be seen of the Indian country, situated north. The travellers were not delayed by either in stopping or accident, and reached Council Bluffs during the night, passing the Missouri bridge and station, and running onward into the State of Iowa. On the 10th, at four o'clock in the afternoon, the train stopped for a few moments at Des Moines, which is the capital of Iowa, and afterwards crossed the Racoon River upon a bridge. During the night they passed by Iowa City and Cedar Rapids; and the next morning, the 11th, arrived at Rock Island, on the Mississippi. At Rock Island begins the third great bridge over the Mississippi, a work of great size, built of iron, and allowing the passage of trains. The river was swollen and rapid, and they passed over it with difficulty. Beyond Rock Island the railway passed to the south-east, to La Salle, where it joins the Illinois Central Railroad, one of the longest lines of the American Union, and runs directly to Chicago. That city was reached at two o'clock in the afternoon, and here the travellers at length found themselves nine hundred miles from New York. The journey across the prairies had been accomplished in three days. From Chicago to New York the distance is about nine hundred miles. Mr. Fogg was therefore right in supposing that he could get to New York in three days. The train from Chicago to New York was ready to start, and Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout took their seats in it. The train passed rapidly across Indiana and Ohio, going by countless towns, some built upon the sites of old Indian villages, and others having risen around the railway stations, with their wooden houses and brick edifices, their mills, large stores, and warehouses. At last the Hudson came in sight. At eleven o'clock on the evening of the 11th, the train stopped in the station at New York, right beside the Cunard dock. The China, for Liverpool, had started at a quarter past seven.

It is the second city in the United States, and is one of the most rapidly growing. It is a huge caravanserai of the west, and more grain passes through it than through any other city in the world.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXXII. IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG ENGAGES IN A DIRECT STRUGGLE WITH BAD FORTUNE

events.title: Missed Steamer and Passepartout's Guilt
detailed_summary: The departure of the steamship "China" dashes Phileas Fogg's most apparent chance of crossing the Atlantic in time.
Consulting his "Bradshaw" guide confirms that alternative steamers from French, Hamburg, or Inman lines are unsuitable due to destinations or schedules, rendering Fogg's efforts potentially futile.
Passepartout feels utterly crushed, blaming himself for the missed connection and other obstacles he feels he placed in his master's path throughout their journey.
He reflects on the significant sums of money spent, partly due to his own errors, and the immense financial ruin Fogg faces if the wager is lost.
Despite Passepartout's self-reproach, Phileas Fogg remains calm, does not blame him, and suggests they postpone decision-making until the following day.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The “China,” in leaving, seemed to have carried off Phileas Fogg’s last hope.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Come.”

events.text_segment:
The “China,” in leaving, seemed to have carried off Phileas Fogg’s last hope. None of the other steamers were able to serve his projects. The “Pereire,” of the French Transatlantic Company, whose admirable steamers are equal to any in speed and comfort, did not leave until the 14th; the Hamburg boats did not go directly to Liverpool or London, but to Havre; and the additional trip from Havre to Southampton would render Phileas Fogg’s last efforts of no avail. The Inman steamer did not depart till the next day, and could not cross the Atlantic in time to save the wager.
Mr. Fogg learned all this in consulting his “Bradshaw,” which gave him the daily movements of the transatlantic steamers.
Passepartout was crushed; it overwhelmed him to lose the boat by three-quarters of an hour. It was his fault, for, instead of helping his master, he had not ceased putting obstacles in his path! And when he recalled all the incidents of the tour, when he counted up the sums expended in pure loss and on his own account, when he thought that the immense stake, added to the heavy charges of this useless journey, would completely ruin Mr. Fogg, he overwhelmed himself with bitter self-accusations. Mr. Fogg, however, did not reproach him; and, on leaving the Cunard pier, only said: “We will consult about what is best to-morrow. Come.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The “China,” in leaving, seemed to have carried off Phileas Fogg’s last hope. Not only was the steamer his last resort, but, in consequence of the "Ta-ko-nia" having passed around the Cape, he found himself twenty hours behind time, a most discouraging lag, and one that rendered his last efforts almost useless. It was true that Phileas Fogg had fifty-five hours left in which to reach London; but there were two oceans to traverse, and, in order to regain his lost time, he would have been obliged to take the speediest of steamers, and these the “China” was by far the best. He consulted his Bradshaw, which he now used for the last time. The “China” belonged to the Cunard Line, and a steamer from that line was able to reach Liverpool in the shortest space of time. The French steamers--the "Pereire" and the "Ville-du-Paris"—did not run to New York, and their speed was less considerable. The steamers of the Inman Line--better as navigators, but less rapid—were eleven, and those of the Hamburg line eight days in crossing the ocean. The voyage to Bordeaux by the Transatlantic steamers would have taken three days, and once at Bordeaux, the trip by rail to Paris and London could not have been accomplished in less than six hours—in all, three days and a half. In short, no matter what line was taken, or what steamer was used, it was evident to Phileas Fogg that the longest of his journeys was not the least difficult. Passepartout was absolutely crushed. He could not conceal his self-reproach. It was his fault that his master had missed the steamer! And as they were going at full speed, he recounted with sobs to Mr. Fogg all the obstacles, delays, and accidents which he had occasioned. "Ah, me! the ‘Ta-ko-nia’ detained twenty-four hours at the Azores, and that was my doing, as I didn't shut off the steam! The collision at Calcutta, and my arrest at Hong Kong, and my adventure in the prison at Yokohama, and my master not being able to get away from there sooner—and now this! And why did you take me with you, sir? And I've ruined you, with my follies and delays! And the elephant money at Allahabad, and the reward to the detective at Hong Kong, and the two thousand pounds obtained from the fix at Yokohama! And I've spent three thousand pounds, of which I am the cause!" Phileas Fogg heard this torrent of grief without getting angry. When Passepartout had finished, he simply said, "Well, let us go aboard the steamer." "Which one?" asked Passepartout. "That of the twenty-fifth, at noon." Passepartout did not understand; it was the twenty-fourth, and the steamer left the same day at noon. "In the meanwhile," added Mr. Fogg, "let us postpone the decision until to-morrow. Come."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The “China,” in leaving, seemed to have carried off Phileas Fogg’s last hope. Eighty days, and to fail by mere hours! All his calculations, his meticulous planning, undone by an unforeseen delay – a storm, a misplaced assumption about the date. Aouda, her heart aching for him, stood close, while Passepartout wrung his hands, muttering imprecations against fate and steamers alike. Just then, a hand fell upon Mr. Fogg’s shoulder. He turned. It was Detective Fix. "Mr. Phileas Fogg, you are my prisoner!" Fix said, his voice betraying a mix of triumph and nervousness. Fogg, despite the crushing weight of his perceived failure, remained outwardly calm. "On what charge, sir?" he asked, his voice level. "You are the bank robber," Fix declared. Passepartout, momentarily stunned, let out a cry of outrage and lunged towards Fix, but was restrained. Aouda watched, horrified. Fogg offered no resistance. He was escorted to a cab, then taken to the police station. There, he was locked in a cell. He sat down, seemingly resigned. He had travelled the world, faced countless dangers, all to win a wager, only to be stopped, not by distance or time, but by this absurd accusation, and arriving back in England just late enough to lose. The ticking clock in his mind had stopped. The game, he believed, was over. His world collapsed around this final, unexpected obstacle.

events.title: An Anxious Night and Calculated Odds
detailed_summary: The group travels by ferry from Jersey City across the Hudson River and takes a carriage to the St. Nicholas Hotel on Broadway.
They secure rooms for the night.
Phileas Fogg sleeps soundly, apparently unaffected by the setback.
In contrast, Aouda and the others (including Passepartout and likely Fix) are too agitated and worried to rest properly.
The narrative marks the date as December 12th and calculates the precise time remaining: nine days, thirteen hours, and forty-five minutes until the deadline at 8:45 PM on December 21st.
It explicitly states that catching the "China" would have allowed Fogg to reach Liverpool and London within the required timeframe.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The party crossed the Hudson in the Jersey City ferryboat, and drove in a carriage to the St. Nicholas Hotel, on Broadway.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: If Phileas Fogg had left in the “China,” one of the fastest steamers on the Atlantic, he would have reached Liverpool, and then London, within the period agreed upon.

events.text_segment:
The party crossed the Hudson in the Jersey City ferryboat, and drove in a carriage to the St. Nicholas Hotel, on Broadway. Rooms were engaged, and the night passed, briefly to Phileas Fogg, who slept profoundly, but very long to Aouda and the others, whose agitation did not permit them to rest.
The next day was the 12th of December. From seven in the morning of the 12th to a quarter before nine in the evening of the 21st there were nine days, thirteen hours, and forty-five minutes. If Phileas Fogg had left in the “China,” one of the fastest steamers on the Atlantic, he would have reached Liverpool, and then London, within the period agreed upon.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The party crossed the Hudson in the Jersey City ferryboat, and drove in a carriage to the St. Nicholas Hotel, on Broadway. Rooms were secured, and it was not until the next morning that Mr. Fogg and his companions found themselves on the New York steamer, of which the destination was Liverpool. This steamer was the China, a magnificent iron propellor, which had started for Liverpool at eleven o’clock on Wednesday, December 11th. Mr. Fogg was therefore face to face with a final misfortune. The China, on which he had counted, had sailed twelve hours before he arrived. It was not the first steamer he had missed. He had missed the Hallifiax at San Francisco, and the Canada at New York, but in each case the next steamer was to sail immediately. This time the China was the last steamer that could serve his purpose. The other lines of steamers, the French Transatlantic, the White Star, the Inman, the Cunard, and the Guion, either starting from New York or neighbouring ports, could not complete the voyage in time. For example, the French line did not leave until the 14th of December, and the time it required—thirteen days and a half—would bring them into Havre too late. It was evident that Phileas Fogg’s last hope was shattered. The situation was grave. For a man who was invariably exact, to miss his connection by a few hours, after having gone over the globe, was heartrending. Phileas Fogg, however, did not betray the slightest disappointment; but Aouda, who stood beside him and could read his thoughts, saw the despair written in his face. “Oh, sir,” said she, “why did you not take me with you? This disaster would not have happened, for I am sure I have brought you misfortune.” “You, madam!” returned Mr. Fogg, warmly. “You are the cause of my good fortune, and if I have come this far, it is because of you. But do not blame yourself, for you are not in the least responsible for this reverse; what was to happen has happened, and we must bear it.” “But what are we to do?” asked Passepartout, who was no less discouraged. “We must think,” replied Mr. Fogg. Passepartout and Aouda exchanged a glance. But they did not know what to expect from Mr. Fogg. It is true that the expedition was ruined. Fogg had missed the China, and had now only one resource, and that was to take passage in a vessel, not in a steamer, and make for Europe. But as he had to be in London on the 21st at a quarter to nine in the evening, he had only nine days and thirteen hours and forty-five minutes left, which was not enough time to cross the Atlantic, even under canvas, unless he met with favourable winds, which was not very probable at that time of the year.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The party crossed the Hudson in the Jersey City ferryboat, and drove in a carriage to the St. Nicholas Hotel, on Broadway. At the hotel, Fogg meticulously consulted his notes, calculating the time difference. A grim realization dawned; despite their haste across America, they were behind schedule. Just as they prepared to depart for the Reform Club, Detective Fix confronted them, presenting a warrant for Fogg's arrest. Passepartout, in a fury, swiftly knocked Fix down. The crucial minutes ticked away. Fogg was briefly detained at the police station but released immediately upon learning the real robber had been caught. Rushing home, they arrived believing their incredible journey had ended in failure and ruin.

events.title: Fogg's Solo Search for Passage
detailed_summary: Fogg leaves the hotel by himself.
He instructs Passepartout to stay behind and ensure Aouda is prepared for a potentially sudden departure.
Fogg proceeds to the banks of the Hudson River.
He meticulously scans the numerous vessels moored or anchored, searching for one suitable for immediate departure.
He notes that while many ships are preparing to leave with the morning tide, demonstrating the port's busyness, most are sailing ships.
Fogg recognizes that sailing vessels lack the necessary speed and are therefore useless for his purpose.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Fogg left the hotel alone, after giving Passepartout instructions to await his return, and inform Aouda to be ready at an instant’s notice.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But they were mostly sailing vessels, of which, of course, Phileas Fogg could make no use.

events.text_segment: Mr. Fogg left the hotel alone, after giving Passepartout instructions to await his return, and inform Aouda to be ready at an instant’s notice. He proceeded to the banks of the Hudson, and looked about among the vessels moored or anchored in the river, for any that were about to depart. Several had departure signals, and were preparing to put to sea at morning tide; for in this immense and admirable port there is not one day in a hundred that vessels do not set out for every quarter of the globe. But they were mostly sailing vessels, of which, of course, Phileas Fogg could make no use.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Mr. Fogg left the hotel alone, after giving Passepartout instructions to await his return, and inform Aouda to be ready at an instant’s notice. He repaired to the banks of the Hudson, and, in the midst of the dense fog, scrutinised the vessels lying at anchor or moored along the quay. There were many of them getting ready for sea; it was the hour when they were usually starting for California, and the southern isles. But most of them were sailing vessels, and were therefore of no use to Mr. Fogg.

Three thousand ships are constantly anchored in it; and at least a hundred a day leave it for all parts of the globe. But most of them were sailing vessels, and were therefore of no use to Mr. Fogg.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The worthy fellow obeyed, and sat down tranquilly to wait for Mr. Fogg. An hour after, Mr. Fogg returned, and seeing Aouda ready, and Passepartout awaiting him, he asked if the steamer was not yet signalled. 'Not yet, sir,' replied Passepartout. 'This steamer must be late,' said Mr. Fogg. 'However,' he added, 'it is well for us to be ready to embark when she arrives.' Aouda was also awaiting with impatience the moment of departure. Passepartout, with his nose against the window-panes, was looking seaward.

events.title: Spotting the "Henrietta"
detailed_summary: Just as his hopes seem to dwindle, Fogg observes a trading vessel anchored near the Battery.
The ship possesses a screw propeller and its smoking funnel indicates it is actively preparing to depart soon.
Acting quickly, Fogg hails a small boat.
He gets into the boat and is rowed out to the vessel.
He boards the ship, which is identified as the "Henrietta," noted for its iron hull and wooden upper structure.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He seemed about to give up all hope, when he espied, anchored at the Battery, a cable’s length off at most, a trading vessel, with a screw, well-shaped, whose funnel, puffing a cloud of smoke, indicated that she was getting ready for departure.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He ascended to the deck, and asked for the captain, who forthwith presented himself.

events.text_segment:
He seemed about to give up all hope, when he espied, anchored at the Battery, a cable’s length off at most, a trading vessel, with a screw, well-shaped, whose funnel, puffing a cloud of smoke, indicated that she was getting ready for departure.
Phileas Fogg hailed a boat, got into it, and soon found himself on board the “Henrietta,” iron-hulled, wood-built above. He ascended to the deck, and asked for the captain, who forthwith presented himself.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: He seemed about to give up all hope, when he espied, anchored at the Battery, a cable’s length off at most, a trading vessel, with a screw, well-shaped, whose funnel, puffing a cloud of smoke, indicated that she was getting ready for departure. Phileas Fogg hailed a small boat, leaped into it, and in a few moments was alongside the Henrietta, iron-hulled, with the upper works of wood, and commanded by Captain Andrew Speedy.
