events.title: Confronting Captain Speedy
detailed_summary: Fogg encounters the ship's captain, Andrew Speedy, described as a fifty-year-old, rugged "sea-wolf" type from Cardiff.
Speedy confirms he is the captain and the ship, the "Henrietta," is departing within the hour.
He states his destination is Bordeaux and clarifies he is sailing without freight ("in ballast").
Speedy explicitly states he never takes passengers, finding them inconvenient.
He confirms the vessel's speed capability is between eleven and twelve knots.
Fogg directly requests passage for himself and three others to Liverpool.
Captain Speedy bluntly refuses, reiterating his unchangeable destination is Bordeaux.
Speedy dismisses Fogg's inquiry about cost, indicating money is not a deciding factor.
The captain asserts his sole ownership of the vessel when Fogg attempts to appeal to potential owners.
He rejects Fogg's offers to freight or even buy the ship.
Fogg remains outwardly calm, but recognizes the gravity of the situation, as his usual reliance on money to overcome obstacles has failed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He was a man of fifty, a sort of sea-wolf, with big eyes, a complexion of oxidised copper, red hair and thick neck, and a growling voice.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Now money failed.

events.text_segment:
He was a man of fifty, a sort of sea-wolf, with big eyes, a complexion of oxidised copper, red hair and thick neck, and a growling voice.
“The captain?” asked Mr. Fogg.
“I am the captain.”
“I am Phileas Fogg, of London.”
“And I am Andrew Speedy, of Cardiff.”
“You are going to put to sea?”
“In an hour.”
“You are bound for—”
“Bordeaux.”
“And your cargo?”
“No freight. Going in ballast.”
“Have you any passengers?”
“No passengers. Never have passengers. Too much in the way.”
“Is your vessel a swift one?”
“Between eleven and twelve knots. The “Henrietta,” well known.”
“Will you carry me and three other persons to Liverpool?”
“To Liverpool? Why not to China?”
“I said Liverpool.”
“No!”
“No?”
“No. I am setting out for Bordeaux, and shall go to Bordeaux.”
“Money is no object?”
“None.”
The captain spoke in a tone which did not admit of a reply.
“But the owners of the ‘Henrietta’—” resumed Phileas Fogg.
“The owners are myself,” replied the captain. “The vessel belongs to me.”
“I will freight it for you.”
“No.”
“I will buy it of you.”
“No.”
Phileas Fogg did not betray the least disappointment; but the situation was a grave one. It was not at New York as at Hong Kong, nor with the captain of the “Henrietta” as with the captain of the “Tankadere.” Up to this time money had smoothed away every obstacle. Now money failed.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
He was a man of fifty, a sort of sea-wolf, with big eyes, a complexion of oxidised copper, red hair and thick neck, and a growling voice. "Are you the captain?" asked Phileas Fogg of this man. "I am the captain." "I am Phileas Fogg, of London." "Hoo! hoo!" growled the captain, with a knowing smile. "Mr. Fogg, eh?" "And this is my servant Passepartout." "Hoo! hoo!" "This is Sir Francis Cromarty." "Hoo! hoo!" "and this is Aouda, who is my companion." "Hoo! hoo!" reiterated the seaman, who seemed to have a singular penchant for this interjection; "so you are the travellers from India, eh?" "We are." "And you are going to Liverpool?" asked the captain. "No." "To Bordeaux?" "No; to Liverpool," replied Mr. Fogg. "No go. I am bound for Bordeaux, and shall sail within an hour." "No go," repeated Phileas Fogg, perfectly calm, "I offer you 
£2000 for the passage of myself and three others to Liverpool." "No go. Not if you paid me 
£6000." "Is the ship your own?" "Yes; and I am sailing in ballast. I've a cargo of casks in the hold, and nothing else. I never take passengers. Passengers are only in the way." "I offer you 
£8000." "No go. My course is set for Bordeaux, and I'm going to Bordeaux." "But the owners of the 'Henrietta'...?" asked Phileas Fogg. "The owners are myself," replied the captain, curtly. "I'm not only captain, but owner." "I offer you 
£10,000," said Mr. Fogg. "No go. Though you offered me 
£20,000, I should not cross the Atlantic otherwise than to Bordeaux." Phileas Fogg, without changing his expression, then said, very quietly, "I will buy your ship of you." "No. I won't sell it." "But I will freight it for you." "No. I will not freight it. I am bound for Bordeaux, and go." It was a last blow. Money, contrary to 
admirable
 Crichton's opinion, was not able to over come this obstacle. Phileas Fogg had come upon a man as inflexible as himself.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: He was a man of fifty, a sort of sea-wolf, with big eyes, a complexion of oxidised copper, red hair and thick neck, and a growling voice. Captain Speedy, commander of the steam-vessel Henrietta, was a man who lived up to his name in temper, if not always in speed across the waves. He was a stubborn, cantankerous old sailor, fiercely independent and utterly contemptuous of delay or inconvenience caused by others. His gruff exterior and explosive temper were legendary amongst those who knew him or had the misfortune of doing business with him. When Phileas Fogg and his companions arrived, desperate for passage to Liverpool, they found themselves confronted by this formidable and unreasonable individual. Speedy was in a foul mood, exasperated by a delayed crew and the prospect of his own schedule being disrupted. He was utterly unwilling to entertain Fogg’s proposition for passage, dismissing their urgency with harsh, dismissive words. His initial response was a flat, emphatic refusal, punctuated by oaths and gesticulations. He seemed to relish the opportunity to refuse the refined Englishman and his unusual request. He was a man who prided himself on his independence and his adherence to his own plans, and the idea of altering them for a passenger, especially one as peculiar and insistent as Fogg, was deeply offensive to his nature. He saw it as an imposition, an attempt to bend his will to another's, something he would not tolerate. It was clear that conventional negotiation would yield nothing from this obstinate captain. His resistance was absolute, his resolve seemingly unbreakable. He stood firm, a bulwark of nautical obstinacy, against the tide of Fogg's quiet, yet persistent, logic.

events.title: A Change of Tactics: Securing Passage to Bordeaux
detailed_summary: Fogg considers the necessity of finding some boat transport across the Atlantic, briefly dismissing the impracticality of balloon travel.
He devises a new strategy and asks Captain Speedy if he would take the party to his intended destination, Bordeaux.
Speedy initially scoffs, saying he wouldn't even for two hundred dollars.
Fogg then makes a substantial offer of two thousand dollars per passenger.
Upon realizing this amounts to eight thousand dollars for the four passengers, Captain Speedy hesitates, scratching his head.
The significant financial incentive overrides his aversion to passengers, whom he now mentally categorizes as valuable cargo rather than nuisances.
Speedy curtly agrees to take them to Bordeaux, confirming the departure time is nine o'clock.
Fogg simply states that he and his party will be on board by then.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Still, some means must be found to cross the Atlantic on a boat, unless by balloon—which would have been venturesome, besides not being capable of being put in practice.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “We will be on board at nine o’clock,” replied, no less simply, Mr. Fogg.

events.text_segment:
Still, some means must be found to cross the Atlantic on a boat, unless by balloon—which would have been venturesome, besides not being capable of being put in practice. It seemed that Phileas Fogg had an idea, for he said to the captain, “Well, will you carry me to Bordeaux?”
“No, not if you paid me two hundred dollars.”
“I offer you two thousand.”
“Apiece?”
“Apiece.”
“And there are four of you?”
“Four.”
Captain Speedy began to scratch his head. There were eight thousand dollars to gain, without changing his route; for which it was well worth conquering the repugnance he had for all kinds of passengers. Besides, passengers at two thousand dollars are no longer passengers, but valuable merchandise. “I start at nine o’clock,” said Captain Speedy, simply. “Are you and your party ready?”
“We will be on board at nine o’clock,” replied, no less simply, Mr. Fogg.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Still, some means must be found to cross the Atlantic on a boat, unless by balloon—which would have been venturesome, besides not being capable of being put in practice. But Phileas Fogg was as if inspired, and was seeking the realisation of an idea which had occurred to him. When he had discovered Captain Speedy, he accosted him, and asked if he would take him and his four companions to Bordeaux. “To Bordeaux?” growled the captain; “I wouldn’t go so far for two hundred dollars. “I will give you two thousand.” “Apiece?” “Apiece.” “Including you?” “Including me and the others.” Four passengers at two thousand dollars each makes eight thousand dollars. Eight thousand dollars! Egad! Captain Speedy, who prided himself on not taking passengers, and who had always avoided doing so, scratched his head. Passengers, at the figure, are no longer passengers, but valuable cargo. “I’ll go,” said Captain Speedy, curtly. “When can you start?” “In an hour. My men are just putting aboard the coal, and I am getting up steam.” “All right. I will be on board with my party, before then.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Still, some means must be found to cross the Atlantic on a boat, unless by balloon—which would have been venturesome, besides not being capable of being put in practice. But Mr. Fogg was not thinking of a balloon. He was only thinking of how to get a vessel. A vessel of some sort or other was absolutely necessary to cross the Atlantic in time. Phileas Fogg, after consulting the Annalen des Seewesens, ascertained that a steamer named the Henrietta, a screw-propeller, 2,500 tons, belonging to the Liverpool packet company, was to leave that very evening for Bordeaux. This was not the route for him. If a vessel was leaving for Bombay, or Calcutta, or Hong Kong, or Shanghai, or Yokohama, or any other part of the world, Mr. Fogg would have gone on board; but a steamer for Bordeaux, and thence by rail to Paris and London—that would have destroyed all he had done. Mr. Fogg did not wish to go to London by Bordeaux and Paris. He wished to go by the direct route.

events.title: Swift Return and Departure on the "Henrietta"
detailed_summary: It is now half-past eight, leaving only thirty minutes before the scheduled departure.
Fogg executes his plan with remarkable speed and characteristic coolness.
He disembarks the "Henrietta," hails a carriage, speeds back to the St. Nicholas Hotel.
He efficiently gathers Aouda, Passepartout, and the ever-present Fix.
Fogg successfully returns with the entire party to the "Henrietta" just as the ship is preparing to weigh anchor.
Upon learning the cost of this unexpected voyage segment, Passepartout lets out a long, expressive sound of shock.

Fix internally muses that the Bank of England is unlikely to fare well financially in this affair, estimating that Fogg's expenditures will have already surpassed seven thousand pounds by the time they reach England.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was half-past eight.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: When they reached England, even if Mr. Fogg did not throw some handfuls of bank-bills into the sea, more than seven thousand pounds would have been spent!

events.text_segment:
It was half-past eight. To disembark from the “Henrietta,” jump into a hack, hurry to the St. Nicholas, and return with Aouda, Passepartout, and even the inseparable Fix was the work of a brief time, and was performed by Mr. Fogg with the coolness which never abandoned him. They were on board when the “Henrietta” made ready to weigh anchor.
When Passepartout heard what this last voyage was going to cost, he uttered a prolonged “Oh!” which extended throughout his vocal gamut.
As for Fix, he said to himself that the Bank of England would certainly not come out of this affair well indemnified. When they reached England, even if Mr. Fogg did not throw some handfuls of bank-bills into the sea, more than seven thousand pounds would have been spent!

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: It was half-past eight. The weather was cold and clear, and the polar star glittered brightly. The engineer's whistle sounded, and the captain said, “Any passengers?” “No!” replied the second mate, who was on the deck. “Go ahead!” Then the steamer jingled, and began to move slowly out of the harbour. Phileas Fogg was then on the deck, with Aouda, Passepartout, and the inevitable Fix. It is true that Fogg, having in his pocket the bank-notes which he had drawn from his New York bank, had been excusable for not coming sooner. When he left the "Henrietta" with his three companions, he was surprised to find that there were only a few minutes before the advertised time of sailing. He hailed a carriage, and the driver was ordered to drive quickly to the St. Nicholas Hotel. This was on Broadway, at a short distance from the harbour. They alighted, and Fogg, having paid the cabman, rushed into the hotel, and ran up to the third floor, where he had rooms. He knocked at the door, and it was opened by Aouda, who was just leaving. Passepartout followed her, and Fix came after. Fogg led the way back to the carriage, and they drove rapidly to the harbour. They got on board the "Henrietta" just as the vessel was getting ready to weigh anchor. "This is a dear passage!" cried Passepartout, with a long, expressive sound. "What did it cost?" asked Fix, aside. "Seven thousand pounds," said Fogg. "Seven thousand pounds!" echoed Passepartout. "I am sure the Bank of England is not going to get off cheap in this affair," muttered Fix to himself. "Seven thousand pounds! It is a great deal of money. But the money will not be lost. We shall get to England in time. If we lose the money, we will be ruined. But we shall not lose it. We are going to get there in time." Passepartout was in despair. He thought of the seven thousand pounds, and he groaned. "It is a shame," he said. "It is a crime. It is an assassination. Seven thousand pounds for a passage across the Atlantic! It is too much. It is infamous. It is abominable. It is frightful. It is terrible. It is horrible."

There were five or six passengers in the carriage, among them a general officer, a brigadier-major, and a young lady of some distinction, going, it was rumoured, to the continent on a matrimonial errand. Mr. Fogg had made his calculations, and knew that they would arrive in Paris at seven o’clock the same evening. The journey from London to Paris occupied seven hours. Phileas Fogg was one of those perfectly punctual people, who, though on a journey, are always on time. He carried

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXXIII. IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG SHOWS HIMSELF EQUAL TO THE OCCASION

events.title: Fogg Takes Command of the Henrietta
detailed_summary: The Henrietta departs New York City, heading east.
Phileas Fogg is revealed to be commanding the ship from the bridge, not Captain Speedy.
Captain Speedy is confined to his cabin, vocally expressing his fury.
Fogg, initially denied passage to Liverpool by Speedy, had booked for Bordeaux.
During the first thirty hours, Fogg used his money to persuade the temporary crew, who disliked Speedy, to mutiny and follow his orders.
Fogg now directs the ship towards Liverpool, demonstrating considerable seamanship.
Aouda feels apprehensive but remains silent.
Passepartout considers Fogg's takeover a brilliant move.
The ship maintains a speed of eleven to twelve knots as predicted by the former captain.
Potential obstacles like rough seas, adverse winds, or mechanical failures still pose risks to completing the voyage in the required nine days (by December 21st).
The narrator notes that Fogg's actions regarding the ship, combined with the bank robbery suspicion, could lead to future complications.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: An hour after, the “Henrietta” passed the lighthouse which marks the entrance of the Hudson, turned the point of Sandy Hook, and put to sea.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It is true that, once arrived, the affair on board the “Henrietta,” added to that of the Bank of England, might create more difficulties for Mr. Fogg than he imagined or could desire.

events.text_segment:
An hour after, the “Henrietta” passed the lighthouse which marks the entrance of the Hudson, turned the point of Sandy Hook, and put to sea. During the day she skirted Long Island, passed Fire Island, and directed her course rapidly eastward.
At noon the next day, a man mounted the bridge to ascertain the vessel’s position. It might be thought that this was Captain Speedy. Not the least in the world. It was Phileas Fogg, Esquire. As for Captain Speedy, he was shut up in his cabin under lock and key, and was uttering loud cries, which signified an anger at once pardonable and excessive.
What had happened was very simple. Phileas Fogg wished to go to Liverpool, but the captain would not carry him there. Then Phileas Fogg had taken passage for Bordeaux, and, during the thirty hours he had been on board, had so shrewdly managed with his banknotes that the sailors and stokers, who were only an occasional crew, and were not on the best terms with the captain, went over to him in a body. This was why Phileas Fogg was in command instead of Captain Speedy; why the captain was a prisoner in his cabin; and why, in short, the “Henrietta” was directing her course towards Liverpool. It was very clear, to see Mr. Fogg manage the craft, that he had been a sailor.
How the adventure ended will be seen anon. Aouda was anxious, though she said nothing. As for Passepartout, he thought Mr. Fogg’s manœuvre simply glorious. The captain had said “between eleven and twelve knots,” and the “Henrietta” confirmed his prediction.
If, then—for there were “ifs” still—the sea did not become too boisterous, if the wind did not veer round to the east, if no accident happened to the boat or its machinery, the “Henrietta” might cross the three thousand miles from New York to Liverpool in the nine days, between the 12th and the 21st of December. It is true that, once arrived, the affair on board the “Henrietta,” added to that of the Bank of England, might create more difficulties for Mr. Fogg than he imagined or could desire.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: An hour after, the “Henrietta” passed the lighthouse which marks the entrance of the Hudson, turned the point of Sandy Hook, and put to sea. During the day the vessel skirted the Long Island coast, passing the Fire Island light, and towards evening steamed rapidly offshore from the New York shores. The next day, January 12th, at noon, a man mounted the bridge to take the sun’s altitude. It would be thought, of course, that this man was Captain Speedy. Not at all. It was Phileas Fogg, accompanied by Passepartout, who held the chronometer, and by Aouda, who looked on with an anxious countenance. As for Captain Speedy, he was securely locked up in his cabin, and was uttering deafening cries, which proved his great wrath. The situation of affairs, in effect, was as follows: Phileas Fogg, having, in spite of the captain’s teeth, taken passage on the “Henrietta,” did so in order to go to Liverpool. When he paid his fare, he thought he was going to Bordeaux, and on the strength of this made himself comfortably on board. But during the first twenty-four hours, Fogg had seen that, by steering directly for Liverpool, he would gain a much longer time than by touching at Bordeaux, and then taking a French steamer to reach England. He could not, however, force Captain Speedy, to change his course. What was to be done? Phileas Fogg had an idea, but a dangerous one, which he determined to carry out. The “Henrietta” was a paddle-wheel steamer, and the propeller might be damaged or broken. Besides, the hull was not sheathed with iron, and the sails could not help the engine; for it was a steamer and not a sailing vessel. Nevertheless, she was still a good vessel, and might be driven at good speed. Fogg had bought for himself the right of using her. Captain Speedy did not know that Fogg had paid him for the use of his vessel at the rate of five hundred dollars per day, besides the ordinary fare. So Fogg did not hesitate to take command of her, and, after having shut the captain up in his cabin, he had called the sailors together, who were not much attached to Speedy, and proposed to take them to Liverpool. There was no hesitation, for there were some cases full of gold. During the first thirty hours, the “Henrietta” had steered due east, but at night, upon Passepartout’s suggestion, she was put directly towards Liverpool. She proceeded at a speed of eleven to twelve knots, and in nine days, if the sea was not too rough, and if the wind was not too contrary, and if there were no accidents to the machine, the “Henrietta” might reach Liverpool by the 21st of December. Phileas Fogg was on the bridge, looking as if he knew the matter well. Aouda was anxious, but said nothing. Passepartout considered the matter to be one of unexampled audacity and skill. As for the engineer, the stokers, and the seamen, they were quite pleased with the change. The captain had annoyed them by his ill-temper and caprices. Now they were in for it, and were to be led on by a quiet and generous man. In the meantime, the poor captain, shut up in his cabin, was swearing and storming. He would be released when he should be no longer able to prevent the vessel from sailing for Liverpool. Phileas Fogg had committed an act which, along with the suspected robbery of the bank, might be very prejudicial to his future. But he was quite self-possessed. He was not thinking of the future, but only of the present.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: An hour after, the “Henrietta” passed the lighthouse which marks the entrance of the Hudson, turned the point of Sandy Hook, and put to sea. During the day and night, the steamer went at full steam, struggling bravely against the wind. The screw laboured, the waves beat upon the deck, but the `Henrietta' moved rapidly on her course. Phileas Fogg remained as impassible as ever. He had not been successful in obtaining the captain's permission to increase the speed by putting on more coal, but he had been able to arrange for the ship to keep moving at its highest possible speed. Still, she did her best, urged on by the peculiar circumstances. Passepartout was becoming more and more anxious. He knew the crucial nature of every hour and minute, and he watched the sea and skies with growing unease. Fix, too, observed the ship's progress, his motives vastly different. He was anxious Fogg arrive in London before the deadline, still clinging to the hope of arresting him there. His position was awkward; he was effectively helping the man he suspected of being a criminal complete his escape, all while bound by the necessity of reaching English soil to exercise his authority. The three unlikely companions – the imperturbable gentleman, the anxious valet, and the conflicted detective – were thus united on deck, absorbed in their own thoughts and fears regarding the outcome of this final, desperate leg. The weather remained relatively fair, though choppy seas reminded them of the ocean's power. Captain Speedy, frustrated by Fogg's actions, nevertheless drove the vessel forward with professional determination. He might be kidnapped, but he would not be accused of slacking. The engines roared, the steam hissed, and the kilometres fell behind them, but would it be enough? The time difference, which had previously favoured Fogg, was now against him, or at least neutralised. Every moment lost was irrecoverable, eating into the small remaining margin. The race against the clock was entering its final, most critical phase, and the fate of Phileas Fogg's wager, and perhaps his reputation, hung precariously in the balance upon the heaving bosom of the Atlantic.

events.title: Smooth Sailing and Character Reactions
detailed_summary: The initial part of the voyage proceeds without major issues.
The sea conditions are favorable, the wind holds steady from the north-east, and the ship makes good progress under sail and steam.
Passepartout is overjoyed by his master's bold actions, oblivious to potential negative outcomes.
He becomes very popular with the crew, impressing them with his agility and positive attitude, praising their seamanship and the stokers' efforts.
His cheerful demeanor spreads throughout the ship.
He puts past troubles behind him, focusing solely on the imminent successful conclusion of the journey, occasionally becoming very impatient.
He frequently observes Fix with suspicion but avoids interaction due to their broken relationship.
Fix is utterly bewildered by Fogg's actions – commandeering a ship, bribing a crew, and expertly sailing it.
He speculates that Fogg, having stolen money, might now be acting as a pirate, planning to sail the Henrietta to a safe haven rather than Liverpool.
The detective regrets becoming involved in the pursuit.
Captain Speedy remains locked away, loudly protesting.
Passepartout delivers Speedy's meals cautiously.
Fogg appears completely indifferent to the presence of the imprisoned captain.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: During the first days, they went along smoothly enough.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mr. Fogg did not seem even to know that there was a captain on board.

events.text_segment:
During the first days, they went along smoothly enough. The sea was not very unpropitious, the wind seemed stationary in the north-east, the sails were hoisted, and the “Henrietta” ploughed across the waves like a real transatlantic steamer.
Passepartout was delighted. His master’s last exploit, the consequences of which he ignored, enchanted him. Never had the crew seen so jolly and dexterous a fellow. He formed warm friendships with the sailors, and amazed them with his acrobatic feats. He thought they managed the vessel like gentlemen, and that the stokers fired up like heroes. His loquacious good-humour infected everyone. He had forgotten the past, its vexations and delays. He only thought of the end, so nearly accomplished; and sometimes he boiled over with impatience, as if heated by the furnaces of the “Henrietta.” Often, also, the worthy fellow revolved around Fix, looking at him with a keen, distrustful eye; but he did not speak to him, for their old intimacy no longer existed.
Fix, it must be confessed, understood nothing of what was going on. The conquest of the “Henrietta,” the bribery of the crew, Fogg managing the boat like a skilled seaman, amazed and confused him. He did not know what to think. For, after all, a man who began by stealing fifty-five thousand pounds might end by stealing a vessel; and Fix was not unnaturally inclined to conclude that the “Henrietta” under Fogg’s command, was not going to Liverpool at all, but to some part of the world where the robber, turned into a pirate, would quietly put himself in safety. The conjecture was at least a plausible one, and the detective began to seriously regret that he had embarked on the affair.
As for Captain Speedy, he continued to howl and growl in his cabin; and Passepartout, whose duty it was to carry him his meals, courageous as he was, took the greatest precautions. Mr. Fogg did not seem even to know that there was a captain on board.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: During the first days, they went along smoothly enough. The sea was not very rough, the wind seemed stationary in the north-east, and the sails were spread, Phileas Fogg having purchased them as well as the vessel. The Henrietta kept straight on her course, and the first four thousand miles, from New York to the close of day on the 11th of December, were accomplished in eight and a half days. Phileas Fogg was as calm as ever. Passepartout was overjoyed at the turn of affairs. His master's boldness, the purchase of the boat, the navigation of which he now shared, filled him with unmixed delight. The worthy fellow was on the best terms with the crew, and was constantly astonishing them with his acrobatic feats. He and the sailors were two bodies with one soul. He took an interest in everything, and was sure to be found lending a hand wherever it was needed. He was perpetually encouraging the stokers, and exceedingly cordial with the engineer, who was rather a sulky fellow. Passepartout's spirit permeated the ship. He had forgotten the past, its troubles, delays, and anxieties. He only thought of the nearing future, and the speedy termination of the journey. There was a passenger on board, however, who shared neither his joy nor his good-humour. This was Fix, who did not cease to pace the deck, and who looked upon the daring move of Fogg as pure piracy. He was in a fever of anxiety, though he could not but admire the gentleman's energy, and was utterly bewildered by his coolness and perfect self-possession. He had no longer any doubt that Fogg was a criminal, and a criminal, besides, who was about to land with his plunder at some unknown, far-distant, and inaccessible port. The conjecture that Phileas Fogg, when he reached Liverpool, would calmly walk into court, did not seem at all probable now. Fix was in a quandary, and heartily regretted that he had had anything at all to do with an affair which was turning out so badly. As for Captain Speedy, he continued fuming in his cabin, and Passepartout, whose duty it was to carry him his meals, so placid and calm as to make it appear that nothing unusual was going on. Speedy's wrath at first knew no bounds. The poor man would have paid a hundred thousand dollars to have been able to extricate himself from his predicament. He blustered and blasphemed, but the walls of the cabin were solid, and the sailors, whom he did his best to conciliate, were in the interest of Fogg, and only laughed at his wrath. They had their owners to deal with, after all, and the Henrietta, instead of sailing for Liverpool, was running at full speed towards the east. Phileas Fogg took no notice of the captain's outbursts.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The Mediterranean was kind, and the steamship Mongolia was not too rocky. Passepartout was as cheerful as ever. He had been very much concerned about the fifteen days' difference between London and Shanghai, and the thirty days' difference between Shanghai and San Francisco; and he had been in constant alarm lest the various clocks should be regulated by the meridian of Paris, and not by that of Greenwich; for, though a Frenchman, he was compelled to admit that the English are more accurate than the French in the matter of timekeeping. He therefore spent his time in regulating his watch by the ship's clock, and was for ever running to the officer to ask him the time and the ship's speed. There were twenty knots registered during the twenty-four hours, and Passepartout was delighted. He no longer felt any doubts about the success of the tour. He thought the fifteen days in which they were to get from Bombay to Calcutta were a good deal of time, and that the trip round the world would be accomplished, and the programme followed out in every respect. There were a number of passengers on board, some going to Bombay, some to Calcutta, some to Singapore, some to China, and some to Japan. There were also some officers of the English army, who were returning to their posts. The weather was fine, and they had a pleasant voyage. Passepartout made friends with the officers and the other passengers, and told them all about his master and the journey round the world. He was never tired of praising Mr. Fogg, and extolling his generosity. One of the officers told him that he had travelled a great deal in India, and that it was a very interesting country. Passepartout was very anxious to see India, and to visit the temples and the mosques. He also wanted to see the elephants and the tigers. Mr. Fogg, meanwhile, had shut himself up in his cabin, and was studying his Bradshaw, with the help of a pocket map of the world. He spent the greater part of the day in this way. At meals, he would sit down at the table d'hôte, and speak to no one. He was a very quiet man, and did not like to talk. He would eat his dinner, and then go back to his cabin.

events.title: Storm Hits the Atlantic Crossing
detailed_summary: The ship reaches the hazardous Banks of Newfoundland.
Weather conditions deteriorate, foreshadowed by a falling barometer the previous evening.
The temperature drops, and the wind shifts to the south-east.
This shift is problematic, forcing Fogg to furl the sails to stay on course and rely solely on steam.
The ship's speed diminishes due to rough seas with large waves breaking over the stern.
The vessel pitches violently, hindering its progress.
The wind intensifies into a storm, raising concerns about the ship's stability.
Passepartout's mood darkens, and he endures two days of intense fear.
Phileas Fogg, however, proves himself a courageous and skilled mariner, maintaining course and steam power.
The Henrietta often cuts through waves rather than riding over them, frequently washing the deck but remaining intact.
Sometimes the propeller lifts out of the water when the stern is raised by large waves, but the ship maintains its heading.
The storm doesn't reach hurricane intensity but persists.
Crucially, the wind remains fixed in the south-east, making the sails unusable for assisting their eastward journey.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: On the 13th they passed the edge of the Banks of Newfoundland, a dangerous locality; during the winter, especially, there are frequent fogs and heavy gales of wind.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It continued fresh, but, unhappily, it remained obstinately in the south-east, rendering the sails useless.

events.text_segment:
On the 13th they passed the edge of the Banks of Newfoundland, a dangerous locality; during the winter, especially, there are frequent fogs and heavy gales of wind. Ever since the evening before the barometer, suddenly falling, had indicated an approaching change in the atmosphere; and during the night the temperature varied, the cold became sharper, and the wind veered to the south-east.
This was a misfortune. Mr. Fogg, in order not to deviate from his course, furled his sails and increased the force of the steam; but the vessel’s speed slackened, owing to the state of the sea, the long waves of which broke against the stern. She pitched violently, and this retarded her progress. The breeze little by little swelled into a tempest, and it was to be feared that the “Henrietta” might not be able to maintain herself upright on the waves.
Passepartout’s visage darkened with the skies, and for two days the poor fellow experienced constant fright. But Phileas Fogg was a bold mariner, and knew how to maintain headway against the sea; and he kept on his course, without even decreasing his steam. The “Henrietta,” when she could not rise upon the waves, crossed them, swamping her deck, but passing safely. Sometimes the screw rose out of the water, beating its protruding end, when a mountain of water raised the stern above the waves; but the craft always kept straight ahead.
The wind, however, did not grow as boisterous as might have been feared; it was not one of those tempests which burst, and rush on with a speed of ninety miles an hour. It continued fresh, but, unhappily, it remained obstinately in the south-east, rendering the sails useless.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: On the 13th they passed the edge of the Banks of Newfoundland, a dangerous locality; during the winter, especially, there are frequent fogs and heavy gales of wind. But the sea was then comparatively calm, and the _Henrietta_ passed along without impediment. On the 14th, a tremendous gale set in, accompanied by rain, and the vessel was violently tossed. The wind, coming from the north-west, was favourable, and the captain would have still carried on sail but for the violence of the waves, which prevented his doing so. The ship lay-to under trysails, and pitched frightfully. The gale continued during the 15th. The weather, however, grew lighter, and the wind veered round to the south-west. The steam still aided the sails, and the _Henrietta_ made good progress. On the 16th, the wind was in the east, and the vessel still ploughed the waves with rapidity. But on the 17th, at about noon, the gale revived, and with extreme violence. The barometer sank low, and the storm, which was a hurricane, was accompanied by a frightful churning of the sea. The _Henrietta_, therefore, was obliged to lie-to again. The wind came from the south-east, and was dead against them. The captain furled his sails, and, relying on steam alone, struggled against the tremendous billows. In this situation the ship's speed was reduced to a minimum. The vessel pitched violently, and the waves broke over her from stern to stern. This was a trying time for Phileas Fogg. If he had been going to Liverpool, he would have put into some neighbouring port, and waited for the gale to subside. But he was going to New York, and to gain time, he was obliged to brave the storm. The _Henrietta_, though a strong ship and a good sailer, was not built to encounter hurricanes. However, she struggled bravely, sometimes riding over the waves, sometimes cutting through them, and, with the help of the steam, making some headway. Passepartout was in despair. He had been so confident in the speed of the vessel, and the near approach of land, that this check was a terrible blow to him. He could not eat, he could not sleep, and wandered about the deck like a ghost. Phileas Fogg, on the contrary, was perfectly calm, and looked upon the storm as a simple incident in the voyage. He had a good ship, and a good captain, and he felt certain that they would come through it all right. And, indeed, Captain Speedy showed himself equal to the occasion. He was a thorough sailor, and knew how to manage his vessel. The _Henrietta_ did not suffer much, though she was roughly used. Her decks were often under water, and the waves sometimes swept over her from stem to stern; but no serious damage was done. The storm continued with the same violence during the 18th. The wind still blew from the south-east, and the vessel could make but little progress. On the 19th, the gale began to abate. The wind shifted to the south-west, and the sea went down. The _Henrietta_ was able to set sail again, and made good speed towards her destination.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: On the 13th they passed the edge of the Banks of Newfoundland, a dangerous locality; during the winter, especially, there are frequent fogs and heavy gales of wind. The barometer had fallen perceptibly the evening before, and during the night the temperature decreased, and the wind shifted to the south-east. This was a serious obstacle. To keep on their course eastward, the Henrietta was obliged to furl her sails and rely solely on steam. The ship's speed was much diminished by the rough sea, the waves breaking over the stern. She pitched violently, and her progress was greatly impeded. The wind increased to a storm, and there were fears for the vessel's stability. Passepartout's mood darkened, and he endured two days of intense fear. But Phileas Fogg showed himself equal to the occasion, proving himself a courageous and skilful mariner. He maintained his course and kept up the steam. The Henrietta often cut through the waves instead of riding over them, and the deck was frequently washed; but the vessel held together. Sometimes the propeller was lifted out of the water when the stern was raised by a huge wave, but the ship kept her heading. The storm did not reach the intensity of a hurricane, but it was a violent gale, and it persisted. Crucially, the wind remained fixed in the south-east, rendering the sails useless for assisting their eastward journey.
simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.refinement_prompt:
IMPROVEMENT GUIDANCE:
1. MAJOR STRUCTURAL ISSUES:
- The completion introduces several invented events and extended timelines that are not present in the original, such as additional days of storms, changes in weather over multiple days, and references to specific dates beyond the initial one mentioned in the original passage.
- There are invented reflections and perspectives, including detailed emotional states and actions for both Passepartout and Fogg that go beyond what is described in the original.
- The completion adds new characters' actions and attributions, such as Captain Speedy's role and his management of the vessel, which are not part of the original excerpt.

2. MISSING ELEMENTS:
- The completion omits the original's detailed description of the atmospheric changes leading up to the storm, such as the barometer's behavior and the specific sequence of temperature and wind changes during the night.
- The original's account of the vessel's handling of the waves, including the technical details of how the ship crossed or rose upon the waves, is largely missing or replaced with more generic descriptions.
- The nuanced depiction of Passepartout's fear and its direct connection to the worsening weather is not fully captured; instead, the completion generalizes his despair over a longer period.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- The completion provides inaccurate timing by spreading the events over several days and assigning specific weather conditions to each, whereas the original focuses on a much shorter, more concentrated timeframe.
- The sequence of events is altered, with the completion describing calm seas followed by a series of storms, rather than the original's immediate onset of adverse conditions.
- The direction and impact of the wind are inaccurately described at various points, with changes in wind direction and its effects on the ship not matching the original progression.
- The completion attributes actions and decisions to characters (such as the captain's choices and Fogg's reasoning about ports) that are not present in the original passage.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: On the 13th they passed the edge of the Banks of Newfoundland, a dangerous locality; during the winter, especially, there are frequent fogs and heavy gales of wind. Phileas Fogg and his companions, however, were in no mood to heed such perils. Their thoughts were fixed solely upon reaching Liverpool by the 21st at noon. The Henrietta, though a sturdy vessel, was not built for speed against the elements, and the Captain, a gruff man named Speedy, began to show signs of impatience. The sea grew rougher, the sky darker, and the wind howled like a banshee around the rigging. On the 14th and 15th, the storm intensified. Waves crashed over the deck, making movement difficult and dangerous. Passengers were confined below, their faces pale with seasickness or anxiety. Aouda remained remarkably calm, watching Fogg with unwavering trust. Passepartout, despite his usual cheerful disposition, was less enthusiastic about this violent pitching and rolling. Fix, on the other hand, was consumed by a feverish agitation. Every hour of delay was torture to him. He paced the narrow confines of the cabin, cursing the elements that seemed determined to foil his plans. He watched Fogg closely, half-expecting him to betray some sign of worry, but the impassive gentleman remained serene, consulting his notebook and calculating the ship's progress with his usual precision. The storm became so violent that Speedy was forced to take extreme measures. The sails were torn or rendered useless by the furious gusts. The coal supply, though thought to be sufficient, was rapidly diminishing due to the engine being driven at maximum power against the formidable waves. Speedy, his face grim, informed Fogg that they could not maintain this speed much longer without more fuel. Fogg, without hesitation, suggested burning the wooden parts of the ship. This audacious proposal stunned Speedy, but seeing no other way to make their deadline, he agreed. The crew began dismantling cabins, masts, and anything combustible, feeding the hungry furnaces to push the Henrietta onward through the tempest.

events.title: Coal Shortage Crisis Emerges
detailed_summary: By December 16th, day 75, the voyage is roughly half complete without major delays, despite passing difficult areas.
Success seems likely in summer, but the winter season makes the outcome uncertain.
Passepartout remains hopeful, relying on the steam engines if the wind fails.
The ship's engineer approaches Fogg for a serious discussion.
Passepartout feels a sense of foreboding and strains to overhear their conversation.
He catches Fogg asking the engineer for confirmation of his statement.
The engineer confirms that while they had enough coal for a low-steam trip to Bordeaux, the constant high-steam usage means they lack sufficient coal to reach Liverpool.
Fogg calmly states he will consider the situation.
Passepartout grasps the critical nature of the problem: they are running out of coal.
He mutters that if Fogg can overcome this, he'll truly be remarkable.
He feels compelled to share the news with Fix.
Fix sarcastically asks if Passepartout still believes they are heading to Liverpool.
Passepartout affirms this, to which Fix replies dismissively, calling him an 'Ass'.
Passepartout is initially angered but stops himself, reasoning that Fix is likely bitter and embarrassed by his fruitless pursuit.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The 16th of December was the seventy-fifth day since Phileas Fogg’s departure from London, and the “Henrietta” had not yet been seriously delayed.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Passepartout was on the point of vigorously resenting the epithet, the reason of which he could not for the life of him comprehend; but he reflected that the unfortunate Fix was probably very much disappointed and humiliated in his self-esteem, after having so awkwardly followed a false scent around the world, and refrained.

events.text_segment:
The 16th of December was the seventy-fifth day since Phileas Fogg’s departure from London, and the “Henrietta” had not yet been seriously delayed. Half of the voyage was almost accomplished, and the worst localities had been passed. In summer, success would have been well-nigh certain. In winter, they were at the mercy of the bad season. Passepartout said nothing; but he cherished hope in secret, and comforted himself with the reflection that, if the wind failed them, they might still count on the steam.
On this day the engineer came on deck, went up to Mr. Fogg, and began to speak earnestly with him. Without knowing why it was a presentiment, perhaps Passepartout became vaguely uneasy. He would have given one of his ears to hear with the other what the engineer was saying. He finally managed to catch a few words, and was sure he heard his master say, “You are certain of what you tell me?”
“Certain, sir,” replied the engineer. “You must remember that, since we started, we have kept up hot fires in all our furnaces, and, though we had coal enough to go on short steam from New York to Bordeaux, we haven’t enough to go with all steam from New York to Liverpool.” “I will consider,” replied Mr. Fogg.
Passepartout understood it all; he was seized with mortal anxiety. The coal was giving out! “Ah, if my master can get over that,” muttered he, “he’ll be a famous man!” He could not help imparting to Fix what he had overheard.
“Then you believe that we really are going to Liverpool?”
“Of course.”
“Ass!” replied the detective, shrugging his shoulders and turning on his heel.
Passepartout was on the point of vigorously resenting the epithet, the reason of which he could not for the life of him comprehend; but he reflected that the unfortunate Fix was probably very much disappointed and humiliated in his self-esteem, after having so awkwardly followed a false scent around the world, and refrained.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The 16th of December was the seventy-fifth day since Phileas Fogg’s departure from London, and the “Henrietta” had not yet been seriously delayed. Furious she must be, to get across the Atlantic in winter, as she could not but run against the terrible north-westers! But Phileas Fogg was one of those sailors who seemed to have vanquished the ocean itself. The “Henrietta” answered to his will, and went in any direction he desired. Passepartout was not now so anxious. As for Fix, he seemed utterly disheartened. Passepartout saw little of him. Fix was still on board, but had kept aloof in his cabin, and appeared to have given up all hope. No doubt he considered Phileas Fogg a lost man, and was wondering whether it was really worth his while to follow him further. Passepartout, on the other hand, was again full of life and hope. The near approach to the American coast filled him with delight. If the wind failed, they could fall back upon the steam. It is true that the “Henrietta,” with all her canvas spread and her engines working at full pressure, did not make more than ten miles an hour; but, if the wind held good, she might still make Liverpool. About the 17th or 18th it was presumed they would be there.

On the 16th, the day Passepartout had just recorded, the engineer came to Mr. Fogg, and began to consult with him. Passepartout pricked up his ears, and contrived to catch some words of their conversation.

“You are sure of that, sir?” asked Mr. Fogg.

“Sure, sir,” replied the engineer. “We have as much coal as we can carry for going at moderate speed. But, ever since we left New York, we have been under forced steam, and, if we burn it as we have been doing, we shall only have enough to carry us to Bordeaux, instead of Liverpool.”

“Ah, indeed!” said Mr. Fogg, with the same composure. “And when shall we be there?”

“In about twenty hours, sir, if we have good weather. That is, to-morrow evening.”

“Very well,” said Mr. Fogg. “Do not fail to inform me when we get to the end of our coal.”

And Mr. Fogg resumed his promenade.



Passepartout now understood the situation. There was not coal enough to carry them to Liverpool! “Ah, my dear master,” murmured he, “you will get over that, I am sure. If ever you were Phileas Fogg, you are so now!” And, his spirits rising, he went to find Fix.

“So, Mr. Fix,” said he, “you are still here? You haven’t left the boat?”

“No, Mr. Passepartout,” replied Fix, in a tone of vexation. “And you?”

“I am going to see the end of it,” returned Passepartout.

“Ah! To see the end of it?”

“Oh, I assure you that Mr. Fogg is going to make good his word!”

“Ah! You still believe in him?”

“Certainly! Don’t you?”

“No! I don’t! And what about your going to Liverpool?”

“Why, to Liverpool, of course!”

“Ass!” replied the detective, turning on his heel.

Passepartout was on the point of vigorously resenting this epithet, when he reflected that Fix’s disappointment rendered him irritable. Fix, too, was evidently mortified at having made so many useless journeys, and spent so much money in tracking a man whom he had been ordered to arrest at Hong Kong, and who was calmly pursuing his way around the world, at the rate of fifty miles a day! If Phileas Fogg should be innocent of the Hong Kong robbery, Fix would be the most ridiculous of detectives.

Furious she must be, to get across the Atlantic in winter, as she could not but run against the terrible north-westers! But Phileas Fogg was one of those sailors who seemed to have vanquished the ocean itself. The “Henrietta” answered to his will, and went in any direction he desired. Passepartout was not now so anxious. As for Fix, he seemed utterly disheartened. Passepartout saw little of him. Fix was still on board, but had kept aloof in his cabin, and appeared to have given up all hope. No doubt he considered Phileas Fogg a lost man, and was wondering whether it was really worth his while to follow him further. Passepartout, on the other hand, was again full of life and hope. The near approach to the American coast filled him with delight. If the wind failed, they could fall back upon the steam. It is true that the “Henrietta,” with all her canvas spread and her engines working at full pressure, did not make more than ten miles an hour; but, if the wind held good, she might still make Liverpool. About the 17th or 18th it was presumed they would be there.

IMPROVEMENT GUIDANCE:
1. MAJOR STRUCTURAL ISSUES:
- The completion introduces invented reflections and characterizations, particularly regarding Phileas Fogg's supposed mastery over the ocean and the "Henrietta" responding to his will, which are not present in the original.
- There is an added invented narrative about Fix's behavior, including him staying in his cabin and giving up hope, which does not appear in the original passage.
- The conversation between Passepartout and Fix is expanded with invented dialogue and additional exchanges that are not in the original.
- The completion includes invented speculation about arrival dates and travel speeds, which are not part of the original excerpt.
- The ending introduces invented internal reflections about Fix's feelings and the consequences of his pursuit, which are not present in the original.

2. MISSING ELEMENTS:
- The completion omits the original's specific mention of the season and the contrast between summer and winter conditions, as well as the sense of being at the mercy of the weather.
- Passepartout's internal hope and his secret comfort regarding the possibility of relying on steam if the wind fails are not fully captured.
- The original's depiction of Passepartout's anxiety upon overhearing the conversation and his specific reaction to the news about the coal shortage is not fully represented.
- The completion does not include the original's detail about Passepartout's desire to overhear the conversation between Fogg and the engineer, nor his method of catching a few words.
- The original's sequence where Passepartout imparts what he overheard to Fix is altered and expanded, missing the concise exchange and Passepartout's confusion about Fix's reaction.
- The reflection on Fix's disappointment and humiliation is present but is expanded with invented details rather than focusing on the original's concise reasoning.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- The completion provides inaccurate or invented timing details, such as the presumed arrival dates and travel speeds, which do not match the original.
- The sequence of events is altered: the completion introduces Passepartout's hope and Fix's despair before the engineer's conversation, whereas in the original, Passepartout's anxiety and hope are direct responses to the overheard conversation.
- The dialogue between Fogg and the engineer is altered, with invented questions and responses, and the engineer's statements about coal and timing are not accurate to the original.
- The completion attributes invented motivations and emotional states to Fix and Passepartout that are not present in the original, such as Fix's supposed withdrawal to his cabin and Passepartout's rising spirits after learning about the coal shortage.
- The order of Passepartout's reactions and his interaction with Fix is changed, and the nature of their exchange is expanded beyond the original's brief and pointed conversation.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The 16th of December was the seventy-fifth day since Phileas Fogg’s departure from London, and the “Henrietta” had not yet been seriously delayed. Under the forceful direction of Mr. Fogg, who had effectively chartered the vessel by agreeing to pay Captain Speedy an exorbitant sum for passage to Liverpool at maximum speed, the steamship ploughed through the Atlantic waves with relentless energy. Captain Speedy, initially reluctant and blustering, soon found himself compelled by Fogg’s calm determination and generous payments to push the Henrietta to her absolute limits. Every knot of speed was vital, as Fogg meticulously calculated their progress against the unforgiving schedule. However, the prodigious speed demanded a colossal consumption of coal. By the 18th of December, the seventy-seventh day, the engineer reported a grim reality: the coal bunkers were nearly empty, and they were still a considerable distance from the Irish coast, let alone Liverpool. Stopping to refuel was out of the question; it would mean certain failure. Phileas Fogg, faced with this crisis, exhibited no panic. Instead, he made a characteristic, audacious decision. He offered to buy the "Henrietta" from Captain Speedy for a sum far exceeding her value—fifty thousand dollars. Speedy, astonished but tempted by the offer for his rapidly consuming vessel, accepted. Having purchased the ship, Fogg instructed that everything combustible be used as fuel. Masts, spars, and the upper deck structures were systematically cut down and fed into the hungry furnaces. The cabins, bulkheads, and all wooden fittings followed, piece by piece, as the ship was dismantled from within to keep the engines running at full throttle. The air was thick with smoke, and the stripped vessel became a skeletal frame driven forward by sheer will and burning timber. By the 21st of December, the eightieth day of the journey, the coast of Ireland was sighted, a desolate, fog-shrouded land appearing through the smoke. They were close, agonizingly close, but the race was far from over.

events.title: Fogg's Audacious Purchase of the Henrietta
detailed_summary: Fogg appears to have decided on a course of action regarding the coal shortage.
That evening, he instructs the engineer to burn coal at maximum rate until it is completely depleted.
Shortly after, the ship's funnel emits massive amounts of smoke as it proceeds under full steam.
On the 18th, the engineer confirms the coal will run out later that day.
Fogg orders the fires kept high and valves filled until the very last moment.
Around noon, after checking their position, Fogg instructs Passepartout to fetch Captain Speedy.
Passepartout reluctantly obeys, anticipating an explosive reaction from the captain.
Captain Speedy bursts onto the deck, furious and demanding their location.
Fogg calmly informs him they are 770 miles from Liverpool.
Speedy calls Fogg a pirate.
Fogg ignores the insult and proposes to buy the ship from Speedy.
Speedy vehemently refuses.
Fogg states he will be forced to burn the ship (the wooden parts) because the coal has run out.
Speedy is aghast at the idea of burning his $50,000 vessel.
Fogg offers $60,000 in cash.
The sight of the money instantly changes Speedy's demeanor, overriding his anger and imprisonment.
He considers the 20-year-old ship and the generous offer.
Speedy notes he will retain the valuable iron hull and engine.
They agree on the sale.
Speedy takes the banknotes, counts them, and pockets the money.
During this exchange, Passepartout is pale with shock, and Fix appears stunned.
The narrator notes the immense expense (£20,000) and that Fogg essentially gave away the most valuable parts of the ship, though £55,000 was stolen from the bank.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: And now what course would Phileas Fogg adopt?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: When Andrew Speedy had pocketed the money, Mr. Fogg said to him, “Don’t let this astonish you, sir.

events.text_segment:
And now what course would Phileas Fogg adopt? It was difficult to imagine. Nevertheless he seemed to have decided upon one, for that evening he sent for the engineer, and said to him, “Feed all the fires until the coal is exhausted.”
A few moments after, the funnel of the “Henrietta” vomited forth torrents of smoke. The vessel continued to proceed with all steam on; but on the 18th, the engineer, as he had predicted, announced that the coal would give out in the course of the day.
“Do not let the fires go down,” replied Mr. Fogg. “Keep them up to the last. Let the valves be filled.”
Towards noon Phileas Fogg, having ascertained their position, called Passepartout, and ordered him to go for Captain Speedy. It was as if the honest fellow had been commanded to unchain a tiger. He went to the poop, saying to himself, “He will be like a madman!”
In a few moments, with cries and oaths, a bomb appeared on the poop-deck. The bomb was Captain Speedy. It was clear that he was on the point of bursting. “Where are we?” were the first words his anger permitted him to utter. Had the poor man been an apoplectic, he could never have recovered from his paroxysm of wrath.
“Where are we?” he repeated, with purple face.
“Seven hundred and seven miles from Liverpool,” replied Mr. Fogg, with imperturbable calmness.
“Pirate!” cried Captain Speedy.
“I have sent for you, sir—”
“Pickaroon!”
“—sir,” continued Mr. Fogg, “to ask you to sell me your vessel.”
“No! By all the devils, no!”
“But I shall be obliged to burn her.”
“Burn the ‘Henrietta’!”
“Yes; at least the upper part of her. The coal has given out.”
“Burn my vessel!” cried Captain Speedy, who could scarcely pronounce the words. “A vessel worth fifty thousand dollars!”
“Here are sixty thousand,” replied Phileas Fogg, handing the captain a roll of bank-bills. This had a prodigious effect on Andrew Speedy. An American can scarcely remain unmoved at the sight of sixty thousand dollars. The captain forgot in an instant his anger, his imprisonment, and all his grudges against his passenger. The “Henrietta” was twenty years old; it was a great bargain. The bomb would not go off after all. Mr. Fogg had taken away the match.
“And I shall still have the iron hull,” said the captain in a softer tone.
“The iron hull and the engine. Is it agreed?”
“Agreed.”
And Andrew Speedy, seizing the banknotes, counted them and consigned them to his pocket.
During this colloquy, Passepartout was as white as a sheet, and Fix seemed on the point of having an apoplectic fit. Nearly twenty thousand pounds had been expended, and Fogg left the hull and engine to the captain, that is, near the whole value of the craft! It was true, however, that fifty-five thousand pounds had been stolen from the Bank.
When Andrew Speedy had pocketed the money, Mr. Fogg said to him, “Don’t let this astonish you, sir.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: And now what course would Phileas Fogg adopt? It was plain that he could not look to the Windward for help. That vessel was of too small a tonnage, and was besides encumbered with the coal he had bought. His visibly-decreasing stock of coal, however, was the chief cause of anxiety. Unless the steamer’s boilers, instead of forcing up full pressure, were fed only enough to keep them going, it could hardly reach Queenstown in time. Passepartout telegraphed from the deck to his master, who was shut up in his cabin with Captain Speedy. “We are burning forty tons of coal a day!” cried he. “Go on, my boy,” replied Mr. Fogg, “and keep up the fires. We must be there by the 21st.” At length, on the 18th, the engineer came on deck, and cried, “The coal is giving out, sir!” “Ah, really,” said Mr. Fogg. “But we have wood?” “Yes, sir, we have some wood.” “And when shall we use it?” “When we’ve burned all the coal. Not a bit of coal left! The engineer has just told me so.” “We will not use the wood, then,” returned Mr. Fogg. “But what are we going to do, sir?” asked Passepartout, astonished. “We are going to keep up the fire,” replied Phileas Fogg. And this time, the ship did not slacken her speed. On the 19th, the engineer stated that he had used up all the coal. “Then use the remaining wood,” said Mr. Fogg. “But we have no wood, sir,” replied the engineer. “No wood!” exclaimed Mr. Fogg, surprised. “I am very sorry, sir,” returned the engineer. “The last bit was used this morning to cook breakfast.” Phileas Fogg did not betray the least sign of disappointment. “Ah, very well,” said he. “Then we will have to burn the ship itself.” “Burn the ship!” cried the captain and Passepartout, in dismay. “Yes,” said Mr. Fogg, coolly. “The steamer must be there on the 21st. She will be there. I have spoken.” And Phileas Fogg directed his course straight towards the stern, and there was the captain standing by the rudder. “Captain,” said Mr. Fogg, “we have no more coal or wood.” “Ah, what!” cried Captain Speedy. “What do you mean? Are you really going to burn my ship?” “Yes,” replied Mr. Fogg, “at least the upper part of her. The hull is iron, and cannot be burned. But the upper part is of wood, and will burn very well.” “But it’s worth fifty thousand dollars!” cried the captain. “You cannot do that!” “Yes, I can,” returned Mr. Fogg, calmly. “I will buy the vessel from you.” “Buy my vessel!” exclaimed the captain. “Buy the Henrietta?” “Yes, from the keel to the trucks of the masts, and all that it contains. How much is it worth?” “Seventy thousand dollars,” said the captain, in a fury. “Eighty thousand?” said Phileas Fogg. “No! One hundred thousand!” replied Captain Speedy. Passepartout and Fix, who had come up during this scene, were as much excited as the captain. “One hundred thousand dollars!” cried Fix. “But you will ruin yourself!” “Not at all,” replied Mr. Fogg. “The vessel is of wood, and will burn very well. And I have plenty of money.” Passepartout began to be reassured. His master was going to have the ship burned, but he was going to pay for it. It was perfectly simple. Mr. Fogg took out a roll of bank-notes and handed them to the captain, who counted them, and put them into his pocket. Then Mr. Fogg asked him for a receipt. “A receipt!” cried the captain. “A receipt for a ship that I sell and you burn! I must be dreaming!” “No, you are not dreaming,” returned Phileas Fogg, coolly. “Here are the notes, and here is the ship. She is now mine.” And indeed, Passepartout saw that the captain was now looking upon Mr. Fogg with eyes of intense admiration. “You have a fire there, have you?” said Mr. Fogg to the engineer. “Yes, sir,” replied the engineer. “Keep it up, then,” said Mr. Fogg. And from that moment, there was a large amount of smoke coming out of the chimney, as if a factory was burning. All the wooden parts of the vessel were used, from the deck-house to the masts. For not only the deck-house and the masts, but the boats, the frames, the floors, the bulkheads, the partitions, the cabins, the bunks, in a word, all the wood which the steamer contained, was burnt. The captain himself lent a hand. They felled the masts, and cut them up. The boats, benches, and spars were broken up, and the operation went on with incredible fury. Passepartout was constantly throwing wood into the fire. There was a perfect rage for fuel. When anything of wood was found, it was seized upon by the stokers, and crammed into the furnace. The chimney sent forth a perfect torrent of smoke. The speed was kept up. The Henrietta plowed through the waves at the rate of fourteen miles an hour. On the 20th, the ship had made 550 miles. There remained 220. During this time, Fix was in a state of the most complete anxiety. He could not understand what Mr. Fogg was going to do. He saw him throwing away all his money, the money he had stolen, without the least scruple. The steamer was worth at least fifty thousand dollars, and Fogg had paid one hundred thousand for it. The detective could not understand this prodigality. He was on the rack. He was more anxious than Passepartout. The latter was now completely won over by his master, who was performing wonders at every step. Even the captain had ended by being a convert. No doubt he had pocketed a fine sum of money, but over and above that, Fogg’s coolness, his equanimity, his imperturbable placidity, struck him dumb with admiration. He was no longer an eccentric, but a man of genius. On the 21st, at one in the morning, the engineer stated that the fires would not hold out above two hours. “Very well,” said Mr. Fogg. “We will arrive in two hours.” At ten minutes past three in the morning, the Henrietta cast anchor in the harbour of Queenstown. Phileas Fogg had accomplished the crossing in a hundred and fifty-eight hours, instead of two hundred and forty, from New York to Queenstown. There was not a moment to lose. At the moment the anchor dropped, Passepartout hastened to Mr. Fogg. “Monsieur,” said he, “this is the 21st of December.” “Yes,” replied Mr. Fogg. “And we have arrived at Queenstown?” “Yes.” “At three in the morning?” “Yes.” “And the steamer is going to start immediately for Liverpool?” “She is.” “Ah! Monsieur,” cried Passepartout, “the warrant!” “What warrant?” “The warrant of arrest!” cried Passepartout. “The warrant which Mr. Fix has against you!” Phileas Fogg simply rose, and taking his watch, said, “We will leave at seven o’clock. From Queenstown to Liverpool is six hours’ journey.” And indeed, at seven o’clock, Passepartout, Fix, and Mr. Fogg were on the railway, and at noon, they arrived at Liverpool. Mr. Fix, however, did not leave them. He had never left them since their departure from London. He had followed Mr. Fogg in all his journeyings, step by step, without ever losing sight of him. At the moment of arriving at Liverpool, Mr. Fix felt a thrill pass through him. He had reached his goal. He was in England. He had the right to arrest Mr. Fogg. He went up to him, and putting his hand upon his shoulder, said, “Mr. Fogg, I arrest you in the Queen’s name!”

At the moment the anchor dropped, Passepartout hastened to Mr. Fogg. “Monsieur,” said he, “this is the 21st of December.” “Yes,” replied Mr. Fogg. “And we have arrived at Queenstown?” “Yes.” “At three in the morning?” “Yes.” “And the steamer is going to start immediately for Liverpool?” “She is.” “Ah! Monsieur,” cried Passepartout, “the warrant!” “What warrant?” “The warrant of arrest!” cried Passepartout. “The warrant which Mr. Fix has against you!” Phileas Fogg simply rose, and taking his watch, said, “We will leave at seven o’clock. From Queenstown to Liverpool is six hours’ journey.” And indeed, at seven o’clock, Passepartout, Fix, and Mr. Fogg were on the railway, and at noon, they arrived at Liverpool. Mr. Fix, however, did not leave them. He had never left them since their departure from London. He had followed Mr. Fogg in all his journeyings, step by step, without ever losing sight of him. At the moment of arriving at Liverpool, Mr. Fix felt a thrill pass through him. He had reached his goal. He was in England. He had the right to arrest Mr. Fogg. He went up to him, and putting his hand upon his shoulder, said, “Mr. Fogg, I arrest you in the Queen’s name!”

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: And now what course would Phileas Fogg adopt? It seemed that Mr. Fogg had decided upon one. That evening he called the engineer, and ordered him to put on a full head of steam, and keep it up to the last. The engineer answered that the coal would give out the next day. “Keep her going as long as there is a pound left,” said Mr. Fogg. The next day, the 18th, the engineer stated that he had only about four hours’ supply of coal left. “Is that all?” asked Mr. Fogg. “Yes, sir.” “Keep the fires high, and the valves filled till the last moment.” Towards noon, Mr. Fogg, having ascertained their position, called Passepartout, and bade him go and fetch Captain Speedy. Passepartout obeyed, though he thought his master was going to have a row with the captain. He was not mistaken. Captain Speedy came on deck in a furious rage. “Where are we?” cried he. “Where are we? Are you going to take me to the bottom of the sea?” “We are,” said Mr. Fogg, calmly, “seven hundred and seventy miles from Liverpool.” “Seven hundred and seventy miles!” roared Captain Speedy. “And you are burning forty tons of coal a day! You are a pirate, sir!” “I have sent for you, Captain,” said Mr. Fogg, ignoring the insult, “to propose to buy your vessel.” “Buy my vessel!” cried Captain Speedy, who could scarcely believe his ears. “No, by all that’s sacred, no! I have been imprisoned, insulted, and now you want to buy my vessel!” “I will be obliged to burn her,” said Mr. Fogg, “for I have no more coal.” “Burn the Henrietta!” cried Captain Speedy, aghast. “My vessel, worth fifty thousand dollars!” “Here are sixty thousand,” replied Phileas Fogg, handing him a roll of banknotes. This produced a tremendous effect upon Captain Speedy. His anger, his imprisonment, his vexation, vanished at the sight of the money. He was a man who loved money, and he saw that he was going to make a large sum. He looked at the banknotes, then at the vessel, which was twenty years old, and which he had bought at a low price. He thought that the iron hull and the engine were worth a good deal, and that he would keep them. He accepted the offer. “And I retain the captaincy?” asked he. “No, I will navigate myself. You will remain on board as my guest.” Captain Speedy, softened by the sixty thousand dollars, agreed to everything. He took the banknotes, counted them, and put them into his pocket. During this transaction, Passepartout was pale with astonishment, and Fix seemed ready to faint. Twenty thousand pounds for a vessel of forty tons! It is true that Mr. Fogg had given away the most valuable parts of the vessel, but it must be remembered that fifty-five thousand pounds had been stolen from the bank.
