simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: Passepartout left the room, and went to find Aouda, to whom he delivered his master’s message. “Madame,” said he, “Mr. Fogg desires you to accept his excuses for not coming to see you this evening. He is engaged in arranging his affairs, and asks you to defer the interview he proposed with you until to-morrow.” Passepartout felt himself to be utterly powerless to act upon his master’s will. He knew that no entreaties, no arguments, could induce him to change his mind. He could not even suggest to Aouda to appeal to him. Mr. Fogg was inaccessible. But he thought that Aouda might have some influence over him. “Madame,” said he, “perhaps you might be able to do something. Mr. Fogg is not very communicative; he has never, I believe, recognised the depth of your gratitude to him, or the strength of your affection. But you might try.” “I,” replied Aouda, hesitatingly, “I have no influence over Mr. Fogg.” “Madame, you must not leave him alone,” said Passepartout. “He is in great trouble.” “I know it,” replied Aouda. “And I think,” she added, “that he means to discuss with me to-morrow the arrangements for my future in England. He must be thinking of that.” “Perhaps so,” said Passepartout, who did not know what to think. “But, Madame, you must not leave him alone.” Aouda remained thoughtful. The house in Saville Row was as still as if it were deserted. Sunday was a day of rest for Mr. Fogg, but it was also a day of routine. He did not leave the house at eleven o’clock, as was his custom, to go to the Reform Club. He saw no reason to go there. His friends no longer expected him. He had lost the wager the evening before. He had no need to go to his bankers, Baring Brothers & Co.; his opponents held his cheque, and could claim the twenty thousand pounds directly. He remained at home, shut up in his room, arranging his affairs. Passepartout wandered about the house, restless and uneasy. The hours seemed terribly long to him. He listened at his master’s door, and peered through the keyhole, fearing some terrible event. His thoughts turned to Fix. He did not feel any anger towards him. Fix had simply done his duty; he had been mistaken, as Passepartout himself had been. It was his own folly, his own credulity, that had ruined his master. This thought tormented him ceaselessly. Feeling that he could not bear his misery alone, he went to Aouda’s room, and sat down in a corner, watching her sadly. Aouda was still lost in thought.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Passepartout left the room, and went to find Aouda, to whom he delivered his master’s message. The young woman listened with a mixture of surprise and gratitude. She had expected to be left behind, to somehow make her way alone in a world utterly strange to her, reliant only on the vague promises of a distant relative. Mr. Fogg’s proposal, while unexpected, was a lifeline. "Mr. Fogg desires me to... to accompany him?" she repeated, her voice soft, almost disbelieving. Passepartout, with his usual earnestness, confirmed it. "Precisely, madame. To Europe. He says it would be unsafe for you here." He added, perhaps venturing slightly beyond his direct instructions, "And Mr. Fogg is always right, madame. He is a man who decides quickly but never wrongly." Aouda's eyes, which had been fixed on him with a fragile hope, now filled slightly. "How can I ever repay such... such generosity?" she murmured. Passepartout waved a dismissive hand. "Repay? Madame, Mr. Fogg does not act for repayment. He acts because it is the right thing to do. It is... well, it is Mr. Fogg." He pondered for a moment, reflecting on the sudden, immense responsibility his master had shouldered. Taking on a passenger, a lady, in the middle of such a breakneck journey! It was utterly characteristic of his eccentric employer, yet also utterly confounding to the orderly soul of the poor Frenchman. "We must prepare you immediately, madame," Passepartout continued, snapping back to the present duty. "Mr. Fogg waits for no one, not even for us. We have little time. What few belongings you possess, we must gather them. And perhaps... perhaps you should wear something less... less revealing, if you will pardon my suggestion. Europe is different from India." Aouda nodded, understanding. She had been dressed in the traditional Indian garments suitable for her life before, but now she was to travel across continents at bewildering speed. The change felt abrupt, immense. "I have very little," she said quietly. "Only these clothes, and a few small personal items." Passepartout’s brow furrowed slightly. "Very well, madame. We will make do. Mr. Fogg provides for what is necessary." He thought of the strict itinerary, the ticking clock, the absolute precision with which every moment had been planned. Now, a new, unpredictable element had been introduced. It was exciting, in a terrifying sort of way, like adding a wild card to a perfectly calculated game of whist. But beneath the apprehension, there was also a flicker of satisfaction. It felt right that Aouda, saved from a terrible fate, should not be abandoned. Mr. Fogg’s decision, while inconvenient for the schedule, felt deeply human, a rare glimpse of something beyond mere punctuality and wagers in his master's character. Passepartout resolved to do his utmost to ensure Aouda’s comfort and safety, seeing it as his personal duty now, in addition to guarding the luggage and keeping track of the tickets. He imagined the conversations, the questions, the sheer strangeness of travelling with a lady from the East across Europe. It would certainly complicate things, but perhaps... perhaps it would also make the incredible journey a little less purely mechanical. He looked at Aouda, standing fragile and uncertain before him, and felt a surge of protective instinct. This was his new charge, in a way. "Come, madame," he said, extending a hand in a gesture of hurried encouragement. "We must not lose a single moment."

events.title: Fogg Reveals His Ruin to Aouda
detailed_summary: Around 7:30 PM, Fogg requested to see Aouda and was soon alone with her.
He sat opposite her, displaying no outward emotion, appearing exactly the same calm and impassive man as before his journey.
After a period of silence, he addressed Aouda, asking her forgiveness for bringing her to England under false pretenses.
Aouda attempted to speak, but Fogg asked to continue.
He explained that when he rescued her, he was wealthy and intended to use part of his fortune to ensure her a comfortable and independent life.
He stated plainly that he was now financially ruined.
Aouda acknowledged she knew of his ruin and asked his forgiveness in return, suggesting her presence might have caused delays contributing to his failure.
Fogg countered that leaving her in India was impossible and her safety required bringing her far away from her persecutors.
Aouda observed that Fogg felt obligated not only to save her life but also to secure her future well-being.
Fogg confirmed this but noted circumstances prevented it, offering her the small amount of money he had left.
Aouda inquired about his own future.
Fogg coldly replied that he personally needed nothing.
When asked how he faced his impending fate, he answered simply that he faced it as he always did.

events.text_segment:
About half-past seven in the evening Mr. Fogg sent to know if Aouda would receive him, and in a few moments he found himself alone with her.
Phileas Fogg took a chair, and sat down near the fireplace, opposite Aouda. No emotion was visible on his face. Fogg returned was exactly the Fogg who had gone away; there was the same calm, the same impassibility.
He sat several minutes without speaking; then, bending his eyes on Aouda, “Madam,” said he, “will you pardon me for bringing you to England?”
“I, Mr. Fogg!” replied Aouda, checking the pulsations of her heart.
“Please let me finish,” returned Mr. Fogg. “When I decided to bring you far away from the country which was so unsafe for you, I was rich, and counted on putting a portion of my fortune at your disposal; then your existence would have been free and happy. But now I am ruined.”
“I know it, Mr. Fogg,” replied Aouda; “and I ask you in my turn, will you forgive me for having followed you, and—who knows?—for having, perhaps, delayed you, and thus contributed to your ruin?”
“Madam, you could not remain in India, and your safety could only be assured by bringing you to such a distance that your persecutors could not take you.”
“So, Mr. Fogg,” resumed Aouda, “not content with rescuing me from a terrible death, you thought yourself bound to secure my comfort in a foreign land?”
“Yes, madam; but circumstances have been against me. Still, I beg to place the little I have left at your service.”
“But what will become of you, Mr. Fogg?”
“As for me, madam,” replied the gentleman, coldly, “I have need of nothing.”
“But how do you look upon the fate, sir, which awaits you?”
“As I am in the habit of doing.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: About half-past seven in the evening Mr. Fogg sent to know if Aouda would receive him, and in a few moments he found himself alone with her. He sat near the fireplace, silent, according to his custom. Phileas Fogg had not changed. His look was clear, his countenance as impassive as ever. He had not betrayed the slightest agitation when he pronounced the words, “I am ruined,” but now that he was alone with Aouda, he seemed to feel more deeply his misfortune. Aouda seated herself upon a stool near him. She did not speak, but looked at him with that gentle look which is so full of womanly pity. During the forty-eight hours they had been living in Albemarle Street, she had thought constantly of the rash gentleman, who, without taking her from India, would have been rich and happy. Her gratitude towards him could not be better expressed than by her silence. Passepartout had told her what had taken place at the Bank, and she knew that Mr. Fogg was absolutely ruined. When Mr. Fogg finally spoke, it was to ask her, in a soft voice, and without the least emotion,-"Aouda, you will pardon me for having brought you to England?" Aouda shuddered slightly, and replied, "I? —pardon you? You saved me from death! How can I not be for ever grateful to you? But what you ask me is not what I should ask you. It is I who should ask you for pardon." "For what, madam?" asked Mr. Fogg. "For not having followed you," replied Aouda. "When you determined to go round the world, you were rich, and counted on reaching London in time, and dividing your fortune with me. You expected then to be able to secure my comfort and independence. But time failed you, and you are ruined! It is my fault, for if I had not insisted upon your bringing me to England, you would have reached the end of your journey safely!" "Madam," replied Mr. Fogg, "it was impossible for me to leave you in India; your safety required that I should bring you far away from your persecutors. You know that I could not do otherwise." "Yes," said Aouda; "and I see that you have not only saved my life, but that you have also felt yourself bound to secure my future well-being. When you asked me to come to England, you thought you were certain of success, and you offered me a share of your fortune. Now you are ruined, and you think yourself absolved from your promise; but no, Mr. Fogg, you shall not be absolved. I will be with you, and I will share your fate, whatever it may be. If you are poor, I will be poor with you. If you are rich—no longer rich, you said, did you not?" "Yes, madam," replied Mr. Fogg, "I am ruined." "Ah! and I too am ruined, if you are!" cried Aouda. "I have nothing left but you!" Phileas Fogg gazed at her. He saw that her eyes were full of tears. He felt that this woman, who had followed him across the world, was ready to share his fate, and that she clung to him more than he had expected. He was touched by her devotion, and for the first time in his life, he felt a pang of emotion. "Aouda," said he, "you are right. I have brought you to ruin with me. I have nothing left in the world but the twenty thousand pounds which are due to me from the Bank. With this small sum we can live comfortably together in some corner of the world, but it will not be the splendid fortune I intended to share with you." "And I, Mr. Fogg," replied Aouda, "shall be very happy to share with you the little that remains to you. But what will you do? Where will you go?" "As for me, madam," replied Mr. Fogg, coldly, "I need nothing." "But how will you live?" asked Aouda. "I will live as I always have lived," replied Phileas Fogg. "I can always earn my bread." "And I?" asked Aouda, in a trembling voice. "You, madam," replied Mr. Fogg, "you shall share my lot. I have brought you to England, and here I will maintain you. I will provide for your wants, and you shall want for nothing." "And I, Mr. Fogg, what can I do for you?" asked Aouda. "Nothing, madam," replied Mr. Fogg. "You can do nothing for me. I am ruined, and I must bear my ruin alone." "But you have not told me all," said Aouda. "You have lost your fortune, but you have not lost your honour." "No, madam," replied Mr. Fogg, calmly, "I have not lost my honour." "And you are not cast down?" she continued. "You face your fate as you always have faced it?" "As I always have faced it, madam," replied Phileas Fogg.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: About half-past seven in the evening Mr. Fogg sent to know if Aouda would receive him, and in a few moments he found himself alone with her. He sat opposite her, silent, his hands resting upon his knees, his body straight, his head erect; he was the same man that had left the Reform Club fifty days before. He had not aged a single day. Aouda was seated near him, waiting. A great sadness was depicted upon her countenance. Phileas Fogg did not speak. Aouda did not speak. What had she to say to him? He had saved her, and then he had ruined himself. And Passepartout had related to her the catastrophe which had occurred at the Bank. Phileas Fogg was ruined, and this woman, who owed him everything, could offer him nothing. At last, Mr. Fogg broke the silence. “Aouda,” said he, “you must pardon me for having brought you to England.” Aouda shuddered slightly. “Mr. Fogg,” she replied, “you do not have to ask my pardon. It is I who should ask yours. You were rich, and you have ruined yourself for me.” “Do not speak of that, madam;” replied Mr. Fogg. “When I rescued you from the pile, I had a fortune, and I intended to share it with you. Then your existence would have been assured. But now I am ruined.” “I know it, Mr. Fogg,” replied Aouda; “and I ask you to pardon me. It is my fault.” “Your fault, madam? How so?” “In not having left you,” replied Aouda. “If I had insisted on your leaving me in India, you would not have lost everything. You would have arrived in London before the expiration of the time agreed upon.” “Leaving you in India was impossible, madam,” replied Phileas Fogg. “Your safety required that I should bring you far from the reach of those fanatics.” “So,” resumed Aouda, “you were not only obliged to save me from a terrible death, but also to secure my future well-being?” “Yes, madam; but circumstances have been against me. I can do no more.” “Except to share with me what little you have left?” “But what will become of you, Mr. Fogg?” asked Aouda. “What will you do?” “As for me, madam,” replied Phileas Fogg, coldly, “I need nothing.” “But how will you live? You are ruined.” “I will live as I always have lived,” replied Phileas Fogg. “I can always earn my bread.” “But I?” asked Aouda, timidly. “You, madam, you shall share my lot,” replied Mr. Fogg. “I have brought you to England, and you shall remain here. I will provide for your wants.” “But you are ruined!” resumed Aouda. “I know it, madam. But I have still the twenty thousand pounds which are due to me from the Bank. With that sum we can live comfortably in some corner of the world.” “So you are not cast down?” said Aouda, looking at him. “You face your fate as you always have faced it?” “As I always have faced it, madam,” replied Phileas Fogg.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: About half-past seven in the evening Mr. Fogg sent to know if Aouda would receive him, and in a few moments he found himself alone with her. The young woman was reclining upon a sofa in a simple but elegant robe, her hair neatly arranged. There was a sorrowful expression in her lovely eyes, which seemed to look into the void. Phileas Fogg sat near her and took her hand. Aouda did not remove it; the hands of the beautiful Parsee remained in his, a silent acceptance of his presence and maybe more.  Mr. Fogg gazed at her attentively. Ruined, as he imagined himself to be, he was no longer the protector who had saved her life. Now, their roles were reversed; she had been the one to console him in his darkest hour.  “Aouda,” said Mr. Fogg, very calmly, “they say I am ruined.” Aouda made no reply. He continued, “That is true. My entire fortune is gone.” He paused, observing her closely, gauging the effect of his words. She did not withdraw her hand. Her gaze remained fixed on him, filled not with pity but with a profound, quiet affection.  “I could not,” he resumed, “condemn you to share my poverty. I have nothing left to offer you but my affection and a ruined name.” He felt a deep tenderness towards her, a feeling that perhaps for the first time transcended his methodical nature. He waited, the silence heavy with unspoken emotions, ready to accept whatever she might say, or do. Aouda's soft hand gently squeezed his.

events.title: Aouda's Proposal and Fogg's Declaration of Love
detailed_summary: Aouda suggested Fogg's friends could help prevent him from facing poverty.
Fogg stated he had no friends.
She then mentioned relatives.
Fogg replied he no longer had any.
Aouda expressed pity for his solitude, remarking that shared sorrow can be easier to bear.
Fogg acknowledged the saying.
Standing and taking his hand, Aouda asked if he desired both a relative and a friend, offering herself as his wife.
Fogg rose, showing uncharacteristic emotion with a light in his eyes and trembling lips.
Aouda observed his reaction, her own gaze conveying sincerity, strength, and devotion.
Her willingness to sacrifice everything for him initially surprised Fogg, then deeply moved him.
He briefly closed his eyes, seemingly overwhelmed.
Upon opening them, he declared simply and profoundly, "I love you!"
He affirmed his love was sacred and complete, dedicating himself entirely to her.
Aouda cried out, clutching his hand to her chest in joy and emotion.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “At least,” said Aouda, “want should not overtake a man like you.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Ah!” cried Aouda, pressing his hand to her heart.

events.text_segment:
“At least,” said Aouda, “want should not overtake a man like you. Your friends—”
“I have no friends, madam.”
“Your relatives—”
“I have no longer any relatives.”
“I pity you, then, Mr. Fogg, for solitude is a sad thing, with no heart to which to confide your griefs. They say, though, that misery itself, shared by two sympathetic souls, may be borne with patience.”
“They say so, madam.”
“Mr. Fogg,” said Aouda, rising and seizing his hand, “do you wish at once a kinswoman and friend? Will you have me for your wife?”
Mr. Fogg, at this, rose in his turn. There was an unwonted light in his eyes, and a slight trembling of his lips. Aouda looked into his face. The sincerity, rectitude, firmness, and sweetness of this soft glance of a noble woman, who could dare all to save him to whom she owed all, at first astonished, then penetrated him. He shut his eyes for an instant, as if to avoid her look. When he opened them again, “I love you!” he said, simply. “Yes, by all that is holiest, I love you, and I am entirely yours!”
“Ah!” cried Aouda, pressing his hand to her heart.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
At least," said Aouda, "want should not overtake a man like you. Your friends. . ."

"I have no friends, madam," replied Mr. Fogg.

"Your relatives. . ."

"I have no longer any relatives."

"So much the more reason. Pitying my fate, you have shared it. You have borne my burden of sorrow, and now you are ruined. Ah! Mr. Fogg!"

Aouda rose, and extended her hand to him. "I can make you happy," said she. "Will you have me for your wife?"

Mr. Fogg, at this, rose in turn. There was an unaccustomed light in his eyes, and a slight trembling of his lips. Aouda watched him. The sincerity, rectitude, firmness, and sweetness of this noble woman, who was offering herself to him in marriage, moved him deeply. He stood there, with eyes fixed upon her, not daring to believe, and yet convinced, so much did this offer harmonize with the wishes of his heart. He at last faltered out, "I love you! Yes, by my sacred honour, I love you! and if you will be my wife, I shall be the happiest of men!"

"Ah!" cried Aouda, pressing his hand to her heart.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: “At least,” said Aouda, “want should not overtake a man like you. You possess such remarkable intellect, such ingenuity, and calm resolution. Even without this fortune, which I fear is lost, you possess qualities far more valuable. A man who can navigate continents, outwit villains, and rescue those in peril, as you rescued me, cannot truly be poor. Your skills, your presence of mind, are assets no misfortune can entirely dissipate. I… I possess a little fortune, not vast, but sufficient for my needs and perhaps yours, should you deem it acceptable. It is entirely at your disposal. Do not speak of want as if it were an inevitable fate for Mr. Phileas Fogg. You have faced and overcome greater obstacles with apparent ease. This is merely another, albeit different. But you will confront it with the same composure, I am sure. And please know I am here. My gratitude is immense, bound forever by your actions. If my modest means can be of the slightest service, you have only to say the word. You have given me back my life; the least I can do is offer what comfort and security I might provide in return. Do not despair, Mr. Fogg. The world holds opportunities for a man of your calibre, regardless of temporary financial setbacks. Your journey, though it may not have ended as planned in terms of wealth, has revealed a strength and capability undeniable.”

events.title: Joyful Acceptance and Immediate Wedding Plans
detailed_summary: Passepartout was called and entered the room promptly.
He saw Fogg still holding Aouda's hand and instantly grasped the situation.
His face lit up with immense joy, compared to the brightness of a tropical sun.
Fogg inquired if it was too late that evening to contact Reverend Samuel Wilson of Marylebone parish.
Passepartout beamed, assuring him it was never too late.
The time was noted as five minutes past eight.
Fogg proposed the wedding take place the next day, Monday.
He confirmed this with Aouda, who readily agreed.
Passepartout departed immediately, rushing to make the wedding arrangements with great speed and enthusiasm.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Passepartout was summoned and appeared immediately.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Passepartout hurried off as fast as his legs could carry him.

events.text_segment:
Passepartout was summoned and appeared immediately. Mr. Fogg still held Aouda’s hand in his own; Passepartout understood, and his big, round face became as radiant as the tropical sun at its zenith.
Mr. Fogg asked him if it was not too late to notify the Reverend Samuel Wilson, of Marylebone parish, that evening.
Passepartout smiled his most genial smile, and said, “Never too late.”
It was five minutes past eight.
“Will it be for to-morrow, Monday?”
“For to-morrow, Monday,” said Mr. Fogg, turning to Aouda.
“Yes; for to-morrow, Monday,” she replied.
Passepartout hurried off as fast as his legs could carry him.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Passepartout was summoned and appeared immediately. He saw Mr. Fogg still holding Aouda’s hand, and understood it all. His face beamed with a joy which was bright as the tropical sun, and he waited for his master to speak.

“Passepartout,” said Phileas Fogg, “have you not gone to the Reverend Samuel Wilson, of Marylebone parish?”

“Not yet, sir.”

“Go now, and beg him to appoint the wedding for to-morrow, Monday.”

“To-morrow, Monday?” cried Passepartout, astounded. “To-morrow?

But that is impossible! To-morrow is Sunday!”

“No,” returned Fogg, “it is Monday.”

“No doubt you are mistaken, sir. It is Sunday. Today is Sunday. Look at the almanac.”

Passepartout drew a little almanac from his pocket.

Phileas Fogg took it and read:

“Sunday, December 22nd.”

He had not counted the Sundays; that was the only thing he had omitted. Like a gentleman, he had made his tour around the world, but he had inadvertently added a Sunday to his journey; and this was the Sunday which now seemed to have made him a defaulter, since his eighty days were completed the evening before, Saturday, December 21st, at a quarter before nine P.M. He was ruined—just as he was about to embrace his bride!

But Aouda’s quick eyes were intent upon his face, and saw there the trouble he was suffering. “What is it, my dear Phileas?” she asked.

“What has happened to you?”

“Nothing, my dear—nothing,” returned Phileas Fogg, in a voice which betrayed his emotion. “Only a blunder of mine.”

“A blunder? But you have not made any.”

“I have omitted a day from my calculations,” replied Fogg.

“Sunday is to-day—the 22nd. When I arrived in London, it was 8.50 P.M. yesterday, Saturday the 21st. I had finished my tour in eighty days, and….”

“You have not failed!” cried Passepartout, rushing to the bell-rope, and giving it a tremendous peal. “Ah! that’s because I forgot….

“Forgot what?” asked Fogg.

“When I went into the steamer, I put the hands forward twenty-four hours! The tour of the world has been accomplished in seventy-nine days!”

Phileas Fogg did not have to repeat his orders to Passepartout. A quarter of an hour later, the latter was at the house of the Reverend Samuel Wilson. The wedding was fixed for the next day, Monday.

He was a true Parisian, recently arrived in England, seeking a life of regularity and peace after a tumultuous career in various trades. He stood before Mr. Fogg, his round, good-natured face showing a mixture of readiness and mild apprehension. Having just secured what he believed would be a perfectly calm and predictable position, he was eager to please but perhaps slightly wary of this enigmatic and precise gentleman. His previous experiences as a singer, circus performer, and even a fireman had left him yearning for domestic tranquility. Little did he know the extraordinary adventure that awaited him, far from the settled routine he so desired, involving trains, steamers, elephants, and the entire globe. His arrival marked the unexpected beginning of a journey that would test his skills, his loyalty, and his understanding of the world, all initiated by a simple, prompt summons.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXXVI. IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG’S NAME IS ONCE MORE AT A PREMIUM ON ’CHANGE

events.title: Shift in Public Opinion and Renewed Interest in Fogg's Wager
detailed_summary: Public perception of Phileas Fogg dramatically changed upon the news that the actual bank thief, James Strand, was apprehended in Edinburgh.
Previously viewed as a fugitive, Fogg was now recognized as an honorable gentleman undertaking a remarkable, precise journey.
Newspapers revisited the wager, reigniting interest among bettors both for and against Fogg.
Trading of "Phileas Fogg bonds" resumed, and new bets were placed, significantly increasing Fogg's standing in financial circles.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It is time to relate what a change took place in English public opinion when it transpired that the real bankrobber, a certain James Strand, had been arrested, on the 17th day of December, at Edinburgh.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Phileas Fogg’s name was once more at a premium on ’Change.

events.text_segment:
It is time to relate what a change took place in English public opinion when it transpired that the real bankrobber, a certain James Strand, had been arrested, on the 17th day of December, at Edinburgh. Three days before, Phileas Fogg had been a criminal, who was being desperately followed up by the police; now he was an honourable gentleman, mathematically pursuing his eccentric journey round the world.
The papers resumed their discussion about the wager; all those who had laid bets, for or against him, revived their interest, as if by magic; the “Phileas Fogg bonds” again became negotiable, and many new wagers were made. Phileas Fogg’s name was once more at a premium on ’Change.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: It is time to relate what a change took place in English public opinion when it transpired that the real bankrobber, a certain James Strand, had been arrested, on the 17th day of December, at Edinburgh. A warrant had been issued for him eight days before, on the 9th of December, and he had been arrested on the 17th. Phileas Fogg, who, on the 9th of December, was a fugitive, was now an honourable gentleman, punctually pursuing his whimsical journey. The newspapers resumed the discussion of the wager; all those who had laid bets, for or against him, in their abandoned hopes, were as excited as if Fogg were at that moment coming across the Irish Channel. The Phileas Fogg bonds again became negotiable, and many new bets were laid. Phileas Fogg’s name was once more at a premium on ’Change.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: It is time to relate what a change took place in English public opinion when it transpired that the real bankrobber, a certain James Strand, had been arrested, on the 17th day of December, at Edinburgh. The news spread like wildfire, clearing Mr. Fogg’s name completely. The respectable gentleman, who had been pursued halfway around the globe by Detective Fix under suspicion of being the thief, was now vindicated. The public, which had debated his guilt so vehemently, shifted its focus entirely to his extraordinary feat. Phileas Fogg, the intrepid traveller, was no longer a potential criminal but a national hero, or at least an astonishing figure of daring and perseverance, his incredible circumnavigation the only topic of conversation.

events.title: Heightened Anxiety and Speculation Over Fogg's Fate
detailed_summary: Fogg's five associates at the Reform Club endured three days of intense uncertainty, wondering about his whereabouts and status.
December 17th, the day Strand was arrested, marked seventy-six days since Fogg's departure with no word received.
Speculation arose whether Fogg was deceased, had given up, or was still on track to arrive by the deadline of Saturday, December 21st.
London society experienced profound anxiety; communication attempts via telegrams to America and Asia, and messengers to Fogg's home, yielded no information.
The police remained unaware of Detective Fix's location after his mistaken pursuit.
Despite the lack of news, betting activity surged, with the odds dramatically improving for Fogg, now likened to a racehorse nearing the finish.
Even the elderly Lord Albemarle placed a significant bet supporting Fogg.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: His five friends of the Reform Club passed these three days in a state of feverish suspense.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The bonds were quoted, no longer at a hundred below par, but at twenty, at ten, and at five; and paralytic old Lord Albemarle bet even in his favour.

events.text_segment:
His five friends of the Reform Club passed these three days in a state of feverish suspense. Would Phileas Fogg, whom they had forgotten, reappear before their eyes! Where was he at this moment? The 17th of December, the day of James Strand’s arrest, was the seventy-sixth since Phileas Fogg’s departure, and no news of him had been received. Was he dead? Had he abandoned the effort, or was he continuing his journey along the route agreed upon? And would he appear on Saturday, the 21st of December, at a quarter before nine in the evening, on the threshold of the Reform Club saloon?
The anxiety in which, for three days, London society existed, cannot be described. Telegrams were sent to America and Asia for news of Phileas Fogg. Messengers were dispatched to the house in Saville Row morning and evening. No news. The police were ignorant what had become of the detective, Fix, who had so unfortunately followed up a false scent. Bets increased, nevertheless, in number and value. Phileas Fogg, like a racehorse, was drawing near his last turning-point. The bonds were quoted, no longer at a hundred below par, but at twenty, at ten, and at five; and paralytic old Lord Albemarle bet even in his favour.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: His five friends of the Reform Club passed these three days in a state of feverish suspense. What had become of Phileas Fogg? Would he appear at the deadline, Saturday, December 21st, at a quarter before nine in the evening? Not a word had been received from him. The suspense was shared by all London. Wagers were being laid on the issue as if he had been a racehorse, and the betting-books were overflowing. If, like a steed, he was nearing the goal, the odds were constantly changing, and became more and more favourable to Phileas Fogg. A great many persons who had before laid bets against him were now putting their money on him. Phileas Fogg’s name was once more at a premium on ’Change. His five friends at the Reform Club were in a most anxious state, it is true; but they did not give way to discouragement. From the 17th of December, they had been watching the papers and telegraphic dispatches, as if they would bring them news of the traveller. James Strand, who had been arrested on the 17th, had been set at liberty on the 19th; for the likeness which had existed between him and the real bank-robber, A. W. F., had been fully proved not to be sufficient to warrant his detention. But where was Phileas Fogg? Had he got to America? Had he given up the four-fifths of the journey already accomplished? Was he dead? They knew nothing, and for them, as for the public, the situation was shrouded in complete uncertainty. The evening papers, which they eagerly sought, did not further enlighten them. The Daily Telegraph, Post, Standard, Morning Chronicle, Evening Star, Pall Mall Gazette, and Examiner were silent as death. They were offered in vain to the managers of the Rich Exchange and Lloyd’s, and to the different betting-houses. No news of Phileas Fogg; not even a trace of his passage. Nevertheless, a few rash souls persisted in maintaining that the gentleman would arrive on the appointed day, and, among the members of the Reform Club, John Sullivan and Samuel Fallentin were the most sanguine. They went so far as to bet 4,000 pounds sterling, with a single backer, upon the event. As for Andrew Stuart, he had of course given him up, and was in a state of feverish excitement, but not from anxiety, but from rage. He had wagered and was sure to lose; and, the more so, as the bet was a heavy one, 20,000 pounds sterling, which he did not happen to have in his pockets. As for the others, they were almost as nervous as the president of the company, Lord Albemarle, who had laid a considerable wager, but with less chances of winning, upon Fogg’s arrival.

Would he appear at the deadline, Saturday, December 21st, at a quarter before nine in the evening? Had he given up the struggle, and was he living quietly in some corner of the world? Or was he continuing his journey, and would he appear, according to the schedule, on the appointed day and hour? LLM_completions.prefix-probing: His five friends of the Reform Club passed these three days in a state of feverish suspense. The wager, the seemingly impossible wager, occupied their minds incessantly. Messrs. Stuart, Fallentin, Sullivan, Flanagan, and Ralph could think of nothing else. They met daily at the Club, poring over maps and calculating distances with nervous frequency. Each conversation revolved around Fogg's journey, the delays he might have encountered, the vanishing possibility of his success. Doubt gnawed at them, presenting itself as certainty that Fogg was irrevocably delayed or had given up. Yet, a faint glimmer of hope would sometimes surface, fueled by the recollection of Fogg’s precise habits and unflappable nature. But hope was fragile against the crushing weight of logistics. As the deadline of December 21st drew nearer, the tension became almost unbearable. They huddled together, sharing anxieties. Newspapers offered no news, adding to their unease. They checked the clock constantly, each tick a hammer blow against their nerves. The appointed time, 8:45 PM on Saturday, loomed large, a moment of truth. It would either vindicate their friend's audacity or confirm the folly of his enterprise. The air was thick with anticipation, a mixture of dread and desperate hope.

events.title: Anticipation Builds Outside and Inside the Reform Club
detailed_summary: On the Saturday evening Fogg was due, a large throng gathered in Pall Mall near the Reform Club, resembling a permanent assembly of brokers.
The crowd hampered movement and engaged in widespread disputes and financial dealings related to the wager.
Police faced difficulties managing the onlookers as excitement intensified closer to Fogg's expected arrival time.

Inside the club's main saloon, Fogg's five betting antagonists convened: bankers John Sullivan and Samuel Fallentin, engineer Andrew Stuart, Bank Director Gauthier Ralph, and brewer Thomas Flanagan, all waiting with palpable tension.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A great crowd was collected in Pall Mall and the neighbouring streets on Saturday evening; it seemed like a multitude of brokers permanently established around the Reform Club.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: John Sullivan and Samuel Fallentin, the bankers, Andrew Stuart, the engineer, Gauthier Ralph, the director of the Bank of England, and Thomas Flanagan, the brewer, one and all waited anxiously.

events.text_segment:
A great crowd was collected in Pall Mall and the neighbouring streets on Saturday evening; it seemed like a multitude of brokers permanently established around the Reform Club. Circulation was impeded, and everywhere disputes, discussions, and financial transactions were going on. The police had great difficulty in keeping back the crowd, and as the hour when Phileas Fogg was due approached, the excitement rose to its highest pitch.
The five antagonists of Phileas Fogg had met in the great saloon of the club. John Sullivan and Samuel Fallentin, the bankers, Andrew Stuart, the engineer, Gauthier Ralph, the director of the Bank of England, and Thomas Flanagan, the brewer, one and all waited anxiously.

A countless number of people were swarming in the streets, and all the public conveyances were blocked up. The pavements were obstructed by the bettors, who were vociferously discussing the wager. The police had great difficulty in keeping order; and as the hour when Phileas Fogg was due approached, the excitement rose to its highest pitch. The great saloon of the club was crowded with members, and the five antagonists of Phileas Fogg were seated in a row, in the great drawing-room. They were, —John Sullivan and Samuel Fallentin, bankers; Andrew Stuart, engineer; Gauthier Ralph, Director of the Bank of England; and Thomas Flanagan, brewer. When the clock struck twenty minutes past eight, Andrew Stuart said:

In the great saloon of the club, the five antagonists of Phileas Fogg were assembled: John Sullivan and Samuel Fallentin, bankers; Andrew Stuart, engineer; Gauthier Ralph, Director of the Bank of England; and Thomas Flanagan, brewer. They were waiting, one and all, with intense anxiety.

events.title: Antagonists Debate Fogg's Chances as Deadline Nears
detailed_summary: At 8:20 PM, Andrew Stuart announced that only twenty minutes remained until the deadline.
Thomas Flanagan inquired about the last train from Liverpool, which Gauthier Ralph confirmed arrived at 7:23 PM, with the next not due until after midnight.
Stuart asserted that Fogg would have already arrived if he were on the 7:23 train, suggesting the bet was effectively won.
Samuel Fallentin urged caution, reminding them of Fogg's known eccentricity and punctuality, suggesting he might appear precisely at the last moment.
Stuart expressed disbelief, stating he wouldn't trust his eyes even if Fogg appeared.
Flanagan reiterated his view that Fogg's plan was inherently flawed due to unavoidable delays.
John Sullivan added that the lack of any communication from Fogg, despite available telegraph lines, was concerning.

Stuart firmly declared Fogg had lost multiple times over, mentioning that the steamer *China*, Fogg's only viable transport from New York, had arrived the previous day without him listed as a passenger.
Stuart estimated Fogg was likely at least twenty days behind schedule, predicting Lord Albemarle would lose his bet.
Gauthier Ralph concurred, stating their only remaining action was to cash Fogg's wager cheque the following day.
The club clock indicated 8:40 PM.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When the clock indicated twenty minutes past eight, Andrew Stuart got up, saying, “Gentlemen, in twenty minutes the time agreed upon between Mr. Fogg and ourselves will have expired.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: At this moment, the hands of the club clock pointed to twenty minutes to nine.

events.text_segment:
When the clock indicated twenty minutes past eight, Andrew Stuart got up, saying, “Gentlemen, in twenty minutes the time agreed upon between Mr. Fogg and ourselves will have expired.”
“What time did the last train arrive from Liverpool?” asked Thomas Flanagan.
“At twenty-three minutes past seven,” replied Gauthier Ralph; “and the next does not arrive till ten minutes after twelve.”
“Well, gentlemen,” resumed Andrew Stuart, “if Phileas Fogg had come in the 7:23 train, he would have got here by this time. We can, therefore, regard the bet as won.”
“Wait; don’t let us be too hasty,” replied Samuel Fallentin. “You know that Mr. Fogg is very eccentric. His punctuality is well known; he never arrives too soon, or too late; and I should not be surprised if he appeared before us at the last minute.”
“Why,” said Andrew Stuart nervously, “if I should see him, I should not believe it was he.”
“The fact is,” resumed Thomas Flanagan, “Mr. Fogg’s project was absurdly foolish. Whatever his punctuality, he could not prevent the delays which were certain to occur; and a delay of only two or three days would be fatal to his tour.”
“Observe, too,” added John Sullivan, “that we have received no intelligence from him, though there are telegraphic lines all along his route.”
“He has lost, gentleman,” said Andrew Stuart, “he has a hundred times lost! You know, besides, that the ‘China’—the only steamer he could have taken from New York to get here in time arrived yesterday. I have seen a list of the passengers, and the name of Phileas Fogg is not among them. Even if we admit that fortune has favoured him, he can scarcely have reached America. I think he will be at least twenty days behind-hand, and that Lord Albemarle will lose a cool five thousand.”
“It is clear,” replied Gauthier Ralph; “and we have nothing to do but to present Mr. Fogg’s cheque at Barings to-morrow.”
At this moment, the hands of the club clock pointed to twenty minutes to nine.

He had been among the most doubtful regarding Phileas Fogg’s eighty-day journey. The odds against Fogg completing the impossible voyage seemed overwhelming, given the vast distances, reliance on schedules, and inevitable delays. Most in the Club, and indeed, the public, saw Fogg’s plan as an extravagant failure waiting to happen. Significant bets had been laid, the majority against the traveller. Other members nearby feigned interest in their papers, but their gazes repeatedly drifted to the clock on the wall. The remaining fifteen minutes stretched out, each passing second confirming Fogg's probable failure and their potential gain or loss. Every distant sound from Pall Mall sparked a moment of alert. A carriage wheel, a footstep – was it him? No, surely not yet. The calculation was exact: eighty days from October 2nd, 8:45 PM meant arrival by 8:45 PM on December 21st. Stuart consulted his own watch, comparing it to the club clock. Eight twenty-five. Ten minutes remained. The atmosphere was thick with anticipation, the balance of fortunes hanging in the balance. They waited, silent and tense, for the appointed time.

events.title: The Final Minutes Tick Down in Suspense
detailed_summary: With only five minutes remaining, Andrew Stuart noted the time.
The five gentlemen exchanged glances, their anxiety mounting.
Attempting to conceal their tension, they agreed to Fallentin's suggestion of a card game.
Stuart declared he wouldn't forfeit his potential winnings even for a near-total sum.
The clock showed eighteen minutes to nine.
The men picked up their cards but were unable to divert their attention from the clock.
They perceived the remaining minutes as unusually long.
At seventeen minutes to nine, Flanagan noted the time while preparing the cards.
A tense silence fell over the saloon, punctuated only by the murmurs of the crowd outside and the rhythmic ticking of the pendulum.
Each player mentally counted the seconds with precision.
At sixteen minutes to nine, John Sullivan spoke, his voice revealing his strain.
Realizing only one minute was left, Stuart and his companions abandoned their card game.
They stopped playing and focused entirely on counting the final seconds.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Five minutes more,” said Andrew Stuart.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: They left their cards, and counted the seconds.

events.text_segment:
“Five minutes more,” said Andrew Stuart.
The five gentlemen looked at each other. Their anxiety was becoming intense; but, not wishing to betray it, they readily assented to Mr. Fallentin’s proposal of a rubber.
“I wouldn’t give up my four thousand of the bet,” said Andrew Stuart, as he took his seat, “for three thousand nine hundred and ninety-nine.”
The clock indicated eighteen minutes to nine.
The players took up their cards, but could not keep their eyes off the clock. Certainly, however secure they felt, minutes had never seemed so long to them!
“Seventeen minutes to nine,” said Thomas Flanagan, as he cut the cards which Ralph handed to him.
Then there was a moment of silence. The great saloon was perfectly quiet; but the murmurs of the crowd outside were heard, with now and then a shrill cry. The pendulum beat the seconds, which each player eagerly counted, as he listened, with mathematical regularity.
“Sixteen minutes to nine!” said John Sullivan, in a voice which betrayed his emotion.
One minute more, and the wager would be won. Andrew Stuart and his partners suspended their game. They left their cards, and counted the seconds.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Five minutes more,” said Andrew Stuart.

It was twenty-five minutes past eight. The five gentlemen were assembled in the great saloon of the Reform Club. Phileas Fogg, after having taken leave of them in the very room, at twenty-five minutes past eight in the evening, eighty days before, was to re-appear at the expiration of the eightieth day, and before this saloon of the Reform Club, precisely at this hour, twenty-five minutes past eight P.M. on the 21st of December. If he did not appear, the wager was lost.

“Five minutes more,” said Andrew Stuart, and going to the window, he looked out into the street, which was already black with people, and yet, in spite of the hurrying crowds, and the thousand carriages passing to and fro, the pavement before the club was perfectly bare. No one was there.

“How can we pass the time?” asked Samuel Fallentin. “Even if we played a game of whist, we couldn’t keep our minds on it.”

“The stake is so great!” returned Andrew Stuart. “Nearly twenty thousand pounds for us, if he loses!”

“For my part,” said Thomas Flanagan, “I wouldn’t give my forty thousand pounds for the whole, even if I were sure of winning it. It is throwing money out of the window.”

“It seems to me,” said Gauthier Ralph, “that the only thing we can do is to wait. Let us wait in silence.”

The five gentlemen sat down at a table, and picking up the cards, began to play. But their attention was not on the game. They were constantly looking at the clock. They felt as if the minutes were hours, and the seconds were centuries. At eighteen minutes to nine, Thomas Flanagan, holding his cards in his hand, said: “It is eighteen minutes to nine.”

A profound silence reigned in the saloon. The murmurs of the crowd outside and the rhythmic ticking of the great pendulum were the only sounds that broke the stillness. Each player mentally counted the seconds, and measured the slow progress of the hands on the dial.

At seventeen minutes to nine, John Sullivan, unable to bear the suspense any longer, rose from his seat and went to the window. At sixteen minutes to nine, he turned around and said: “Sixteen minutes to nine.”

Then, a minute later, he added, in a voice that revealed his emotion: “Only one minute more!”

Andrew Stuart and his companions, unable to endure the suspense any longer, threw down their cards and rushed to the window, their eyes fixed on the clock. Only one minute more!

The five gentlemen who met daily at the Reform Club for whist were engaged in a lively discussion that had strayed far from the card table. The topic was the recent article in the *Daily Telegraph* detailing the completion of a new railway section in India, which theoretically made a circumnavigation of the globe possible in eighty days. John Sullivan, Samuel Fallentin, Thomas Flanagan, and Gauthier Ralph were all present, arguing the feasibility of such a journey, factoring in delays, accidents, and unforeseen obstacles. Stuart tapped his foot, waiting for the game to resume, but the debate, fuelled by the seemingly impossible timetable presented by the newspaper, held them captive. The air was thick with scepticism, and little did they know, the quiet man by the fire was about to turn theory into the most audacious wager in history.

events.title: Phileas Fogg Arrives at the Last Moment
detailed_summary: As the final minute counted down, the fortieth and fiftieth seconds passed with no sign of Fogg.
At the fifty-fifth second, a loud noise erupted from the street outside, consisting of applause, cheers, and some angry shouts.
The five players stood up abruptly.
At the fifty-seventh second, the saloon door swung open.
Before the clock's pendulum could mark the sixtieth second, Phileas Fogg entered.
He was accompanied by an excited group from the crowd who had managed to push past the club's entrances.
In his characteristically calm manner, Fogg announced his presence to his waiting antagonists.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At the fortieth second, nothing.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Here I am, gentlemen!”

events.text_segment:
At the fortieth second, nothing. At the fiftieth, still nothing.
At the fifty-fifth, a loud cry was heard in the street, followed by applause, hurrahs, and some fierce growls.
The players rose from their seats.
At the fifty-seventh second the door of the saloon opened; and the pendulum had not beat the sixtieth second when Phileas Fogg appeared, followed by an excited crowd who had forced their way through the club doors, and in his calm voice, said, “Here I am, gentlemen!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
At the fortieth second, nothing. At the fiftieth, still nothing. All five members had risen from their seats, and were palpitating with anxiety; not so much on account of the twenty thousand pounds, as because their honour was concerned in the result. At the fifty-fifth second there was a rumbling at the external door, and a sound of cheering. The door of the great saloon opened, and the pendulum had not beat the sixtieth second when Phileas Fogg appeared, followed by an excited crowd who had forced their way through the club doors, and among whom were prominent the woman Save, and the Parsee half-caste, Aouda. Calm as ever, Phileas Fogg stepped forward, and, in either hand, holding his two children, he said:

“Here I am, gentlemen!”

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XXXVII. IN WHICH IT IS SHOWN THAT PHILEAS FOGG GAINED NOTHING BY HIS TOUR AROUND THE WORLD, UNLESS IT WERE HAPPINESS

events.title: Passepartout's Frantic Discovery of the Date Error
detailed_summary: The narrative confirms the person arriving is Phileas Fogg.
It recalls that approximately 25 hours earlier, Passepartout was dispatched by Fogg to arrange a marriage ceremony with Reverend Samuel Wilson for the following day.
Passepartout undertook the task happily but discovered the clergyman was not home.
He waited for 20 minutes before leaving the clergyman's residence at 8:35 PM, appearing utterly disheveled and hatless.
He ran through the streets in an unprecedented manner, colliding with pedestrians and moving like a force of nature.
Within three minutes, he returned to Saville Row and stumbled into Fogg's room, initially speechless.
Fogg asked what was wrong.
Passepartout managed to gasp that the marriage planned for tomorrow was impossible.
When Fogg questioned why, Passepartout exclaimed it was because the next day was Sunday.
Fogg countered that it was Monday.
Passepartout insisted that today was actually Saturday.
Fogg found this unbelievable.

Passepartout emphatically repeated his assertion, explaining Fogg had miscalculated by one day, they had arrived 24 hours earlier than believed, and only ten minutes remained before the wager's deadline.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Yes; Phileas Fogg in person.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “You have made a mistake of one day! We arrived twenty-four hours ahead of time; but there are only ten minutes left!”

events.text_segment:
Yes; Phileas Fogg in person.
The reader will remember that at five minutes past eight in the evening—about five and twenty hours after the arrival of the travellers in London—Passepartout had been sent by his master to engage the services of the Reverend Samuel Wilson in a certain marriage ceremony, which was to take place the next day.
Passepartout went on his errand enchanted. He soon reached the clergyman’s house, but found him not at home. Passepartout waited a good twenty minutes, and when he left the reverend gentleman, it was thirty-five minutes past eight. But in what a state he was! With his hair in disorder, and without his hat, he ran along the street as never man was seen to run before, overturning passers-by, rushing over the sidewalk like a waterspout.
In three minutes he was in Saville Row again, and staggered back into Mr. Fogg’s room.
He could not speak.
“What is the matter?” asked Mr. Fogg.
“My master!” gasped Passepartout—“marriage—impossible—”
“Impossible?”
“Impossible—for to-morrow.”
“Why so?”
“Because to-morrow—is Sunday!”
“Monday,” replied Mr. Fogg.
“No—to-day is Saturday.”
“Saturday? Impossible!”
“Yes, yes, yes, yes!” cried Passepartout. “You have made a mistake of one day! We arrived twenty-four hours ahead of time; but there are only ten minutes left!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Yes; Phileas Fogg in person.
The reader will remember that Phileas Fogg, at five minutes past eight in the evening, twenty-four hours before, had commissioned Passepartout to beg the Reverend Samuel Wilson to be ready to solemnise his marriage with Aouda the next day, Monday.
Passepartout had gone to the clergyman’s, and had only found him at home with great difficulty. He had at last come upon him, but could not instantly fix the hour for the ceremony. While Passepartout was waiting for the reverend gentleman, he observed a notice on the chimney-piece of the principal apartment, which determined him to remain no longer. This was a notice stating that the service of the church would take place at the usual hour of half-past eleven P.M. that evening, Sunday, December 22nd.
Passepartout stared at the placard, rubbed his eyes, and stared again. The notice was formal and explicit; it could not be doubted. The service was to be celebrated on the evening of Sunday, December 22nd. But to-day was Sunday. No, not at all, it was Monday. Mr. Fogg’s arrival in London had been upon this day, Monday.
But the placard said Sunday. December 22nd was Sunday. Passepartout became on a sudden fearfully perplexed. What was the matter? Mr. Fogg had made a mistake. There was no doubt about it. They had reached London on Sunday, not Monday. Passepartout rushed out of the house, and returned to Saville Row at the top of his speed, and covered with perspiration. His hat was gone, and he ran against everybody. When he got to the house, he dropped panting into a chair in Mr. Fogg’s room.
He could not speak. “What is the matter?” asked Mr. Fogg, calmly.
“My master!” gasped Passepartout, “a marriage impossible!”
“Why so?”
“Because to-morrow—is Sunday!”
“No,” said Mr. Fogg, “to-day is Monday.”
“No—positively—to-day is Saturday.”
“Saturday? Impossible!”
“Yes, yes, yes!” cried Passepartout. “You have made a mistake of one day. We arrived twenty-four hours ahead of time; but there are only ten minutes left!”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The members of the Reform Club were then in the large saloon, and felt a great sensation at the appearance of this gentleman. According to the regulation, the door-keeper should have announced him; but he was so overcome that he was unable to speak. Mr. Fogg walked straight up to the card-table, which Fix, Aouda, Passepartout, and the three friends, Phileas Fogg's compurgators, were surrounding. "Gentlemen," said Phileas Fogg, "I ask your pardon for not having called sooner; but I have been greatly hindered on the way." "You, Phileas Fogg!" said Thomas Flanagan, holding out his hand to his colleague, but with trembling not of fear, but of nervous excitement. "You are a brave fellow, and a man of honour—" "No, my dear Flanagan," replied Fogg, "I am only a fellow who has been going around the world." "In eighty days!" exclaimed Andrew Stuart, who could not hold his tongue. "Yes, in eighty days; or rather, in seventy-nine days, for I got back an hour ago." "But how is this? You are a day behind!" cried Stuart, "and you are ruined!" "No, Mr. Stuart, I am not ruined," said Phileas Fogg; "I have got back from my tour around the world, and I am not ruined, because I have accomplished it in seventy-nine days!" "But it is impossible!" exclaimed Stuart; "the train arrived at 8.50, and has been due more than ten minutes!" "But I have not come by the train, gentlemen," said Fogg, quietly.

events.title: The Desperate Dash to the Reform Club
detailed_summary: Passepartout grabbed his master by the collar and forcefully dragged him along.
Phileas Fogg, taken by surprise and without time to process, was hurried out of his house and into a cab.
He promised the cab driver a hefty sum (£100) for speed.
Their hurried journey involved running over two dogs and overturning five carriages.
They successfully reached the Reform Club.
Fogg entered the great saloon precisely at a quarter to nine (8:45 PM).
Phileas Fogg had successfully circumnavigated the globe in eighty days.
Consequently, Phileas Fogg had won his £20,000 wager.

events.title: Explanation of the Gained Day Through Eastward Travel
detailed_summary: The narrator ponders how such a precise individual like Fogg could have made a one-day error in calculation.
It questions how Fogg came to believe he arrived in London on Saturday, December 21st, when the actual arrival date was Friday, December 20th, the 79th day since his departure.
The reason for the mistake is presented as simple.
Phileas Fogg had unknowingly gained a day during his journey solely because he consistently traveled eastward.
Conversely, traveling westward would have caused him to lose a day.
By heading east, towards the sun, his days effectively shortened by four minutes for every degree of longitude he traversed.
The Earth's 360 degrees, when multiplied by four minutes each, totals exactly 24 hours, representing the unconsciously gained day.
Thus, while Fogg observed the sun crossing the meridian 80 times during his eastward travel, his friends remaining in London observed only 79 meridian passages.
This difference explains why they anticipated his arrival at the Reform Club on Saturday (their 80th day), while Fogg, based on his 80 experienced days, expected it to be Sunday.
It's noted that Passepartout's watch, consistently set to London time, might have revealed this discrepancy if it had also displayed the date.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: How was it that a man so exact and fastidious could have made this error of a day?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And Passepartout’s famous family watch, which had always kept London time, would have betrayed this fact, if it had marked the days as well as the hours and the minutes!

events.text_segment:
How was it that a man so exact and fastidious could have made this error of a day? How came he to think that he had arrived in London on Saturday, the twenty-first day of December, when it was really Friday, the twentieth, the seventy-ninth day only from his departure?
The cause of the error is very simple.
Phileas Fogg had, without suspecting it, gained one day on his journey, and this merely because he had travelled constantly eastward; he would, on the contrary, have lost a day had he gone in the opposite direction, that is, westward.
In journeying eastward he had gone towards the sun, and the days therefore diminished for him as many times four minutes as he crossed degrees in this direction. There are three hundred and sixty degrees on the circumference of the earth; and these three hundred and sixty degrees, multiplied by four minutes, gives precisely twenty-four hours—that is, the day unconsciously gained. In other words, while Phileas Fogg, going eastward, saw the sun pass the meridian eighty times, his friends in London only saw it pass the meridian seventy-nine times. This is why they awaited him at the Reform Club on Saturday, and not Sunday, as Mr. Fogg thought.
And Passepartout’s famous family watch, which had always kept London time, would have betrayed this fact, if it had marked the days as well as the hours and the minutes!

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: How was it that a man so exact and fastidious could have made this error of a day? How came he to think that he had arrived in London on Saturday, the twenty-first day of December, when it was really Friday, the twentieth? The cause of this error is very simple. Phileas Fogg, having, in his tour around the world, constantly travelled eastward, had, unawares, gained a day on his journey. While he was hurrying eastward, the sun was crossing the meridians in the opposite direction, and he consequently advanced, in relation to it, four minutes for every degree of longitude traversed. There are three hundred and sixty degrees on the circumference of the earth; and these three hundred and sixty degrees, multiplied by four minutes, gives precisely twenty-four hours—that is, the day unconsciously gained. In other words, while Phileas Fogg, going eastward, saw the sun pass the meridian eighty times, his friends in London, who had remained stationary, saw it pass but seventy-nine times. For this reason, the Saturday, which he had reached at London, was for them but Friday, and the Reform Club clock, instead of marking twenty minutes past nine on Saturday evening, marked that hour on Friday evening; and this was the case throughout the two hundred and sixteen thousand miles accomplished around the world! Phileas Fogg then, and the reader will remember that he was perfectly unconscious of his gaining a day, had been surprised by the bet being won by a day, just because he had made the tour around the world going east, and not west. It is by travelling eastward that a traveller hurries towards the rising sun, and so the days shorten for him in proportion as he advances to the east; while by travelling westward he goes towards the setting sun, and consequently the days lengthen in the same proportion. It would have been of course the exact contrary if he had proceeded westward from London. In this case, his watch, always pointing to London time, would have warned him of this lengthening of the days. But his journey was constantly eastward. Supposing, however, that Passepartout's watch, which he prudently kept at London time, had marked the days as well as the hours, it would have indicated the difference of twenty-four hours, and the terrible mistake would have been avoided.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: How was it that a man so exact and fastidious could have made this error of a day? The explanation lay not in any oversight of itinerary or timing during the arduous circumnavigation, but in the very nature of traversing the globe eastward. Phileas Fogg, in his methodical calculation, had accounted for every hour and minute lost or gained at each point of the journey according to local time, adjusting his watch meticulously. Yet, in his absolute focus on meeting schedules and navigating distances, he had inadvertently neglected the grand temporal shift inherent in opposing the earth's rotation. By constantly travelling towards the rising sun, crossing each degree of longitude, he gained local time relative to his starting point. Over the course of their eighty-day journey across continents and oceans, these small gains accumulated imperceptibly. He had not lost a day, as he feared upon reaching London when the local date seemed to confirm his failure. Instead, he had gained one full day, relative to his calculations based purely on elapsed time at Greenwich. He had arrived, not on the supposed eighty-first day according to the Reform Club's calendar, but truly on the eightieth. This fundamental error, a consequence of the planet's spherical geometry and his eastward passage across the International Date Line's principle, was the crucial, blinding oversight for his otherwise infallible mind. It was this very oversight that saved him, allowing him to win his extraordinary wager by a single, unexpected day, arriving moments before the deadline.

events.title: Distribution of Winnings and Settling Gas Bill
detailed_summary: Phileas Fogg had indeed won the £20,000.
However, having spent nearly £19,000 during the journey, his net financial profit was minimal.
His primary objective had always been achieving victory, not monetary gain.
He decided to divide the remaining £1,000 between Passepartout and Fix, showing no ill will towards the detective.
In a characteristic display of exactitude, he deducted from Passepartout's portion the cost of gas burned in Fogg's room for the duration of the journey (1920 hours).

events.text_segment: Phileas Fogg, then, had won the twenty thousand pounds; but, as he had spent nearly nineteen thousand on the way, the pecuniary gain was small. His object was, however, to be victorious, and not to win money. He divided the one thousand pounds that remained between Passepartout and the unfortunate Fix, against whom he cherished no grudge. He deducted, however, from Passepartout’s share the cost of the gas which had burned in his room for nineteen hundred and twenty hours, for the sake of regularity.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Phileas Fogg, then, had won the twenty thousand pounds; but, as he had spent nearly nineteen thousand on the way, the pecuniary gain was small. His object was victory, not wealth. And he had had to give up, by the way, four of the five thousand pounds awarded to him by the Bank of England. His expenses, however, had been considerable, for a long and far journey costs money, and the eighty days in question had been expended in running about the earth. Passepartout had received notice to the effect that the thousand pounds was his, and besides the gas, which had been burning for nineteen hundred and twenty hours, the worthy fellow had had to pay a considerable sum for his food and clothing. Fix, too, received a share of the two thousand pounds, though not so large a one as Passepartout. Mr. Fogg bore no grudge against the detective.

events.title: Fogg and Aouda Reaffirm Their Marriage Intentions
detailed_summary: Later that evening, Fogg, maintaining his usual calm composure, asked Aouda if she still wished to proceed with their marriage.
Aouda gently reversed the question, implying it was more pertinent for her to ask, given his recent change in fortune from supposed ruin back to wealth.
Fogg clarified that his fortune was now hers.
He reasoned that had she not proposed marriage initially, his servant wouldn't have visited the Reverend Samuel Wilson.
Consequently, Fogg would not have learned about his crucial date error in time to win the wager.
Aouda expressed her endearment towards Fogg.
Fogg reciprocated with an affectionate address to Aouda.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: That evening, Mr. Fogg, as tranquil and phlegmatic as ever, said to Aouda: “Is our marriage still agreeable to you?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Dear Aouda!” replied Phileas Fogg.

events.text_segment:
That evening, Mr. Fogg, as tranquil and phlegmatic as ever, said to Aouda: “Is our marriage still agreeable to you?”
“Mr. Fogg,” replied she, “it is for me to ask that question. You were ruined, but now you are rich again.”
“Pardon me, madam; my fortune belongs to you. If you had not suggested our marriage, my servant would not have gone to the Reverend Samuel Wilson’s, I should not have been apprised of my error, and—”
“Dear Mr. Fogg!” said the young woman.
“Dear Aouda!” replied Phileas Fogg.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: That evening, Mr. Fogg, as tranquil and phlegmatic as ever, said to Aouda: “Is our marriage still agreeable to you?”  “Mr. Fogg,” replied Aouda, “it is for me to ask you that question. You were rich, and now you are ruined; you are my deliverer, and I am your burden, perhaps.”  “Dear Aouda,” replied Mr. Fogg, “do not say that. If I have returned to the fortune I have risked, it is to you that I owe it.”  “Mr. Fogg!” said Aouda, in astonishment.  “To you, my dear Aouda. For, had you not proposed to me, my servant would not have gone to the Reverend Samuel Wilson’s, I should not have learned that the 5th of April was Sunday, and I should not have been at the Reform Club at the opportune moment!”  “So you are going to marry me, the poor woman you saved?” stammered Aouda, her heart beating.  “So I am going to marry you, as you will,” replied Phileas Fogg.  “And know this, my dear, that in spite of my ruin, in spite of my being poor, I shall share with you what little I have left.”  “And what remains to you?” asked Aouda.  “Eight hundred and sixty pounds,” replied Mr. Fogg.  “And what remains to me?” asked Aouda.  “Everything that remains to you is mine,” replied Mr. Fogg.  Aouda’s hand rested in the palm of Phileas Fogg, and they went together to the little parlor, where Passepartout was just bringing in a light.  On seeing the couple, Passepartout stopped short. He saw that the hour of the denouement had come.  Mr. Fogg stepped up to him, and said: “Passepartout, my good fellow, you have served me faithfully and well.”  “I have done my duty, sir,” replied Passepartout.  “You have done more,” returned Mr. Fogg.  “You have saved me. You have discovered the mistake I made in counting the days. Here are five hundred pounds which I give you. If you like, you can keep them.”  “Ah, sir!” cried Passepartout, with tears in his eyes. “And you are going to marry Miss Aouda?”  “Yes, Passepartout,” replied Mr. Fogg.  “And you will have me always with you, will you not, sir?”  “Always, Passepartout,” replied Mr. Fogg.  Passepartout went out, delighted. He went immediately to tell the news to his future master’s betrothed. He found her still more delighted. She already loved the silent, serious man, to whom she was going to link her destiny.

events.title: Passepartout's Realization of a Hypothetical 78-Day Journey
detailed_summary: The following day, at first light, Passepartout knocked insistently on his master's door.
Fogg opened and inquired about the matter.
Passepartout excitedly announced a realization he had just had.
He declared that they could have potentially completed the world tour in merely seventy-eight days.
Fogg calmly acknowledged this possibility.
He added the crucial caveat that achieving this would have necessitated not crossing India.
Fogg pointed out the consequence: without crossing India, he would not have rescued Aouda, and therefore, she would not have become his wife.
Having made this significant point, Mr. Fogg quietly closed his door.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The next day, as soon as it was light, Passepartout rapped vigorously at his master’s door.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mr. Fogg quietly shut the door.

events.text_segment:
The next day, as soon as it was light, Passepartout rapped vigorously at his master’s door. Mr. Fogg opened it, and asked, “What’s the matter, Passepartout?”
“What is it, sir? Why, I’ve just this instant found out—”
“What?”
“That we might have made the tour of the world in only seventy-eight days.”
“No doubt,” returned Mr. Fogg, “by not crossing India. But if I had not crossed India, I should not have saved Aouda; she would not have been my wife, and—”
Mr. Fogg quietly shut the door.

events.title: Final Reflection: The True Prize of the Journey
detailed_summary: The narrative summarizes Fogg's success: winning the wager and circling the globe in eighty days.
It lists the varied modes of transport he utilized, including steamers, railways, carriages, yachts, trading vessels, sledges, and an elephant.
The author highlights Fogg's consistent display of remarkable coolness and exactitude throughout the venture.
A rhetorical question is posed: What was the real gain from all this effort and travel?
The narrator muses on what Fogg brought back from his long and demanding journey.
It initially suggests the answer might be 'nothing' in a material sense.
However, it quickly counters this by identifying the true reward: a charming woman (Aouda) who, perhaps unexpectedly, brought him profound happiness.
The final sentence provocatively asks if achieving such happiness wouldn't be worth undertaking a journey around the world.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Phileas Fogg had won his wager, and had made his journey around the world in eighty days.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Truly, would you not for less than that make the tour around the world?

events.text_segment:
Phileas Fogg had won his wager, and had made his journey around the world in eighty days. To do this he had employed every means of conveyance—steamers, railways, carriages, yachts, trading-vessels, sledges, elephants. The eccentric gentleman had throughout displayed all his marvellous qualities of coolness and exactitude. But what then? What had he really gained by all this trouble? What had he brought back from this long and weary journey?
Nothing, say you? Perhaps so; nothing but a charming woman, who, strange as it may appear, made him the happiest of men!
Truly, would you not for less than that make the tour around the world?
